file: KEMIRA - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 22July2015 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Tero. Good afternoon. I'm pleased how our progress in Q2 continued in our strategy execution. When  we entered this year, we knew we had some visibility problems, especially around the oil price drop, rig count  drop, and how will that impact our Oil & Mining business and especially in North America. Now, we can see that  we have been able mitigate those downsides. We have, [ph] well, (01:01) naturally not been able to avoid that  downside, but we've been nicely been able to mitigate that.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Last September in our Capital Markets Day, we introduced our willingness to enter the chemical enhanced oil  recovery market with our polymers. Q2 we started first shipments into that market. I will talk a bit more about  that later.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The Klabin investment is ongoing. We're in construction phase of the Klabin plant, and it's on track and Klabin  plans to start ramping up that pulp mill somewhere middle of next year. That's when our organic growth and yield  to the bottom line will also start. So those are some of the initiatives going in that area.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Oil & Mining was a fuzzy picture going into the year and you all know how the horizontal rig count has dropped,  and seems to now be stabilizing out at about 800 rig, 850 rig level. It's come down about 55% from its peak. The  fracking drop from last year is not as big as the rig count drop, but still also a significant drop and, therefore, our  shale fracking business has obviously taken a hit.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: What I'm really pleased about is that we have been able to maintain our bottom line and protect our profitability  and even increase our EBITDA margin. So O&M has done a really good job in that. The mining side of the  business has been steady as she goes, no growth, no big change. We have some other laterals coming from the  distribution network that distributes the products through Oil & Mining. They take it to other industries. There's  no change there. And I would say the traditional oil side has not yet changed that muc h. They'd keep on pumping  and they use their product as before and now the CEOR has kicked in.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also have some first smaller contracts but entries to the Canadian oil sands, which is good execution step for  our Oil & Mining strategy going forward, despite the radical change in the oil price.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So first CEOR deliveries started from UK, our Bradford site. We deliver dry polymers there and if you remember  typically you push from traditional oil wells the oil out with water, but the water drills through and t here will be a  short circuit, so then they pump water and oil, but when you put a flood of polymer in between which has higher  viscosity that wells are almost like a wall that washes out the oil there and this is what our customers are looking  more and more.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: During the first half of the year, we've seen more opportunities coming up in CEOR in traditional oil fields and not  in the shale fields. This is outside of North America and we are working with those opportunities. Customers are  deferring their CapEx, big CapEx projects. They are looking at their OpEx and they're focusing on their existing oil  fields on how to get out more from those and this is why the CEOR opportunities are coming up now more. And  we are working with the customers to develop those business opportunities.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We've had some benefit in all of the segments from the oil-related raw materials, but we don't foresee that going  forward to benefit us, especially in the long run. Naturally, we want to hold on to it as much as we can, but we  need to be also realistic that the competition has the same benefit and the customers fully understand the  situation.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As we look at the organic growth in Oil & Mining, that's – it's all market. And so, we believe that we've been able to  protect our position in the market in shale, and Jari already mentioned, actually gained some very valuable early  wins for us, in chemical EOR and oil sand sands markets. Then moving on to the segment, so 4% organic growth  rate, double the market; 25% growth rate reported helped by the currencies and FX – acquisitions as mentioned.  But more importantly, we're also moving into the right direction with our profitability improvement.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving onto the oil and mining, so we all know that the drastic oil price has impacted the shale activity against  that backdrop again, like Jari said, we've done a fantastic job of defending profitability. In fact, operating EBITDA  percentage is higher in Q2 2015 than it was a year ago in Q2.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Talking about raw materials, just a reminder, you've seen the slide before. So some 30% of our raw material prices  are directly or indirectly oil based. So we do get some benefit up there. And I think this slide, we have updated on  the right, just basically shows that the spread between our average variable cost and sales price has c ontinued to  expand. So we've been able to protect and build margins in this environment quite well. Again, another proof or  guarantee for future, but it's also – I think it's also a sign that we have been purchasing well. Our sourcing  organization – internal sourcing organization has done a good job of supporting our businesses.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Investments, I think I warned after Q1 that we will see higher investments throughout the year. Q2 is now proving  that, so the chlorate chemical island in Brazil is clearly one of the things that is driving our CapEx higher.

file: KEMIRA - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 21July2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining still suffers from the difficult market situation. And I'd like to point out that last year Q2, the shale  business was on its way down and by far not down where it is on today's level. So the comparison situation is a  bit different, and I look at things sequentially from quarter to quarter rather than year-on-year when talking about  Oil & Mining situation. But we are growing on volumes. So we are growing above the market and winning market  share.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Our South American units are running at full capacity. We started up the Klabin new chlorate plant in March. It's  ramping up. So, that's not in full capacity yet, but starting now to contribute nicely to revenue and profitability. Our  share of bleaching business has grown. So there's a mix change and that's also good. We are running bleaching  chemical plants at full capacity, and as you remember, we announced an investment for the Nordic markets  adding a full chlorate line to Finland, Joutseno, investing €50 million to €60 million for that line. We expect that to  start up by the end of next year.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If we next look at Oil & Mining, different market condition obviously continued. Yes, the oil price has recovered  some. We saw under $30 oil prices in Q1. Now we're looking at $45 to $50 per barrel, but is still on a low level.  Industries more and more talking about that the bottom especially in the sale has been seen. We hope that's  really true, but I can say our visibility has clearly improved from previous quarters and you can see that our  quarterly revenue has been flat on an average €75 million level, so visibility has increased. We continue to  develop EOR opportunities and continue deliveries to [ph] carry in India (06:05) and developing new customers.  We also are now doing more and more in oil sands, which was a small business that we entered only last year,  and now we're getting more traction in oil sands in Canada.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Reminding on our positioning for growth for EOR, so our original plan and strategy was to go first after the shale  business and direct our capacity and resources to that and, then in the second phase, go to EOR and oil sands  when we talk about oil and gas industry. Obviously, change in the oil price and drop – dramatic drop in the shale  business, we directed immediately our attention to EOR where customers are taking more out of what they have  today, so not investing CapEx into exploration or opening new fields. And therefore, there's a need for this  business and that's what we've been able to now open and continue, and we develop that. I'd like to point out that  that's still a business that takes a bit of time to develop with the customers. So it's not a fast sales cycle business,  but it's going to the right direction.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Bringing up one strategic point on M&I, we now have been demonstrating after the restructuring phase that we  can start to grow the business and improve the profitability, and it's going rather steady. So we have started now  more looking into what's next for the municipalities, especially as the industrial customers are more advanced in  treating their freshwater and their wastewater. They're looking more and more now into advanced water treatment  for the future. So, now, municipalities are ready to start thinking how to do things better in the future. They've  been quite traditional in how they operate.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: It's also good to remember that EU is changing its public tender regulations. Previously, it was, to put it bluntly,  the cheapest price wins. Now, they are allowed by the new regulations to start to think who brings the best total  value, and it doesn't mean necessarily that the cheapest price wins. And then our relative size is really good on  developing services on top of the chemical deliveries.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We continue to do short-term mitigation in O&M and follow the shale market and see how that develops and then  we continue to develop EOR and oil sands, and obviously not forgetting mining and other verticals that we have in  the oil and mining business. Not forgetting operational excellence, you can see that we again did some pruning of  our network and manufacturing network. So we have some one-off costs, but those paybacks are really fast. And  therefore, we look at our cost structure all the time and then diligently executing our CapEx projects, which I'm  pleased to say have gone rather well in the couple of last years.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In many of the TCM or Total Chemistry Management deals that Jari was talking about, many of them are from  APAC region and clearly are already now contributing. Some are still left to come. So, it's not at the full benefit of  the contracts that we have talked about is already in the numbers yet. So, clearly, a good momentum, very strong  momentum that is happening there.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I mentioned in my beginning, the sale of these PVO shares. So we did sell about 16% of our electricity production  assets in Finland and the transaction took place just before the Finnish midsummer. So, it may have gone  somewhat unnoticed, but this resulted in a gain of €5 million which is now visible in the financial line items. So, not  above the EBIT line, but below that in the financial line items and obviously resulted in [indiscernible] (23:04) of  net debt and gearing. So, positive impact from that sense.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And when we look forward, this will not have any dramatic or any material impact on our electricity costs. Small  one, yes, as we need to increase the amount of electricity that we source externally, but the impact will not be in  any way material.

file: KEMIRA - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 20July2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, let's look at the Q2 in brief. Revenue increased 5% and 4% organically, so that's encouraging. Oil and gas, Q- on-Q, year-on-year, increased 59%, which is a nice step forward, but let's remember that last year was almost the  bottom of the cycle in Q2, Q3, so from a small price, but still a really good step to the right direction.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: A reminder of the new organization effective in June, and we probably won't return to this anymore in the future.  So, we combined Oil & Mining and Municipal & Industrial into one new segment called Industry & Water.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Profitability picked up from previous quarter. Year-to-date, we are still behind the last year. There's still some  pressure on sales prices. Mostly, that comes from raw materials and there are different dynamics in Pulp & Paper  and Industry & Water raw materials. Also, the market remains rather competitive. So, pushing prices through and  increasing prices is a slow step.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Our biggest ongoing investment in the company is the bleaching capacity line addition here to Finland serving  Nordic markets and export to outside of Nordics. Good progress there and we expect to have that operational in  Q4. And good work has been done in contracting that new capacity with customers. So, when we have that up  and running, it starts to pretty soon contribute.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Industry & Water, so meaning Oil & Mining and Municipal & Industrial units now combined. The new combined  units had a strong growth year-on-year of 9% during first half of the year. Driven by volume growth across the  board pretty much and especially driven, as said, in North American oil and gas market.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Growth in oil and gas was, in the first half of the year, 47% so this is the last six months and mainly coming from  shale and oil sands in North America. And even if oil prices now have again fallen below $50, we see so far quite  a good resilience in the shale market.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, if you follow the rig count, which is an indirect indicator for us on fracking, that rig count continues to go up,  week by week, despite the mid-40s WTI prices. So, we obviously continue to follow that. Rig count is double and  over double from a year ago. So, that's been quite rapid development.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Water treatment, which is the bigger part of Industry & Water, grew also by volumes by 2%, so continued small  but solid growth. And we can see sales prices stabilizing now.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: But when you look at the – if you look at – and if you follow the pulp prices, which are, obviously, public and  relatively well-followed, you'll see that the pulp prices have increased actually throughout this year. So, that itself  gives at least, to me, a good confidence that our end markets for the segment are doing quite well.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Moving to Industry & Water. So, obviously, tremendous growth in oil and gas, almost 60% growth to €45 million.  But let's not forget that we had a good underlying steady growth in our, what we call now, water treatment  business, sort of the rest of the Water & Industry, which is again, according to our plan, growing steadily in  volumes there.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And within oil and gas, as Jari was alluding to, most of the growth came from the North America, from the shale  markets, and also, we are growing steadily our business in the Canadian oil sands. And there, it's not market- dependent. We're growing and getting share, meaning getting new customers and increasing the business with  new customers. Clearly, the shale is more market-driven.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, generally, that's the history. And when we are looking at the raw material pricing environment today, like Jari  was saying, it has clearly stabilized. And one can never, in this business, predict the future. But today's – like I  said, today's situation clearly is more stable, and we don't project major changes in raw material prices anymore  this year.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Finally, I'll stop, but I need to remind you that we have a Capital Markets Day coming in September, and as  presenters, we will have our two segment heads, Antti Salminen and Kim Poulsen, as well as we have our Head  of Sourcing, Thierry Blomet; and Pedro Materan, who covers our oil and gas business, Senior Vice President for  that business. So, the two topics that have been raising a lot of questions, meaning raw materials and what  happens to oil and gas. We'll have some of our own experts addressing those and addressing your questions. So,  welcome your participation there and obviously, Jari and I will be there as well.

file: KEMIRA - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 20July2018 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Variable costs and cost volatility has been a headache for a while now, and it comes from supplier input prices  like oil related things, oil and gas prices, but it also then comes from supply, demand balance and any upsets in  the production value chains. This has been quite volatile the last 12 months, including weather. Therefore I  wanted to give you a bit more dynamic on how this works.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Here you can see a chart where it splits up €1.5 billion of our input cost purchases, 20% is logistics inbound and  outbound logistics, 15% is energy mostly electricity, and 65% is the classic raw materials which we use then to  make our own products for. When we look at the raw materials, 70% of those are non-oil and gas related and  30% are oil and gas derivatives. The 10 top materials you can see on the right side, they form about 45% of the  70% of raw material purchases and the biggest one being sodium hydroxide i.e. caustic soda and it's good to note  that that is a mostly a trade through product for us on a cost plus basis. We manufacture a bit here in Finland, but  there's been a lot of volatility in that and prices are significantly higher in Q2 than they were a year ago. And then,  you can see a marking in the 10 raw materials which are Oil & Gas related derivatives.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In Industry & Water, the Water business, water treatment business, very similar, one year contracts are locked,  but in Oil & Gas, it's mostly [ph] frame (00:07:31) contract type of pricing and more day-to-day type of pricing or  formula pricing and therefore, there is more room to update the prices per the input costs as they change. This is  why I&W has been faster in taking the price increases to the customer prices and it's been slower especially in the  Process & Functional Chemicals or Pulp & Paper segment.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Sales prices are starting to come up, but as said we need to do much more work on that in Process & Functional  Chemicals. Operative EBITDA in the first half is below last year, but impacted by a €9 million CapEx impact in six  months, so that's a big number. Our bleaching units are running well and the new Finland Joutseno bleaching unit  is also running well and as said shutdown season in Q2 was a bit bigger one than last year. We're also working  on the JV closing and expecting those final approvals from the Chinese officials.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Moving on to the raw materials, Jari was explaining the dynamics and how the raw materials are increasing and  what's causing it – here's sort of the result visually that the price increases really have started to offset in Q2, the  impact of raw material prices, but it's good to know that this is only the first quarter in two years when [ph] this is  through (00:18:23) and like Jari was saying, we still have a lot of work to do to sort of offset the last two years of  headwind if you will. So the work continues on that sense.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And secondly, I think it's fair to say that our current look of the raw material environment is such we'll continue to  see inflationary pressure on raw material and other input costs as long as we can see in our sort of planning  horizon, estimation horizon is now covering even 2019. So, that's the environment that we're in now.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: As said by Jari, excellent growth in I&W, Industry & Water, led by the Oil & Gas business, 30% organic growth  rate is really, really dramatic and now if you sort to look at the big picture and look at the business, now it is more  than last 12 months trailing, we are more than €200 million business in Oil & Gas. So, this Oil & Gas business has  really grown to be quite meaningful in the last one or two years, if you look at that way.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And similarly majority the Oil & Gas growth is also coming from higher sales prices which are offsetting higher  input costs. Underlying growth profitability is also improving in our water treatment business. We see the  increasing input cost also impacting that business but at the steady rate we are passing this to our customers and  that customer base and contract base rolls over on a steady basis. So profitability on a good upward trend  regardless of the negative currency and raw material impact.

file: KEMIRA - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 28October2010 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Oct-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Before I will say a couple of words about this Q3 result and also some items from the first nine months of this  year, I'll try to remind you our strategy that is to really focus on water chemistry and if we go to slide number four  where we can – I'll say only a couple of points of that so that why we are at Kemira focusing on water. The simple  reason is that we have competencies and long history of water, and we see that demand is increasing  significantly in coming 20 years, 50% and there will be a major gap of 40% between demand and supply in 2030.  It means that it gives a lot of growth options for Kemira but also possibilities to develop new technologies.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Also first to remind you is that Kemira's water business is not only municipal water treatment, but it's – the bigger  potential is even in industrial water treatment. From Kemira's point of view, we see the potential from water  intensive industries being 80% whereas municipalities offer 20% market potential. Both municipal and industries  are important for Kemira. At the moment, we are very much looking at the industry serving us Paper industry, oil  and gas, mining, but we're looking at also entering other industrial segments.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: During Q3, we have done many strategic actions to implement the strategy, and I will give a couple of examples.  So last spring we established the Finnish Research Institute, VTT a center of water excellence here in Finland.  However, there are many universities like University of Alberta in Canada and Nanyang Technical University in  Singapore that have joined the program, and this gives us a lot of opportunities to develop new solutions and  products for water intensive industries.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We closed acquisition in UK for oil and gas water treatment chemicals. We also have established a partnership  with Outotec, which is a major mining, engineering and constructing company and that's globally that opens us  new possibilities to develop business. We also have announced an investment to build a production hub in  Nanjing in China for water treatment chemicals.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also have signed a JV agreement with Indian company called IVRCL that is a major engineering and  construction company in water treatment area, and gives us also new possibilities to grow and penetrate the  Indian market that is very lucrative for Kemira.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have closed one coagulant acquisition called Water Elements in North America more as a – we can see that  more as a tactical move to strengthen our market position serving municipalities in North America. And also I can  say we have basically completed our fixed cost savings program with €60 million that we started for two years  ago.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: EBIT at the Group level rose 32% and EBIT margin rose to 7.6%. Net profit before taxes improved even much  more by 93% and there are two main reasons for good improvement, one is lower interest cost but it's also worth  mentioning that perhaps you remember that we established in September 2008 a JV with a American company  Rockwood, concerning titanium dioxide business. In that JV, Kemira had 39% share and we are not reporting that  in net sales and EBIT but certainly it will impact in net profit.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The titanium dioxide industry had historically a very demanding and challenging last year and this year the  industry has recovered, improved a lot meaning also that we have been doing positive result that has been  impacted positively in net profit. And that's why our net profit has improved or almost doubled. The same reason  being these earnings per share improvement.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So this is very, very positive thing. EBIT rose by 39%, and we closed one divestment in Germany, FWA, meaning  Optical Brighteners that are functional chemicals, and nothing to do with water. So this is one strategic action we  have now completed. Then we can go to this next statement, Municipal & Industrial revenue increased by 5%  compared to Q3 last year. Demand in Municipal customer segment has been steady. Normally it is very steady.  It's a good cash flow contributor to the company.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: What has been [indiscernible] (14:54) is the Industrial customer segment improvement in profitability. When we  started this Industrial part in late 2008, our business model and earning logistics was totally selling water  chemicals to distributors, where they served different kind of industries. We have since now, according to  Kemira's new strategy that business model, not totally but very much to direct sales to customers, meaning that  the profitability has increased and it looks very, very promising in that segment.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining, it's the impressive story for Kemira at the moment, revenue increased by 43%. At the same time  also EBIT margin improved to a level of 11%. And this is based on higher sales volumes, but also based on many  other reasons, customer and product mix. Water chemicals demand has been very strong in all those customer  segments inside this industry. Also higher sales prices and volumes have had positive impact to increased EBIT  and profitability and EBIT more than doubled compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And finally, the key focus areas for going forward are four items, we continue to implement our water strategy,  number one. The second one, focused on enabling profitable growth. Third one, continued focus on cost. We  have done successfully cost reduction, but we need to continue high discipline in that area as well in having a  direct cash flow management.

file: KEMIRA - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 27October2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Having said that, it becomes obvious that you cannot expect now a destructive move. Because if now suddenly  everything will be changed, and obviously I would have done something wrong in the past three years. Therefore,  clearly we will continue with the successful water strategy. And this was actually what appeals me very much,  when I got a call from Pekka Paasikivi, asking me whether I would be interested to serve as the CEO of Kemira.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Water is the vital element for mankind going forward. A human body can survive for three weeks without food,  but only three days without water. And this will be the biggest challenge on earth, the distribution of water, clean  water and making water available when people need it. Not just for their own consumption, but also, of course, for  food production because food production without water is also not working.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The other challenge which Kemira has taken up already for many years and it's getting an even bigger threat going  forward is that we have to deal with increasing volumes of polluted water. So it's not just that you can make and  have to make fresh water available for the people, you have to find ways and you have to find ever-sophisticated  ways, more sophisticated ways to turn polluted water into drinkable water. This is where chemistry and modern  technology, and ultimately, innovation comes into play, where Kemira with the SWEET project has already put in  a great step and a great commitment in order to develop new technology for the challenges not of today but for the  challenges of tomorrow.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I also lived in Asia, back in '93 in Hong Kong, when I was responsible for certain Asian business operations of  BASF. So therefore I have quite the broad exposure and have a broad exposure to the various geography on this  cloth, which I would suggest helps me in guiding Kemira when it comes to solving water needs in the different  geographies, because obviously the challenge and the attitude of the industry, but also of governments in various  geographies are different.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The only downside, then I also said it this morning to the employees, is the average temperature gear up in  Helsinki. 5.3 degrees to me is not the most appealing. 15 would be better, but okay it is what it is. I think Kemira  has a great future. I'm very proud to be part of this future. I'm also very proud that I can contribute my past  experience to that business, and I'm looking forward, not just to continue to guide you in the future on what  Kemira is doing, but also to show tangible results alongside this excellent water strategy. Thank you very much.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Okay. Thank you very much, Wolfgang Büchele. So I wish you all best. And the good news is that water is the  connection. So the strategy is to stay, but it can be developed further certainly. So without saying no more in this  stage, so I will jump to this January-September 2011 results and call some main points out of that.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Profit before taxes was less – a bit less than last year, based especially on financial expenses, but also these  divestments. Financial expenses, the one reason is currency impact. So that is basically not the reason, it's  something else. But cash flow was very strong in Q3. €56 million is a large number in the size of this company, so  in that we performed very, very well.  There are some messages that I would like to address to you. First of all, looking at this new Kemira based on  water, you have to remember we have 75% of Kemira's present business is water and 25% is something else. 75%  certainly means that we are a water company overall. And looking at this present Kemira, so Q3 looking at  revenues are the highest ever in this period, a little bit higher than earlier record. That indicates really that the top  line is not that deteriorating, so it's stable.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We had, based on this really high and still continuously high oil – crude oil price globally that's impacted the dip  of EBIT earlier this year, because many of our raw materials are all related less and less by the way all the time.  But anyway, so it came down quite a lot. But now, it's delighted to see that Q3 result is already better. So – and I  can also say that looking at within a quarter months has always been improving, so that's one message.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We had operative EBIT declined compared to last year as a small disappointment, but this has only to do the best  at – in this segment as well the profitability should improve. We announced in the morning today that we signed –  early, early today, very early with Evonik Degussa a transaction, a deal where we sell to Evonik Degussa our  hydrogen peroxide assets and business in Canada and following our strategy to focus on our water. And it has  some positive impact as a one-time item in Q4 in our EBIT. But financially, looking at the whole Kemira concern,  it has not any significant impact financially.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have also so-called specialty chemicals not so-called but we're not reporting separately. They're reporting as a  segment, Others. They're – and they are serving pharmaceutical, other chemical industry, they're serving – they  are producing and selling de-icers, laptops, also food preservatives as well feed additives. It's not water business.  This is the biggest part of the so-called non-water business.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then, we look at this Q3, our result is still quite okay. So that is of course a certain kind of concern, but now our  sales still increased ultimately in Q3. The rest of Kemira's businesses I still believe they are even – we have this  As you know that it's only a raw material, oil price volatility that I explained earlier, but all in all, the demand is  stable.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining has been stable, steadily growing. I believe it will continue like that even the GDP growth is not so  high and ChemSolutions certainly has demonstrated a stable business performance; meaning that all in all,  Kemira's strategy should be very okay even in the conditions that the growth is globally not so big. We have some  concerns, but we have many businesses that, like we have demonstrated in Q3, was rather stable. So that is good  news.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Balance sheet is an extremely important normally when so much talking about in this confidence is about that,  and certainly cash flow has big impact on that. And we have many years in the past that Kemira's balance sheet,  starting even from earlier than 2005, was negative meaning that our gearing increased to the level of almost 120%  in 2008 when we started this new focused water strategy. And now our gearing was something like 35% and can  be improved and cash flow has been positive. I think it's nice to show that we have changed that fully.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Wolfgang Büchele said about this water demand, some megatrends and so on. Our strategy is based on of course  two factors. I think we understand and recognize that water will be a bigger and bigger issue in the world and it's  many times in industrial applications connected to energy, certainly also four, but in our life, energy.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And our whole business strategy is based on building a common technology platform using common product lines  towards selected customer segments that are basically Oil & mining, biomass, meaning Paper and something else  outside Paper and then is municipalities and cities and some selected niche industrial sectors.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: There are many other water incentive markets that Kemira is not serving at the moment, because the strategy is  all about choices. So we've also selected what we are not doing. Oil & Mining is important, because role of water is  continuously rising and our position in the market is – it's been one to four; meaning that we should have a good  pricing power and that we have demonstrated.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Paper business is €10 billion market. We have a good position in selected geographies and selected, how to say,  customers and also offering. We are more and more – what has been changed within last three, four years is that  we are more and more focusing on water chemistries, retention system, waste water treatment, raw water  purification, and basically, we are using exactly same chemicals and chemistries here that we are using here.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And then we have Municipal & Industrial, basically our position – we are number one in coagulants and certainly  like serving municipalities it is the only company that we can offer the whole offering – basically all chemicals  needed. So the differentiation is important, not only a market position. We have also changed the brand – even  the Kemira has 90-year-old history. I believe that within one – this and last year, Kemira's image have changed  and we are recognized a water company, meaning that many statistics and also on management understanding is  that we are number one – number two in water chemistry market anyway among three biggest players.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have a lot of potential to develop and go and enter more and more emerging markets because 2030 50% of  world global water business, size of the business is $500 billion is going to be in Asian markets; India, Indonesia  and China. So we need to be there. And – but also mature markets offer many new possibilities. We have always  increased as every year in Eastern European markets. We have even growing in North America like in shale gas or  oil sands. It's interesting that finally now U.S.A. is requiring phosphorus removal that is the one of the core issue  that Kemira is doing in Baltic Sea catchment area. That is a big thing looking at the society point of view.

file: KEMIRA - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 24October2012 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We were disappointed on the one hand, but naturally when you listen to the comments in the market from our  competitors, the income from associated companies went down to only €0.3 million versus €9 million a year ago.  So, the titanium dioxide market is in a bad shape. Kronos has commented accordingly, and DuPont yesterday has  made similar comments. We, as Sachtleben's smaller owner, can only live with the market circumstances; and  clearly, Sachtleben is not immune against the overall market events.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: That R&D is important. It can be taken from Oil & Mining. If you think about the Oil & Mining revenues, in 2011,  about 20% of sales are generated with new products. And the new products have on average or had on average a  15% higher gross margin in comparison to the products which were substituted or which were phased out. So  clearly, the innovation pipeline is relevant not just to improve our position continuously further, it's also  important to improve constantly our top line and our underlying profitability.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We will continue to optimize our utility cost, and we expect to be able to save roughly €5 million by improved  energy efficiency in our major manufacturing sites. Let me talk a little bit on lean operation. We are embarking on  lean manufacturing in a first step, but overall lean management as the guiding company philosophy. And we have  chosen Helsingborg in Sweden, which is our flagship individual manufacturing site and is at the same time a  multi-segment integrated site.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have chosen secondly, as a batch-process site, Botlek in Holland, and we have chosen Rheinberg in Germany  as a single product line site in order to assess, from a lean manufacturing standpoint, how we can improve, how  we can optimize these different sites. And we have identified quite a substantial number of measures where the  efficiency can be improved in these three sites as part of the lean manufacturing approach; and we are going to  implement these findings in the next three quarters.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We clearly will continue with Paper. I made it clear during Capital Markets Day that we want to be a leader in the  paper industry. We are committed; we are, at this point in time, the only one who has committed themselves to  the paper industry. We consider, based on explanations that I've given during the Capital Markets Day, the  packaging and board as well as the tissue segment to be a very long-term, stable growing segment; because it's,  from a sustainability point of view, ideally suited also to replace plastics to a ever wider extent. And therefore, we  see a lot of underlying growth drivers.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining is running well from a profitability standpoint. We had lower revenues than you all expected. The  revenues were lower for two reasons. On the one hand, we are phasing out still the, so to speak, underperforming  or low margin businesses. We have stated that before. And this will – trust that there is no misunderstanding,  because this is long-term contracts that will be visible until the end of 2013.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, the phase-out is not something which you do today and then it's done. There are contractual obligations, and  that's why this phase-out will ramp in until the end of 2013; and 2014, we are clean and then this is completely  digested. That's one impact. The other impact, and that's fortunately now turning again around, there was a  substantial slowdown in shale gas in the United States due to the low gas price.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The gas price fell down to just $2.50 per million Btu. The gas price is now starting to recover. This has impacted  us that the demand for chemicals temporarily has slowed down. But we are confident that this is now, with the  increase in gas price, quickly coming back. So, that is why the revenues were lower than expected. However, as  you can see, profitability of this business has now more than doubled in a three years period.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also could further improve our ChemSolutions business. We had a low point in profitability in Q2 that was  associated with the maintenance shutdown in our large formic acid plant in Oulu. However, this is now over, and  Q3 saw already a substantial improvement. We are still, in this business, suffering from high raw material prices.  And as the market currently is more or less in equal supply-demand balance, we are not fully able to pass this  through to the market. But as part of Fit for Growth, we have also taken measures now in order to bring this

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Jyrki Mäki-Kala  Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj  Thank you, Wolfgang. So, let's continue with the quarter three in more details. First, let's say the three good things  that we faced in our quarter three was really our EBIT margin reaching 8.2%; that was the highest that we have  witnessed during this water chemistry strategy, what we have been running now basically four years. The Fit for  Growth savings that you heard, they came in €3 million in quarter three. That was a good achievement within a  very short period. And then like, if you heard already, the volumes especially in our Municipal & Industrial  segment came back.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: But the other side, the flip side of the story, not-so-good things is really we saw a slowdown of the Oil & Mining  business, mainly coming from Mining operation, but also with the oil and gas in North America. Our titanium  dioxide [ph] partner (0:35:26) business, they are really – the [indiscernible] (0:35:28) market is going in total  different direction that earlier, and so the competitors of [indiscernible] (0:35:31) titanium dioxide also coming –  came out with their comments.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The other side of the story is that the sales prices has a direct link to our raw material prices, and maybe this will  give you the idea why the sales prices are now different compared to few quarters back when the raw material  prices are going down. When we look quarter-by-quarter comparing to last year, the raw material that I'm  referring here is more around the polymer-related chemicals, raw materials, electricity price in Finland and also  like aluminum hydrate.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If we look the same €60 million by segment, it's very clear that our two biggest segments, Paper and Municipal &  Industrial get the biggest benefit in their P&L; roughly the same figure, €20 million. And then Oil & Mining and  ChemSolutions, since they have less sites in their hands, certainly will get less savings. But the important thing is  that it will improve all the profitability in each of our four segments going forward. And the savings during the  first part of this program in quarter three, like you see, they mostly went into Municipal & Industrial and also the  other part into Paper segment.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining, I think for the first time, they have a minus figure there in the revenues compared to last year's  quarter, and that's really the softness in oil and gas market in North America and overall the mining operation  where we serve our customers. But basically the lower raw material prices and also that they walk away with  certain low margin customer contracts made the position that, in fact, they slightly improved their EBIT margin to  a level of 11.8%.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The outlook for 2012 is basically untouched, the same what we have announced earlier. Our revenues and our  operative EBIT remain at the same level as last year. There are a few assumptions mentioned here concerning oil  price and also the currencies. So, any big changes relating to these two of course has an impact. But based on these  assumptions, we are confident that this guidance that is stated here is the one that we will deliver.

file: KEMIRA - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 22October2013 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Clearly, focus here is on paper as well as on oil and mining. Because if you recall what we said in the strategy, M&I  is earmarked as cash optimization. In ChemSolutions, we are evaluating strategies to exit the formic acid business  and that's why growth going forward is expected to come from the paper market as well as from oil and mining,  and this is where our pipeline is geared to deliver and support this growth.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: What I would like to also use the opportunity is to highlight our sustainability performance. We have, at the end of  last year, on the management board level, defined sustainability targets for the company and we are measuring  our sustainability targets on a quarterly basis in order to track whether we are moving in the right direction or  whether the targets are just a word of mouth.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Where we are meanwhile doing very good is considering sustainability targets in our new product development  process. We have guided that in every new product development which is launched in our R&D sustainability will  be considered and sustainability targets will be linked to in 80% of the projects we've launched this year this has  been taken into consideration and has been lived up to. So we are on the right way to really also orient our  portfolio under the guidelines of sustainability.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Overall, we are well on track. As I have said, room for improvement, but sustainability has been anchored in the  Kemira culture of the future as a very vital pillar. And from that point of view, I'm confident that we will progress  also in the delivery of these targets.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Reported revenues declined 2%, as Wolfgang was explaining, but the organic growth measured in local currencies  were still a growth of 3%. The operative EBIT margin, it's worth noting, was the highest of Kemira's water  strategies since 2008. And all three segments, core segments, reported an EBIT margin close to 9%. So in that  sense, we are on the right track with our execution.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then if you look at this variance mix from bridging the quarter from year ago, you'll see that we have been able to  – improving in terms of volumes and sales prices. Sales prices did not fully offset the cost of – the increases in  variable costs, but the combination of volume and price increases more than offset the increases in variable costs.  The costs were mainly in propylene as well as electricity cost in paper and M&I.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Recently, we have opened up new AKD sizing product plants in Finland, Sweden, Canada, and China, and also the  hydrogen peroxide capacity expansion in Uruguay. And those are all along the lines that helping us in the organic  growth side.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Let's see. Regarding ChemSolutions, again, there was a big drop in reported revenue, but this is almost entirely  explained by the divestiture of the food and pharmaceutical business in the beginning of 2013. Regarding the  businesses, the formic acid related core business is quite stable. And in addition, we have now improved the  sodium percarbonate performance after a weak second quarter. So that is also reflecting in the sequential  profitability improvement.

file: KEMIRA - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 22October2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Oil & Mining, we have been growing strongly. The markets are growing strongly especially in North America,  shale gas and oil deals. And we have grown 15% year-to-date and 23% with acquisitions. And we plan on adding  capacity to our Oil & Mining segment to keep the growth up.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our Oil & Mining segment has continued to grow well. And combined with the M&A, mainly 3F, which we closed  Q4 last year, the growth has been really nice. We are coming to an end to a rather successful integration project of  the 3F business. We will continue to drive growth, especially in North America and in the Oil & Gas segment  where the demand for shale gas and oil chemicals is growing strongly.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We are the world's second largest polymer producer in the world for this type of applications, and the EPAM and  DPAM products mostly used as friction reducers. You can see on this slide the other products that we also  combine and deliver to the industry.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The, sort of next step outlook is the chemical EOR or enhanced oil recovery. We don't gain any revenue from that  business yet, but that's an excellent opportunity going forward and a large tonnage of polymers will be needed to  serve that market. However, I'd like to point out – we don't expect any major revenue from that segment or that  market until one year to two years down the road. But we are working closely with customers for test cases and  test fields to be deployed.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Y ou can also see the activities that we have announced already that will be the next growth engines in the  business. And as said, we'll be investing more into Oil & Gas, and Pulp and Paper capacity. We also will continue  to look at M&A opportunities and I prefer bolt-on type of cases, but let's see what the opportunities out there  might provide.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Elsewhere, we also need to improve profitability through additional scale and efficiency improvements. And I  said, we'll continue to grow in the most profitable part of our business which is particularly our Oil & Gas business  in North America.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The growth is supported by market – the last time we looked at rig count, it's still up 11%, even with the oil price  have come down. So, it seems – and the evidence that we are seeing that the shale production is very cost effective  even at these oil price levels and actually can support even lower oil prices. And the activity seems to continue at  the very high level.

file: KEMIRA - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 23October2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: Oil prices obviously are significantly down from this time last year. Q2 was actually in the $60s on Brent, and Q3  has now been around $50, even below $50 per barrel. That has benefit in raw materials, obviously especially the  oil-based raw materials, but we have had some raw material movements that are adverse to our business also. On  top of that, the geopolitical movements that could affect our business and could definitely affect our customer  business, so that's been when we entered the year.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: We have also progressed in our EOR business and have gained some new business from oil sands. We haven't  been in Canadian oil sands before. Now, we have some new contracts from there, so that's going nicely forward.  And we have added a small bolt-on acquisition by acquiring the Soto business from USA. Three years ago or two  years ago, we bought the Canadian side of the business; now, we got the sister company from U.S. side.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: In the CMD in our Espoo research center, we also showed how we have a pipeline of R&D projects ongoing. And  during Q3, we launched a new surface size solution to the markets. The project in Brazil for Klabin, the chemical  island project, is on schedule, on budget and scheduled to start up first half of next year; obviously, linked to the  huge customer greenfield project, but it's looking promising.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: In Oil & Mining, the market conditions obviously have been not good for us this year. You can see the indication  on the oil price, rig count and so on. Also, metals prices have gone down. I'm still pleased how we've been able to  protect the top line and the bottom line. Yes, we have some pressure there, but the drop has been only on top line  6%, aided obviously by FX.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: After Q2, we said that we could see the bottoming out of the shale business in Q3. We still see some softness in the  market and we might not bottom out fully, but certainly the drop is not as dramatic anymore. If there is further  drop, then it has been in the early part of the year. Let's see how the market develops.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: The good news is that we have made a good and faster-than-expected advance in the EOR business. Our current  deliveries to India are continuing. We are developing our business with Chevron. We have now the oil sands  contract signed that will start giving some volume this year but mostly kicking in next year, so that should be  compensating for the shale sometime next year.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: So, what are we doing in Oil & Mining? Pricing discipline. Obviously, customers are coming now to us with  concessionaires – asking for concessions. We give the gain. We negotiate that we can get more volumes for price  concessions if – so we've been somewhat successful in that, not obviously in all cases. Also, we try to negotiate that  once prices come back, the concessions go away.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: Portfolio management, meaning where do we sell? Last year, this time, we were fully busy in serving the shale  market. And our factories were running full. We weren't looking at other possible areas of selling polymers. Now,  we are looking more into that. And actually, we've been able to grow volumes into the mining industry.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: New products and services, I already talked about EOR. I already talked about oil sands, and the Canadian side is  a new business for us, that's good. So I'm optimistic that next year, we can turn Oil & Mining back to growth  space, based on this new business coming and then shale bottoming out and eventually then hopefully seeing  some growth also there. But we're not banking on that changing any time soon.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: In Oil & Mining, we want to return to organic growth regardless of oil price. You can see that we've made good  steps in EOR and Canadian oil sands, for instance; mining also going quite nicely. We obviously keep on getting  ready for the turn of the market, although we don't look forward to that happening any time soon, especially in oil  and gas. So, we want to achieve double-digit growth over the cycle. And mining and oil is a cyclical business as we  know, so that's why we look at it over the cycle. Profitability, as we saw last year, should be over the group average.  So, we can gain the operating leverage from oil and mining, so that's why the target is above the group average.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: So we drive both organic and inorganic growth. We improve profitability by operational improvements, leveraging  growth and capturing synergies. We are executing all of those, and we updated our vision to be the first choice in  chemistry for water-intensive industries, which means a lot more than just being biggest in the industry. We want  to be the first choice in customer mind when they are making choices in their chemical supplier and chemical  technologies.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Jari, and good morning, everyone. So really summarizing the quarter and really what Jari already said,  the AkzoNobel paper chemical acquisition integration is going real well. Sales volumes are increasing in M&I. We  continue to get the benefit of the raw material environment, and also we had a nice cash flow generation in Q3.  These are all positives and I will sort of demonstrate some of the proof points in the numbers soon. Obviously, on  the negative side we continue to see a difficult oil environment that impacts the Oil & Mining segment.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Municipal & Industrial delivered stable organic growth, and that growth was driven by volumes which is obviously  very good. And then the 15% decline in Oil & Mining, already well addressed, driven by the downturn and the  difficult times, particularly in the shale operations.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The positive part of that, of course, for the segment is that chemical enhanced oil recovery and the oil sands  revenues are increasing. They're coming off a very small base, but they're steadily increasing and starting to  demonstrate profitability and growth from that segment. And these are giving the confidence for us that we're  saying that the segment, regardless of what the oil price environment is, is expected to return to growth in 2016.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In M&I, which is clearly a great story, so the profitability has been really the three drivers behind that. It is the  efficiency measures that we have taken in the past years. Now, our fixed costs are about 2 percentage points lower  than they were just a couple of years ago. Also, we have become more efficient in terms of our net working capital  management. They are obviously helped by the additional volumes. And I said the benign raw material  environment is clearly benefiting of this to the tune that we are at 15.5% EBITDA for the quarter in the segment.  We are already above our long-term sort of target rate for the segment.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: There have been some questions – some people have questioned that we are sort of entering emerging markets, as  we have talked about our growth in APAC which is growth in China and whether we are sort of taking undue risks.  Let me make a couple of comments there. First of all, it is sort of a low-risk approach what we are doing in China.  So we are exporting from Europe, so we do not have – we haven't added local fixed cost base for manufacturing  for that business. We target the high-end applications like sludge dewatering and also [indiscernible] (21:38) the  high-end customers or the sort of biggest customers there.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We are already profitable now, so we are doing this in a profitable way. And sort of an example of the type of  customers, we are already working now or two of the four water treatment facilities in Shanghai are using our  polymers for sludge dewatering. So, these are the type of examples what we do in China.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving on to the raw material side, if you look at the graph on the right-hand side – we've shown this graph  always in our results – you see that the gap between the variable costs and the sales price has widened. And  clearly, this is a sort of a proof point of the very benign raw material environment which, by the way, is now  expected to continue at least through 2015. But it's also the fact that we have been able to protect our pricing quite  well. So, this is the pricing discipline that Jari was talking about.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We have also received some questions about electricity. People who look at electricity prices in the Nordics  particularly see that the trend has been going down and whether this has been benefiting us. Yes, it has to some  extent, but most of our top contracts are chloride contracts. And chloride production is the high-electricity  consumption where we use electricity. But most of those contracts are indexed from the market price and the  forward prices, so not that much, has been some help but not the major driver.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And then despite the weakness in the oil market, we continue to invest in the market to be able to take advantage  of the chemical enhanced oil recovery opportunity and take advantage of the oil sands. But you see the number,  €19 million, for the first nine months of the year, that's clearly much so much less than what we had anticipated  more than a year ago before this oil downturn started.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Just to summarize our investment case highlights. We have a leading market position in all our core technologies  like polymers, like sizing and bleaching chemicals. We have a strong financial position, and we continue to look at  synergistic and accretive acquisitions. And I think we're building a good track record of capturing synergies.

file: KEMIRA - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 25October2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, when looking at then some of our biggest investment and especially our bleaching chemicals, the Klabin plant  for Brazil, which we started up in March, is well ramped up and running well. So, that's good progress. We also  announced that we will build a new plant here in Finland. That was announced in March. That's progressing well  on schedule, on quality, on budget and safely. And we expect it to start up last quarter of next year. In total, we  have 10 bleaching chemical assets around the world, and they are all running well at the moment, although we  will be experiencing some maintenance shutdowns by customers in our Fray Bentos site in Uruguay last quarter  of this year.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining markets remain challenging. As I said, the Shale business, we saw the bottom during the summer,  and we saw some recovery in volumes during Q3, somewhat offset by competitive prices but still some  improvement. Our Oil Sands business is developing not huge millions but still on a totally different level than last  year this time. And our Mining business is going steady. And our other verticals are going steady. The EOR  business we continue to develop, but those businesses are slow to develop in this market environment. And we  have seen some tough price competition in some biddings also.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So in Oil & Mining, we've said before, we've been working on short term, looking and mitigating the costs. And our  operating structure, while we've been also looking longer-term investments into oil sands, oil recovery and shale,  looking at mining and other verticals, and then developing EOR. So, this dual strategy has the arrow show we've  been now developing, and the bottom has been reached for Oil & Mining, but market continues to be challenging,  I have to admit that.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If we look at the future targets for M&I and the development on top of doing Advanced Water Treatment and  developing that business, we are developing also the business geographically, going more to Middle East, to  Africa, and continuing to grow our business in APAC. Meaning, offering more of our offerings to existing  customers and especially to new customers, and then going to new geographies on top of what we've done today.  And we do it selectively, so it's not a full charge going to new areas, but doing it carefully.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And also I'd like to sort of, in my own words, so that there's no drama in this revenue outlook update. The  currencies have worked against us. That's more than €20 million of negative hit on the top line from the  currencies. The oil and mining market is sort of well-established. And the lower raw material prices have impacted  our top line or our sales prices. That's more than what expected. But in retrospect, we have been able to manage  our profitability very well.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: But let's go and look at the numbers. I'll try to give my remarks relatively short, so we have enough time for  questions. So, I mentioned the currency. It has been about a 1 percentage point per quarter, so about €20 million  on a year-to-date prices. Clearly, the more bigger impact is the decline on sales prices. This has impacted all  segments, but relatively the most Oil & Mining segment, where we have the largest share of oil-based raw  materials. So, again, it's natural. Volumes were about flat against the very strong Q3 of 2015.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Regarding Oil & Mining, market is still challenging especially when one looks at the year-on-year comparison.  Sequentially, we're already seeing some pick-ups, as Jari mentioned, in the shale business. We have seen  volumes going up from the summer, some 10% perhaps quarter-on-quarter, but there continues to be some  pressure on prices. That's why the recovery is coming slowly and not immediately visible in the profitability.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Also, I'd like to point out in that on the longer term, when we anticipate the growth from CEOR, Chemical  Enhanced Oil Recovery, we expect that initially that growth will come with a dilutive impact. And the dilutive  impact comes, because we will need to deploy some new manufacturing technologies, and we sort of need to go  through the learning curve and get through down the cost curve with this. So, that's something to be expected.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Looking at M&A, again, very strong, steady performance in Q3. Another quarter with above 16% profitability.  Volumes grew, but that growth was offset again there also in sales basis and somewhat impacted by the negative  currency development. This segment for example, the British pound is relatively important as we are selling quite  a bit of water treatment chemicals in the UK.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then let's look at the raw material prices. And typically, we tend to focus on the chart on the right. And as you can  see, input costs still continue to decrease in Q3. And so, this benign raw material pricing environment has  persisted quite a long time. We've been flagging that we do expect raw material pricing environment to turn. And  now I think we're probably at the bottom now, but this reversal we see is very modest. So, I don't think that there's  anything drama in how the raw material pricing environment as of today's knowledge is going to appear.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Sales price have continued to come down driven by this raw material prices. And again, like we said in some  areas by increased competitive pressures. However, I think the industry, overall, sees that the raw material  decline environment is coming to an end, and there are already some signs of sales price stabilization.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Investments, we are investing into growth, and we have this guidance for €200 million of CapEx. Year-to-date,  we're only about €120 million, roughly at the same level of last year. So we do expect quite a significant CapEx  pickup in Q4. And whether we will reach €200 thereabout, less or little more, depends really on the timing of some  of the bigger ongoing projects like, for example, the chlorate mine expansion, which we are going in settlement.  We basically do not manage the CapEx to a number, but rather manage the CapEx projects in the most efficient  way.

file: KEMIRA - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 24October2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Strong momentum continued in Oil & Gas, but all areas also saw growth. One new thing is good to note in our  numbers that in Q3, we had oil sands delivery campaign on treating tailings pond material. Most of it was during  Q3 and it's now over for the season. That's a new business for us that has good opportunities and good volumes  going long term forward, but that is clearly diluting and affecting Q3 relative profitability.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Looking at Pulp & Paper, and I'll be talking about year-to-date, organic growth has been above our targets, but  profitability has been hampered by FX. Year-to-date organic growth has been 6%. Bleaching and sizing markets  are strong, and our plants are running well. Some raw material issues in the sizing side, but that's been there for a  longer time. Sales prices are starting to catch up, but our focus is in the Process & Functional Chemicals, and we  still need work to do.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
