texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Industry & Water, organic growth year-to-date 12%, led by Oil & Gas. Oil & Gas growth year-to-date 26%, but it's  worth to note that there's been 18 months of recovery now, real growth, so this growth pace will be now easing  off. That's a natural development, so nothing to worry about. We see the market as growing strong, but we won't  be growing. So, big double-digit numbers next quarters. Positive development also in the water treatment area,  but naturally, more modest in the Oil & Gas.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: One development in the quarter was the surprise Venator titanium oxide closure announcement here in Finland.  They earlier announced that after the fire in early 2017, they will be reconstructing the plant, but now they  abandoned that, and they plan to close the plant sometime by 2021. We have not received any raw material from  them during the last 18 months, so how we operate is going well. We now have to then plan during the coming  quarters on what is our longer-term reaction to their decision. And as said, insurance coverage is consumed up.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Looking and reminding of the sort of foundation for our strategy and business selection, the fundamentals on what  we are working on: global growth, urbanization, [ph] sustainability need to drive or (00:06:06) use of water,  energy, pulp, packaging and tissue, and we're at the heart of those; e-commerce driving really big way packaging,  and different than going to a normal shop and not needing so much packaging.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Resource efficiency for energy is driving unconventional oil and gas, demand, and the plastics dilemma, for  example, drives for need for recyclable packaging out of fiber. Regulation is getting tighter and tighter, and water  intake quality, meaning that more treatment is needed, is getting more challenging. So, thinking of medium and  long term, we're in a right place from a strategic point of view.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Demand for pulp in the world remains strong. And bleaching is obviously needed when pulp wants to be made  white for paper and tissue and other applications. Newsprint is going down. That means that there's less recycling  paper in the market, so that drives the pulp demand. Also, the Green Fence initiative in China is limiting recycled  paper entry to Chinese players, so they are more reliant on virgin pulp.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: This time last year, we started ramp-up of Joutseno, investment of a new line of €50 million to bleaching capacity.  So I can state that the timing of that investment was really good. We have already added some new [ph] reactor  cells (00:07:50) into that site and increased somewhat the capacity. So – and we continue to look at additional  debottlenecking possibilities at all of our bleaching sites.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Another example, and you can see the one-time costs in this quarter, we have for the [ph] past (00:08:08) 20  years been making washing detergent in Sweden, consuming some of our bleaching capacity, that business now  is ramping down, [ph] and the end (00:08:20) outlook is not so good. And we have a strong demand for bleaching  chemistries. So we are closing down that plant and directing that capacity to our Pulp & Paper customers, which  is in core of our strategy. The closing down costs would be around one-third of the investment costs for releasing  that capacity, so it makes perfect sense from a strategic point of view.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So bleaching continues to be strategic to us. We do have our proprietary technology to manufacture it, so we are  committed to serve our customers in the bleaching space.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Looking at the water trend in that area, so classical water treatment and knowledge continues to be another  backbone of our business. We deliver chemistries and technologies to treat drinking water, meaning raw water  taking in and turned into drinking water. We are a part of the wastewater sludge removal in municipalities. We are  in industrial processes in recycling the water and feeding it back to the process. And we are treating industrial  waters that are released back to the nature. And often, they have to be even more clean than the raw water intake  was originally to the industrial plants.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Regulation, as said, is tightening all the time. And if you're not aware, EU is in a process of relooking at their 20- year back regulations in Europe regarding what are quality wastewater treatment. Those are not applied in  European countries equally even at today, but after 20 years, EU is looking at what is the next level of regulation  here in Europe.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: To close off my update, good organic growth driven by sales prices. We had a good campaign of – and technical  success to the oil sands, but the numbers are not there. We have to next work on our numbers for the next  season. Price [ph] increase still in (00:10:40) progress, but we need to push more as we are in [ph] inventory  (00:10:45) raw material and transportation market, so it's not, by far, over.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Some of the growth that we are seeing, and I'm particularly referring to the oil sands campaign now, which is a  significant or good part of the volume growth, is coming at a low – very low margin. It is coming at a positive  margin but still a margin that is clearly diluting our business. But nevertheless, we can say that the – or happily  note that the volume growth and also the improved pricing actually led to €89 million of EBITDA, which is the  highest EBITDA, absolute euros, since 2009. So there's a little bit of a cause for celebration as we are going into  the right direction, even as we are not yet fulfilling our targets regarding relative profitability.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Regarding the analysis though, I'll make a little bit of a caution here that we don't [ph] make too (00:15:41)  straight-line comments because this is approximation, and product mix can always have some impact to the  numbers, particularly when the numbers are relatively – if they're small. So in Q2, the caustic price increases  actually were exaggerating the positive aspect of it. And now in Q3, the high volume of oil sands deliveries  actually were muting the positive impact of it. So I'm referring to the net €11 million versus net €4 million. So if you  sort of were to eliminate the product mix impact, the line would be much straighter. So, I'm not worried about the  €11 million turning to €4 million, rather worried about the overall trends that we make enough of progress.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Moving on to I&W, again, the story is the Oil & Gas business driving the top line growth. Oil & Gas growth  organically at 28%, and now it represents this quarter more than 10% of Kemira volume. So you remember some  time ago, we were looking at Oil & Gas less than 5% or approximately 5% of Kemira revenue, so now this  important growth area is actually more than 10% of Kemira revenue.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Some comments on the water treatment, EMEA perhaps somewhat limited growth, clearly seeing the pressure on  – [ph] regarding (00:19:28) raw materials. North America has been historically a tougher market for us, and  against that backdrop, performance during Q3 is somewhat encouraging. So we have seen some improvements  in the top line and profitability.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj

And especially slide 9 shows that very good  cash flow improvement within previous years, so that this year – last year 2009, €200 million cash flow is, as a  positive. texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj

Otherwise, stable business industrial water  treatment in certain areas still have the weaker demand compared to last year, but Municipal business was very  stable and doing well.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj

However, there is in the end of the year,  we saw a pickup in oil field chemicals demand based on oil price increase so activities are at the moment higher  than it used be for one year ago the same is in metal industry where we have a water treatment business as well  based on metal price increases, so we saw a demand picking up in the end of the 2009.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And now, still repeat the problem of separating Tikkurila, there are many reasons, one reason being that this  increases shareholder value when we separate these things and put separately in the stock market as we know. texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And now if we move on, there are basically two slides any more and just want to repeat that the rest of the Kemira  will be even now more, more and more focused on water treatment business. texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman- Business and Strategic Management Boards, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Really, 75% of our business is already related to water.
