And we will be more and more innovative company  focusing on hi-tech solutions for customers.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 9February2011 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In Municipal & Industrial case, the Industrial customer segment performed as well. The industrial part, just to  remind you is including different kind of industries like food and beverage, sugar, energy and so on. And it's the  rest of the Industrial customers outside Paper and Oil & Mining.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then we have a smaller business [ph] consult (03:58) ChemSolutions that is not water business. Just to remind  you, we have more than 75% of our net sales is for water treatment business. ChemSolutions is not that but it had  a very strong performance, especially in Q4. I will come back to these Q4 figures later on.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Operative EBIT margin in Slide number 7, it has more about doubled within last two years. Perhaps you  remember that we started focus on water treatment and water technologies in mid of 2008. And looking at the  present business growth, for instance outside Tikkurila, [ph] titanium dioxide (04:57), we had only 3.3% EBIT in  2008, and now it's increased to 7.5; all segments have improved from 2008 level.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: There is in Slide 11 a nice story about Global Water Intelligence magazine or database, where they state that  Kemira was the best performer among water stocks during 2010 competing all our competitors. And it was a very  good story also. And I'm also happy to see that Kemira within a very low – short time, barely two-and-a-half year,  has been recognized as a real water company and also that our performance was very strong in stock market.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Looking at the bridge of Q4 2010 versus 2009, we can see that variable costs meaning raw material prices driven  by oil price development increased quite a lot already in Q4. However, we were able to compensate that by our  own price increases and volume increase. Also, we had €4 million lower fixed costs, meaning that we really  increased our EBIT from €32 million to €40 million level.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: During 2010, we announced to establish a Center of Water Efficiency Excellence with research and development  Institute called VTT in Finland, Slide 19. It is strategically very important for us to differentiate ourselves, identify  and develop new product applications.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We are application-driven company and this is important event and action for us to develop competencies,  understand better our customer processes and customer logic, but also have more innovative offering to selected  customers. And we have a network with other companies offering other technologies than water chemistry. And  we are working with those [ph] guys (13:36) and we have certainly also established a global university network.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So it means that we have a positive outlook for volumes. We have, however, also risk factors. In Kemira Europe  dollar exchange rate always is some kind of risk. It's not a big one but anyway it's good to mention it. More  important one is oil price development. That has been developing a bit unfavorable during last months. So that's  certainly one risk for 2011.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If you look at the different segments and business environment during this year, we still see that it's positive for  pulp customer segment. Paper customers continue to grow, however, demand is expected or demand growth  expected to decrease from 2010 level. Oil & Gas certainly is all about energy and prices will be volatile but going  up, that seems to be so. There are new energy sources in Canada, Canada oil sands, et cetera where Kemira is  actively looking at and penetrating to those businesses. So it also gives us opportunities. It's not only a threat.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In mining industry, Metals & Minerals, we estimate that strong demand – global demand for commodities will  continue and there is also new areas, Brazil, Africa, China, Russia, that seems to be positively – shows positive  development during this year. Municipal water treatment demand has been stable even during recession 2008  and 2009. And it will be stable – more stable also during 2011.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Despite of rising raw material prices, we expect that operative EBIT will be higher in 2011 than in 2010. And  finally, I will close this short presentation showing you this strategy implementation roadmap. When we started in  mid of 2008 water strategy, we were very fragmented in many ways, weak balance sheet and so on.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So we had to fix and focus as we say, a lot of activities to focus on water treatment, fix the business, improve  profitability, especially cash flow, turn cash flow to positive side from negative, et cetera. Also, we build one  common, one Kemira instead of as a holding company that it used to be, meaning a lot of integration activities  that have been completed. There's always – you need to develop, of course, organization further.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: SWEET is a very important strategic element to build future competencies and new offerings, focus on application  and our balance sheet also enables us to have selected acquisitions. We have also some financial assets  available, like we own 14% of Tikkurila shares and we have a 39% ownership of JV Sachtleben that is a titan  dioxide business. Titan dioxide business did very well last year and demand and supply balance was favorable for  producers. Prices went up and it seems to be that it's going strong also now.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 8February2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So headline is growth in water chemistry business in 2011, and let's go right away to this – how to say – big picture  of what happened last year and looking at – from Kemira Group point of view. So we had, first of all, a slight  revenue increase, where our real water business grew anyway by 6%, that is, I'm personally happy about that. And  we need to understand that currencies and divestments, especially in our paper business, had a negative impact in  revenue growth.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have had and we are going to do site consolidation in North America, in Europe that will help in the future  improve profitability and increase our cost efficiency as well. And we are more and more using recycled raw  material, and we are looking at more long-term cost effective raw material contracts, especially North America  and Europe, where our main business is.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining business, of course is a success story. So we started the business in 2008 and we had every year  improved profitability, improved net profit and EBIT, and also we have been growing every year. And especially  last year we had a good penetration so-called in unconventional oil and gas business, especially North America.  For instance, in shale gas. So that every financial raiser was very good in 2011, and I believe that trend will  continue also in the future.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Finally, and this is very important, I'm personally extremely happy that when we started our so-called SWEET  program in spring 2010, and that is focusing on building water competencies in Kemira with our partners. But  also, of course, the final aim is to develop new applications and new products, that in 2011 we had more than €40  million new sales based on the SWEET program with good margin.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And so every segment had better outcome, that was our internal target in 2010, and that is the area where we can  really differentiate ourselves in the future and building a unique position in water chemistry business, where by  the way I personally calculate that we are the second biggest in the world at the moment. And then we can  differentiate ourselves having a wide product palette focusing on application and solving really customer  problems. I really see that this is the key element to be successful in the future, also in long term in this growing  water business, that as we remember is €500 billion business, where relevant market for Kemira is close to €30  million. And we have now about €2 billion business, so there is lot of growth potential for Kemira.  I will only look at, from this slide, the numbers by segment 2011 compared to 2010. And if you look at the Paper,  so the revenue is about that same level as the previous year, as well as the EBIT. That is a relative good  achievement recognizing the tough market conditions during the full year.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining, really every figures is excellent. We had an operative EBIT improvement from €28 million to €36  million. And also that the operative EBIT percentage increased to close to 11%. That is at the good level,  recognizing that we are growing at the same time.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We changed our strategy in 2008 focusing on water chemistry and water. And when we started in 2008, we  heritaged already Water business, partly this is serving municipalities and cities, but partly also serving paper  industry and perhaps something else. Now we have, I think, successfully implemented our strategy innovated in  2011. We have 78% of revenues is coming from water chemistry.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We are not targeting to have fully 100%, because I don't think that any chemical company has – even focusing on  water has 100%. But it's a nice trend and can be perhaps also even be higher in the future. And it's based on the  common technology and common product portfolio and serving selected markets globally. That's the simple logic  there, and I still believe that this is – will be really relevant also in the future.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Certainly, one element is the SWEET and building new products with an applications with higher than 10% EBIT.  That we did last year very well and that trend will continue. So we have created a culture where this is possible.   We are very much focusing on advanced pricing, value pricing in Kemira. We have a special project ongoing that  we started in 2010, that it will be completed within one year. So that is one element to be able to increase gross  margin.  We have this year, 2012, about 200 different kind of productivity actions ongoing. One of them is mentioned here,  energy efficiency improvement, that we have now put also as a little bit visibility. We believe that this year €10  million savings can be implemented in 2012. All-in-all, this productivity needs to be improved by 3% per year.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Paper segment, really – especially pulp customers had lower demand. We also had a divestment in – we divested  in November our hydrogen peroxide business in Canada, so that naturally also decreased our sales and EBIT, but  we had higher sales prices. And basically this operative EBIT landed much less than previous years based on these  reasons.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining segment, basically performed also in Q4 quite well, pretty well. Operative EBIT increased by 30%;  that is fine. And this is a business then you know that when energy price or cost is at the high level, our segments  like Municipal & Industrial and Paper, of course, it's challenging in this business. The higher the energy price is,  the activities in our customer industry is, of course, also high.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: But anyway, that is only one reason. The business is doing very well. And I'm really happy that when we debated  in 2008 focusing on water, that should we penetrate on this segment based on the fact that customer industry is  demanding big companies, oil and gas service companies are big ones, also mining companies. We have  demonstrated that the selection was very good.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So we have built a good customer base. And I think that as an example, those unconventional oil and gas activities  is – especially in North America, Kemira has built an excellent position there. We are within two most important  companies there. So that's fine.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: There are some slides about some points of strategy implementation, not many, but I would like to address and  share with you. We have this strengthening position in key water intensive industries. That is, of course, really  critical for Kemira to be differentiated there. We still can optimize our customer product portfolio, that is, by the

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Technology renewal and growth in those growing areas. We have selected three segments, basically this is water  and energy efficiencies is key element. From our point of view, it is based on same technology base and common  product lines serving these three areas, where Paper for us is serving a €10 billion market potential.  We are more  and more focused on recycling.  Water chemistry is new products, emerging markets, and we have a good market  position in selected areas.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Water is the – always the – it has an increasing role. Again I will – why we are here is that when we – people drill  one gallon oil like in North Sea or Mexico Gulf, it normally  takes seven to 12 times more water. So that's why the  water is the issue. Water is the thing.  Unconventional areas, water is in my mind even more important.  So that's  why the water – it's real water-based, it's very demanding, and that I think is – it's – serving cities and  municipalities is still our important business.  We need to increase our profitability there.  What has been good  that we have building in this, the Industrial part of that, it has been more and more based on application rather  than selling products.  And the business, the potential is €10 billion as well.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have at the moment 74 sites. We are not so big company, but we have many production units. We have closed  24 – 25 sites in the previous years. And so that we are more divested – not water – chemical production units. We  have also closed small sites, non-profitable sites. And we have also, as a third element, stepped out some markets,  like we have stepped out of Japan, Korea and somewhere else as well, like now in Canada basically in the end of  last year, where we don't see from Kemira's point of view 10% EBIT business possible in long term. So we have  been cleaning our site network quite a lot.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So this is also important that – and key and critical element to be able to see and come back to this 10% EBIT level  in serving municipalities to have a first long-term and good raw material contracts for Kemira, and more are using  recycle. Recycling in Europe and North America is getting bigger and bigger every year, but it also means that we  need to renew our production network.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Still two slides, I guess. The SWEET program, I already told, it's also critical to be able to implement out of water  strategy – water chemistry strategy, especially in 2011 when we generated more than €40 million new business.  It's antiscalants, biocides, and new business desalination, that we have discussed with you earlier. So new product,  new applications, and something else as well, but these are perhaps the most critical areas.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Finally, there is some other type of things. There is a picture of healthy lake and algae lake. We have restored 20  lakes with chemical restoration in Finland. The last one was [indiscernible] (32:36) here, and now we've got a new  and the first deal in South America, big deal in Brazil. So that is opening the Brazilian market. So it is somewhere  between €5 million to €10 million deal, single deal. As one example to have something that no other company has.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 6February2013 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: From an EBIT perspective, we came home with €154.1 million, within our guidance 2% below the respective level  of 2011. The operative EBIT margin reached 6.9%, and Fit for Growth which was launched in July 2012 reached  basically contribution as we have forecasted of roughly €10 million and Jyrki Mäki-Kala will explain what has hit  us, while nevertheless we only came home more or less at last year's level.  What was a big disappointment for us is our Sachtleben operation. You might have heard that in the course of  2012, not just demand for TiO2 collapsed, but also the prices and our operative earnings per share reached €0.72  per share, down from €0.89 per share a year before and €0.13 of that actually are the negative impact of joint  venture Sachtleben. So that gives you an idea how challenging the markets in titanium dioxide are under the  current circumstances.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If you look to the development of our major segments or of our segments, you see clearly that there are two  categories. The first is obviously Oil & Mining, which is small, growing, but still the most profitable part. Paper is  constantly improving its profitability. So Paper is clearly on the right track. ChemSolutions in 2012 was hit by an  extended shutdown which we had in summer 2012, but is now already on the way up and we are sure that in 2013  ChemSolutions will return to a profitability level we had at least before and which is north of 10%.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We continue with our asset optimization program and we are reviewing at this point the final sites which we have  originally earmarked which might be eligible for closure and as we are progressing with our decisions we will keep  you posted.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Raw material costs clearly is a challenge in this business and you all are aware that the iron ore prices and  therefore the iron source has increased quite a bit over the recent months. That hits all the manufacturers of  coagulants. So access to raw materials is key and we are increasing our efforts to secure not just short-term, but on  a long-term byproduct sources for Kemira in order to mitigate our exposure to fluctuations on the raw material  markets.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Last but not least, we have initiated a program to optimize freight cost. The business is challenged by substantial  freight cost and to a large extent water is shipped between manufacturing sites and customers and we are now  allocating customers based on logistics optimization to individual plants, rather than taking geography as a  decisive point. So we're using tools of forwarders how to optimize cost in the context of our supply chain from the  manufacturing site to the customer.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If you go to ChemSolutions, clearly we had issues with raw material prices in summer and with the extended  shutdown. We've discussed it already when we were presenting the Q2 and the Q3 results. With Fit for Growth, we  on the divestment of [ph] Valerie (00:15:11) so the formic – the food and pharmaceuticals business based on  propionic acid and acetic acid.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We are focusing the business on formic acid and derivates and apply a lean operation model on top of that and  drive the Oulu capacity to its limits. We have meanwhile found ways to further increase this capacity and we had  actually even production records in the last two months of 2012 and we are driving that further. So in the future,  ChemSolutions will clearly focus on formic acid and derivatives and will serve the chemical industry and the feed  industry, but no longer the food and pharmaceutical industry where we do not have any benefits.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: De-icers, you are aware of, is a seasonal business. Currently, the business is doing very well. So from that point of  view, especially January seems to be a good month for de-icing with all the snowfall, but you know from previous  years that this is rather unpredictable. So that's why we take this as when it comes it comes and we will of course  entertain it, but we're very careful in predicting how it's going to develop long-term, but clearly it will stay part of  our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: This also helps in the streamlined operation based on formic acid to leverage the Oulu plant in a better way,  because we're really focused on the large volume mainstream products. So from that point of view, we also get  additional capacity out of the plant. And this shows that if you go along a stringent path, there are many aspects  which this is improving your performance, not just simply by reducing the complexity, but also by freeing capacity  in the respective acid footprint.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: What is clearly the trend is that packaging is getting lightweight. So the industry is looking for less fiber to be used  to get stabilized and stable packaging and the same holds true for tissue and this is something where clearly  innovation comes into play and Kemira is participating in that. And the second trend is clearly that recycled fiber  is getting evermore important which requires more chemistry and from that point of view we are encouraged to  stay on track with considering Paper to be a core element of Kemira's strategy and continue to move towards  packaging and board and tissue.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And just to give you an example, with Fennobond we are able to get at a lower fiber content, the same tensile  strength of the respective packaging and therefore without sacrificing the stability of the carton box, less raw  material can be used which means a direct saving for the manufacturer. And these figures are not our own figures;  these figures are actually results of MetsäBoard, so one of our customers. And we are rolling out this innovation  now in the industry and we have more innovation coming also with respect to saving raw materials when it comes  to producing more sophisticated packaging materials.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If you go to Oil & Mining, the good news is Oil & Mining continued its success story with respect to profitability.  are at this point in time very much exposed to shale gas and shale gas in the United States due to the low gas price  has tremendously come down in Q4 and we have seen that in a substantial slowdown in demand. Secondly, in Q4,  the overall global mining industry slowed down, declining raw material prices and this is a little bit of a challenge  in this business is they are very much depending on supply/demand balances in the global markets and they are  also very much depending on the overall prices of raw materials as well as oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have finalized in 2012 a capacity expansion for our polymer capacity via various measures of de-bottlenecking  in our facilities in the United States in order to be ready and to be prepared for the next level of demand rise when  the industry pops back and we are looking currently into smaller acquisitions to gain a stronger market position  beside fracking to balance our portfolio more with respect to also wet shale.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If you look to the revenue bridge, basically we have in 2012 some €66 million new sales coming from products and  applications which have been introduced to the market over the last five years. We have another €11 million  general growth. We have €20 million or had €20 million exit of low margin products in Oil & Mining and we had  €23 million divestments coming from the divestment of the hydrogen peroxide plant in Maitland, Canada at the  end of 2011 and also the Galvatek's business, so altogether minus €23 million. That is how we get to €2.24 billion  in revenues relative to the 2011 figure.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And then of course Fit for Growth program that we launched in July, it went according to the plan, and we  continue to implement that also this year 2013. But then the other side of the story that also affected our figures,  the negative ones basically Wolfgang already touched some of those, is really the performance of our Municipal &  Industrial business as well as ChemSolutions, and then of course this titanium dioxide situation what is now  globally very clearly seen. It hit our earnings per share very clearly as we can see in our figures.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Over the years, Kemira has been criticized a lot that we can't respond to the fact what happened in raw metal  prices, but this is a development over the last four years and in the background with these columns is the price of  oil that has been in those quarters. You'll see that whenever there's a big change in the raw metal prices, it takes  few quarters because – before it starts to hit our figures both in raw material prices but also in the sales prices, but  now when we are there in quarter four 2012, you will see that we are getting to the point that the raw material  price effect is getting very low, getting close to a zero level and we're still having – keeping our sales prices or the  change in sales prices above the change in our raw material prices. So actually this is giving the feeling that and  very strong evidence that we are able to change our prices according to the market circumstances.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining, basically it was more or less the first time that we saw a declining trend in the top line, but that was  deliberate because part of that was walking away with this so-called low margin products and we had the softness  in the North American oil and gas market. Both these elements made this effect why we saw the lower revenue in  that quarter, but overall when you look the whole year 2012, Oil & Mining continued to improve the profitability,  getting close to the 12% EBIT, which is excellent and again very positive cash flow behind, meaning how they  manage their CapEx and how they are managing their working capital.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Another big thing is about the operating expenses. It's – roughly 25% of our revenues are fixed cost. It's a little bit  classification company by company, but that's how we classify and that is always something that the cost inflation  has a meaning, 3% a year and you need to beat that with your actions of improvement and efficiency, but this is  just something you have to do.  And then oil price overall, we have seen now higher oil prices during the last three years basically, but Kemira  itself, it's only roughly 20% of our raw material spend that is really directly related to oil price and that is  something we have to tackle with our pricing systems et cetera, et cetera. But overall, I think that we have really  let's say toleration to manage these changes in the business environment.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 7February2014 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also signed a deal with Brenntag to divest our distribution businesses in Denmark, a deal which was closed at  the beginning of January this year, and we also signed a deal with Taminco in order to bring home the strategy by  disposing off the last non-core item, which is our formic acid business. Taminco is a large – the largest amine  producer. They are looking for diversification, and from that point of view, the formic acid business has a better  home with them than what it has with us, and we are expecting to close that deal in the course of the first quart er  of this year.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also finalized with the announcement to relocate the segment management and the RBU management for the  Americas from Atlanta to Houston. We are bringing the business where our competitors – where our customers  are. Houston, Texas is the global center for the oil industry, and from that point of view, we will, in the course of  the second quarter, start to relocate from Atlanta with the oil and gas people, so that we are also where our  markets are. This has proven successful when it comes to Paper, which relocated in the course of 2013 from  Finland to Frankfurt.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Just for the avoidance of doubt, the regional headquarter in North America will remain in Atlanta, so we are just  talking when we talk about relocation, about the oil and gas part of the RBU and the Oil & Mining segment  management of the group.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Again, just for the sake of accuracy, the deal regarding formic acid is not closed, but that's going to close in the  first quarter. That's included in this €200 million. So from that point of view, we have clearly improved the quality  of our business in line with our strategy substantially.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also completely reshuffled our R&D pipeline. We have, in line with the strategy that Paper and Oil & Mining  are earmarked as the growth businesses, revisited all of our R&D portfo lio. We've discontinued a substantial  number of low-contributing projects and we have really focused our R&D, to a very large extent, on the two  growth segments.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Y ou can see from the chart that M&I, as well as ChemSolutions, are playing a minor role when it comes to R&D.  And with respect to M&I, I just want to reiterate again the microbial fuel cell, which is a strategic project for us to  prepare Kemira to be a service provider to the, especially APAC mega cities, once legislation on water treatment  comes into play. So we are spending quite a lot of efforts to develop the microbial fuel cell as a new technology,  which we then can market once legislation ramps in and the markets are ready.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We've achieved a lot when it comes to optimizing our bottom line. We've clearly done a substantial amount of cost  reduction when it comes to manufacturing fixed cost. We reduced the manufacturing fixed cost by roughly 7%. We  took more or less 0.5 million metric tonnes of coagulants manufacturing out of operation by streamlining our  asset footprint and – and that's the most important for me – we launched the LEAN manufacturing, and  ultimately also the LEAN administrative initiative, in order to optimize the company from within.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: With my last slide, I would like to remind everybody the second phase of our strategy is headline -focus. The focus  as such has been achieved, and once the formic acid divestment is closed, we are from a focus perspective the  company we want to be. We will then run as a three-segment company. And from that point of view, growth is  what is then taking the [ph] lead on the agenda (20:32). And from that point of view, we are feeling well on track  and well-positioned with respect to delivering on the overall strategy which we have shared with you in April this  year.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Non-recurring items in the quarter were €7 3 million, and for the year, approximately in the last year, at €122  million. The most significant was the divestment of the coagulant business in Brazil. We mentioned this already in  our press release when we announced the sale, at €43 million. We also took some environmental provisions for  the Vaasa site, which was closed by the end of the year, and we then have various continuous efficiency measures.  These are related to some still restructuring activities that are going on. These are related to some country exits  which we have done. We decided – we exited during the fourth quarter from Mexico. We are exiting from  Colombia, again lightening our Latin American footprint and focusing in the area s that Wolfgang was talking  about.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Generally, the variable costs have remained roughly flat. We have seen some increases, particularly the propylene  prices are slowly edging up and that is impacting our polymer business in the Oil & Mining and M&I, Municipal &  Industrial; but at the same time, we are seeing benefits from the electricity prices coming down, particularly here  in Finland, and that's helping in the Paper segment with – well, in the bleaching product, the electricity is a  significant component into the price – to the cost of goods.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And if we take a look at what's coming in the future, just Wednesday, we – as you heard in [indiscernible] (30:07 )  report that they expect that [indiscernible] (30:08) this should be coming online in the comin g months as you  know and we have informed, we have a contract to be the provider of the bleaching chemicals there, and that  would be helping our – particularly on our South American which will now will be then reported as a part of  Americas Paper revenue.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining, the revenues continue to recover. So Oil & Mining during the quarter was helped by the 3F  acquisition in terms of reported revenue. At the same time, they faced about 4% currency headwinds, so the  organic growth or revenue growth in the segment was about 3%. At the same time and as Wolfgang was  mentioning, we feel that we have not been able to really participate in the growth in the oil and gas sector  specifically. And that's why, we are now taking the actions that Wolfgang mentioned.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: ChemSolutions, now clearly, ChemSolutions has divested majority of its business during the year. Earlier in the  year, the food and pharmaceuticals business was divested, and just before Ch ristmas, we entered into the  transaction to sell the formic acid business. This we expect to close during the first quarter. And once the  transaction is closed, we will transfer the remaining sodium percarbonate business to our Paper segment. And  starting from second quarter onwards, ChemSolutions as a segment will not exist anymore in our report.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Net debt during the year has been reduced by €75 million, and if you can fast forward and take into account €140  million that we expect to – we're contracted to receive from the sale of the formic acid business, you will see that  we are in a much improved balance sheet position. And as well, I must say this actually positions us quite well for  the future growth, both organic growth as well as position to look at inorganic opportunities.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 10February2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If we look at the segments, 5% growth on the full-year on our paper segment, which is clearly the biggest segment  on track and I'm pleased about this progress. Really good 33% growth in our Oil & Mining. Organic growth  without the acquisitions was 15%, driven by good demand in the oil and gas markets. Really good performance.  Obviously, now oil prices will be affecting 2015. In M&I, we turned the corner on top line during H2. Really good  progress on reaching above 12% EBITDA margin, and the role in generating cash is now clearly visible.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In oil and mining, as said, growth was strong. Naturally now this radical change in oil price has us watching out  what the market is. I'd like to point out that less than 50% of our oil and mining segment's volumes go to the shale  business. So, other parts go to the mining and other laterals of that business.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We are a friction reducer leader in U.S. and especially in the fracking and polymer technology is a n ew technology  to the industry. It wasn't in use three, four years ago. So, it's going as penetration, as new technology. You can see  that from the oil and gas business that we have in our oil and mining segment, about 50% – 15% comes from the  drilling and drilling related chemistry, 75% from the hydraulic fracking, 10% from the production, so when the  wells are producing. And we yet don't have anything from chemical-enhanced oil recovery but see as the exciting  future opportunity and we are continuing our development with the customers on the pilots of this area.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In September in the CMD, we flagged that we would need to invest more into polymer capacity in oil and mining.  Now we obviously need to be careful and look at the timing and the feasibility of those investments and we have  not launched any new capacity investments in Q4 or early part of this year. So, we're more monitoring the market.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If we look at our revenue split by the application area where Kemira operates, about 30% goes into treating water,  when water is taken in, when water is recycled or water is released into back to the nature, whether it's industry or  municipal applications. 20% comes from process energy and efficiency, and by this we mean keeping processes  and machines running smoothly. And above 50% goes to the properties of the end products, meaning giving end  product quality tissue strength, packaging strength and those type of things that he lp the customer to improve  their products and gain the qualities they want. And you can see the list of number of products we impacted  during 2014.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, as a conclusion short, I think we're in a really solid position [audio gap] (00:08:30 – 00:08:36). We have a few  things that will be impacting this year. U.S. dollar, if it remains on this level, it will help us in a positive way. Oil - related raw materials, which Petri will be talking about bit more later, will be neutral to positive. Why I say neutral  is that those will be going into also our competitor prices and our customer base knows that also. So, yes, we see  some positive signs from there, but let's not be too optimistic that trend will help us too much. Oil price in oil and  mining is something obviously we need to look at and how it impacts our friction reducer and other products  demand. I'd like to point out that so far we haven't seen a reaction in that in our order intake. However, we cannot  be naïve that that impact will come at some point. The question is what will the impact be.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Looking at the year-end and by four quarters. So, each quarter, other than the first, we improved the year-on-year  comparison. And again I would say that the first quarter was really impacted heavily by the ChemSolutions.  Remember we still had the formic acid business good part of the first quarter and the de -icing season was really  non-existent in first quarter of 2014, whereas it was very strong in first quarter of 2013. That's history now. And  now we have a clean portfolio of three segments and you see that we are delivering good year-on-year profitability  improvement.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: There are really three sort of macro changes. Talked a little bit already about the currency. Gary addressed a little  bit about it, how the oil price can impact or how we're looking at it. How it may impact our demand in the oil and  mining, but it has the flipside of it that's well. So, oil and oil derivatives are significant raw material component for  us. So, about 30% of our raw materials, oil is either direct, which basically means that it's a formula-based  pricings, so reduction of oil price has an automatic impact to the raw materials, or indirect where the impact is not  direct but it clearly linked. And clearly we will see some help, but as Gary was saying, this is not unique to us; this  is the industry phenomena and everybody recognizes that and we just need to make sure that we do our best  [indiscernible] (00:15:50) savings, and we obviously try to protect pricing as the competition will take advantage –  try to take advantage of the same thing.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The other area is that 20% of our costs are logistics costs. Going into the year, we had been expecting quite a bit of  inflationary pressure on the logistics costs. And here in the home territory in Finland, we have a n ew Sulphur  Directive, which is impacting cargo shipment costs. Lower oil price will help offset some of that pressure. Similarly  in North America, there has been a chronic shortage of trucks and drivers, and also shortage of train cars. Again so  the reduction in the oil price and the gasoline prices will help some of the inflationary pressures that we otherwise  would be experiencing in 2014 – I'm sorry 2015, of course.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving on to oil and mining, again 17 % organic growth, and this was already at the time when we saw oil prices  coming down. So, we're not hiding behind – or not hiding, but – we're looking at what will happen to the  marketplace because clearly the oil price will have some sort of an impact on the demand. But if you look at the  statistics of oil production in North America, they still have been steadily going up, even as the rig count has now  turned to the decline. So, clearly, the market has supported our growth, but there is now uncertainty regarding the  near future on that one.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving on to the non-recurring items, and you'll see that for the full year we actually have zero items impacting  EBITDA. So, those were offsetting the major items, the gain that we received from the sale of the formic acid  business, some other smaller acid disposals, offsetting by the CDC settlement, which was early in the year in the  second quarter, as well as some restructuring through the year.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Then few more things about CapEx. The annual CapEx is now fairly – has been very stable at €135 million. Y ou  see that for the quarter there was sort of a seasonal acceleration, partially seasonal in a way that tends to be the  reason that we spent more towards the end of the year, the second part of the Q4, CapEx being higher was that  now the project in Brazil, the sodium chloride plant is under construction. And that's shown on the chart there.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We are seeing an increase in CapEx in our paper segment in the future. So, you'll see that because of this project in  Brazil and because of the estimated €20 million to €30 million CapEx that we will invest to bring in the  production capacity from those AkzoNobel sites which we are not acquiring. However, we are carefully reviewing  the capacity needs in oil and gas because of the market uncertainty.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, if one excludes the sort of a chlorates Chemical Island that type of project, and if one excludes the CapEx  needed to bring the AkzoNobel integration CapEx, if you will, we have been about 6% of sales – CapEx to sales  ratio. We now see only a modest increase in that ratio in 2015.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 11February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: Thank you Olli. Good morning. Looking at the full year of 2015, I'm pleased how the outcome came. We hit our  own internal targets and were able to improve our operating EBITDA. But when I look at the year how we started,  we had really low visibility going into the year. We all know how the oil price was coming down. No one knew in  the beginning how fast, how low it's going to go and what impacts it has in various industries.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: So, we had some small organic growth in Pulp & Paper. Also, Municipal & Industrial grew or ganically. Naturally,  Oil & Mining industry came down with the drastic drop of oil price. But, all-in-all, we feel that the progress was  good in these volatile markets.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: Pulp bleaching chemicals demand remained high and you've been seeing how the market has announced new  investments debottlenecking projects in the Nordics, in Europe and also in South America. Our new plant in  Brazil for Klabin is practically complete. We are doing some test runs and waiting for the customer to complete  their project and do a startup. We need some inputs from them like steam to do the final testings of our plant. But,  we are on time and on schedule to start it up in the coming weeks and months.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: Oil & Mining, so a difficult year for obvious reasons. Our mining business continued steady even some growth  there especially in volumes. And our other verticals through the distributors, when we started this business, we  used only distributors, now we use them less and less, that business remained unchanged. But, o bviously, the oil  and gas was hurt. We got some benefit from raw materials. We got some benefit from U.S. dollar strengthening,  but still the top line came clearly down especially in North America.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: What we're now looking at is we entered Chemical Enhanced Oil Recovery. We could call it polymer enhanced oil  recovery, where polymers instead of injection of water only are put into the injection water and they aid out taking  oil from existing fields and give a higher yield from the oilfields than they could ge t otherwise. We entered this  business for the first time last summer, and we announced the current India deal. We are continuing that. We are  working with Chevron, we're working with other people to increase this. We've moved our focus from shale,  because there was no more growth in shale, [indiscernible] (9:31) reducing business in shale to EOR. It takes  awhile for us to get in there and get the revenue there. We're working hard on that to flatten our revenue out and  then get back on to the growth path, but this is a good opportunity for us in the future, and we're working hard on  that.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: Oil & Mining, we want to get back into growth track. It takes some time to get there that we get these EOR deals in  and get them yielding, and therefore from a smaller basis, we can drive double-digit growth over the cycle and  [indiscernible] (11:55) that Mining & Oil is a cyclical business. Oil & Mining, went back on track, has a good  opportunity to yield better than average profitability on a group level.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director
texts.text: As a summary, our vision is to be the first choice in chemistry for water intensive industries. We've chosen Pulp &  paper, Oil & Mining and Municipal & Industries and other process industries that are water intensive as our  primary target. We drive both organic and in-organic growth. We're trying to improve profitability by operating  improvement, leveraging growth and capturing synergies. And I believe on a bigger picture, we are on track to  deliver that growth also in the future.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So let's start with the growth. So in Q4, organic growth for Pulp & Paper was flat and this has to be put in  perspective that in Q4, we had a very strong quarter in Pulp & Paper. We grew actually 6% organically in Q4, 2014.  So against that quarter, the organic growth of flat was, I don't think it was too disappointing particularly as we had  couple of things. In – we had some longer maintenance breaks by our customers, also we did have some storm  damage in one of our sites in North America, which impacted our deliveries of sodium chloride to customers in  North America. This storm damage by now has been fixed.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So that's why we're very optimistic as we look at the market. So the new deals that Jari was highlighting and also  we will be getting the benefit of the new sodium chloride project in Brazil once that gets in line. We have said that  we expect the startup to take place in first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving onto the Oil & Mining, clearly the decline is driven by the North American shale. So the rest of the  business has actually performed quite steadily and we are growing from a small base, but we're growing in the new  applications of Canadian oil sands and the Chemical Enhanced Oil Recovery, but the North American shale is  impacting the business most dramatically.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: This is the dynamic of the shale business, and it cost us about €1 million credit loss. Now, €1 million credit los s in  perspective of Kemira is relatively minor and I wouldn't even mention if the numbers for EBITDA in Q4 for Oil &  Mining wouldn't have been so small.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: M&I, I mentioned that the 2% organic growth actually like I said almost 4%, about 4% volume growth. The  profitability was impacted however in Q4 and there are couple of things why that happened. It is not that the raw  material cycle would have changed, no. There was a – in North America, there was a titanium dioxide plant from  which we were getting large quantities of byproducts that we used to sell as coagulant to our customers. That  titanium dioxide plant was closed and we had to sort of reorganize our production streams, meaning that we had  to source new raw materials to manufacture coagulant. Also that means that we had to reorganize the  manufacturing plant. So we temporarily lost the optimal transport efficiency that we have there. So the transport  costs increased significantly in this part of the business in North A merica.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Oil & Mining, there were some assets that needed to be written down, and like Jari said, in M&I area, we've  decided to close one site. So, we have started procedures, employee consultation process in Europe to close down  one site. And so, what we can say is that, within in 2015, each segment has closed one site, or has started actions to  close one site. And this is part of what we have said that complexity reduction and manufacturing footprint  optimization that we need to go through.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We are investing into growth, so you'll see that the 25% increase in c apital expenditures and now this is CapEx  without M&A, is significant. The bulk of the increase is in Pulp & Paper, where clearly the investment in the  sodium chloride plant in Brazil really approximates the increase there.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, market environment, really, the way we're looking at the market is obviously, we're looking at a market where  GDP growth is only modest, volatility will continue. We right now look at input costs, i.e. raw material costs, will  remain at low level. The activity in shale not immediately picking up. There is a growth driven by regulatory  enforcements in water treatment and we see good opportunities to grow in Pulp & Paper and hence, have positive  long-term market growth expectations.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 8February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Markets continued extremely tough for Oil & Mining. If you remember, in February, we even saw a $27 Brent  price. And the market contracted during the first half of the year, especially in shale. In the summer, as reported  earlier, we saw it leveling off and then in the late months of the year, it started to increase and this increase came  from shale business. Our strategic programs are progressing well.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Gaining growth during the last part of the year was tough, but profitability continued to improve, gaining synergies,  starting up the Klabin co-existence site, the new bleaching chemical plant there in March in 2016. We were able  to ramp that up in six months and now, it's running well. We continuously look at our capacity utilization and we  were having higher capacity utilization and cost discipline and better customer focus.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining segment had a second difficult year in a row. And as I said earlier, we even bottomed in oil price at  $27 in February. Revenue continued to drop by lower volumes, but mainly also by prices, and operative EBITDA  declined. In shale market which was the biggest winner in this, mostly our other oil customers, our gas customers,  our mining and other verticals stayed on volumes the same, some price erosion. So, shale was the main impactor  here. Shale saw the bottom in the summer and now we're back on track.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Also, oil sands, we've been able to deliver. We haven't been in the market before. We entered in 2015 with small  volumes. We did really well last year and hope to improve also this year. Obviously, those volumes and revenues  were not enough to offset the drop in shale.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Here, you can see the split of Oil & Mining. 40% to oil and gas, 25% to mining, and through distributors, polymers,  to other industry is 35%. Shale plays in our oil and gas market the biggest role. And last year, for the full year,  was about €60 million in revenue. This is down about 65% from the peak in 2014.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Now, the market has recovered. I'm cautiously optimistic, but it's still a few months into it. So, we keep on  following, but things are at least going to the right direction. So, we continue to push oil sands. We continue to  push EOR mining other areas, and now obviously, shale once it's returning.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The revenue split for M&I is shown here. Really no major changes in that over the last year. We continue looking  at efficiencies, how do we run this machine faster and smarter. Part of the boosting also come in here and we  continue to work on Advanced Water Treatment offering – developing that and introducing it step by step to the  market.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: One event I would like to bring out for M&I. There was a fire last week here in Finland in Pori at Huntsman, and  Huntsman is a key raw material supplier for us. So, we've been out for a week and up and running. Now, our plant  is fine, but Huntsman plant will be out for an unknown time at the moment; they have announced that they will fix  it up.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We are now okay after mitigation plants for the next few months, so impacts are still quite minor, but it goes to  show that overnight, things can happen and affect us and then, we would have to talk to our insurance  companies. But so far, looking promising, but good to know these type of developments.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, CEO & Managing Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Cost control and efficiency high on our map and then, obviously driving the turnaround of the oil and gas  business. It continues to be in our focus. So all-in-all, I think in a challenging year, we fared out quite nicely.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Volume growth accelerated somewhat from Q4. And as Jari was talking about, the synergy capture, that is going  on well. We're now around 70% capture rate, and we have two larger CMA, Contract Manufacturing  Arrangements, that are now scheduled to end in Q2 and by end of Q2 – during Q2 and end of Q2. So, we sort of  expect to see a step-up in that capture rate in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then moving to Oil & Mining. So, clearly the much anticipated, and I think last couple of quarters, everybody had  been asking us whether the shale recoveries is getting visible, now it is getting visible. Volumes grew more than  10% year-on-year, still on average at the lower sales prices. So, that's why, the organic growth rate is only 5%.  But for the segment, the volumes were already at 10% or double-digit growth rate which is obviously positive.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: One more comment regarding the North America shale market. You may remember that during last year, we  closed one site – one small site permanently, and then we reduced operating shifts in some of our other plants.  Now, we're bringing back those plants to seven-day work-week. So, that sort of indicates that the market pickup is  starting to feel real. And one needs to also be flexible when the downturn is flexible, down quickly and when they  upturn is to be able to ramp up production relatively quickly.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: There's perhaps one exception that I'll point out. We have seen in the recent month or so a bit higher jump in the  propylene and ethylene prices in North America and some of the derivatives like acrylic acid, acrylonitrile  increased quite a bit in North America. And obviously, this is something that we are reacting to. We already  announced last month, in January, a across-the-board polymer increase in Americas of 5% to 15%. So, this is  again how the market reacts.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Moving on to CapEx. CapEx for the year 2013 [sic] [2016] (23:56), we are clearly in a middle of a high investment  phase, because projects obviously – at the early part of the year, we finished the chlorate plant in Ortigueira,  serving Klabin pulp mill in Brazil. This was the peak year for the in-sourcing or integration CapEx for the Akzo  acquisition. And then, I'll name the third one, Joutseno, where we add in a chlorate capacity.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 8February2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also started our biggest investment, a new chlorate bleaching line here in Finland that is now fully ramped up.  And unfortunately, there were some adverse headwinds during the year, but despite these dire circumstances like  a fire at Huntsman in the beginning of the year, we saw two hurricanes, severe winter conditions, lacking raw  materials. So not only pricing of raw materials, but [ph] availability (00:01:47) problems, and then strongly  weakening U.S. dollar during the second half of the year. Despite these, we were able to grow the business and  increase our profitability.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The Board of Directors proposes a dividend of €0.53 per share, and that offers a 4.6% yield on the end of the year  share price. If I look at a longer term development of four, five years, we've been able to grow in five years at 3%  average CAGR level €260 million, but if I look at comparison to 2014, when we had divested our formic acid  business, from there we've grown €350 million. While in 2015 and 2016, oil & gas was down significantly, and  now back to the 2014 levels. We have improved our operative EBITDA steadily and above our growth level, so  profitable growth. And our margins did come down, like I said, but second half was already more normal and  going to the right direction.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Moving on to Industry & Water from a full year point of view. Industry & Water was a merger of Municipal &  Industrial and Oil & Mining segments 1st of June last year. Obviously, any numbers that we show are back-stated.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Strong organic growth, 12% year-on-year. Volumes also grew 12%. Strong recovery, as I've said already in oil &  gas. Oil & gas, we're now back to the old levels after two missed years. Water treatment also grew quite nicely  and as a point of interest, our coagulants business grew 4% with volume and prices last year.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, looking longer-term perspective, we can see now good step-change in revenue even if we take out that  equipment delivery last year of €20 million and water treatment, on top of oil & gas, has grown well also. In water  treatment, we focus into EMEA, North America, and less to South America and rather small presence still in  APAC.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In oil & gas, still shale oil & gas in the fracking stage, oil sands, and CEOR. And as I mentioned, we started a €30  million investment for CEOR in Europe and hope to complete that mid-next year. We have continued profitable  growth and relative profitability improvement. That's what we want to continue to drive. We have ongoing actions,  which will contribute into our profitability next couple of years. Markets are looking rather positive at the moment.  We get this year the full benefit of the new chlorate capacity in the Nordics.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Okay. Thank you, Jari. As Jari was saying, and describing really the progress during the year, I will more focus on  what took place during Q4. So, actually, there are three key points that I'd like to – at least from my perspective  are the most important in the quarter are: first, it's the continued growth and it's volume growth and I'll give you a  bit more data on that one. But 11% at organic rate, very strong momentum, particularly in the bleaching chemicals  business, and obviously, very, very strong continued recovery, as Jari was talking about, continuing in oil & gas.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Second key point is improving profitability. We talk a lot about the raw material cost pressure and the sales prices.  And here, we're still sort of behind the curve, if you will, but we are improving in our position. And I'll come back to  that when we talk about the raw material prices as we typically do.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The second item that is worth singling out is that we've received emission trading compensation here in Finland,  and that was obviously something that was only in Q4. So if you take those two items out, for the quarter the  profitability, I would say, would have been about 14%, which is still going into the right direction and a good level,  but not quite there. We're not quite yet at the 15% mark yet.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: However, I'd like to highlight that full year basis, obviously, the accruals are really from one quarter to another and  the emission trading compensation really does not have a material impact. Maybe [ph] 0.1 (00:18:55) on the  profitability. So I would like to say that on a full year basis, it all evens out, but on the Q4 this was a bit positive in  terms of the results.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: For Industry & Water, so the opposite was true. First of all, we had a similar bonus accrual adjustment going to  the other direction in I&W. So we have to increase some of these incentive accruals, which obviously evens out  for the full year. The second topic is a bit more complicated and also a bit more difficult to estimate. All of our  polymer plants are owned by our Industry & Water segment. The polymer plants provide polymers that are sold  through both segments, both Pulp & Paper and I&W. Some of the challenges, headwinds, weather-related,  hurricane-related impacts, which are causing disruptions to our operations. Cost of those is borne proportionately  higher by Industry & Water, because it sort of falls into the plant ownership philosophy.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Similarly, the raw material price increases that take place during a quarter that doesn't go into the standard costs,  they are sort of variable costs or manufacturing variance costs, they fall solely on Industry & Water. So there is a  tendency that when this sort of abnormal costs happen and during the Q4, we had two things – or had several  things actually. We had the hurricane impact, was impacting the operations, and how smooth those operations  were running, because we did have some raw material supply issues.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And secondly, the increasing costs, and which particularly hit the polymer business. So the impact on a run rate  level or Q4 level is probably 1 point to 2 points. I can't say as precisely as I can say for the Pulp & Paper, probably  closer to 2% than 1% of that. And then, of course, there is the normal seasonality, seasonality in the business; Q1  and Q4, the winter periods being slower in the traditional water treatment business. Still a comment on the  growth, which was for the segment organic growth at 20% rate, which you can see on the left-hand lower. About  half of that was due to the equipment deliveries. So that would have been about 10% for the segment.

file: KEMIRA - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 8February2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then looking at Industry & Water, organic growth during 2018 was a good 9% driven by oil and gas mark quite a  bit, but water treatment capacity and demand was also growing but obviously for more modestly and growth came  mainly from prices up. Operative EBITDA grew 15% to $131 million, which is good when we take into account the  minus $6 million year-on-year impact from FX.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We continue to complete the polymer plant in Rotterdam for CEO market. And we made a strategic decision to  invest €60 million to additional emulsion polymer capacity in United States to our existing site. We believe in the  long-term demand for emulsion polymers, and that's why this two-year construction project and then we're up and  running.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Industry & Water, relevant chemical market seemed to grow 3% to 4%, highest growth from the oil and gas  customer base. Water treatment demand growing also through regulation, recycling needs of sludges, and more  challenging intake water and recycling needs of industrial water.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Shale and gas production especially in the United States continues to grow. During the last two years or three  years also, the oil majors have entered that area and are investing heavily into that area. Oil sand producers in  Canada are more regulated and they need to treat their tailings waters and tailings more diligently. They also  have a lot of legacy tailings ponds to be treated. And we have entered last year into that market and continue to  develop that business.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: End of 2014, before the oil price dip came, United States was pushing 9.5 million barrels of oil per day. In middle  of 2016 at the bottom it was producing 8.5 million barrels per day. Last week, EIA reported 11.9 million barrel  production. So a 35% increase in just two and a half years. So that growth has all practically come from sale and  goes to show how dynamic a shale market is.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Our product and service excellence is at focus to right size the service that we have and gain value for it but also  focus on our product portfolio and optimizing it in production and managing inventories. We have four large  product groups in our portfolio: bleaching chemicals, polymers, sizing products, and coagulant chemistries. These  flows to €2 billion of revenue our of our €2.6 billion revenue. And if you have looked at where we are investing and  will be investing, it's been bleaching, it's been polymers as discussed already, and the AKD is a sizing product. So  that's one area of investment.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Our business is inherently complex so we need to reduce complexity and work on our operational excellence. We  in this business rarely talk about tonnages, but we did deliver 5.3 million tons of chemistries to our customers last  year. That's more than some of the steel mills that there are in the world.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Second area we haven't talked about that much is our employee engagement, and we measure that step by step.  And here you can see compared to global reference data, we are also in good shape. Employee engagement  performance in employment and integrity are in a good, well, level. So, we are fit for fight going forward. And just  as a perspective here on our sort of five-year development in revenue, a growth of 3% on average on revenue  and 5% on operative EBITDA. So, steady development, and we have to remember that 2015 and 2016 were  challenging years from the oil price dip and how it impacted the world. And then the raw material cycle, still we've  been able to develop steadily.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And in some areas, actually, in the last couple of months, we have seen that the cost of raw materials has come  down, particularly those ones that are oil-based. I'm going into – largely to a polymer manufacturing, but at the  same time, I do want to remind that we see continuing raw material price pressure on many of the other areas.  So, the general basket is still on an inflationary side, if one will.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Pulp & Paper, 4% growth really driven by pricing and, again, supported by high demand in bleaching chemicals.  Jari was always talking about that the price increases have varied from pocket to pocket. And clearly, in Pulp &  Paper, the price increases had been slow to be implemented, particularly in the Process & Functional Chemicals.  And again, obviously, this is now the primary focus for the segment.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In oil and gas, growth continued at a very strong pace. The reported growth in oil and gas was 15%, but again  eliminating the oil and gas equipment delivery a year ago, this growth would have been over 30%. So it's worth  sort of noting that the oil and gas business in three years has about doubled from roughly 5% of revenue, and  groupwide it's now getting close to 10% of revenue.
