file: KER - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 16February2012 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, PPR SA
texts.text: Lastly, our Group will be able to meet its commitments in the area of sustainable development. This is a priority of  our strategic development. In that area we'll be publishing our consolidated environmental profit and loss or our  income statement, so we can really show what our ecological footprint is to better pare it down.

file: KER - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 15February2013 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, PPR SA
texts.text: Furthermore, we've clearly defined the group's objectives when it comes to sustainable development and we're  looking at a timeline of 2012-2016 here. Also, at the same time, we put together a group wide environmental  income statement. And this environmental income statement helps us target possibilities for improvement  throughout the group's supply chain.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, PPR SA
texts.text: Our targets for 2016 will reach for us to even further reduce our overall environmental footprint. Sustainable  development is a priority for our group. This is a policy which is now being headed by Marie-Claire Daveu. Marie- Claire came to the group in September of 2012 after a great deal of successful experience both in the private sector  and also as a top administration official. I'd also mention Marie-Claire, who's here this morning, is also going to be  in-charge of our institutional relations, our international relations. Welcome to Marie-Claire.  Thirdly, as we mentioned last year, we've really bolstered our human resources policy. Our executive committee  approved the strategy now of setting up a mobility platform, which will help us further strengthen our ability to  attract, develop, and retain highly talented people who we need to support the group's pace of growth. Fourthly, in  2012, we continued strengthening our various capacities for major corporate functions such as brand marketing  and property management.

file: KER - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 21February2014 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-14.pdf
KER - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 17February2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Duplaix
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the economic climate described by Jean-François, we favored throughout the year prudent approach in setting  out our priorities for capital allocation. Consequently, operating expenditure is down 14%. This trend reflects the  investment choices both in face with sector cycles, but also adapted to the varying maturity stages of our brands  and the development priorities identified for each of those brands.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Duplaix
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Conversely, Gucci suffered from deteriorating market climate in Asia-Pacific in the second half of the year, within  particular declining revenues in Hong Kong, Macau or even Singapore both in Q3 as well as Q4.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Duplaix
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And the group Pomellato, the trend is buoyed in particular by the success of new collections at Dodo. In  watchmaking, Sowind's activity remained under pressure in a market climate still marked by extreme caution of  wholesalers, more particularly at the end of the year.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, again, we take the long-term view, therefore, our group is fully aware of its responsibility to its employees and  to its environment. The business community must minimize the impact caused by business activities. But in  addition, imagine and come up with and actually roll out innovative solutions to create sustainable economic  development. Our group is very attached to sustainable development. This comes from the belief that in  responsibly doing business, you can create value.

file: KER - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 19February2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We've also further built our commitment in terms of social and environmental responsibility. You know this is an  essential component of our strategy and a key way that we stand out from others. I often say this in English term,  it's sustainable luxury is smart luxury.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lastly, at Kering, the way we act is as important as the objectives we pursue. That's why our fourth focus area,  sustainable development, underpins all our actions. On the social front, our priority rests on gender equality, as  well as the fight against violence against women. And we must deploy our creativity, bolstering our environmental  responsibility in order to minimize the impact through our activities in terms of supply, in te rms of production  and logistics.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our environmental P&L that in fact we share with others confers upon us recognized leadership in a world where  an increasing number of customers and, for that matter, an increased number of investors concerned about the  environmental fallout of their decisions. Our commitment contributes both to our performance as well as to our  image.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Five years ago, we set a series of social and environmental objectives that allowed us to grow and create a  momentum within the group. This year, we will present the review of these objectives. And above all, at the end of  the year, we'll set out our strategy and ambitions for the period 2016-2025.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lastly, we've continued and will continue to adapt and store networks such as our indirect distribution. We've  improved store further management and tools to supervise all of our stores. And today, with more reliable and  faster information, we're better placed to increase to further the productivity of our network. As you see, we're  ready to address all the challenges whatever the environment in which we operate.

file: KER - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 10February2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Kering SA
texts.text: The choice of the creators that we've made these last few years illustrate our approach as well as its audacity. We  prefer creators who's personalities, creative talent embody the codes of their maison, creators who can decipher  their environment and anticipate on the ongoing changes and to win over new generations by helping them  discover unknown territories that they cannot experience anywhere else.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Kering SA
texts.text: Last month, we announced our corporate and our societal, rather, and environmental objectives for 2025. Our will  to innovate means that today, we can be well ahead of our competitors, and we want to go even further and to  share with them, the progress that we make. And that framework, I'm working closely with all of our brands  managers in order to integrate sustainable development to all our activities, to mainstream it.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: However, it is difficult in today's world to predict what will happen over the year. And we can't ignore the  geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainties in this uncertain climate. Nonetheless, we are confident in our  ability to outperform the market and to draw on all the levers we can. We, of course, remain attentive to the  different changes in our environment, and we will be agile whenever the circumstances require.

file: KER - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 13February2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François Palus
texts.profession: Group Managing Director & Director, Kering SA
texts.text: Let's talk about products. Puma revamped its approach to design to develop new and different models, more  relevant, more desirable, and more commercial. The brand also created great store innovation, for instance, using  technology included in soles to improve return of energy or NETFIT, which is a system of adjustable laces. The  brand is also using some very strong well-known lines: Ignite, Fierce, Creeper, Tsugi, and Basket Heart, which  have really fueled sales in 2017, and are very sound commercial basis for the future.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Director, Kering SA
texts.text: And now, Luxury today, must express a genuine creative vision, and it's a sincerity that allows one to stand apart  in a world where everything is similar, the powerful brands of those whose creative universe is based on  imagination and on an original and consistent perspective on the world. I don't view Luxury that could not be  sustainable and attentive to society, the environment in which it is part of for the long term. This, for us, is a  source of inspiration and innovation. This engagement is an opportunity. It's also an opportunity for our group to  generate efficiencies.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Director, Kering SA
texts.text: The store renovation program affected in 2017 some 20 units and this year will affect some 30 stores; that's a  tenth of the total.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Director, Kering SA
texts.text: Our ambition is very much to be the most influential and most innovative luxury group worldwide in terms of  creative boldness, social and environmental responsibility, as well as economic performance. Our objectives of  value creation and our financial ambitions which guide and validate our operating strategy remain unchanged, of  course. Our priority continues to be organic growth for all of our brands with growth rates that we want to be  substantially above those of industry averages.

file: KER - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 12February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Director, Kering SA
texts.text: I'd like to use this opportunity to emphasize the contribution by the 35,000 employees of the Kering group  worldwide. We all share the self-same ambition. The ambition means we intend to make Kering the most  influential group worldwide in terms of creativity, environmental responsibility, social responsibility. Also in terms  of innovation and, of course, then in terms of financial performance. To that end, we share the same group  corporate culture.

texts.speaker: François-Henri Pinault
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Director, Kering SA
texts.text: Our group culture is alongside the culture of our Houses, they're mutually beneficial, and this culture is based on a  deeply held belief of ours, regardless of company size, any company has sort of reason for its existence that goes  beyond simple economics. And that's why over 10 years ago now, well over 10 years ago, we've placed great  emphasis on corporate social and environmental responsibility, they're at the very core of our strategy.

texts.speaker: Jean-François Palus
texts.profession: Group Managing Director, Kering SA
texts.text: The financial considerations are quite substantial and our ambitions are quite substantial as well. In the longer  run, unit logistics costs will go down significantly. Inventory levels will go down significantly. And lead times, B2B  and B2C lead times, will be cut.

texts.speaker: Jean-François Palus
texts.profession: Group Managing Director, Kering SA
texts.text: As you can see, we are very much able to adapt to our environment and our markets. We invest appropriately  with a long-term view. Therefore, we will be in a good position to move on possible opportunities for external  growth that would create value, if there are. Just as for our operational strategy, our financial targets remain  unchanged; growth in revenue above – outpacing the industry and improvement in operating margin.

texts.speaker: Mikko Helander
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer of Kesko Corporation and Chairman of the Group Management Board, Kesko Oyj
texts.text: Next, Car Trade. In the third quarter, Car Trade net sales decreased by 5.6% to €200 million due to the  implementation of the new WLTP emission testing. At €7.8 million Car Trade operating profit remained on a good  level despite the decrease in net sales. Market wise first time registrations of passenger cars and vans were at  least at last year's level in the third quarter, up by 5% year-to-date. This reflects that WLTP emissions testing that  is causing delays in car deliveries on the market. Measures to prevent rise in car tax are expected from the  Finnish government.

texts.speaker: Mikko Helander
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer of Kesko Corporation and Chairman of the Group Management Board, Kesko Oyj
texts.text: In the third quarter, the development of our Car Trade was in line with our expectations. Net sales and operating  profit were at a good level even though the implementation of the new WLTP emissions testing at the beginning of  September had a weakening impact on performance in the short term.

texts.speaker: Mikko Helander
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer of Kesko Corporation and Chairman of the Group Management Board, Kesko Oyj
texts.text: Launching new mobility services is a cornerstone of Car Trade strategy. The leasing services for B2B and B2C  customers launched this spring are off to a good start with order book at around 500 cars. There has been good  demand for car sharing services at the K-Supermarket and K-Rauta private store locations. We are also building a  nationwide charging network for electric cars with nearly 400 charging points at more than 70 charging stations by  the end of 2019. The first 10 charging stations will open during this autumn.

texts.speaker: Mikko Helander
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer of Kesko Corporation and Chairman of the Group Management Board, Kesko Oyj
texts.text: Also, our partner Volkswagen is having heavily into future mobility and new electric car models to customers. The  new All-Electric Audi e-tron was launched recently to the market and will be available at the start of next year. We  have already received 100 pre-orders for it. Other notable electric car models to enter the market include Porsche  Taycan and the Volkswagen I.D. series.

texts.speaker: Mikko Helander
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer of Kesko Corporation and Chairman of the Group Management Board, Kesko Oyj
texts.text: Lastly, a few comments on our outlook. In comparable terms, the net sales for continuing operations for the next  12 months are expected to exceed the level of the previous 12 months. The comparable operating profit for  continuing operations for the next 12-month period is expected to exceed the level of the preceding 12 months.  However, investments in the expansion of logistics operations and in information systems and digital services will  burden profitability during the period. Furthermore, in the Car Trade, profitability is burdened by the shift to WLTP  emissions testing which postpones car delivery at times.

texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Kesko Oyj
texts.text: Next, car trade. Due to implementation of WLTP emissions testing and change in car tax, net sales declined by  12.9% to €190 million in fourth quarter and by 1.8% to €893 million in 2018. texts.speaker: Mikko Helander
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Kesko Oyj
texts.text: A few comments on the car trade market. First, registrations of passenger cars and vans were up by 1.3% in 2018  and down by 12.1% in the fourth quarter. The Porshce business had a record year, with registrations up by  65.7%. Our new mobility services were off to a good start. Also, car trade was incorporated more tightly under the  K brand with its name changed to K-Auto and K Caara.

texts.speaker: Mikko Helander
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Kesko Oyj
texts.text: The objective of our corporate responsibility work is to enable a sustainable lifestyle for our current and future  generations of customers in the areas of food, mobility and living. We were pleased that Kesko was recently again  included on the Global 100 list as the most sustainable trading sector companies in the world. We will move to the  new K-Kampus this spring. This is a significant step toward – forward in implementing our strategy as it brings all  divisions and functions together in one location.

file: KGFL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 16September2010 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Sep-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian Cheshire, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Morning. My name is Ian Cheshire. Welcome to Kingfisher’s Interim
texts.text: In terms of Eastern Europe, worth mentioning that Poland had a extremely difficult first half, where  we had serious massive snow and when it then, surprisingly enough, melted we had floods. So we  had a pretty biblical first half. And in addition to that, we had the plane crash and the disruption to  the economy, which was quite more pronounced particularly since we were there at the time, than  you might have thought at a distance.

texts.speaker: Ian Cheshire, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Morning. My name is Ian Cheshire. Welcome to Kingfisher’s Interim
texts.text: So, we’ve definitely seen a difficult first half in Poland, but we’re looking towards the second half  hopefully without the same level of one-off weather incidents and others to really get us a better  picture. And I think the longer-term picture in Poland remains extremely positive. GDP keeps  growing. The question is just where are we going with the consumer spending. We remain on the  expansion track in Poland and we’re going to be growing particularly in the second half of this year.  We’ve got a strong pipeline in Poland. And we also now believe that we’ve got, and I’ll come back  to it later, but in the order of 100 store potential in Poland which we can continue to develop.

texts.speaker: Ian Cheshire, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Morning. My name is Ian Cheshire. Welcome to Kingfisher’s Interim
texts.text: And then a new innovation landing at the moment an exclusive deal with JCB steel range power  tools, which we’ll be landing shortly, which again we’ve developed in KSO through our sourcing  offices, sourced them, put them together, together with the guys at JCB. And we’ll be launching that  in the second half. So we think there is a lot happening there and I think the encouraging bit is that  some of these programs that we were celebrating months ago have landed faster and with more  encouraging signs than we originally thought. We still think this is still early days, so great progress,  but more to come.

texts.speaker: Ian Cheshire, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Morning. My name is Ian Cheshire. Welcome to Kingfisher’s Interim
texts.text: So we are now moving to a system, which fundamentally redirects this. We’re creating an all-south  DC and putting much more of the range in each one. So you’ve got shorter travel times to the  stores, much more direct, we are closing three of the RCCs. We still have the smaller minimum  order quantity, as you have to have some regional consolidation. But we think also fundamentally  this moves from a storage model to a cross-stock model much more and so both the total time from  dispatch to store will go down but the total flow time through the system should go down.

texts.speaker: Ian Cheshire, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Morning. My name is Ian Cheshire. Welcome to Kingfisher’s Interim
texts.text: So, what we should end up with is lower stocks, quicker response times, which will drive better  availability, and lower distribution cost and lower emissions. And that is not a sort of easy push- button there and everything will come. And Swindon will take some time to come on track over the  next 18 months. But we do believe what this will give us is a fundamentally much more fit for  purpose supply chain, and interestingly, it also opens up some longer-term opportunities for how  we might coordinate on a Pan-European level on imports, which the supply chain directors around  the group are beginning to work on.

texts.speaker: Ian Cheshire, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Morning. My name is Ian Cheshire. Welcome to Kingfisher’s Interim
texts.text: On the eco agenda, we’ve added to the previously recycled plastic bottles, we’ve got sheep’s wool,  natural paints and the slightly weird one, which is ex-clothes cut up to make carpet underlay. But  it’s a great, great product, and a very efficient way of recycling old clothes.

texts.speaker: Ian Cheshire, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Morning. My name is Ian Cheshire. Welcome to Kingfisher’s Interim
texts.text: On direct sourcing, a couple of areas where we’ve seen profile, our new composite decking, which  is a key example of how direct sourcing can take a price point from something which is slightly non- mass market to make it much more accessible. So for most people, composite decking is a lot  more preferable to trying to oil your existing wood decking every year. It’s actually easier in many  ways to work, but traditionally it’s always been too expensive, and by bringing down the costs,  we’ve seen major growth in the product category.

texts.speaker: Ian Cheshire, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Morning. My name is Ian Cheshire. Welcome to Kingfisher’s Interim
texts.text: So one of the points about direct sourcing is it’s not just a “we’ll tuck away some margin.” It allows  us to change price points, it allows us to change volumes, and also it gives us more exclusive  products. And the garage storage system there is a good example of something where we’ve been  looking to develop a whole new integrated range, just beginning to come through, and it’s  something that we’ll see actually in the other up case, and then sell our land through more  traditional, basic e-auction category where you can achieve pretty significant savings, again by  going through KSO.

file: KGFL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 15September2011 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Sep-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In the related area of Screwfix, we've announced today that we're accelerating the expansion of Screwfix. It's really  because we've been testing and trialing over the first six months a slightly smaller footprint model. So a 4,000  square foot instead of 7,000, 8,000 square foot footprint.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So easier – how do we make it easier for our customers? We know that they would spend more in home  improvement if we can make it easier when we have innovative product that makes it easier. There's no doubt that  the upsize in the market is there.  Can we make it more affordable? So sourcing is critical there. How do we really exploit multi-channel? And  increasingly this sort of phrase, not so much multi-channel as omni-channel, how do we be available to our  customers whichever way they want to shop? And how do we provide advice? Because it's clear that actually  people would like to do more but they don't know how. So, the DIY classes and we've had over 20,000 people  through in the U.K. How do we then do that online through YouTube channels? All sorts of ideas about that. And  de-mystifying eco. There's a huge opportunity coming in the eco refurb market. But it's very complicated for  consumers to figure it out. So what can we do to do it?

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Kingfisher U.K. and Ireland sales were down 1% in a difficult market. Sales of B&Q were down 2% in total and  like-for-like. So the seasonal products were impacted as we'd previously announced by poor weather patterns in  quarter two and stock clearance activity by the administration focus. Sales of indoor products were down 1%,  reflecting a weaker consumer environment.

texts.speaker: Euan A. Sutherland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Kingfisher United Kingdom, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Now, I've got one example for you today, which I'm going to give out actually, which is an example – I'd like it  back as well, if that's all right. It's not that attractive. It's not that expensive, but this is printed bamboo. The point  of this product is – and bamboo flooring is not that new, but this is. This is three times harder than oak. It's half  the price and it grows 20 times faster. 100% eco-sustainable. This is very new and very different. The point of this  is we can scour the world, use our in-house innovation team, put it through the brands, and this brings real  sustainable difference to our market. The point of giving it out is not to hit people in the front row; it's to feel the  quality of this product. If you can imagine bamboo versus oak, it's a very different source. The end result is very  different.

texts.speaker: Euan A. Sutherland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Kingfisher United Kingdom, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And packaging efficiencies. I'm just going to show you one example which again sounds very simple, but has saved  us about £7 million in France and £7 million in the U.K. When you're looking to align a range such as light bulbs,  this is in the new Diall brand that we've got, we have different merchandising solutions driven by history across  every single operating company in our overall market.

texts.speaker: Euan A. Sutherland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Kingfisher United Kingdom, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Now, in the U.K. for light bulbs, we use shell so it sits like that. In Casto in France, it hangs on a peg tooth like  that. If you're trying to get one packaging, actually it seems very simple now, how do you get it? Well, actually you  put a hook on the box. That saved us £7 million in one go and one of the board meetings it's really high strategic  stuff we're doing here. The point of this is it's in the detail. Absolutely in the detail of what we do product by  product that will eek out the results that we need.

texts.speaker: Euan A. Sutherland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Kingfisher United Kingdom, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: The difference for our vendors is that a vendor who, for example, supplies light bulbs would supply a brief to a  Casto in France, a B&Q U.K., a Casto Poland, a Brico France, all slightly differently. They now source and supply  for the brands. So the brand – they source for the Diall brand, which has huge efficiencies in allowing us to have a  very different conversation with our big vendors.

texts.speaker: Euan A. Sutherland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Kingfisher United Kingdom, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: So we're starting to work and, I guess, the easiest way to look at that is to go into store and see what's happening.  This is the best brand. It's heaters, it's happening in the U.K., Poland and France. Exactly the same packaging,  exactly the same product, starting to get into the same way of merchandising and leverage some of the benefits  we've got.

file: KGFL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 12September2012 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Sep-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Another material swing that we hit in the real trading terms was the weather impact. Retailers bleating about the  weather as a sort of long sort of practiced piece. But this was once-in-a-hundred-year weather, and we saw quite  clearly in our trading patterns a major shortfall in seasonal, a major shortfall in traffic as a result from not having  seasonal; and as a result, having to promote very hard and clear very hard, which meant that there was at least  £30 million taken off the bottom line, courtesy of that weather impact. And that was, as Kevin will come and talk  about, both the U.K. primarily, but also quite clearly visible in France in the North compared to the South.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Moving on to talk a bit about the weather, and again, it's not something we'd like to talk a lot about. But this half,  the results have been significantly impacted by the record adverse weather across the U.K. and France,  particularly Northern France. April to June was the wettest U.K. in history. I probably don't have to tell you that.  No one in the business can frankly recall having wet and rain on every bank holiday right through the whole  season. It was unusual. And in France, April and June and the first half of July were the wettest for many years.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: This had a knock-on effect on footfall and sales of our season and outdoor product ranges in both the U.K. and  France. In the U.K., sales of these ranges were down about 11% in B&Q, with footfall down about 20% in the wet  weeks. That's over 1 million less customers per week in our stores. In France, Castorama seasonal sales were down  2.3%, and the impact on Brico Dépôt's like-for-likes was around 1%. We saw a clear split between the performance  in Northern France and Southern France in those wet weeks, as we had particularly in the Northern France the  very wet weather.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Kingfisher's U.K. and Ireland sales were down 1.7% in a difficult market; down 5% on a like-for-like basis. Sales at  B&Q were down 3% and 6% on a like-for-like basis; the ex-Focus stores contributing 3% to total sales. The adverse  weather significantly impacted outdoor and seasonal product sales. Sales of building products were also affected  by the weather, although indoor decorative products did benefit.  Sales in the first half were also impacted by the planned change in trading strategy for kitchens and bathrooms,  with the move to Every Day Low Prices, reducing orders taken in quarter four last year, and therefore, reported  sales in the first half of this year. And Ian will talk more about that change in a few minutes. Despite all this, we  were pleased that B&Q grew its share in the period outperforming the market. Screwfix, which targets  professional tradesman, grew by 8.9%. This strong performance was supported by a continued rollout of new  outlets, range improvements and the success of click, pay & collect, and the recent introduction of mobile click,  pay & collect.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And in the period, Spain incurred a £1 million pre-opening cost as it recommenced its store opening program.  Russian profits were up some £4 million in the half and Hornbach results were down in the first half by £3  million, impacted by a number of factors, including increased spending on energy-saving initiatives and an  impairment of an investment in Eastern Europe. All the businesses in our other international area, with the  exception of China, were profitable in the first half.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Moving on to B&Q, B&Q experienced a particularly tough first half. As discussed, the adverse weather impacted  sales and stock clearance, with a financial impact of over £25 million. In the weeks impacted by the weather, we  saw customer numbers drop by 20% or over 1 million, and it's hard to compensate for this impact. We started the  year with a 40 million lower order balance following our planned move to Every Day Low Prices on kitchens and  bathrooms.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: YouTube channel, there's over 100 videos on the YouTube channel, increasingly driving traffic. We're actively  testing new formats; I'll come to talk a bit about the new format in France. And preparing for the Green Deal. And  again, I'll come onto that in a second. And Screwfix pay & collect. The other three ones that don't have a sort of  tick next to them, it's always a dangerous thing to put up a milestone and not have a tick next to it, but we are six  months in. So we're working on these things and we'll report later.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: So that's on easier. The other aspect, we talked briefly Green Deal, will start in October. We'll obviously see a slow  B&Q and leveraging the NES acquisition, which gives us access to nearly 3,000 home energy advisors. And we've  created, under Steve, a very interesting strategic alliance.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Rather having to spend vast amounts of money, we put together a series of component manufacturers, who can  actually then create one integrated home energy efficiency solution. Because actually it's the integration of the  answers, be they control valves, systems or renewables or new boilers, it's putting it together that counts. And  we're tied up with a series of – well, particularly one leading installation company. So by creating a virtual  network, we think we can do a one-stop shop concierge service for the Green Deal. We'll see that start to be  effective a little later this year.

texts.speaker: Euan A. Sutherland
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: The position, as we sit now, is we still have three DCs, but we have a north-south split. So, we now have access to  all the ports in the U.K. to bring in our direct sourced product, with the introduction of Swindon DC. We have  taken our RCCs down from seven to five, and that means that 55% is routed direct to store. Benefits in that, clearly  it's more flexible for our direct sourcing platform to come in. It's quicker to store; between 24 hours and 48 hours  has been taken out of the supply chain once it lands into the U.K.  There's better availability. The top selling lines have moved forward from 99.3% availability in B&Q up to 99.7%.  And our distribution costs down by 10 basis points over the last couple of years; and it's less CO2 as well, 8.5%  CO2 savings so far this year on top of 3.5% last year. So, lots of work happening. We are at an early stage in the  steps three and four, which are the big economic engine of growth. And I think we've got a little bit of lag as we see  some of those benefits coming through. But the early input indications are strong.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: You'll see there, at this point, we've got 35 open. We're making good progress. Actually in the U.K., we've upped  the Screwfix target from 50 to 60 openings, which again reflects the success that's happened. We're probably  seeing some slight slippage in some of the other countries like Russia, where some of the permit issues make it  very difficult to land on a sixpence or on a one month. But the basic direction is fine. So the space growth that  we've announced is essentially more or less the same pattern.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: What's become clear is the Chinese customer just doesn't do that. They do whole apartment; move out for four  months; rip everything out down to the wiring and the cabling; come – do everything in one massive piece; and  they wouldn't even fix a little bit of wallpaper. So Kevin was talking to the team in China recently. A little tear in  wallpaper, no, we'll wait for the sort of seven-year refurb. And at the end of it, wait a month for the paint to dry, to  stop the danger of potentially killing yourself with paint fumes.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Moving onto the last two elements of Creating the Leader, developing leaders and sustainability; this is normally  where I lose the analysts in the audience. But just sort of keep your interest, this is actually quite important,  particularly because we are trying to connect the business together. And that really is about creating the links  amongst the people. So actually enhancing our talent and then creating a truly sustainable business that will be  around in 40 years and that can exploit new opportunities of the last two points.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And what we've – so we do is launch the Kingfisher Academy under that and then launch our new sustainability  strategy Net Positive. Quick updates on that; we've actually created essentially a virtual academy, where the top  particularly focused on making sure everyone understands Kingfisher economic profit, i.e. how much capital do  we have to put in to generate this return and how do we think about our business differently on a returns basis.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And then on Net Positive, apart from winning a gratifying number of awards, which is always nice to get some  recognition, we'll be announcing on the 15 of October the more detailed milestones and OpCo plans about Net  Positive and launching that really on sort its sort of own five years of journey. But I think the reaction we've had  very clearly, from an ambition to not just be less bad, but think about how we can be genuinely positive and create  competitive advantage and sustainable business advantage by doing this has been really, really encouraging. And I  think the opportunities for us here to, again, be a leader and drive both our sector and our market are pretty  major.

file: KGFL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 11September2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Sep-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: So we saw sort of Q1 outdoor product down 10% and then up again in Q2 by 9%. Profit as a result of the fixed cost  down heavily in what is a small quarter and then bouncing back up. And it was good to see the recovery in Q2 as  we did finally get a heat wave in July. And I think certainly in Europe, we had the first proper summer, I'd say, for  three years and certainly July was the best since 2006. So it is important to underscore the weather can be good  news, and it was good news in Q2. But it really effectively offset of the impact in Q1.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Let me just go back again, sorry. B&Q like-for-like sales were down 1.7%. The sales results reflected the generally  weak consumer backdrop and the impact of that extremely bad weather in quarter one. Sales of outdoor products  fluctuated with the weather across the period, but indoor products were still down 3% right across the half-year.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Weather and foreign exchange were the key swing factors. Year-on-year foreign exchange gains came largely in  quarter two, and much better weather in quarter two drove up the seasonal categories. Although, as you can see,  other categories were still actually down year-on-year reflecting continued weak market condition.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: As we've previously commented on the high operational gearing in our business model, in this half year you can  see the extent of that gearing as we traded in very different conditions in quarter one and quarter two. Quarter one  was badly hit by that extremely cold weather, particularly in March when it disrupted one of our peak trading  times over Easter. And then when the weather improved, sales rebounded and the impact dropped to the bottom  line and therefore the retail margins recovered significantly.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: So in summary, trading conditions remain quite challenging. Whilst the weather driven upturn in quarter two was  very welcome, the overall position is still subject to volatility. So we will continue with the self-help measures that  we're confident of delivering and which will help to offset headwinds. This will allow us to take advantage of our  operational gearing when the market improves. And in the meantime, we continue to invest the growth while  focusing on cash management. Thank you.  Ian M. Cheshire  Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc  Thanks Karen. And if we switch to the strategic review, the mission remains the same. The purpose for the group  remains helping customers create better homes and having better lives as a result. And we are continuing to drive  the eight points on Creating the Leader, and we're going to use that just again as a cycle to quickly update you on  some of those.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: We've developed a whole range of energy efficiency products based around the new boiler range which has  traditionally not been an area B&Q has been that effective in. And some might say that it has something to do with  the cartel in the boiler market. I can possibly comment, but it's very nice to have affordable warmth as a scheme  that we can use to develop sales in the boiler market in the UK.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And we've been working with a series of manufacturers and Loughborough University to develop a whole brand of  integrated energy efficiency which will feed in to the eco refurb initiatives such as Green Deal, FIT, RHI and  others. And we are very – see this as a major opportunity in the UK, and longer term, an opportunity around  Europe as governments try and encourage the refurbishment of existing housing stocks. So we think that that's got  off to a good start and we'll be rolling out across B&Q and Screwfix.

texts.speaker: Guy Colleau
texts.profession: CEO Group Sourcing & Offer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Our knowledge in product development, innovation and design have now a starting impact on product  differentiation, the launch of our new Blooma charcoal called barbecue range in Casto France and B&Q UK this  spring is a good example, which will be followed up next year with a gas one with very encouraging results.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: The next thing is on Expand. Sounds a bit contrary to talk about reduction because it's actually sort of – it's not  expanding. The right size, right place program, I think, has proved a very sort of strong success so far. We've only  however got one store which is for real trading which is Belvedere with Asda. It's already generating the footfall we  hoped for. We're seeing an improvement of sales density at 75%. I think that needs to run for a little while. I think  it'd probably be more than that once we settle down.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: So finally, it's again to how we run the business as one team. A couple of points to mention there in terms of  people and net positive. We're extremely pleased to have recruited Richard Gilles who's really probably the  practical founder of Plan A for M&S who's going to join as Group Sustainability, to really deliver net positive as  opposed to framework. And the Good Woods piece, we are developing a working woodlands program for the UK  which has already got 3,000 hectares of woodland management signed up to really allow us to take out the wood  product from it, encourage jobs in local economy and biodiversity in those woods. And we think that will be a  great showcase for how you can have a net positive impact. We've also seen a major shift in the number of people  we're moving around the group, not just the ones you see here on the stage but actually a significant push. And the  Kingfisher One Academy where we are increasingly developing a cadre of international leaders is definitely  making progress. So I think we are continuing to land things against the framework that we already announced.

file: KGFL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 10September2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Sep-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Daniel M. Bernard
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman
texts.text: He also leaves a strong sustainability legacy in net positive and an impressive management team throughout the  businesses. And moreover, I would like to say that it has been a great pleasure for me to work with Ian. And on  behalf of the board and my colleagues and all the colleagues of the group, I want to thank him for his successful  leadership. It has been a great phase in the life of Kingfisher. Bravo, Ian.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Director, CEO-Koctas Brands & B&Q
texts.text: And the property work that we're going to do is, there's two phases to it. Phase 1 is what we've called Right Space  Right Place, which we've talked to you about before. And Phase 2 is working through catchment by catchment. So  let me just touch on each of those for a minute.

texts.speaker: Kevin O'Byrne
texts.profession: Director, CEO-Koctas Brands & B&Q
texts.text: Phase 1, Right Space Right Place, this has been slower than we would have liked. But when we've been able to do  it, as we did in Belvedere, it's working. Belvedere was more straightforward because it was a freehold property.  We've had two planning consents agreed and two planning consents have been declined. Moving to big box food  retailing has become a bit trickier from a planning point of view. Overall, we're now expecting eight of the 18  stores, about 2% of space, to be agreed, and that's just over 500,000 square feet of space.

file: KGFL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 15September2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Sep-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thanks very much, Véro. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. I do hope you're feeling a little  bit warmer in this room than I am. Apparently Steve Willett turned it down, turned down the temperature.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Leading offer, it's about innovation, it's about quality, but it's about sustainability as well, and this is very much  embedded in that. What we want as well is we want to deliver the same proposition across our geographies, and  we will be starting that as well. We want to be an omnichannel company, and we want to be leading in that space,  and we will, as we do that, we'll be focusing on two formats in order to execute them very, very well.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Then if you look at those 4,000 (sic) [400,000] (22:41) SKUs, almost half of those SKUs are not listed today, are  not ranged SKUs, and half of it are already SKUs. The non-listed SKUs will be – remember, and I won't do a big  deep dive on that, but just to update you on the cut the tail initiative. The cut the tail initiative will concern this  half of the SKU which are not listing today. Just as a reminder, those 193,000 SKUs are representing 2% of the  sales. So it's not [indiscernible] (23:08) number of sales, but it's creating a lot of pollution within the organization;  pollution in the system, pollution for our colleagues on the shop floor and at the end, pollution for the customer as  well, because those products are around.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: What we can do as well if we work as one and we will be leading in trends, LED for instance. We've been looking at  because we've done that on certain category. We've been seeing that on LED for instance, some operating  company are far more developed than others. We will really upgrade everybody to the highest level than we can.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, two example, batteries. We had more than 300 batteries across the different operating companies, and we had  up to 13 ranges in certain operating company. Where we have been to is we will have 36 SKUs for the common  range, for the unified range, and we will have up to max four level of ranges within our format.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Lightbulbs, another example, we had almost 3,000 SKUs in lightbulbs and we had 63 suppliers. Where we are  moving to is we will have less than 500 SKUs, including local SKUs because we will have some local SKUs, and we  are in negotiation with 20 suppliers, and we are targeting today six suppliers. Those products will be available in  store in 2016, that's the important thing. The important thing is the pace at which we've been doing that and the  reality of it. It is real. It will be there in store for the customer next year.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, to start off with B&Q in UK and Ireland; we said in March that we were going to address the issue of over- space in the UK. We've been quite public about the fact that if we'd started with a blank sheet of paper, then we  would probably have 15% to 20% fewer B&Q stores in the UK. And the plans that we've got are to reduce the space  by 60% over two years. And we said that we would close 30 – around about 30 stores this year and the following  30 stores next year.

file: KGFL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 20September2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Sep-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: This is slightly weaker than the Banque de France home improvement sales data, which reported a broadly flat  position. There were some unusual factors during the first half. There was widespread industrial action in France,  exceptionally wet weather and those created a more challenging external environment in the second quarter that  we'd seen in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Arja Taaveniku
texts.profession: Chief Offer & Supply Chain Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: They have started to land – ranges have started to land in the stores, but it is early days still because the  launches are heavily H2-weighted. Likely, the forecast that I see today is likely that we will end up on somewhere  between 3% and 4% by the year-end on the unified offers. It's H2-weighted because I think you remember that we  started these projects in May last year. I have worked with product development for many, many years, and the  timelines have been very short. So, this – why it's H2-weighted is because we have done a lot delisting of  suppliers, and we have also been managing the clearing of old stock.

texts.speaker: Arja Taaveniku
texts.profession: Chief Offer & Supply Chain Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: This plan will deliver significant customer benefits, which is the main thing with our plan. This is not a cost price  reduction exercise entirely. The main thing is that it would deliver much better ranges for our customers. These  photos show light bulbs out in the stores, the new unified light bulbs, and these photos are from our best practice  – the four Big Box best practice. And Véro will come back and talk a bit more about those best practice stores  later.

texts.speaker: Arja Taaveniku
texts.profession: Chief Offer & Supply Chain Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Well, we have the sales so far, it's not season for bulbs yet. I got the question, are bulbs really seasonal, and I  understand that some of you are coming home so late every evening, so you always put on the lights in your  homes. But as a matter of fact, it is seasonal because there are parts of the year when we are selling more bulbs  and it's in the darker parts of the year.

texts.speaker: Arja Taaveniku
texts.profession: Chief Offer & Supply Chain Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: It's newer products. And as an example, two-thirds of these bulbs will now be LED and sold under our own brand,  Diall, where we have really secured a good quality at the very low price. And I could recommend that you go to a  B&Q stores and look for yourself because it's out in the stores. You would see it there.

texts.speaker: Arja Taaveniku
texts.profession: Chief Offer & Supply Chain Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: When doing this unification, we have been able to do this unification, but still continuing to address the local  needs because there are some. And as an example, in Poland and Romania and I would say Russia as well,  there's still a need of having light-colored sinks, meaning [ph] best sinks (29:28) things. We can add that into the  unified range. We're not removing that.

texts.speaker: Arja Taaveniku
texts.profession: Chief Offer & Supply Chain Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: In the UK, you probably know about the Belfast sinks. We are still having that in the range, so we're adding that  as a local need. We have also been able to add new good functions to markets that didn't have it. Example is  scratch-resistant, linen finish sinks into the UK. We didn't use to have it here and we've been able to add that.  Those local ranges, they are still benefiting from the cost price reductions that we're achieving on the unified  ranges. In many of them, we can use the same supplier base. The Belfast sink is a porcelain sink and we are  using the same supplier base as for the unified ranges.

texts.speaker: Arja Taaveniku
texts.profession: Chief Offer & Supply Chain Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Having that said, we do know that we have big challenges ahead. This is not a straightforward easy journey we  are into. We are aware of the challenges. In that Wave 1 which of course is covering, we'd almost say a small  part, it's now 3% to 4% of the COGs, if not a lot, even if we were to own 7%. But we have learned it has been  great experience because we know that the benefits are coming through. But we have also had that as a learning  case on things where we have to become better. And we are aware of the challenges in terms of clearing of old  ranges, the cost of remerchandising in our stores. And we can also foresee new and different demand from our  existing supply chain networks. And Véro briefly mentioned this in her startup that this year, we are touching  roughly 3% of the store space. Next year, we will be touching 22% of the store space. So we have big genesis  next year. However, having that said, it's worth it, it's really worth it.

texts.speaker: Arja Taaveniku
texts.profession: Chief Offer & Supply Chain Officer, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Let me take you through some of the ranges that we are working on to bridge from this 4% to 20%. The first one  being stick timber. Stick timber, it stands for one-third of the total company wide timber sales, and we are big in  timber in Kingfisher. It has four main product types, and this is a category that used to be seen as very difficult to  unify. People were saying that that's impossible to unify. Well, as a matter of fact, we have discovered now in that  process of really looking on customer needs and really analyzing the business, out of those four product types,  we can do unification on three of them. Three of four can be unified because the customer needs are very similar  in terms of stick timber.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: If we start with this space rationalization program, well, it's well advanced. Just as a reminder, 15% of space  equated to 65 stores to be closed. And that program is now 80% complete. We've got 52 stores closed to-date.  We did 30 last year, and they were mostly backend loaded. And we've done 22 closures in the first half of this  year. That leaves us 13 stores to close in the remainder of the year.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: In the full year, our original guidance was £190 million, and that's come down quite significantly, so £100 million,  but that's what I've just described. So the P&L transformation costs £60 million rather than £70 million, the  exceptional charge around £10 million rather than £50 million, and the CapEx, which Steve has explained, thank  you, around £30 million rather than £70 million. We're not going to change our overall guidance. Our £800 million  of total transformation cost is still pretty much what we think the total cost of achieving a £500 million sustainable  uplift in EBIT will be.

texts.text: So, we deliver against our plan. I'm not going to look – to take all those milestones. You know them, they are  written on this slide. But we've already achieved 42% COGS. Being really honest, more worth believing [ph] two  years and a half ago (00:05:16) that we would do this, there were few – a lot of skepticism in the room, we've  almost rolled out our unified IT platform in less than three years across nine geographies. I don't know many  companies that have done that without any [indiscernible] (00:05:37). Someone told me [indiscernible] (00:05:38)  profit warning.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher plc
texts.text: And the fourth idea I would like to share with you today is that we are taking any decision required to deliver this  plan and deliver a long-term sustainable growth for this business. It's not or. It's [ph] and. It has to be and  (00:19:01). This is our commitment as an executive team with the support of the board. We are making this  business more efficient as we go and as the environment [indiscernible] (00:19:10).

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher plc
texts.text: This is a positive move. This is just a manifestation that we are taking the right decision as we move. Arja came in  to build OSC. She has done it. OSC is a machine that is working. She came to deliver those COGS number that  I've been talking all along in this morning, 42%. It is done.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher plc
texts.text: And what we are going to look as well is to try to bring more efficiency. We are delivering against our efficiency  plan. We are going to look at with the teams, so that can we do more. Why? Because we are committed to deliver  this plan, because we are going to look at everything we can do to deliver.

file: KGFL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 22March2012 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And we've ended up with stronger foundations in terms of our balance sheet. We've got rid of £1.5 billion of debt.  We've actually carried on investing in our growth expansion in CapEx, so this hasn't been about starving the  business of cash. And we've developed both sourcing operations and very highly engaged colleagues around the  business. So the foundations for the next phase are there. And I'm also really pleased that that's been done in a  highly responsible and sustainable way. So we're selling a lot more eco products to our consumers, and our own  operations have significantly cut store waste and CO2 emissions. So this isn't a quick dash for growth. It isn't  something that has been sacrificed, one element that has been sacrificed in order just to hit an artificial set of  numbers.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The final aspect about why we're stronger today because of Delivering Value is about our sustainability agenda.  We made the operations more sustainable in carbon emissions. We also cut store waste to landfill. And for the last  two years, we've been one of a handful of companies in the U.K. awarded the Platinum Plus standard, and we're  very proud of that achievement. We've also done it to customers there, and we've let customers live in a much  more sustainable way by making the products more useful.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Essentially, we've broadly doubled as now 13% of our sales are an eco-certified product. So it's over £1.4 billion.  And if I had to pick sort of one other area where I think we have led the industry and continue to want to lead the  industry is around timber. We often used to say that Kingfisher as a whole uses a forest the size of Switzerland  every year for its timber requirement. We are a major global user. We have to do that sustainably.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We're up to over 80% around the group, but the two things I pick out, B&Q in the U.K. has hit 100%, so it has  brought us sustainable timber. The first retail had to do it and it isn't easy. So I would salute the B&Q team for  that.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And then I'm really pleased to see the other day from Philippe, the Castorama and Brico being rated in their own  category as the best in terms of sustainable timber retailers by WWF. And this is a team that we will come back to.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And finally, sustainability, and I'll come back to this in a minute. We have an ambition to be more than just  sustainable. We would like to be one of the first businesses to try and challenge itself to become net positive. So  not just simply neutral, but actually positively regenerating. And I'll explain that in a minute.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: In the UK, if you take a very narrow definition of the shared market, we're already over 60% of that market. So, we  have to actually grow this market if we're going to be a leader. So, we think pricing, easier products, easier stores  to shop, DIY education & advice. 20,000 people have been through the you can-do-it clinics and stores, half of  those were kids, and we're building for the future. But particularly, online research and demystifying eco for the  home; eco is going to be a massive opportunity for us. I'll come back and talk about the milestone, but we think  with Green Deal arriving this year, home improvement will change and we need to be ready and help customers  with it.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Finally, based on sustainability, becoming net positive. This is something we will do a proper fuller launch on later  this year. But I think we've identified already that we think we can make a difference in timber; in energy, both in  our own stores and our consumers; communities, because we're in 900 places around the world and we have a  direct impact; and cradle-to-cradle innovation, so the circular economy trying to find new business models, new  ideas for how we might work in the future.  All these four coming under a theme of net positive. And essentially, the idea is to say it's no longer going to be  good enough to do slightly less evil and to use slightly less in the way of resources. At some point, you've got to  have an ambition that says, Yes, I want – for example, on timber, to have all my products 100% sustainable. That's  a gate I've got to go through. But maybe in the future, my supply chain is setup so that I actually am reforesting  certain areas where I can make a difference because of all that can bring from the supply chain – my end of the  supply chain, and actually positively have an impact for good.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And how about energy. Why not have, instead of a customer's home being more energy efficient – yes, let's make  it even more energy efficient but with micro renewables, could we make streets or individual houses, net power  exporters? So, we're going to have to think and challenge ourselves to say how could we become a net positive  company rather than just a neutral company? But it will be around the four themes that we've set out and we'll  talk about it a bit later this year.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: The Green Deal is really important for us. We're going to invest about £10 million a year over the next two years to  develop a new business model to allow us to take part in the Green Deal development. And we've been very closely  involved with DECC and the government in trying to get this right. We think it will change home improvement  because people will then be able to take on projects which they can finance through Green Deal which they  couldn't otherwise finance. And it will have a direct impact on our business because it's a direct opportunity  drawing on our stores, drawing on Screwfix, drawing on some new thinking. That's a key innovation for us.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: I'm very pleased to welcome now, in terms of the two roles that [ph] Ewing (01:35) used to cover, Steve Willet,  who's formally CEO of Screwfix. He's now taken up the role of Group Productivity and Development, which means  he covers IT systems , multichannel, and our productivity initiatives – which we will be putting more focus on as  we go through the year – in addition to some development projects, which he's been involved with, including  Kingfisher Future Homes, the Green Deal operator. So Steve brings a wealth of experience, including a prior  sense, obviously, of  B&Q.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And then the weather effect – we just quoted the UK. I think realistically is – probably you could estimate more,  but I think that was a clear-cut impact. And we obviously had sort of flat to talking about the weather, but this was  – we run a weather-related business. It was the worst weather in 100 years.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Gross margin in the UK and Ireland contracted slightly by 10 basis points. We largely offset the impact of  significant promotional activity in the market in the latter part of the year and weather and range change impact  earlier on with self-help measures including variability in staff and bonus cost and sourcing and supply chain  benefit.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: This waterfall chart shows the key drivers behind the reduction in profit and the importance of our well-rehearsed  self-help initiatives which went someway to offsetting the downward pressure. As previously noted, our best  foreign exchange movement hit profits by £39 million and we estimate the impact of bad weather cost us around  £25 million. Cost inflation pressure around the group, which averaged 2%, was largely offset by self-help,  including a focus on store productivity, savings on the cost of goods not for resale and reductions in discretionary  spend.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And I think this is a really fundamental shift into more experiential type of retail where we can build more of a  relationship. And it's clear that consumers want help. The YouTube channel has done very well, and formats I'll  come on to talk a bit about otherwise. Green Deal, up and running. Both are early days.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: So there are wealth of opportunities. But to take the example here, we've launched the opening price point power  tool range Energer from Brico into Screwfix. And it's at a lower price to customer, interesting margins and the  early signs are very positive. And that essentially replaces an existing own label OPP that we were using on  Screwfix. But we get a better deal by putting the two volumes together.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: So looking forward, 2013-2014 the to-do list, I pick out maybe just one – well, two things on this page. Rolling out  the new UK Castorama colored emulsion. We're tendering here 21 million leases of paint. It's one of the biggest  single common programs that we're going to tackle in terms of value.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: Now moving on to the one team, I'm very much a set of ambitions but built around developing people and  launching the net positive sustainability strategy so just a quick update on what happened there.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And net positive, I mean it's fair to say we've gone through a process of explaining sustainability. It's the idea of  going from do less bad to can we be a force for good that can actually put things back in. So around timber, yes,  great that we've got being queued to 100% sustainable. Could we actually be part of a net reforestation program.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: And in the UK, picture of a wood, very exciting. There's a program called good woods. 11,000 hectares we're going  to try and bring back into active ownership as a sort of exemplar project. But we basically take the wood fuel out  and sell it locally and other wood products that creates the local cycle, local economy, local jobs and what we think  about is it creates a market opportunity for us, binds us into our local community and makes us a better citizen  and more likely to be around in another 30, 40 years.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: So we are in a pragmatic business-led view of sustainability but one where we want to lead. We'll be publishing a  dashboard later on this year and we'll be, I'm sure, seeing lots of different examples. But to give sort of one  example, one of the four pillars, so we talk about timber, energy, communities and innovation. So we're looking  for new business models, looking at [indiscernible] (54:52) economy and new ways of making money.

texts.speaker: Ian M. Cheshire
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingfisher Plc
texts.text: If I take energy, one of the top things on all consumers list all over Europe is how do I cut my energy bill. Last year  in Castorama, insulation sales were up 20%. This is a growth market for us that we've got to have leadership in. So  for us, there is absolute 100% alignment between the sustainability plan and the business plan and it's part of the  type of business that we want to be in the future.

And then as the weather changed, we saw some  rebalancing in quarter two. Then in quarter three and four, we continued to  deliver like-for-like growth.

file: KGFL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 31March2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Energy costs are rising. The energy costs have risen by 4% between 2008 and 2012. There is 11% of people in  Europe who can't pay their energy bill. And when we did, we conduct our last European research, it was in every  country, the main problem for people to go after in their home. So, again, this is a massive market. It will be highly  regulated, but we can do something about it. Rates raising in regulatory requirements, of course, European has  tried to harmonize [ph] opportunity (43:05) lots of those rules, including about energy costs, it's about the way we  will do e-commerce for instance. So, again, there is opportunity for us to be integrated in those things.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Having said that, we've been looking a lot at the home improvement sector and there are things which are already  given for us. So first, Omni is growing very fast in our industry, and even if it's not by the big companies, you have  lots of lots of very small websites which are starting to do very, very good job, and will be coming straight for us in  terms of competition. The important thing about the digital in our industry as well is about research, because it's  quite complicated project. People are researching a lot of lines. So, our Omnichannel capability will have to be not  only about selling, even if it will have to be about selling. It's about all the environment around that.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Second, creating a unique and leading offer. What does that mean? That means that we won't be selecting  products from the shelves of the supplier anymore. We will develop, design, [ph] indeed, (01:02:06) as well,  because we will still have products for [ph] regular (01:02:10) supplier, of course, when it's needed. But we will  develop design and add in unique solutions for home improvement at lowest costs. Those solutions will be design,  they will be innovative, they will be complete, it will be stable as well, we will have a much, much stable range, so  people can find their products over and over. Coordinated, of course, that everything is matching with everything.  Good quality, that's very important. And sustainable, the sustainability will be fully embedded in the way we will  be designing our products. It won't be something on the side. It won't be one positive, but it would be completely  embedded in the way we do our business. But more importantly, we are creating our product.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: It will be the same everywhere. The size of the flooring, for instance, won't be the same in every country. If the  wood flooring is bigger in one country, the [ph] foot space (01:04:42) of the wood flooring will be bigger [ph] at  that type, so we will do that, (01:04:46) but with the same merchandising principle and the same customer  experience. And we will have the local adaptation when it is required.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally, although there is a wider backdrop of political uncertainty, both in the UK and globally, in terms of the  shorter term outlook for our key markets, as we've said before, the UK environment remains positive, and we  remain cautious on France.

texts.speaker: Karen Witts
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Then we've got an allocation of capital around revamps and relocations. And I wanted to highlight that because  we've got a couple of our Big Box pilots which are revamp stores included in this figure here and also our ongoing  program of revamps which, up until now, has been largely something that we've done in France. So, in France, in  the year that we just reported on, we did like six revamp stores. We've got some CapEx allocated for that. And  then, last but not least, we have been investing in renewables and PV panels and LED lighting.

texts.speaker: Véronique Laury-Deroubaix
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So these are the new operational targets which is to deliver the offer and supply chain organization. This is a very  important milestone for us. And of course, we will update you on that one more precisely as we are doing it, and  we have the numbers. Actually, Arja's board is now in place and working. And we are continuing to build, but this  is really the work of this year. Of course, the 4% COGS that we've been talking to you about in January is in our  roadmap, as well as the digital platform, we've been talking about that.
