texts.speaker: Stefan Świątkowski
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board-Finance, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now, let me discuss the [ph] Polish and (28:11) KGHM Polska. Although stable production of mine, we had a  slight reduction from 1.52% to 1.5% and this is the content of Cu in ore and that was compensated with the  increased production of ore. As a result of that, the production of copper in concentrate has not changed at all.  And the very fact that we had slight decline of the production of electrolytic copper and silver is related to the fact  that we shifted to the new furnace.

file: KGH - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 15November2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Radosław Domagalski-Łabędzki
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, KGHM Polska Miedź SA
texts.text: But when we look at the production volume on a year-to-year basis, we are basically on the same level, 507,000  tonnes of copper produced after three quarters of 2016 is pretty much on line with the current output, which is  500,000 tonnes. This is just 1% less. And comparing quarters, basic quarter-to-quarter, we are basically on the  same level. So the slightly lower volume is due to the lower production in KGHM International.

texts.speaker: Radosław Domagalski-Łabędzki
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, KGHM Polska Miedź SA
texts.text: You may be interested why we only have PLN 28 million on the minerals extraction tax and the explanation is  quite clear. We have lower volume of sales. So, let me remind you that we pay taxes on concentrate, which we  [indiscernible] (00:14:16) but in terms of profit and loss, we see it in the form of sales.

texts.speaker: Radosław Domagalski-Łabędzki
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, KGHM Polska Miedź SA
texts.text: As you probably know, we have growing inventories, which results from – which is also seen in EBITDA results.  So, we process less of our own concentrate, which results from the fact that we have a shift in time concerning  the launch of the concentrate roasting plant in Głogów plant. And we hope that this process will be launched  tomorrow, so we are having a start-up right now, but we see a small delay here. So, some of the concentrate,  especially these with low copper grades and with high coal and sulphur grades, these inventories are growing.

texts.speaker: Radosław Domagalski-Łabędzki
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, KGHM Polska Miedź SA
texts.text: And you will probably ask about it, but we are prepared for reducing these inventories over time, especially in  Głogów. So, we want to do it until the end of 2019. And we must take into consideration the fact that our roasting  plant will work as it has been forecasted. So, it's even now no blackout, no damage, we will do everything on time.

texts.speaker: Radosław Domagalski-Łabędzki
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, KGHM Polska Miedź SA
texts.text: A small summary, copper concentrate production. Here, we see no major threats as compared to our forecasts  made at the beginning of the year, 125,000 tonnes. As for electrolytic copper produced from own resources, this  volume will be lower than expected, and this results from the breakdown of our smelter plants in Głogów and  taking into consideration all these factors and the repairs in Głogów. So, in accordance with the data we have as  of today and if there are [ph] no stoppages no more (00:22:06) then this copper concentrate production should be  366,000 tonnes. And it will be a bit lower than forecasted and it will become offset by higher production from third- party concentrate, so total volume should be about 200,000 tonnes. And the production is even a bit higher.

texts.speaker: Radosław Domagalski-Łabędzki
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, KGHM Polska Miedź SA
texts.text: As for International, the production should be as forecasted. As for Sierra Gorda, I won't talk about copper. We  should state that we stick to the plans. But looking at molybdenum production volume, it will be a bit lower by  nearly 4 million tonnes. So the total sales will be lower by 22,000 tonnes. This is about – I'm talking about copper.  And for silver, we'll stick to the plans, to the forecast. The cost should be standard ones.

texts.speaker: Radosław Domagalski-Łabędzki
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, KGHM Polska Miedź SA
texts.text: So, to sum up the highlights of our financial numbers for three quarters of 2017, so, first of all, reduced production  of electrolytic copper, 22,000 tons. This is mostly due to the unplanned shutdown at Głogów plant, but we also  were affected by the force majeure that is the Xavier windstorm, we had a failure of power supply and, therefore,  we had to put production on hold. And we were delayed with the start-up of our concentrate roasting installation.

texts.speaker: Radosław Domagalski-Łabędzki
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, KGHM Polska Miedź SA
texts.text: I already talked about the inventory of copper. This is 72,000 tonnes that we are going to have saved at the end of  2017. Volume at Sierra Gorda will be less than anticipated and this is because of the need to shift the production.  Well, currently, we are actually producing molybdenum at the site that is almost – that has twice less content of  molybdenum in the ore than the previous site. Until recently, we were actually producing from the site where we  had 0.11 of molybdenum content in the ore. Now, it's half of it. And then I already said that we actually have less  capital expenditure on International products.

file: KGH - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 15November2018 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Radoslaw Stach
texts.profession: Vice President-Production, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Let me focus now on our projects after nine months progress of making available, the deposits program for  metallurgy development construction of [indiscernible] (00:02:00) furnace on Legnica plant, our plans for re- melting in the future of copper. Everything moves on in accordance with our planned development of the Iron  Bridge, things that are future oriented for KGHM related to storage of [ph] waste (00:02:24). Also the development  of the Southern Quarter's, we are after a round of consultations with international experts who evaluated our  activities, [indiscernible] (00:02:35) investment as very professional and very well thought out.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: As regards operating results of our group, EBITDA was 11% lower than EBITDA after nine months 2017. The  principal reason for that was an increase in operating costs where we recorded an increase in the cost of coal  operations as well as higher tax on minerals as compared with the last year.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Now let me move on to the macroeconomic environment, and I would like to comment on today's prices of  copper, silver and molybdenum. Well, these prices are important to us because they have direct impact on our  financial performance, higher price of copper compared to last year, but exchange rate slightly was a little bit to  the down side. And molybdenum has been coming up. We are watching the global markets and we are tracking  the global inventory. We can tell from the chart that the global inventory is actually going down and therefore we  are optimistic about the prices of copper in the future and the prices of copper cathodes in China make us  optimistic about the future prices.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Now, main activities that are planned for 2018. And here I would like to highlight the launch of the concentrate  roasting installation. This is the last stage of our investment in the Głogów Smelter. We've already run two tests  on the existing installation. The technology test disclosed certain errors, but had to be mitigated. So we are  looking forward to the further round of tests. And we are looking forward to launching the concentrate roasting  installation because it will help us deliver better performance at Głogów.

texts.speaker: Adam Bugajczuk
texts.profession: Vice President-Development, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now, let me comment on key domestic projects. For mining operations, Deep Głogów is the key project. This is  our deep deposit. On the left hand side, you see the gray bars which show the change compared to Q3 2017. We  were up, which means that the progress is underway and we are producing from the deeper deposit. So it is  happening. As we promised, we are delivering and this is a positive thing.

texts.speaker: Adam Bugajczuk
texts.profession: Vice President-Development, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now in addition to that, we continued to build the GG-1 shaft and we also work on the Surface-based Central Air  Conditioning System. We are also working on the expansion of GG-2 shaft. This is the future of our company. We  are looking forward to 2034 and 2036, so long-term planning, positive news for the positive developments for  KGHM in the future.

texts.speaker: Adam Bugajczuk
texts.profession: Vice President-Development, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now, we also have a range of different projects that are underway to bring us to compliance with the [ph] BAT  (00:20:50) directive and we included emissions of arsenic in the scope and we have a number of projects that will  help make sure that our emissions are not as harmful to the environment as they could be.

texts.speaker: Adam Bugajczuk
texts.profession: Vice President-Development, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: And finally, let's have a look at the key international projects. First of all, Sierra Gorda mine and the production of  mine – of copper for the last nine months, 69,000 tonnes, molybdenum 19.5 million tonnes. And the most  important thing is to continue the debottlenecking program, where we want to remove the bottlenecks that are  affiliated through the processing operations. This project is underway and, again, it makes us very optimistic when  we look into the future.

texts.speaker: Adam Bugajczuk
texts.profession: Vice President-Development, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Sierra Gorda Oxide is the next project and this oxide processing project is at Sierra Gorda and now Victoria and  Ajax are currently under review. We are revising certain underlying assumptions that we made for this project, the  macro environment situation is evolving. Therefore, when we are presenting results on the next occasions, it will  be a good opportunity to keep you updated on the plans regarding this project. But please bear with us because  we need to complete our review.

file: KGH - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 1March2013 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert Wirth
texts.profession: President & CEO, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: A very important event this year is that for the first time KGHM has a technical report where potentials – main  potentials were identified and they were appraised by a Canadian standard NI 43-101. That shows that KGHM  has the highest standards and has a resources potential for 30 years or 40 years and it's the owner through  concession of 17 million of tonnes of ore in earth.

texts.speaker: Herbert Wirth
texts.profession: President & CEO, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Another important thing this year is finishing of the exploration works in the – in Lower Silesia. Technologies in  these conditions enable them to reach further potential for exploration. It's more than 10 – from 10 – a dozen  boreholes, which comprises of 1.4% of copper plus 50 grams per tonne of equivalent copper. That means that  equivalent copper reaches up to 2%, which is very important potential for Republic of Poland. Sometimes we look  only at different countries and different continents but we don't take a look at our region. This is a proof for the fact  that even Lower Silesia is very important today and in the future copper and silver deposit.

texts.speaker: Wlodzimierz Kicinski
texts.profession: CFO, EVP & First VP-Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: As far as elements of production are concerned, the ore extraction was at the level of 30 tonnes of dry weight, so  2% increase. Production of copper was stable and electrolytic copper at a very similar level to last year – to that of  last year.

texts.speaker: Wlodzimierz Kicinski
texts.profession: CFO, EVP & First VP-Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Expenses by nature increased by 7%, so we can show what are the factors influencing this increase of this  structure of costs. This increase results mainly from the fact that the exploration tax was introduced and foreign  chargers were higher than the year before. Other elements, cost elements caused the increase by 18%. Here we  can say about fuels, materials, and labor costs.

texts.speaker: Wlodzimierz Kicinski
texts.profession: CFO, EVP & First VP-Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: The increase in costs is structured here on the slide, showing its increase compared to 2011 and total cost  productions – copper cost productions show us what is the most characteristics, 74% of this amount is tax  exploration introduced in April 2012, 19% labor costs and 16% is the materials, energy and fuel costs increase.

texts.speaker: Wlodzimierz Kicinski
texts.profession: CFO, EVP & First VP-Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: As far as electrolytic copper is concerned, because in this year we will be having modernization works in mine  Głogów for the first three months, which is quite natural in that industry. If you have any questions, please ask  them during the discussion.

texts.speaker: Jaroslaw Romanowski
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Commercial, KGHM International
texts.text: Copper increased even more to 1,010 tonnes by 12%. Main mines to which these success was due was mine  Robinson, Franke and Morrison. The only factor that negatively influenced the level of production cost was the  decrease in production of silver that influenced directly the cost of production of copper, but owing to other  improvements and price – and the decrease of costs in other areas.

texts.speaker: Jaroslaw Romanowski
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Commercial, KGHM International
texts.text: Moving to our project which is the pearl in the crown not only of KGHM International, but the whole capital group  is Sierra Gorda. It's a project in Chile, which is the best performing project in the world. The quickest one is Chile  as well. We can say that in the last period, we had considerable achievements in strategic growth realization. We  signed significant contracts, for example, for concentrate rail service transport, seawater pipeline construction, for  port facilities, for electrical transmission lines, for power purchase agreement. You remember that the cost of  functioning of this project were higher due to the fact that we had no access to electrical transmission. Since  September, we had an access owing to the kindness of Spence mine, which is an adjacent mine. You will have a  chance to see it while visiting Sierra Gorda.

texts.speaker: Jaroslaw Romanowski
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Commercial, KGHM International
texts.text: During the first five years, it will be a copper and molybdenum mine and molybdenum production will be the 10%  of the world offer and it will cause a lower cost of copper production.

texts.speaker: Jaroslaw Romanowski
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Commercial, KGHM International
texts.text: Appreciation of pass-on inflation was about 40% of the influence of increase of CapEx and labor and material  costs increase is about one-third of the whole increase of investment expenditure. About 20% of this increase was  caused by new administrative regulations introduced during the project by government in Chile, referring to  conditions of mining constructions in earthquake conditions. So we can say that about 90% of factors influencing  the increase of CapEx was not under the KGHM Board's control and they referred to all projects in Chile.

texts.speaker: Jaroslaw Romanowski
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Commercial, KGHM International
texts.text: So we are looking with a lot of optimism into the future regarding the copper price because the copper production  costs will increase and it will refer to all – production in all mines. And only production in Chile amounts to 40% of  the world production of copper. We assume a transfer of two months to three months in CapEx increase, but we  think that other projects are behind. The CapEx increased by 35% compared to other projects in Chile were at  average it was about 60%, shows that our project is managed in a perfect way.

texts.speaker: Jaroslaw Romanowski
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Commercial, KGHM International
texts.text: I would like to show one of the initiatives that is under analysis. Right now we are getting to the end of the results  and we are thinking about introducing another shape of the pit. We are working on a steeper pit, compared to the  shelf. And I can say that it will influence considerably the value of the mine in the future. We have examples of  adjacent mines, for example Spence, that kind of change of slope is possible to introduce and we are waiting now  for final confirmations of that schedule change proposed by our technical advisors.

texts.speaker: Jaroslaw Romanowski
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Commercial, KGHM International
texts.text: As far as other possible areas for identification of added value for Sierra Gorda are other financial leverages.  Please remember that project Sierra Gorda was designed with the copper price at the level of $2.10 per pound  which is $5,500 per tonne.

texts.speaker: Jaroslaw Romanowski
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Commercial, KGHM International
texts.text: When we talk about CapEx we should show – always show the part of analysis which reflects the profit because  there is a correlation between the production and the materials price. If today the copper price is about $3.5 per  pound, which is about $8,000 per tonne, then materials costs are different, oil and energy price is higher, then  analyzing this project we should think about the correlation of both parties of balance sheet. We are still working  on the possibility of implementing an additional production on oxides. This material is treated as waste, but it still  could be used for production in the future and that could increase production of copper from Sierra Gorda mine.

file: KGH - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 18March2016 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: And now, what is the preparatory work for the production? From the very beginning of our efforts, we have made  93.4 kilometers of preparatory work in the deposit and 14 kilometers of that was completed in the year 2015. Well,  of course, to certain extent, we had to reinforce this area with belt and infrastructure and facilities which are  indispensable to continue mining activities. And by the same token, in 2015, we have completed the first stage of  the construction of the Surface air conditioning station in the shaft R-XI. And, currently the capacity is 15  megawatts, this is the cooling capacity of course, and we do hope and we have certain plans related to that so that  in the second half of 2016 we're going to increase this capacity to 25 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: While the work may have been under way for a number of y ears, related to sinking of the ventilation shaft GG-1,  and by the end of December, it was 665 meters, our plan is that in 2019, we will be able to complete this work.  Well, in 2015 it was 687 meters.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: And then slide number six presents some information pertaining to the Development Program of Metallurgy in  KGHM. I believe that you are aware of the fact that for a number of years we have been working very hard in the  smelter, Głogów I smelter facility. And, well, we are going to install three shaft and furnaces. We are going to  replace them with the furnace flash. These are the furnaces that are of top quality, it is a flash furnace. And thanks  to that, to a very large extent, we are going to be able to improve the environmental impact assessment of our new  facilities in Głogów, and to a large extent, we will be able to reduce the cost of manufacturing in Głogów smelter.  In the second half of 2016, we planned to have four months long shutdown in Głogów I. Well, just to be able to  replace shaft furnace with flash furnaces, and hence since during this period, we are not going to have sufficient  capacity. We planned to sell our own concentrate with 45,000 tonnes of copper.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: And, well, this is going to be the decline of the output. But the point is that – this amount, about 47,000 of tonnes,  to be more precise, of copper concentrate, this is what we want to sell and 106 tonnes of silver should be included.  Well, last year as well as in 2006, well we had a plan, and this plan has been completed to purchase certain  inventory of anode copper to maintain certain level of production during that time.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: Due to the [indiscernible] (13:00) nature of our concentrates as well as the grade of organic coal in the subsequent  years, we plan to have another facility for the concentrates and then the drying equipment. We are going to have a  concentrate roasting and steam drying.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: Slide number seven. Well, Sierra Gorda. In 2015, we have continued the work related to the increase of the  processing capacity in more general terms. In Sierra Gorda, well our target production average in concentrate, it is  about 220,000 tonnes of copper plus about 25 million pounds of molybdenum per annum as well as 64,000  ounces of silver in both stages, in Stage I and Stage II, as you know KGHM has 55% of share in this company.  Sumitomo holds 45% share. This is very large pit. In 2015, copper production amounted to 84,000 tonnes. That  was the [ph] roundup (14:23) phase around the year. The molybdenum production was approximately 15,000  million pounds. They key challenges for this project include the targeted production of 120,000 tonnes of copper  and 50 million pounds of molybdenum and reaching the effective production level to reach stabilization of our  production and processing.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: On March 8, Sierra Gorda was informed about decision of the Chilean Environmental Enforcement Agency where  nine areas were identified where there were some permit breaches recorded. The company is currently working on  the reply to this decision. We had 15 day s to do it, and according to the Chilean law, from the moment the letter is  registered by mail, there are three additional days. So, starting from March 10, there are 15 days to reply to that  decision. So, the company will respond to that, to each of the nine great areas that were identified. The work was  completed [indiscernible] (16:15) technical documentation for Phase 2 of the project. It was completed in 2015.  And in addition to that, we work on the optimization of the Oxide project, that is under way to improve our  processing of Oxide, which is at the higher resource level.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: The next slide is slide number eight, and it refers to individual projects, Project Victoria and Project Ajax. These  are the resource projects under development. For Victoria, the targeted average production is 16 tonnes of nickel  in ore, approximately 15 tonnes of copper in ore, and 150 ounces of TPM in the ore.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: The ownership is 100% KGHM, and the Victoria project is the deep underground mine. In 2015, we were  preparing surface infrastructure. Amongst others, we completed the construction of the transformer stations. The  company made a decision to modify the adopted schedule for the Victoria project, which is located in the Sudbury  Basin. In 2015, there were some additional production works and exploration works to actually confirm that  potential continuous inferred category mineralization below currently identified orebody.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: On the 20th of November, the Environmental Office concluded formal assessment of the environmental  application, and the results was positive. On 19 January, 2016, the Environmental Office began the process of the  review of our application. On 26th of January, the social consultations were opened with the participation of the  residents of Kamloops town as well as the First Nations. And we are obviously part of this process. Thank you at  this point.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: We never know what is the actual reason for such decisions, but nevertheless, the point is that we do not expect  any major increase in supply. So the exchange rate shift and the offset caused by depreciation was that in the  dollars, the copper price fell by 20%, while in zloty, it dropped only by 4%.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: And while the [indiscernible] (28:22) discussed, the cost, well, it translates into operating results. Well, in  EBITDA, adjusted EBITDA for the whole Capital Group, well we saw a decline at the level of 4%. And you can sort  of decompose that into different elements. First of all, at the level of KGHM Polska Miedź S.A., so this is our  company, so this is the decline by 4%, well, this is the company with the biggest impact on the final results and  this is related to the decline of copper prices, so it was not anything spectacular.

texts.speaker: Mirosław Biliński
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board - Development, KGHM Polska Meidz SA
texts.text: So, in other words, we have this production increase from 421,000 to 426,000. And the electrolytic copper  production was at the same level with the sort of own concentrate and we saw a small decline in terms of other  concentrate that was slightly less. It was from the decline from 577 to 574. So, it is less than 1% decline.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Well, please note three large bars, PLN 3 million in 2014 in net profit and then you have this sort of huge orange  minus, PLN 3,617. This is the result of the changes of the prices of the metals that we sell. And the sort of green  bar, PLN 3.29 billion, it is compensated with the exchange rate change.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: CapEx domestically was exceeded by 5% and that was due to additional works that were needed for the  construction of the flash furnace in Głogów, and we had to also curb the CapEx of Victoria due to the change in the  schedule of the project.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: On the next slide, we have the plans for 2016. In 2016, we intend to sustain the average production, copper  production, both ore and concentrate and also silver and electrolyte copper. Well, the numbers that you see are  due to the four months' period between for the replacement of the shaft furnaces with the flash furnaces. To  optimize our inventory management, given that we won't have processing capacity due to this replacement period,  we intend to sell 250,000 dry concentrate which includes 50,000 tonnes of copper and over 100,000 tonnes of  silver. Our CapEx includes the completion of the projects that are underway and the financial supp ort for Sierra  Gorda projects which will take form of the ownership loan.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: The main priority for the upcoming months is to verify our strategy and to revise our investments plans. This is  underway. We need to optimize production and cost for Sierra Gorda project total life cycle, all the three phases.  We also plan to review and revise that development plans for KGHM International assets. And we also intend to  work on the program that involves the replacement of the shaft furnace [indiscernible] (51:21) flus h furnace. We  will also work on the liquidity management and we are going to work on the feasibility study for the old copper  basin. That includes old deposits that were explored by KGHM in the past and they are located in the south of the  lower [indiscernible] (51:44).

file: KGH - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 17March2017 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: In terms of the key operational events, we started up the flash furnace at the Głogów I Copper Smelter. And this is  the largest investment – the largest CapEx that we completed during the past few years. It was successful. And at  this point in time, we are slowly but steadily reaching full nominal capacity. Last year, it was 75% of targeted  capacity, and we are moving upwards which is an excellent performance, given that the start-up was recently.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: We also had new exploration works. 36 kilometers of mine tunnels excavated in the Deep Głogów area which is  the most promising area for KGHM. At this point in time, the production is 5% of our total domestic extraction.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: To summarize, our production and sales and financial results. Well, payable copper production was down by 6%  on a year-to-year basis, and that was due to the standstill of the copper smelter Głogów I in Q3 and that was also  due to the start-up of the new flash furnace in Q4 last year.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: The payable copper sales were up by 1% with the total of 702,000 tonne. We were able to achieve that as a result  of utilizing our own reserves and inventory and copper concentrate.

texts.speaker: Stefan Świątkowski
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Finance), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: [audio gap] (08:07-08:16) managed to maintain stable production of copper throughout the group despite our  challenges around the launch of our new flash furnace. Production of equivalent copper was 742,000 tonnes  which means there was a fall of 1% compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Stefan Świątkowski
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Finance), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: And, of course, low copper prices were persisting at certain point. But, it was compensated by a much higher  EBITDA from KGHM International. We have also mentioned some cost reduction activities. There was quite a  robust program implemented to reduce costs. Headquarters were involved, but also individual mines were  involved and there was a series of projects.

texts.speaker: Stefan Świątkowski
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Finance), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now, another assumption that we take for 2017 is to hold copper and concentrate production at more or less  [audio gap] (19:07-19:14) trends, which in practical terms means that it would be up by 0.2%, so a slight increase  in production of copper and concentrate.

texts.speaker: Stefan Świątkowski
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Finance), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now, looking at the sales volumes, we presume that payable copper will be 536,000 tonnes which is less than in  2016 when we were able to sell 560,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Stefan Świątkowski
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Finance), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: The sales volume of copper and silver is lower in 2017, wherein 2016, it's down by 4% for copper and 10% down  for silver. And this is geared to the fact that we need to pass on to our clients 15,000 cathodes and 47,000 tonnes  of silver that were produced on the third party – based on third-party inputs.

file: KGH - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 15March2019 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now we also see positive outcomes of initiatives that were defined last year. We revised our strategy and we  came up with the new strategic projects. And as I said, we have seen some outcomes. This is our response to  what is happening around the world. On this slide, you see the volatility of copper price 2018, especially the last  six months, were very difficult. The prices were going down below $6,000 per tonne and the prices were much  lower than budgeted, which was a challenge as it impacted our financial performance, our revenue and EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Well, the copper prices and the developments that unfolded in 2018 where it was quite clear the trade war, no  macroeconomic stability as a result of the trade war, 50% of the global demand for copper comes from China.  There was huge uncertainty and that was reflected in the price of copper. We are more stable in terms of  economic relation between China and U.S. right now and, therefore, we believe that the price that we have  currently seems to be quite optimum price and it is in line with our prior projections, which are available in the  public domain. It is our intention to show to you what we believe is the actual situation and the true picture and it  seems that we are right on target when it comes to copper price projections. And in 2019, we believe that the  price of copper will be on our side. So it's no longer going to be a challenge as it was in 2018, a tough challenge  that we had to face.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: The good news is that all think tanks and analysts agree that until 2030, on average, demand for copper will be up  by 30%. So this is an incremental growth of demand and it will be beneficial to us and to the entire industry. This  is triggered by the development of transportation systems, electro mobility, energy sector, infrastructure, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Radosław Stach
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Production), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now, moving on. When we look at payable copper production on a quarter-to-quarter basis, the situation is really  good. At the end of Q3, we said that performance is really good and we are able to show that Q4 was really good.

texts.speaker: Radosław Stach
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Production), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Now, the next slide is about inventories of copper. So we were saying on a regular basis that we are able to  reduce the inventories of copper. We took certain measures in the second half of 2018, and therefore we were  able to reduce the inventory, and this is very visible. Now when you look at the copper anodes inventories, the  movement that you see there is consistent with the plan that we have for the copper smelter, where we are going  to have a plant shutdown.

texts.speaker: Radosław Stach
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Production), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: We also launched the roasting installation we mentioned in Q4, but this is in the pipeline, and we went live with  the roaster and roasting installation has been in business for the last 45 years with no interrupted operations. So  the plan has been delivered. And as a result, the smelter can produce more. This also uses capacity of flash  furnaces, and overall, this is a very positive news that comes from the end of 2018.

texts.speaker: Adam Bugajczuk
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (Development), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: In the context of BAT adjustment program, we have several dozen projects also expanded with arsenium in order  to meet all requirements related to natural environment protection. Of course, we cannot forget investments  related to the development of Iron Bridge and works that are being conducted in southern, of course, are moving  ahead full steam. We expect to hand over the investment for use at the end of the year. All those things are under  control. Thank you.

texts.speaker: Paweł Gruza
texts.profession: Vice President of the Management Board (International Assets), KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Another project which is also linked to Sierra Gorda is the stock of oxygen (sic) [oxide copper] ore, which was  recovered in [indiscernible] (00:26:43) mine. We made some studies how this resource could be used and how it  can contribute to increase the volumes of production of the KGHM Group in the future. Tentative analyses confirm  our assumptions about the possibility to complete this project, but the final success will depend on the consent  and goodwill of our Japanese partner, Sumitomo.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: This strategy covers all areas; local production, international production, our energy generation and higher self- sufficiency when it comes to power supplies. It also covers innovation, projects, R&D, and our search for the  projects that help improve our cost efficiency and production efficiency. Each strategy starts with the first step. We  have already made the first steps.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: In terms of power generation, we identified some areas for possible photovoltaic investment projects. We are  running analysis today and we may be moving to the execution soon. We are the industry where we consume a  lot of energy. Therefore, it's not that we are trying to follow the global trend, but this is the actual need. By having  our own generation sources, we would be able to better diversify supplies of electricity. But we are also in line  with the global trend, where the green copper, copper which is produced with the use of renewable sources, has  become more prevalent. So to be able to compete globally, we have to be able to produce and use renewable  sources.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: And in addition to that, we work on some other initiatives that help us make KGHM more sustainable company.  This is not a sprint, we have to be forward-looking and we have to look at the next 10, 15 or 20 years to prepare  new mining sites.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Deep Głogów is still in business. This initiative has been started some time ago, a few years ago. The G1 shaft is  being continued despite some geological problems. We were also able to locate a G2 shaft. This is where we are  getting into the new mining area. We are applying for licenses at the [indiscernible] (00:34:10) area and the Bytom  Odrzański. These are just exploration licenses and there are some disputes related to these licenses, because of  some legacy issues, but the Ministry was obliged to review the decision making process and licensing process as  a result of the court order. Therefore, we see that we may get these licenses and they will help sustain the lifetime  of KGHM.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: Magnesium salt is another license or – magnesium and potassium salt is another license. Here the deposit is  located at Puck, which is right on the coast of the Baltic Sea. It seems to be quite exotic location, but not as exotic  as Sierra Gorda. These materials are needed for our production. The licensing process was put on hold because  there were some legal disputes, but the Supreme Administrative Court came up with the final decision and now  we are able to resume the operation of this project.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: We are not sure whether we are going to operate it on our own or whether we will work with the partner. We have  to complete restoration process and then we can decide what would be the business model for the actual  operation of this salt, magnesium and potassium salt.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: We've already had some experience with salt mining and the [indiscernible] (00:35:53). So, we are working on this  project not to have an immediate impact, but to have prospects for sustained operation for the next 20 years or  so. At this moment, we are looking at some other potential mining sites that can be subject to exploration. And we  want to include them in our long-term plan, just to work on the development of the longer life cycle for KGHM.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: We want to focus on production, smelting and logistics that put together constitute our main production line. We  are very much interested in solutions that support circular economy, so that we are able to recover a lot from our  side products or waste products. As you know, from the waste products we are able to recover silver and we are  doing quite well with it. So we are looking for other opportunities to explore possible recovery of other metals or  other products that can be sold. So, again, we are going to focus on that in 2019.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: We summarize 2018, let me say again, the year of challenges, but as a result of addressing the challenges, we  were able to maintain the adequate level of production, and we also maintained the right cost level. Labor cost  has been going up. We see that in the service sector and also elsewhere. Last year, there were some  extraordinary events like the breakdown of the furnace. It was a costly event. The natural gas prices were also  growing last year and were impacted our performance. So all these projects involving logistics, KPIs for  purchasing and the new approach for a decision making process where the capital group is making decisions with  the involvement of the CEO of other companies, so all these things are to improve our overall performance.

texts.speaker: Marcin Chludziński
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President of the Management Board, KGHM Polska Miedz SA
texts.text: We are also testing new solutions working with our external partners. These solutions are geared to improve our  production, mining production. So, hopefully, once we deliver all these projects, we will be able to improve  EBITDA and we will be very pleased to take opportunity of the growing demand for copper within the next decade  up to 2030.

texts.text: Now page 13, a deep dive on some of our R&D activities and how they have progressed and led to increased  market shares. We do know that  the world is starting to change, even some of our own numbers confirm that some of our former customers with IC  trucks are now customers – are same customers with electric trucks, so there is a drive in Europe and in  emissions-dependent countries to move to electric trucks. And so, it's very sustainable reduction of the interest payment after our IPO.

texts.speaker: Gordon Riske
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO
texts.text: On page 13, the innovations from the past year that we introduced now at these shows, the Linde Pilot or Safety  Pilot electronic driver assistance. file: KGX - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 6August2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Aug-15.pdf
KGX - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 27July2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Gordon Riske
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, let me turn to the market on page 6, the global market development by region. Western Europe showed a  very strong growth of 11.3% in the second quarter, driven by continued strong momentum in the warehouse  segment. North America saw a slight decline in Q2, although, overall, on a volume basis, it's still a very high level.  Moving to the emerging markets, Eastern Europe showed, again, a very positive development, with a growth of  28.6%, largely benefiting from the continued recovery in Russia and good development in other Eastern  European markets. China is stabilizing. However, the market posted a slight decline of minus 1.2% in Q2 after the  positive effects of new emissions regulations in the first quarter. As stated in our outlook, we do expect the  Chinese market to stabilize throughout the year, but we do remain cautious about the next months ahead of us.  South and Central America continues to decline, minus 5.1%, based on the ongoing decline and the political  situation in Brazil. So, overall, the global market grew only slightly by 1.8%, mainly driven by the demand for  electric trucks and, particularly, for warehouse trucks.

texts.speaker: Gordon Riske
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Eastern Europe, KION grew below the strong market dynamics because we do have a very high comparable to  Q2 of the previous year, where we did get a number of large orders. And in China, KION continued to show a  positive development, and we did again outperformed the market. This was a very good performance, again, in  China. The market has normalized again, as I said, after the pre-buying effects of Q1 due to the engine and new  emissions regulations. In Latin America, we saw a positive mix effect, driven by the growth outside of Brazil.  Overall, we were better than the global market in total in Q2, with a growth rate of 3.9% and a total order intake  for KION in terms of units of 45,600 units.

texts.speaker: Gordon Riske
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, KION GROUP AG
texts.text: So let's get started on page 3, we have summarized our strategic highlights for Q3 2018. With our annual results  back in 2017, we did publish our updated strategy KION 2027. Along its fields of actions, energy, digital,  automation, innovation and performance, our brands introduced highly innovative products during the third quarter  2018. We're showing here some selected examples on this slide. Unlike other industries, food distribution has not  been a traditional market for robotic automation, yet a large supplier in this sector selected Dematic to design and  implement a new robotic solution, especially developed for cold temperature-controlled environments.

texts.speaker: Gordon Riske
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, KION GROUP AG
texts.text: Linde closed the last gap in their portfolio and now offers lithium-ion trucks in the load capacity range from 6 tons  to 8 tons. A load category, very few manufacturers offer electrified forklifts for. Linde also introduced new  functions for its connect fleet management system, the digital applications, zone, intelligence and truck mapping  utilize various technologies to make the use of industrial trucks even safer and more transparent, and still  launched a unique multi-functional tractor with a lifting function in a tugger train or tractor application it effortlessly  pulls trailer loads up to 5 tons and lifts loads up to 1 ton on its folding forks. It is also available with lithium-ion  technology for maximum availability in multi-shift use.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Investment AB Kinnevik

texts.speaker: Mia Brunell Livfors
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Investment AB Kinnevik

And we also continue to invest into the renewable sector, primarily  markets where there is a strong regulatory pressure to improve the performance.

texts.profession: Director-Investor Relations, Investment AB Kinnevik
texts.text: Thank you, Mia. And as you know by now, we have focused our new investments on four segments, which is  Agriculture, Bioenergy, Consumer Finance and Consumer Online. And the reason why we've chosen that selection or weight in the new investment is because of their  growth trends and the pickup we see in the consumer online e-commerce segment globally. And the view we're  facing here is that that would continued for many years to come and secondly that it's important to make sure  you're backing the leaders in the segments and in the markets you are selecting.

texts.profession: Director-Investor Relations, Investment AB Kinnevik

texts.profession: Director-Investor Relations, Investment AB Kinnevik

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Investment AB Kinnevik
texts.text: And we also – the strongest global economic trend that we see right now is on the – in terms of business segment  is online and e-commerce businesses. texts.profession: President, CEO, CFO & Executive Vice President, Kone Oyj
texts.text: Also if you look at the green building target, currently about 2% of new construction in China are green buildings.  The target is by 2020 that 50% of buildings would be green buildings. And this is of course a very positive thing  for a company like us in particular given the fact that we are the market leader in energy efficiency. So we are very  excited about the green building target that they have announced. So that's about China.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: Therefore, we also see good progress in our strategy execution, continuously driving us forward, and finally, a lot  of great opportunities from the changing markets, market environments that we are seeing. I'd also like to  highlight that we have, today, published our sustainability report for last year. I hope you all read it. There's a lot of  interesting information in it how we continue to make KONE a more sustainable company and how we are  developing towards our target of being the leader in sustainability in our industry.

file: KNEBV - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 25April2019 845 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: Thanks, Sanna, and welcome, also on my behalf, to our Q1 results webcast. Today, we have a lot of good news  to share that I'm happy about. I'll start with talking about the highlights of the quarter, our key numbers, but also  as usual in connection with our first quarter results, we also have updates on two of our strategic targets, namely  whether we have grown faster than the market last year and how we developed the sustainability. I'll share and  update on those, talk about the markets, as Sanna said, Ilkka will dive a little bit deeper into our financial  performance and I'll wrap up by looking at the our outlook for the year.

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: But as I mentioned in connection with first quarter results, we also look at two of our strategic targets. As you  know, we have five strategic targets through which we measure our longer term success. Now, we have an  update two of them, it's whether we have grown faster than markets and how we're doing towards being a leader  in sustainability.

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: North America, we continue to be number four both in new equipment and maintenance. However, if I look at over  the past five, six, seven years, we had a continuous good and strong development. And in new equipment, we in  particularly have a very strong position in the most important segment that is growing the fastest, which is the  machine-roomless segment. There's a very large hydraulics segment still in North America, but, there, we are not  present, but we focus on modern energy efficient equipment that we think are the best solutions for our  customers, and also the fastest growing market. So, overall, our market positions, of course, give us a good basis  to continue to develop KONE going forward.

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: The other strategic target where we have an update is we have a target of being the leader in sustainability in our  industry. We know that sustainability is a very broad subject, and we have decided that we want to be good  overall, but then we want to be really a leader when it comes to energy and resource efficiency. That we have –  we measure two ways. We measure, first of all, the carbon footprint from our own operations. Here, we have a  target of reducing our carbon footprint relative to sales by 3% per annum. That we have done consistently. Last  year, we improved it by 4% if you look at overall operations. And it may not sound a lot. 2017 was slightly less  improvement than the other years, but if I go back 10, 15 years in history, every year, we have improved by more  than our target. And that means that we actually continuously improving our operations. So, we are meeting our  targets here.

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: The other aspect for us is that we want to have the most energy efficient elevators and escalators and solutions  for our customers. We have 14 elevator models that have the highest energy efficiency rating based on new ISO  standards. This is more than any of our competitors, and we know that we are the market leader here. We have  three escalator models that have the best-in-class energy efficiency rating. So, we also help and ensure that our  customers can have energy efficient and sustainable buildings.

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: We have also continued to receive a lot of external views and also awards for the work we do in sustainability. If  you look at the CDP, there, we have an A- rating for the sixth consecutive year, that is clearly best-in-class in our  industry. Also, Forbes has ranked us as one of World's 100 Most Innovative Companies very consistently over the  past years, and last year also one of the World's Best Employers, that is important in sustainability. And we are  part of FTSE4Good Index. You can read much more about this in our Sustainability Report which was published  today.

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: So if you look at the markets, we can see that housing inventories have slightly increased and that's particularly  due to the cooling measures, but it has slightly increased in lower tier cities. Higher tier cities, it's at pretty good  level, but that's something of course we need to continue to watch, inventories in lower tier cities.

texts.speaker: Matti Alahuhta
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kone Oyj
texts.text: And because we introduced our most important product introduction during the last 16 years by introducing the  new global product range to the volume market. This introduction is a major step forward in the areas of eco- efficiency, ride comfort, visual design and space efficiency. This is very important for us because in this product  range, we will be extremely competitive in all of these factors that are most essential to the users of our products  and to our customers.

file: KNEBV - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 19July2013 845 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Matti Alahuhta
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, KONE Oyj
texts.text: Also, the second point is interesting. The urban development model in China is based on increasing density in  cities, which is better also in terms of environmental factors. This means that that the cities will be built so that  there are buildings are close to each other, and the buildings are high, and also the [ph] suburban (19:38) open  areas will be built based on a similar architect. We also – it is also good to remember that the residential market in  China is about 60% of the total elevator and escalator market.

texts.speaker: Matti Alahuhta
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, KONE Oyj
texts.text: About the Chinese urban consumption, it is estimated that the high middle class will – consumption that  represented some 20% last year will grow to 56% in 2022. This naturally also means that, let's say, more than  residential buildings are needed more and more.

texts.speaker: Matti Alahuhta
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, KONE Oyj
texts.text: And indeed, a stock of existing buildings is required to rebuild as the buildings don't meet today's urban  development needs. And again, many of these old buildings that have been built before year 2000, they don't have  elevators and the new buildings will have elevators. There is also a code which requires that that all buildings that  are higher than 11 floors have to have two elevators at least.

texts.speaker: Matti Alahuhta
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, KONE Oyj
texts.text: The – and here, I have three important comments. First of all, we launched in June a revolutionary innovative  KONE UltraRope hoisting technology, and it – this story has two different kind of past. First of all, this hoisting  technology enables now single elevator rides that go up to 1 kilometer. It is quite obvious that there will not be a  huge number of buildings that will be so high or even – even close – close to that level. But for the – for  considering the business, the big thing is that with this technology, we have got a very strong competitive strength  in all buildings that are 150 meters or higher. These include lower energy consumption, lower space requirements,  longer lifetimes, lower lifetime costs, faster installation, and also lower sensitive to building s way in high  buildings. And this, of course, is significant, because number of – these kind of opportunities is quite significant  both in the new equipment markets as well as in the case of modernization markets.

texts.speaker: Matti Alahuhta
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, KONE Oyj
texts.text: The third point relates to escalators. We are also – our business has been developing well. Now, we have a new  escalator offering, which also has a lower energy consumption and versatile design options. A lot of different  design options that represent the same design language than our visual design to our elevators, whi ch I am very  pleased with, as well.

file: KNEBV - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 18July2014 845 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: Another important event is that, during the quarter, we were ranked as the 12th greenest company in the world by  Newsweek who did a big survey together with Corporate Knights. So we're 12th overall in the world. And if you  look at the manufacturing sector, we were the third greenest company in the world. And I think this shows and is a  result of the consistent work we've been doing on our – developing our sustainability.

texts.speaker: Henrik Ehrnrooth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Kone Oyj
texts.text: And we can see also that as part of our sustainability, that in 2013, our carbon footprint from our operations  relative to our sales declined by 3.5%. And that is a following on of a consistent improvement we have had each  year in our carbon footprint performance. So that's the continuation of a good performance. And, I would say,  both of these events that we highlighted here are very much a result of the systematic development we have had  over our competitiveness.

texts.text: So first of all, here the focus is again on how we can strengthen our competitiveness in the key growth markets,  and that we have done again during the first half of the year. It brings all of KONE's strength  in this product with ride comfort, with energy efficiency.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you then look at the market in various parts of China, how it's developing, as we have discussed before, the  situation in Tier 1 and many Tier 2 cities continues to be good. In fact, if we look at the inventory levels overall in  Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities, they are at very healthy levels. I think we are, overall, if you look at Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities,  at the lowest inventory levels for about seven years. So the markets continuing to be healthy, growth is spreading  more to Tier 2 and some Tier 3 cities now as a result of the cooling measures that the government has taken in  Tier 1 cities.

texts.text: Let's move on to overland, the market of that business unit, the overland market showed a moderate growth of 1%  to 2% in Europe, and in North America growth of 2% to 3%. The market was heavily impacted by the oil price or  the diesel price as well as the high capacity offering, and thus the rate dilution. We managed a stormy  environment well. We improved our net turnover in constant currencies by 3.9%. We increased the g ross profit,  and we were able, through the acquisition of ReTrans, to improve our footprint in North America in the  intermodal and also e-commerce sector.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As Detlef already said, airfreight does the paradox thing to grow volumes, and actually grow profitability at the  same time, I think in that market environment with very subdued growth even more remarkable.

texts.speaker: Detlef A. Trefzger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: On slide 7, we will start to go into more details with regard to the Seafreight and Airfreight business. Our focus has been very much on cost control, you will see details later. And we have seen  exceptional growth in LCL and reefer. In LCL, we have reached 2 million cubic meters transported in our networks  last year, and in reefer we have seen a 25% growth year-over-year last year.

texts.speaker: Detlef A. Trefzger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: This is unprecedented. We haven't seen that in any industry in such a short period before. So we were able to  partly compensate the margin pressure by efficiency gains and cost reductions, CHF 10 per TEU reduced cost  over the year 2017. And we have launched and seen strong volume growth in our products like KN FreshChain,  the reefer business as I mentioned before with 25% growth, and LCL shipments with more than 2 million cubic  meters transported in 2017. So, our solutions have shown traction with our customers and in our network.

texts.speaker: Detlef A. Trefzger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: Also here, industry solutions, quite a lot of traction, the KN BatteryChain, the solution that we launched for lithium  batteries at the IAA, the Frankfort Motor Show in September last year, was well received and we have a lot of  customers using this [indiscernible] (00:14:26) good solution with certification and very optimized quality-oriented  supply chain for their battery solutions.

texts.speaker: Detlef A. Trefzger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: And KN PharmaChain, our strong business across all business units we mentioned this year in Airfreight,  because we have certified last year 88 locations with the CEIV IATA certification. So, all those locations in the  Airfreight pharma network are IATA certified and lead the CEIV standards, the first one in our industry. We were  the first provider that were able to certify the pharma network in such a way. So, these are the developments in  Seafreight and Airfreight in 2017.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: I know we're going to talk about – when the line is going to be open for questions, we're going to talk about GP  per TEU and GP per 100 kilo and what is the conversion rate, and probably we will get questions around what is  the conversion rate of the Seafreight business in three years from now and all these details that obviously we may  or may not be able to answer.

file: KNIN - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 27February2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Detlef A. Trefzger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: Let's continue going through the different business units. Slide 4, a short overview sea and airfreight, and then we  go as usual through the volume development as well as the unit GP cost and EBIT development.

texts.speaker: Detlef A. Trefzger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: The airfreight business unit has been seeing acquisitions being implemented and integrated into our organization.  And they enhance performance and the delivery of growth, but not only also our operational organical growth has  been very strong. The success of our industry solutions and you know that we have launched KN BatteryChain  and KN InteriorChain last year, was extremely positive. So the take-up of those solutions by our customers and  the volume put through our networks based on this integrated solutions was extremely well perceived and  positive.

texts.speaker: Detlef A. Trefzger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: Let's continue on page 10 with airfreight. Obviously, we have more perishables in our network and usually, you  would expect that the perishables in the network have and generate a much lower yield, which was the case. But  here, the strong yield effect or the strong yield in our hot cargo – classical hot cargo business clearly offset the  mix effect that we generated through increasing the volume – the perishable volumes in our network.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: Out of that addressable volume, our aim is depending on the business unit, seafreight a bit less, airfreight a bit  more, to convert around 20% to 40% of this addressable volume into executed eTouch shipments. That will  clearly drive conversion rate up.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: Page number 20, what is it? When you look at the page, we have tried to use a couple of symbols – commonly  used symbols around supply chain to demonstrate in which areas of supply chain we are active. And for each of  the business units that we have seen, in the sea and in the airfreight area, we have put a couple of numbers  together, which are for illustrative purposes based on today's volume.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: So, when we say the addressable volume in seafreight is around 20%, so we will then be able to convert, let's  say, 10% to 20% of the addressable volume into fully automated. So out of the total volume, we talk today, let's  say around 250,000 TEUs that will be executed with a 60% to 80% conversion rate. This same calculation on the  airfreight side, we will talk around 400,000 tons today that would be operated under full eTouch 60% to 80%  conversion rate.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: In relation to our today's volume, for airfreight, well, 400,000 tons out of 1.7 million, that is like 25%, right? It's like  20%. So this is the magnitude of what we aim for by the year 2022. Is that going to be a linear way to get to that  point? Most likely not. Automation and technology will be put in place side-by-side on a process, process journey.  That means only when processes are linked up together, then we will be able to cover various steps within our  shipment execution in an automated way.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: So today and I'm being very simplistic on this, today, when we operate these shipments with that kind of gross  profit in our existing operational model, we will generate 30% conversion rate. So 30% plus 60%, we will make  CHF 20 EBIT. Yes, we know that. All of us do that. The industry does not only leave out of high value-added  services. But these are the shipments where we are going to target instead of making CHF 20 per shipment, we  want to do CHF 50. And that is where our whole work is going to go to that we have an incremental EBIT per TEU  of CHF 33 in my model or doubling the conversion rate versus the average to that. Same conversation of  airfreight and I know that there is already some questions out there, why is it in airfreight, the gross profit per 100  kilo in the average the same as in the addressable volume?

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: Very simple, because the addressable volume in airfreight is far more around the mix of not specific, specific  meaning perishables, pharma, chain solutions as Detlef has alluded to, it's far more in the general mix cargo  included, where we see the addressable volume. Hence, there, our leverage will be, again, from 30-ish  percentage conversion rate, today into 60% to 80%.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: So now, it should be relatively straightforward when we look into the volume section and the financials around it to  figure out what is the ambition and what is the impact on the financial model on the sea and airfreight.

texts.speaker: Markus Blanka-Graff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kühne + Nagel International AG
texts.text: Talking about working capital, page number 25. I think we are still within the corridor that we have given ourselves  for working capital intensity between 3.5% and 4.5%. We are at 4.1%. You can see there is an increase  compared to a year before. Where does the increase come from? DSOs, I think we have been able to defend, if  you like, to work very well with the customers to have different solutions in place, not to have much longer  extended payment terms, but on the DPO side, very clearly two components that were driving a higher – or  shorter DPOs by around 7.5 days. One is the over-proportional growth compared to sea and airfreight of contract  logistics, which leads to receivables, but no payables other than if you consider payroll as a payable. So payroll  doesn't have payment terms. Unfortunately, it needs to be paid on a monthly basis.
