texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, this is a good visibility picture and as you can see also the new orders are coming in the offshore area. We've  talked about the order situation many times, when it – when you break it down to KPIs, 1.33 in so-called book-to- bill which means that we've built quite significant backlog this quarter and I also mention on the first page 1.19  book-to-bill in the merchant business. So, a good disability and this drilling segment, the LNG segment and the  OSV segment, which are the main contributors to this.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: There are now more than 60 drilling rigs with KM Full Picture equipment onboard in our backlog and there were  16 of these that we are contracted in also – in the first quarter. And as you can see, it is South Korea, China and  Singapore which are the main areas for our contract so far. And we dare to say, that our systems and our Full  Picture solution here is their preferred solution in the marketplace for this particular segment. And you can see our  definition of a Full Picture is what you see here, dynamic positioning, thruster control, automation systems,  navigation, acoustic underwater positioning and safety systems and also riser management systems which  actually is a product that is delivered from oil and gas business to the clients in Kongsberg Maritime. So this is the  highlights for KM. Good start on the year, good visibility, fantastic order intake.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, you'll get a little bit shifting EBITDA from quarter to quarter. So I guess, we'll continue to see that for Oil & Gas  as long as the softer part of that business is about half of the totality. I'll come back to this also.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Let me start by saying the following, Kongsberg is heavily involved in the oil and gas business. About NOK 6  billion of our total revenues are related to oil and gas and oil services. However, the majority of this a few years  back, all of it was related to what we can call the maritime part oil and gas which means our customers  predominantly, the ship owners, the vessel owners and the yards and some companies that are on there, in that  cluster. What we wanted to do a couple of years back? We wanted to use the muscle, the technology expertise of  Kongsberg to develop and position also in different parts of the oil and gas value chain. Working with systems and  products and solutions for oil companies and major contractors around the oil companies in the E&T phase.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So we decided then to develop a strategic unit, start a strategic unit which we called Kongsberg Oil & Gas  Technologies. Some entities from the then Kongsberg Maritime were moved over and we have had some bolt-on  acquisitions and done significant turnaround and positioning on that business over the time since. So that is  where we are at today. So the business today in KOGT is two legs. This is where we stand today. We are  continuing to develop on this basis. But these two legs are very solid and very interesting. And I'll come a little bit  back to them, it's subsea products and solutions related to a unique expertise in certain engineering fields and  products that we have brought forward based on that expertise, pipeline, psoriasis, subsea components and on  the one hand. And on the other hand, it is related to what we have a lot of familiarity with in other parts of all oil  group which is advanced decision support systems for operators and management. This is of course something  that is very visible in Kongsberg Maritime. It is very visible in our defense side, decision support systems, it's a  vital part of what Kongsberg is doing.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Trying to look at it from a little bit different angle, you can see here the phases of [ph] a (00:26:12) field, a drilling  phase, field development installation and also production and you can see some of what we're doing in these  different phases. For example, in the drilling phase, about 18% in 2012 of the revenues, decision support  systems, management information systems for the drilling management, for operations of drilling processes. It's  the predominant product there.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: In the field development which is about half of the business, as you can see, engineering services and products  and solutions for subsea. I'll come a little bit back to that as well. Installation, very much today, our business is  centered around flexible rises and riser management systems i.e. the drilling market or the drilling contractors. On  the production side, our decision support systems again are focused on process optimization, multi-phase flow,  flow assurance, optimization of the production of the field.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We are located as of again 2012, it look like this about 45% in the Norwegian continent itself, North America and  Australia are also significant parts of our business now. If you take one of the two legs, break that a little bit down,  this is what we're doing; we are involved in early phase engineering for oil companies typically looking at – quality  architecture on the seafloor, predominantly related to the pipelines and the risers, flow assurance, designing the  overall picture together with our clients. During project execution, the typical deliveries from KOGT are structures  and systems for subsea riser, pipeline products and some process engineering. And there are some registered  and the patented products which Nemo brought into the picture and when we bought Nemo, which are very well  suited to the rest of the Kongsberg portfolio and we have high expectations for this combination here.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And what is characterizing our delivery here in this area is we're basing everything we do on open IT standards  which enables the operator, our customers and their contractors again to integrate much more effectively in the  total data sharing system, i.e. something that is needed for a [ph] program (00:29:34) management information  system. This has not been the case always in the oil industry where the major players in the oil industry have  proprietary systems for data management. And we are working with some of the biggest oil companies in the  world now to bring together sort of the new generation open standards here. So, therefore, all our systems are  based on open architecture allowing easy interfacing with third-party systems. So, that's a common denominator.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, that's the course in Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies, finishing off my presentation. And with that, we are  opening up for questions. Please.

file: KOG - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 13May2014 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And finally, Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies, this quarter being a disappointment to us, that's fair to say. It's a  small unit, still under development and has been hit by some of the trends in that particular market segment, Oil &  Gas. Come back to that later. That also we have implemented a recovery plan already. And I'll also mention that  later on.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We talked about the disappointing start of the year in Oil & Gas. Of course, Oil & Gas is a small and vulnerable  unit, a little bit more than NOK 1 billion in revenues. And of course, when two to three Subsea projects in that unit  is either cancelled, as we experienced on the [indiscernible] (00:26:12) decrease in scope or seriously postponed,  that hits a small unit like this. So, that's what we've been seeing now.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, we'll make one point more here. This business area, the Oil & Gas business area, we are investing twice as  much money, relatively speaking, in R&D and product development here than the three other business areas. So  that reflects the fact that this is still something that is being built up. And we are continuing these investments  even in the next quarters in 2014, particularly related to some advanced software systems, which we are seeing a  very interesting development for in the marketplace, but also some specialized Subsea solutions. And we should  be able to talk about later when they get a little bit more mature.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And finally then, Kongsberg Protech Systems delivered its last station on the CROWS II contract now. 11,698  stations have been delivered on the CROWS II program, representing a total turnover of NOK 15 billion for  Kongsberg in the lifespan of that frame agreement.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: First of all, in the Maritime Oil & Gas business seen from our side, obviously, there is a clear cost cut pressure in  the oil and gas industry which is having many interesting effects. First and foremost what we read about in the  papers and what we've also seen ourselves we read about in the papers and what we've also seen in ourselves is  that contracts are being stopped or cancelled or postponed, but there are many other effects also. The call for  new technology and also the call for new execution models by the oil companies is very clear which opens up for  new entrants and possibilities for new entrants.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Remotely operating Subsea fields for example is an area we are heavily engaged in the early phases of  development technology forward, environmental protection or monitoring systems, as well as continuing to  develop our software systems with one aim to help the oil companies to reduce downtime, particularly during  drilling operation and also to help the oil companies to improve and optimize production from already producing  fields. This is the opportunities that the big data revolution offers the oil and gas industry much, much better  decision support systems, predictive decision support systems, which again increases the uptime when you are  doing drilling for example. So, we see some clear opportunities here, which is driving our strategic thinking, cost  pressure in the oil industry.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: The other part which is kind of interesting to reflect upon is that we know a lot more on this planet about what  happens outside the planet itself in the universe, in our solar system than what we know about what happens  down under the sea surface, very little over sea bottom of the ocean, so this will have actually been mapped, if  you take the Arctic area, 7% of that has been mapped. Comparing that to the need for energy resources, subsidy  and the need for minerals and the need for management of the resources of the oceans, i.e. fish.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Reducing fuel consumption, more intelligent sailing routes, better weather forecasting, optimizing a fleet rather  than each individual vessel, managing the whole fleet from shore, communication between the components of the  fleet and shore, use of big data, again predictive management of the vessels. All these things are helping to  reduce the OpEx for the ship owner.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And finally, the Offshore part, I mentioned that. It will remain a strong component of our business. Everything that  has to do with oil and gas, floating oil and gas, so to speak. And, we are seeing that although the mix is changing,  we will continue to have a very large component of our business related to Offshore Oil & Gas operations.  Kongsberg Maritime part of the scope. We are expanding our scope there.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So what we did, we launched together with the university, a program called YOUR EXTREME where our job is to  make it clear to the students during the first two years that if you stay on, if you really come over this first two  years hurdle, this is what you will do as a professional engineer if you come to Kongsberg, to try and throw it a  little bit more in practical terms. So we are continuing this program this year together with NTNU. It's called YOUR  EXTREME. And it is actually starting today, being launched in Trondheim today together with Kongsberg being  the main sponsor for the biggest or the fastest electrical car in the world It's a program called [ph] Evolve  (00:43:30) where we are sponsoring students, 46 students building a car that will participate in the global  competition, how to drive furthest with the least use of energy. So this is being launched today...

file: KOG - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 30April2015 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans-Jørgen Wibstad
texts.profession: Group Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Going forward, of course, Kongsberg Oil & Gas, which is by far the smallest business area, is facing some  challenges. But we will see more of the challenges as they orb in the second half of 2015. But we're expecting a  reasonable year at the end of – for 2015 for Kongsberg Oil & Gas technologies.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We have market leading solutions. We are the market leader in merchant and in subsea and in offshore. We have  obviously strengthened our business, the segment which we call Kongsberg Maritime Engineering which is our  EPC contracts related to electrical, instrument and telecom. And you might have seen yesterday that we  announced an FPSO contract in West Africa where we are doing a complete EPC project, all engineering,  integration engineering, all electrical, all instrumental, [indiscernible] (16:50) equipment and telecom. And this is  quite interesting and another win for us in this area. So we're strengthening our position as an EPC niche, EPC  provider here.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Our 24/7 lifecycle services is the backbone of our customer relationship because that's where our relationship or  services meet the ultimate owner of all the projects we are doing, namely the operator or the ship owner. So this  diversification that we have worked at and been very focused on for quite some time is leading us into many  application areas, and I wanted to share with you one of these application areas, which is quite interesting and  has become much more interesting which is an example, among many, in Kongsberg where we take technology  we have and apply this to an area which you not automatically would think that we were involved in. And this is  related to sustainable fisheries and Kongsberg is a world leader in fishing technology. And I wanted to share with  you a little bit around these things and have a look at this.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So the main technologies related to this is our echosounder technology and sonar technology. 2014 was about  NOK 350 million, we're approaching NOK 400 million in this. And obviously, this is an area which is growing. And  you can see that most of it is actually related to refits rather than equipment going out to new builds. So this is a  typical product which goes on to existing vessels. And more than 80% of the biomass estimation, which is the  basis for the quarters is done by Kongsberg Simrad. And we've decided to maintain the old longstanding brand  name. This goes all the way back to [indiscernible] (20:24) in 1947.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So obviously, it's contained on two separate entities, one working with subsea solutions and the other one with  software solutions. And the software solutions had a very slow start for 2015 as well. But obviously, again, will  come into play as soon as the oil companies stabilizes their view on IT investments.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: The same is actually – the same I could say for Kongsberg Defence System. Very good visibility, very good  activity level in 2015, a robust platform. And we expect the KPS business level, all activity level to increase in  2015, adjusted in terms of order intake. And we expect to manage the oil and gas business as we get more  information in Q2 and Q3. We will see how that will – what that will result in. We will manage the capacity to fit the  orders that we have.

texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA

This is an example which we're going to launch now during ONS, the oil and gas exhibition in Stavanger.

texts.speaker: Geir Håøy
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: If you are in Stavanger, I invite you to [ph] our stand (19:00). I believe this – I think this is a very exciting system.  It's a unique concept for all ocean-going – more or less all ocean-going vessels where we combine the operation,  handling and energy. So, you're all welcome to the stand next week.

texts.speaker: Geir Håøy
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: They have signed two small, but very important contracts in KDI in the second quarter. One with Statoil and the  second one with Statkraft, where we're going to deliver management system and power for these windmill  projects. So, full focus from Kongsberg Digital now, as I say, get the digital solutions out in the markets.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA

OIG is our partner in this, and we are working with them to go to the market with  this.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: FPSOs, which we are very enthusiastic about and we think this is a very interesting market. We are trying to grab  an important part of the work related to these FPSOs that are awarded. texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Second thing I'd like to mention is that the so called eBird concept that we've worked on for quite some time is  evolving and is scaling up now. It is a device which is  attached to the streamer, to the seismic cable behind a seismic vessel, and which is keeping this cable in position  laterally, vertically and in terms of roll which is then keeping the spread much more stable, increasing the quality  of the seismic work and also making the turning more efficient. So, this is a very important product for seismic  operators. And this is a part then of the PGS GeoStreamer concept.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA

The first one is related to satellite data services for the next generation of weather stations, or –  and the second one is related to the environmental and security monitoring. So, these are interesting, and it gives  a little hint of how this market is evolving.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, the CROWS III frame agreement for us was a strategic win, which confirms our position as a leading  worldwide provider on this type of Remote Weapon Station solutions.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: What you saw here was oil spill essentially. But the interesting thing and what I want to communicate with this  little video movie here is the change and the increased attention that offshore operations is now getting in terms of  being able to document that the environmental side is within the approved limits. So what we're seeing is that oil  companies in a greater and greater degree will have to demonstrate advanced systems in order to get and maintain  the license to operate, particularly of course, in Arctic areas or in sensitive areas. But this is, as you've seen many  times before, it starts in the North Sea and then it evolves in other areas and other waters in the world.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, I'll show you another one, which is a little bit of the same. And what we see here is down below. What we just  saw was a satellite business, satellites monitoring oil spill services. And what we see here is what it looks like on a  seabed. And this is a drilling operation and what you can see here is debris from the drilling. And in many waters  in the world, there is coral reefs and sensitive organisms close to a drilling and offshore operation. And it is a  requirement in several places already, particularly in – starting in Australia that you shall be able to demonstrate  that you're not affecting in a negative way the life and the corals around the operation.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: What we are doing is that we are working on projects and also developing new concepts where we are integrating  knowledge and expertise from the whole group, our defence side, our satellite side, our offshore side and maritime  side in building overall systems where the oil companies can actually monitor on a real-time basis this  development.

file: KOG - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 31October2014 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: The two smaller business areas have both had a challenging quarter. Kongsberg Protech Systems because of  low volumes and some other factors, we'll explain that later on. And Kongsberg Oil & Gas which is as we've  reported before, in a transition period, and we're continuing that also in this quarter here. And on top of that, of  course in the oil industry, we are also facing some new challenges there.

texts.speaker: Hans-Jørgen Wibstad
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: On KOGT, Oil & Gas, is actually delivering a positive EBITDA. We're happy with that. However, that is due to one- off effects. So, Oil & Gas or Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies division is impacted by what has happened in the  oil and gas sector in the last few months with lower activity level. And also, what we've seen also in other  businesses and other companies which has had an impact on the significantly lower oil price than we saw in the  first two quarters of this year.

texts.speaker: Hans-Jørgen Wibstad
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: In Oil & Gas, Kongsberg Oil & Gas has a negative EBITDA of NOK 45 million for the full nine months despite a  positive result in the third quarter. But that's also due to the restructuring that we saw in the first half and with the  existing state of the oil and gas markets, they are having challenges also. So, we are expecting that the  underlying EBITDA for Oil & Gas also for the fourth quarter will be negative.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And I'd like to take one little snapshot of this one here, which is as you know AUV, autonomous underwater  vehicles, which is an area where we have over the last few years built up a leading position. This is one of a  family of vehicles like this, HUGIN, MUNIN, REMUS, and SEAGLIDER, and we are the leading in this area. And  this is actually a platform for our also world leading products related to hydroacoustic and sonars which are  mounted on vessels like this.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Why am I showing this? This is an interesting example how conservative the oil and gas business is. Now, we  have started to work with these vessels, inspecting pipeline for the oil industry – for the oil companies. We are  doing this four to six times faster with this than with the traditional ROV business. On top of that, this technology  allows the operators to use much smaller vessels on the sea surface and thereby also saving money that way.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And on top of this, the quality of this inspection is much, much better. So this technology has been available for  years. Now, the oil industry is beginning to use it. And I think, the oil industry needs to revise their thinking if they  really want to meet the cost challenge ahead. It has to deal with the conservatism, it has to deal with traditions  and not the least, procurement procedures, which are far too elaborate and preventing the industry from taking  this type of technology into use.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: But with that said, we were happy that we landed the first contract and this one is in Brazil. We are doing it also  now in the Gulf of Mexico and also gradually in the North Sea. Just an example of many, many technologies that  are out there that the oil industry needs to take and to use much, much faster.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Oil & Gas, somewhat more worrisome. It's a small, vulnerable area. It's the smallest business area we have,  about NOK 1 billion in revenues. And it's still vulnerable. As we said before, we had a bad start of the year. We  implemented actions, they are delivering results and while we are doing that, the market is changing even more.  So, what we're seeing now is a great deal of uncertainty in the oil companies in the procurement and responsible  areas in the oil companies, which has delayed some projects. And we have to adapt to that, so we are  implementing further actions.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Again, the paradox is what we, Kongsberg, are delivering in this business area are solutions that are cutting costs  for the oil companies. Half of cost for Oil & Gas Technology is software and services. The products and the  services we deliver there are significantly taking down downtime during drilling and optimizing production results.  So the paradox is that with the uncertainty we have in the market now, the decision processes take longer and  this is hitting us a little bit. But we have no worries in terms of that these are some of our jewels actually, in the  long run, when it comes to what we can contribute to the oil and gas industry with.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So you can see here, 353 students, 83 teams competed, they have 48 hours to deliver a response to a very  challenging task, namely, how do you deal with a super environmental catastrophe in Trondheim. How do you  deal with it pre, during and post the event? And the amazing results that came out of that, you should have seen  it. Worthy winners.

file: KOG - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 30October2015 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have been working on some significant contracts all over the group, but in particular on the de fense side. And  then, at the same time, we are seeing that on – the low investment levels that we are experiencing in the oil and  gas industry, which we believe will last for quite some time, is gradually also impacting those segments in the  group that are providing services to the oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, we are seeing this and we are proactively meeting this situation in terms of adapting to the changes that this  industry is facing. In particular, it has to do with our changes in our product mix, putting togethe r products and  systems in different place to meet different demands, using the competence we have to follow the opportunities in  the industry. But it also has to do with adjusting capacity and preparing the capacity for what we believe will be  coming in the oil and gas industry.

texts.speaker: Hans-Jørgen Wibstad
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Kongsberg Oil & Gas, seeing its revenue base coming down quite substantially, 39% lower than Q3 2014, and  basically representing the run rate that we're now seeing at Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies, maybe even  slightly one notch lower than we saw in Q3, as we are in Q3 ending a couple of large project, including Polarled  with Statoil, which was the very important substantial contract we received some time ago.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, Kongsberg Maritime, in essence, is also quite diversified. Obviously, the offshore part is seeing a very  challenging market. We still work on offshore oil and gas-related products for quite some time. But we are seeing,  of course, the yard contracting at a level going significantly down, which sooner or later also will have an impact  on parts of our business in the offshore side of it.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: When we talk about the merchant part of Kongsberg Maritime, that is the services and products we provide to the  merchant fleet, it's a somewhat and much more positive picture actually. We have, over the last few years, changed  our products and renewed and improved our products, which has led to a higher market share per vessel, and  we're continuing to do so. And we're seeing, as it says there, demand for greener solutions, more effective  solutions. And in the LNG/LPG segment, we are also seeing quite significant demand.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The remote tower solution will contribute to make air traffic control even safer than it is today, something the  Minister of Transport and Communications certainly values.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then to Oil & Gas Technologies, Hans-Jørgen mentioned that this has been a very tough and demanding  period for them, actually starting last year and continuing in this year, and we're seeing that we are still not  through it 100%, but we are getting to a level where we see that a sustainable basis. Gradually, it's in place. We are  changing the structures and also the product mix to reflect more than new market situation and, of course, as we  have talked about had to reduce the capacity in the organization. Then also reduce some of th e international  offices that we have here.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: It is a pity that the oil industry does not see through the full extent that many of the products that we are  providing from this business area actually are the type of progress that the oil industry really needs  in order to  reduce costs. It will come back, but at the current investment levels, we're seeing that oil companies are refraining,  to a large extent, from contracting some of the IT solutions that we are providing from this business.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The idea here is that many of the software solutions that Oil & Gas is providing are actually meeting the future  demand of, also here, a much more digitalized oil industry. And through that better data processing, better  analysis, better decision-making, better forewarning of wear and tear in machinery and all these will reduce costs  significantly, and that's exactly what our solutions are delivering. So, we have still belief in what this will mean in  the future, but we'll have to live through a very demanding cycle just now.

texts.text: So, just to give you some easier examples on that, that could be production optimalization. texts.profession: President-Kongsberg Digital, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, here is another example where you see this [ph] has evolved (00:09:30), and what we see here is that we  have an issue with the gas-lift valve. So, what you see is that the target is 50%, but the estimate now is that it's  only flowing by 10%, so what do we need to do with that? And then, the recommendation comes up for – within  the SAP system that we need to [ph] exchange (00:09:53) the gas-lift valve to get this up and running again. texts.speaker: Hege Skryseth
texts.profession: President-Kongsberg Digital, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, we believe that in the future, we will see more and more oil and gas operations operated from remote  operating centers onshore. And it's also, of course, the ability to construct differently and reduce costs in that perspective.

texts.speaker: Hege Skryseth
texts.profession: President-Kongsberg Digital, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And then, we are looking into the maintenance side, which is of [ph] significance (00:13:09) and of course, to  prevent any downturn of the field. So hopefully, that gave you a peek into what we're working on on digital twin.  We're working not only on the oil and gas operations, but also on wind turbines and wind farms, which we see this  drive significant effect. And as I mentioned, we are working in different projects both in Norway and  internationally. And please have a look at this.

texts.speaker: Egil Haugsdal
texts.profession: President, Kongsberg Maritime AS
texts.text: Yeah. Kongsberg Maritime is to have a broad portfolio of product within the maritime industry. We are very well  established within the merchant market. When it comes to oil, we are in all parts of the business from seismic  offshore vessels, drilling, production, we are all in. The more difficult it is, the higher market shares we have. So  we are really a high-end supplier. We typically deliver the intelligent part of the systems. Also worth mentioning,  sensors and robotics is quite a significant part of our business. We have unique living products, which seems also  to be quite a growing market.

texts.speaker: Egil Haugsdal
texts.profession: President, Kongsberg Maritime AS
texts.text: We are moving around on these bubbles. Last year we had offshore market here in – still on the way down. Our  reading today is that it's picking up. We don't believe in the new build market for the next maybe two or three  years, but it will come back to a better level, probably never to the level it used to be, I hope not, because that  was way too much, but it's picking up and especially on the operational side. As the oil company is increasing  their operations, the activity is going up, which is supporting their global customer support part of our business.

texts.speaker: Egil Haugsdal
texts.profession: President, Kongsberg Maritime AS
texts.text: This contract we took on $18 million, which is about NOK 140 million. That is a consequence of the triangle  projects where we do also the power part of it, the power management. So, we are expanding the scope.

texts.speaker: Egil Haugsdal
texts.profession: President, Kongsberg Maritime AS
texts.text: Now, I think we've proven that we are able to change and we will change that organization, and we will make this  very healthy and good organization for the future. We always respected Rolls-Royce a lot. They have been  working in the same market as we have. They really have top quality products. They have – it's substance. I've  been around now and met a lot of people, and I've seen a lot of locations. There is really – it's really product, it's  really customers, and it's very significant installed base. And as this oil and gas activity is picking up, to be there  with mechanical parts who is operating in saltwater, the after-sale business overall for us will become extremely  attractive. And we can see this changing as we speak.

file: KOG - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 10February2012 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans-Jørgen Wibstad
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So then just finally, let me summarize some of the key figures for Kongsberg Group on a consolidated basis for  2011; EBITDA of NOK2.4 billion; EBITA of NOK2.1 billion; margin 14.1%; earnings before tax just above NOK2  billion. Equity ratio has increased on the back of the good results from – to 35.1%. We had talked about a good  order intake of almost 1-to-1, actually 0.99, reflecting that our revenues is more or less the same as our order  intake, which is quite satisfactory in a challenging global economic climate. Earnings per share NOK11.93, a  moderate increase – decrease from 2010. So I think in summary, on a consolidated basis, Kongsberg has had a  very solid year in 2011 which will provide a very good foundation, both operationally and financially, going into  2012.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And there are some contracts up here mentioned. Of course it is – we are signing thousands of contracts every  year in Kongsberg Maritime, some big but very many small ones. So, only few ones mentioned here would  particularly highlight the FPSOs where we are having a very high value creation on our part, and also on the LNG  side where we are delivering a lot of equipment and systems to the owners. So, that was Kongsberg Maritime.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We have also talked about last time we had the presentation what we are thinking about and what we are doing on  the space side. We acquired Norspace, a space company in Horten. And we are looking at an interesting  combination of competencies in our group in this respect, again opening up some new opportunities for us. Of  course, the Polish contract here was very important because that expanded the delivery that we already have there  for the coastal artillery system quite significantly.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Some other updates; just mention one particular product – or project. You may have seen that we in November  signed a very interesting contract with Statoil. This is Kongsberg, which is leading a consortium with DNV and  IBM. We are working with Statoil to develop what is called Integrated Environmental Monitoring System. This is  – has never been done before but you will see more of it in the future. This is for oil companies that are operating  in difficult – environmentally speaking, difficult areas that needs to take the responsibility of monitoring the  environmental impact of what they are doing throughout the life of the production, from seismic to  decommissioning. So, this is a multiyear program, and we will, together with Statoil, develop a methodology  which I'm sure will be delivered to other oil companies in other parts of the world as we go forward.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Just to mention a few things; final comment is really acquisition of Evotec. As you remember, we made that  acquisition last year. We have opened up offices in [ph] Olson and Molde (34:13). Last year, we also opened office  – specific Oil & Gas office in Bergen and also in Stavanger. So, things are happening in Norway as well.

file: KOG - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 8February2013 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: In the Oil & Gas portfolio, we have made two small or midsize acquisitions in this quarter. It's a software company,  specialized software company in India, in Bangalore, called Advali. And it is the engineering company, Nemo,  here in Oslo, which is expanding our oil and gas business in a very interesting way.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: In terms of LNG carriers and FPSO vessels, we've had high win rate and very interesting and solid projects all  through the year. The eBird concept, which we are working together with PGS on in the GeoStream (sic)  [GeoStreamer] (16:36) concept of PGS, are now coming into a full-rate production phase, which is interesting,  both for our business in Trondheim, where this is invented, and also our business in Kongsberg where important  portions in titanium for this eBird product is being produced.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Hydroacoustic and subsea instrumentation solutions are increasing in production. So, we have had to extend our  production facilities to meet the market need in Horten in particular. And the final point which has been already  addressed which is the supplier bankruptcy and the problematic projects that we have struggled with, in the  offshore area, in Kongsberg Maritime all through 2012 has been very disappointing to us with the losses we just  mentioned. Good news is the projects are now at their end. They have been completed. They are under full  control. And they're moving on from there and have learned a lot of lessons obviously. So that's KM.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: If you look at the other two main areas that we are in, it's the maritime industry and the offshore industry; also a  mixed picture in many ways. The offshore industry being extremely bullish and extremely demanding; this, we see  continuing. And our products are very well0suited for the needs. Harsh environment, deep waters, need for very  reliable equipment. You're seeing that in the order intake in Kongsberg Maritime so far, and we think this will  continue.

texts.speaker: Walter Qvam
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: When it comes to the merchant business, of course, that's a completely different picture. The need for seaborne  trade is still there, but there's been a too high buildup of vessels over the years, so there's overcapacity. This, we  think, will gradually continue to sink, but it will stabilize sometime maybe in 2013 and 2014 on the lower level in  terms of new builds. For us, this means that our business related to oil and gas and offshore will become even  more important in 2013 and beyond. So, in summary, largely, the same market as we had, say, half a year ago.

file: KOG - Q4 2013 Earnings Call Preliminary 7February2014 115 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Some highlights, I've already mentioned, all-time high activity level, a lot of Full Picture, as we call it, deliveries,  both the drilling units and LNG. In fact, our DP-systems in long periods in 2013, we delivered one DP-system  every single day. So that's a very, very high activity level.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We've also had a very interesting and promising development in our acoustic control systems, typically for  blowout preventers, how to remotely operate and control a blowout preventer. So sending signals and receiving  signals underwater is one of our key technologies, and this is also used then in the offshore business for, among  other things, blowout preventer control.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We announced in October a package of 15 offshore and LNG units with our Full Picture delivery in them. That  was a total value of NOK 400 million. And we have also announced a series of Full Picture deliveries to  containerships which is also very interesting. So, in summary, as Hans-Jørgen also said, a very good position in  KM for the time to go.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: It is HUGIN which we are making in Horten. It is REMUS which we are making in the United States. It is Seaglider  which is a new product which we have a license for now in the United States. And it is also Minesniper which is a  defense-related mine-destroying vessel. And then this one here which we are in the market with now very, very  shortly.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: The other very good contract that we recently announced was this, what we call Integrated Full Picture contract  for this huge vessel that you see here, the pipelaying vessel. And this is confirming the strategy that we talked  about before where we are combining our typical Full Picture deliveries with an EPC integrated engineering and  procurement contract on top of that.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Unfortunately, as we also reported a while back, Statoil decided to take out the Kristin part of the Polarled scope  which impacted our Polarled contract with approximately NOK 200 million less business. But still, the remaining  part of the Polarled contract for Kongsberg Oil & Gas is a significant and very good contract.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So we're still in the growth modus. We're still in the development modus in terms of our oil and gas business. It's  now NOK 1 billion plus in revenues, but our strategy remains. We are adding a new scope, adding new products  and we are expanding this business as we move on step by step.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: A little example to the right here. Just how we are able to shorten the work time for building an offshore power  management system by use of intelligent software, reducing the manpower requirements, shortening the time  from two weeks to one hour. So this is actually happening. That kind of process innovation, examples are now  being leveraged throughout the group. So important program.

file: KOG - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 6February2015 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And we're saying that we believe that [ph] defeated a little sort of (01:36) on the headline level, that the next 200  will be decided by actions that we and others are taking in the next 20. And the reason we are saying this is that  we believe that there are some major technology changes coming which will affect our industries but also other  industries and affect Norway for that matter. So I think as a technology company that is focused on innovation,  this is something that is really now meaningful to us to discuss in our strategic processes, which technologies will  change, what will our position be when it comes to climate technologies, energy and new materials, batteries and  remote technologies and robotics and things like that. Many of these technologies are very important to  Kongsberg already today. So that's why we're saying a little bit [ph] boldy (02:27) perhaps on the bottom here that  the next 20 is going to be extremely important.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And of course, as we all know, 2014 contained an earthquake of changes in the oil services industry and both on  the demand side and on the supply side. And as we have experienced, it's of course – we're seeing the two  phases, the first half of the year or maybe it was happening also in 2013. Actually, very much a cost cut drive  which then gradually also got another challenge on the table with the – which of course is the oil price situation.  And this has led to some effects in our business. We'll come back to that later on also.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: The oil services industry is then, as we see, moving into a shakeout phase. For us, this is both, of course, a  challenge, the market is a challenge but is also significant opportunities in terms of M&A and business  development that we are seeing coming up on the horizon which we'll be following very, very closely.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Climate issues are climbing on the agenda in terms of technology solutions, in terms of commercially viable  solutions and services. This is also important to us and to the oil and gas and the technology industry in general.

texts.speaker: Hans-Jørgen Wibstad
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Group EVP, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: KOGT as Walter talked about, had – was facing this massive change in the oil and gas market, also in the fourth  quarter with the lower oil price and its impact. So it had to go through another wave of restructuring. We had one  in the first half and then we had one in the second half. Impact earnings were NOK 25 million.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We communicated in our last quarterly presentation that we will do a deep dive into our organization. In particular,  we'll do it for all the businesses but in particular for oil and gas and maritime in April 2015 because we felt that, at  that time, which was a quarter ago, we felt that the market situation in oil and gas was very difficult to interpret.  And we wanted to see the start of 2015 and the effects on that on us before we made some more clear comments  to the situation.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And remember, this is only related to the traditional products in KPS, the RWS PROTECTOR suite. It is not yet  related to Medium Caliber. We told the market last quarter that we are now in the process in our first bidding  process. We have submitted bids for Medium Caliber, and there are several other campaigns going on. So I'm not  going to promise anything about when these are being landed, but at least now we are in the market with a  commercial product, Medium Caliber. And as we have said before, this product has a significant growth potential.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Oil & Gas, a painful year with necessary changes. We've talked about capacity reduction in two steps and  impairment and goodwill reduction. So painful but necessary, and we are now moving into 2015 with a capacity  and a structure which is more adaptive to the market that we see.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Just to remind you of what our small oil and gas entity is about. It's one portion which is delivering specialized  subsea solutions like tie-ins and pipe solutions and doing a analysis on risers and pipelines, engineering on  subsea systems and so on. And that one we had, through that part of the organization, we had to reduce the  capacity a little bit in the beginning of the year because of some cancellations of our projects.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And then, the other part is related to software and services. And what we've seen in the last part of the year is that  those kinds of investments, the oil companies have actually stopped them or pushed them back in time. So we've  seen quite a significant impact on our software and services business in oil and gas because of the investment  cuts by the oil companies. And here, we are dealing directly with the oil company and we are in the first line, so to  speak.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and CEO, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Oil & Gas, we are facing because we are here directly dealing with the oil companies in, as I said, we are facing a  challenging market here. And we have adjusted, we feel, the organization to meet what we see now in 2015. The  product portfolio and the service and solutions that we provide are interesting, and we will – and we're convinced  that, as we move through 2015, the situation will stabilize and we'll get more predictability in the way we deal with  our customers. And you can see, of course, in the full report for the outlook section there, the detailed wording for  this.

file: KOG - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 11February2016 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: I mentioned Kongsberg Digital, we'll launch that, I'll come back to that as well. And we are as a part of that, partly  driven by our decision to launch Kongsberg Digital. We are also reorganizing and restructuring our oil and gas  activities in KOGT and KM.

texts.speaker: Hans-Jørgen Wibstad
texts.profession: Group Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: KPS -- sorry KDS came in at about NOK 1.1 billion pretty stable over the last few quarters. KPS came in with  NOK 600 million for the quarter, which is actually the highest revenue level recorded in KPS since the fourth  quarter of 2013, showing that we – as we have communicated that activity level in KPS is picking up, and of  course the medium caliber contract, sorry the General Dynamics Medium Caliber project is not part of course of  the revenue yet. So, we're happy with that. And Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies that we will talk about later,  had a very low level of revenues NOK 129 million really, been strongly impacted by the reduced oil price and  reduced activity level in the oil and gas sector.

texts.speaker: Hans-Jørgen Wibstad
texts.profession: Group Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: The order book at the end of 2015 is only NOK 200 million lower than it was at the end of 2014, which I think is a  strong signal that Kongsberg Maritime has been very successful in the market. And it's an impressive  performance, given the status of one of its core market, i.e. the offshore oil and gas market.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: The Merchant business in Maritime is keeping up and the fisheries is growing. So this is a solid drive there. And  but the fact is, of course the oil and gas part of the portfolio in that business area is very weak as we all know, it's  also challenging Kongsberg Maritime as we move forward, hence also the restructuring and the capacity  adjustment measures that we're taking.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: And finally Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies has had a very difficult year in 2015 with two rounds of  restructuring, and what we've done there is we had taken many measures in order to narrow down the scope, and  also to make sure that we are maintaining the competence areas that are important to us. So, there has been, the  impact of the oil and gas market reduction has hit us hard in this particular business area. So, that's a short  review, some very important orders, I shared that with you. Of course, we could have picked maybe a 1000  orders, but these are orders – all of them are of a type which represent a growth potential in related orders and  the similar orders over the years to come.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Johan Sverdrup is a very important project to us, Kongsberg Maritime has a very strong involvement with that  project. And as we'll talk about in a minute, we are now consolidating our oil and gas resources under Kongsberg  Maritime because Kongsberg Maritime has built up also a quite significant team of engineering activities related to  oil and gas. So I will come back to that but [ph] we want to try to give (22:16) an example of that.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We have had a Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies, who has developed software and services, which becomes a  very important part of Kongsberg Digital, but also other areas. At the same time, Kongsberg Maritime has  significant expertise in the oil and gas sector. So we've decided to consolidate all the engineering capabilities we  have within the group related to the oil and gas sector under the management of Kongsberg Maritime.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So a success here, the software and services will be incorporated in Kongsberg Digital, the rest of the KOGT  businesses will be restructured and consolidated and incorporated in Kongsberg Maritime. And we've made this  decision also yesterday and this will also start the implementation – we will start the implementation of that now  and it will be completed during first half. But this means that we will resolve Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies as  a corporate entity on the business area, and then this will happen successfully during the first half.

texts.speaker: Walter Hafslo Qvam
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So from then on – and then on – or then on Kongsberg Maritime will represent also maritime as well the oil and  gas segments for the group. And we think this is giving us the opportunity to focus and strengthen and also to  make sure that we are not suffering from sub-critical engineering environments because we have reduced our  capacity in Kongsberg Oil & Gas Technologies with about 40% over the last couple of years.

file: KOG - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 8February2017 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Geir Håøy
texts.profession: President-Kongsberg Maritime, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: So, we are definitely ready to take the – take it into the next phase of that program. 2016 has been an eventful  year for Kongsberg. It has been an exciting year. We have seen the impact of the oil and gas, weak oil and gas  market, and particular the offshore side of it, resulting in a decrease of 70% of the group revenues.

texts.speaker: Geir Håøy
texts.profession: President-Kongsberg Maritime, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: Okay. Thank you, Hans-Jørgen. Yes. So, then, I will continue giving a more detail of the business update on the  business areas starting with the Kongsberg Maritime. As I said earlier, it has been a challenging year within the oil  and gas and offshore area, and that will continue also in Q4.

texts.speaker: Geir Håøy
texts.profession: President-Kongsberg Maritime, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: This is the new organization simplified a little bit, going from a kind of more market-oriented organization with the  divisional area, market area split to a more kind of functional organization. We have the vessel system which is  kind of more standardized merchant, simpler kind of type of vessels into EIT/EPC based solutions with our energy  part of it included. Subsea remains more or less as has been. And also global customer support should, then, of  course, cover the overall business areas.

texts.speaker: Geir Håøy
texts.profession: President-Kongsberg Maritime, Kongsberg Gruppen ASA
texts.text: We, as many others, expect weak oil and gas offshore market to continue in 2017. As I mentioned, the conceptual  solutions that was released autumn in 2016 for Kongsberg Maritime has been well received in the market. We see  a lot of interest in that kind of concept. That goes both for the traditional core, offshore core, but also for the more  Merchant Marine solutions, and also other type of vessels, such as [indiscernible] (25:06) and research vessels.  Despite that, we certainly believe that the revenue will decline also in 2017 compared to 2016.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Before we go to the results per segment within the Dutch Telco, I would like to have a look together  at our OpEx reductions relating to the Dutch Telco in recent years. So here we don’t take a quarter  – quarterly perspective, but look a few years back. We’ve received many compliments for reducing  OpEx, but also many questions on whether we could continue this trend.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And just to clarify the OpEx reductions are indicated in three categories represented by three  colors. The light blue refers to variable cost, light green to fixed variable and a mixture of cost, and  the dark green to fixed cost only. And as you can see all three categories have experienced cost  reductions during the past few years. And to answer a pressing question we expect this trend to  continue.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the light green category which refers to our internal staffing cost, here we’ve seen and are  planning to see reductions which are resulting from our simplification and improved quality of  service programs throughout the company.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And thirdly the dark green category reductions in fixed costs are eminent. And these reductions  include improved pricing, efficient use of suppliers, lower IT spend but also minimizing office space  and vacating buildings. And Solar, as a general concept, is something that’s certainly been on the rise in the  UK, not just in Solar Thermal but also in Solar Photovoltaics, which we’re seeing in our insulated  panels business. That didn’t really manage to counter the weakness on the Solar Thermal side in  mainland Europe. So, if you look back a couple of years we would have been expecting this  business to grow sustainably well into the future.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: It’s quite an incentive-linked end market and, as you might know, some of these incentives got  pulled in the German market during the course of the year and that became very evident directly  into the sales volumes of Solar Thermal into that market. So that has been weak, and since it was  the biggest part of this business it’s had a fairly pronounced effect, both on open sales and  obviously on operating profits in this overall business. But again, I would say, UK positive, Ireland  although very small it’s showing a very strong growth trend in Solar Thermal, and the building  blocks are well in place for, I would say, a very encouraging long-term future in the US market  where our initial market entry there over the last six to nine months has gone very well actually.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: In all, it's been obviously a very positive period with the integration of the CIE acquisition. Geoff spoke in some  detail about that earlier. And that's something  that's underway and will again be complete, particularly in Germany it would be complete in the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: On slide 21, then we've got the environmental and renewables business, up 17% in total, owing in the main to a  very strong performance of the environmental products, so fuel storage and water storage treatment plant et  cetera. texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: The solar thermal business, our Thermomax Tubes business essentially has been staging a gradual comeback. The  business has grown in the first half, and will again grow in the second half, but it is still posting a significant loss  and that's something we expect to have to nurse through probably into 2012, but we would expect a – to get  through to breakeven in that business next year.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And then in terms of R&D, naturally there's a consistent pipeline of projects large and small coming through the  business. And our next-generation insulation project, as we said, 2013, we expect to come to market with that as a fairly  revolutionary insulation material for the construction sector, which will focus on essentially decreasing the  thicknesses required once again, which has been a key focus of our whole insulation product suite in the past.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: So that's something that we clearly need to watch as we go forward. But for now we'll been planning fairly  consistent raw material costs for the next three to six months.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And by innovative, we mean particularly around thermal and fire performance and no compromise on either of  those fronts. texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And all the while – and we'll deal with this a little more in depth later, internally we want to achieve this by having a  net zero operating environment. And by that, we mean that we will either use or consume only renewably  generated power throughout our organization.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And on slide number 5 and 6, this really deals with the essence of our product portfolio. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And then all the way through the more advanced insulation materials and all the way up to our more recent  product introductions like Quadcore, Optim-R, and soon to be launched, what we call, Next Generation Core.  Brand to be confirmed. texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And on slide number 6, again, this is something we've demonstrated. It focuses particularly around the thermal  performance of our products. And this becomes more  and more critical, as demand for insulation increases and space obviously becomes more an area of focus.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And as I said earlier, we want to achieve all of this without a compromise in terms of whole system fire  performance. But that's been a crucial area for us over many years and we welcome that increased focus  worldwide.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: On slide number 7, completing the envelope, we obviously are the world leader in rigid board, world leader in  Insulated Panels.
