So this will be  around daylighting ventilation and smoke management in buildings, obviously through the ventilation process.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Industrial insulation, we still remain embryonic in as is the case with flat roof membrane, both of which offer  significant avenue for high performance insulation materials. We see these as, both from an organic and an  acquisition platform perspective, very suitable areas for us to grow longer term as well. So plenty of scope for our  organization, both in terms of the existing products and sectors on the ones that we've yet really make a mark on.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And on slide 8, the planet's important to us and our commitment to it has been clear for the last seven or eight  years. As I said, we want to operate a net zero organization which has not been easy to achieve. And I guess, for  a lot of our peers it would be even more difficult to achieve. But we said about trying to find the target at 2020, net  zero position. And as of this year, by the end of 2018, we expect to be comfortably in excess of 70%, and that  includes the impact of having to obviously deal with and absorb acquisitions as well. Once we achieve that 100%  level, we're going to maintain that clearly as we grow and expand and acquire, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of recycling, obviously a critical issue going forward. We live in a world of plastics whether we like it or  not. And as a business, we see significant advantage in being able to recycle PET-based bottles. And at present,  we're using over 0.25 billion of those products in our solutions. And it's our ambition to at least double that to 500  million units in five years' time. So, that's critical. And these materials effectively get recycled into the highest  performance insulation materials that you can find. And so, that's a significant commitment of ours going forward.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And critically important has been the growth of the Quadcore technology which is up 76%, and now represents  6% of our global insulated panels. And that figure incidentally is 18% for the UK and Ireland, which is the area  where we started off in. And that 18% for these markets, we would expect to exceed 25% by the close of this  year, so making very significant progress there on a technology that is really groundbreaking, when it comes to  thermal and indeed fire performance.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Water & Energy, used to be Environmental, we'll be focusing clearly on those two segments going forward,  broadly in line with prior year after, like everywhere else, a slowing up start.

texts.speaker: Geoffrey P. Doherty
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Water & Energy at 5.7%, again has a more significant second half. It would have had a soft Q1 due to the  prolonged winter, but is trading to plan.

file: KRX - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 1March2010 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I think it’s important to point out as well that we’ve – the underlying direction of the business and the  underlying strategy of the business continue unaffected. Our focus on low energy products and our  focus on increasing the geographic footprint of the business is something that we continued even  during 2009. So we’re certainly not planning on this being depressed forever and I think, it’s very  important we keep the building blocks – keep putting the building blocks in place for the future of       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: It’s almost more important – it’s almost – with timber framing at this stage it’s much less important,  the sales value rather than the profitability or whatever. So it’s – let’s say sales aren’t that important  as they’ve come so low. Environmental & Renewables were down 29% and Access Floors down  25. So that’s just the as I said the analysis of sales by product.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Insulation Boards, now I can – I have to emphasize that that includes timber framing, 5.9 in 2008  and 6.4 in 2009. And again, I have to say that the margin on the core Insulation Boards there is  remaining fairly robust. Environmental & Renewables 1.7 in 2009 versus 1% in 2008.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, again, as you know, we’ve had the warranty issue with supplies of raw material which – that  has happened back in 2002 and 2003, but there is a continuing warranty cost coming in there. And  if you add back that warranty cost the underlying margin in Environmental & Renewables is about  5%. So it’s getting to be a little bit more respectable when you add that back.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to 23 to the North American businesses, obviously, a very well published. It’s been a  challenging non-residential environment there and something that’s absolutely certain to continue  into this year. If anything, probably the residential side, which we’re not in, has shown a lot of  stability, but the non-res side still has got further to fall and I’d say particularly in office  development, which we’ll come to later in Access Floors. It’s got a good bit yet to go.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Environmental & Renewables business on slide 25 it’s largely exposed to the U.K. and Ireland.  About 75% of the business is based in those markets. So obviously, it took quite a hit, particularly  given the fact that it’s been in the residential segment. So although there was some improvement  visible in the fourth quarter in that area, actually the first nine months were very depressed in terms  of housing construction. So hot water treatment, water plants, et cetera all talk quite a knock in the  first nine months of the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have seen in the fourth quarter some recovery of that and into the beginning of this year as well  notwithstanding the fact that weather has affected some of the product areas, but we have seen, I’d  say, just a strong performance in this business in the couple of months of 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Solar, which is an area, we’ve put a lot of focus on, a lot of investment in and we’ve a lot of belief in  it for the future, did suffer fairly dramatically, particularly in Germany which has accounted probably  for 70% plus of the order book in this business. We would anticipate, I’d say, a further weakening of  that in 2010 as well. Stock levels would appear to be high in the industry overall with the result of  things that are going to remain pretty weak there, which is a shame just for the time being. We’ve  significantly reduced cost base with the redesign of the solar evacuated tube now underway and  being produced in Northern Ireland in the new facility. But as I said, things are going to remain  pretty much depressed here.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Just a couple of slides towards the end just in terms of the overall environment we’re working in on  the fact that we haven’t lost sight of where we’re going and the attractiveness of the overall  segment long-term. If you look at building codes heading out to 2016 by some of the key markets  that we’re operating in. So the U.K., North America, Germany and Poland, just as representative  markets, you can see that Insulation Standards are planned to improve by anything up to 200%  over the next seven or eight years. So it’s very, very significant. And that effectively just has a direct  impact on the thickness of insulations that are going to be needed to be supplied to meet these  demands.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now of all these aren’t just cast in stone codes yet. Some of them are roadmaps. But the general  direction has been outlined and as I say, it’s very, very positive for our business and our sector  overall.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And just to understand the impact of that to – on our business and on, if you like, competing  businesses, on slide 28, we see what it means in terms of thicknesses of insulation which is a  crucial thing to point out at this stage. So to achieve a 0.1 standard in roof which is close to kind of  passive levels, which is the levels that a lot of markets will be trending towards in 2016, you need  as much as – well, almost a half a meter thick mineral fibre. So if you can just imagine that  thickness of insulation up in your roof, which is probably positive for their industry. But the  attractiveness of our product actually gets – it kind of accelerates in that environment. As you can  see in the far right, the requirement for Kingspan Kooltherm is insulation is less than half the  thickness.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Finally, then just to look at the 2010 outlook and I am sure we’ll cover a few more detail in the Q&A,  but we are expecting overall, let’s say, more predictable and more stable environment. Although  somewhere it is trending weak, at least we recognize that it is – we don’t expect many surprises  this year. And in terms of strengthening, if anything, the only area we would see strengthening is  U.K. housing, in volumes at least. Housing prices and so on have nothing to do with us, but in  volume output, we would certainly, for the first half of this year, expect to see a reasonable  improvement in housing construction, which will affect our Insulation business and our  Environmental & Renewables businesses.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Insulation volumes then, as I said, the U.K. should be good and Western Europe should prove  more steady after quarter one, which as I’ve highlighted earlier has been very, very week largely  weather-related. And overall, just as a general theme, we’d say that margins will remain under  pressure this year, particularly as we go through an inflation environment for most of our materials,  certainly in the first half steel and chemicals are likely to harden further.

file: KRX - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 28February2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Environmental & Renewable still being significantly depressed I suppose by the warranty cost that  are still hitting our P&L in respect of that faulty raw material and it’s subject to a court case as we  mentioned in the reviews that you have. There was a charge in 2010 of about €5.5 million there.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, some of that is being driven of course what Gene alluded to in terms of raw material price  increases, which rolls on into higher stock volumes being carried. Now, physically, we’ve been  carrying more stock as well and that will continue through the first half this year as prices – as raw  material prices increase, we will be and have been stocking up for that year-end and currently as  well.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Refurbishment, obviously, an area we talk about periodically to the market, but we talk about it  every day at the office. This is a part of our business that has got great growth potential. And that  should receive a further boost assuming the UK Green Deal gets implemented. And this effectively  is a very large-scale initiative to upgrade both the residential and non-residential stock in the UK  over the medium-term future, and naturally its products like ours that will benefit greatly from this  sort of an initiative.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Gene M. Murtagh, Chief Executive Officer  Perfect. Thanks, Geoff. Slide 27 then takes us on to the Environmental & Renewables business,  again, a flattish performance. I think Dermot alluded to earlier on just the impact of the costs related  to both the claim and the legal costs of the Borealis case, which is upcoming now in May of this  year was very significant and that kind of blew a hole in the margins, but that aside, it probably was  a reasonably disappointing year for us in solarthermal in any event.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: All early signs have actually been very encouraging and there’s quite a substantial specification  bank building of large-scale solar applications little like the one that you can actually see in the  picture there, which is an aquatic center in California.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our focus incidentally in this business is not really the one-off it has although naturally we’ll take  that business where we can. Our focus is going to be large spreads of roofing area that requires  significant amount of solar power as opposed to just single-house applications. I think it’s in that  kind of area that we can carve out a niche pretty much for ourselves rather than just in the  commodity end as with everybody else longer term.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The more core legacy businesses of the fuel storage tanks, Hot Water and so on were reasonable.  Naturally, the UK is the backbone of this business and there was some housing recovery and that  was evident particularly in our Hot Water sales.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: The Environmental business unit divisional sales grew by 18%, which was quite a turn for that business with  respect to its performance over the last three to five years, largely driven by very strong sales in Continental  overall. Naturally, it's a very office-related business, and it's supported otherwise by the datacentre market, which  overall, I'd say, worldwide, was probably about flat year-on-year. But it clearly wasn't enough to counteract totals.  It was a very, very weak office market, and an office market that remains exceptionally weak in North America as  we speak.

texts.speaker: Geoffrey P. Doherty
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc

The  impact of the sales volume decline during the year clearly having an impact on operating margins. So, overall, the  Group operating margin pre-acquisition is about 6.7% comparing to 6% for 2010.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: So, in comparison there on slide 27 again to the U.K. macros or the house building starts. And then I'll take you on  to slide 29, which takes us into our Environmental division. I'd say a very solid performance throughout the  business unit and quite a term for that business if you looked at its performance over the last number of years. It's  13% of Group sales in the year, and overall up 18%, which is a – it's a mix of volume, price and, indeed, the overall  sales mix in this business.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Continental Europe, as we've mentioned a number of times, was particularly strong. We had the benefit of a one- off contract, if you like, in France, for fuel storage products, which has run into the early part of this year, but is  not likely to take us through the whole year. That was great support for the business.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: We saw solarthermal growth in the U.K., the U.S. and even in Ireland. However, Germany particularly incentive  related, those still remain weak for that particular business unit. And we entered the micro-wind sector. As you  know this particular division sells a range of renewable products from solar to a range of heat pumps and their  micro-wind generation, which is very small, up to 6 kilowatt units, which is an important kind of range  enhancement for the renewable say product suite for us in this business.  But in essence, I'd say a very good year for this business. And we look forward to continued growth in that not just  on top, but particularly in the bottom line of this business. There has been no judgment yet on the Borealis case. It  completed in the third quarter of last year and would expect judgment probably towards the middle of this year.  We have expected it from quarter one, but our information now will tell us that judgment's not likely to come until  closer to mid-year.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: On to our outlook then from slide 32. In essence, we're looking at a reasonable first half. As I said earlier, the key  businesses, the order books, are probably high single digit ahead of what they were a year ago. Intake was  reasonably strong in the fourth quarter in the key markets. And probably in the first two months, things probably  haven't gone quite as strong as we might have liked, but that's more a weather-related comment than it is  anything else. I think clearly there was just the severity of the weather, not just in the middle of Europe, but even  in the U.K. in early February, and did interrupt the pattern of sales in the first eight weeks. And I suppose the  March and April sales pattern will be in key in terms of future indications for the year ahead.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And beyond that, I think it has to be said that things aren't entirely certain from a macro perspective globally, and  we're always naturally very conscious of that. But in essence, I think business is in extremely good shape. Pipeline  is positive. Refurbishment's growing. And really, a little wind assistance from the macro environment and I think  we'll have a reasonable year once again.

texts.text: The – a key theme, which Geoff will deal with again in some detail was the trading margin, which has been  trending towards 7%, bearing in mind that it was also a tough year for our Environmental business, I would say,  [ph] of which (3:05) there's no doubt the margin would have gone ahead of 7%. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Environmental had a tough year. Its trading margin went from 3.3% to 0.7%, largely as a consequence of the  negative operating leverage associated with the poor sales performance during 2012. And Access Floors saw its  trading margin slightly decline by 30 basis points from 10.2% to 9.9%, and that's largely a function of business  mix. So the overall group trading margin grew by 40 basis points to 6.6%, are up 70 basis points if you exclude the  impact of the acquisitions during the year.

texts.speaker: Geoffrey P. Doherty
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of how we deployed that free cash flow, that's set out on slide 14. And you'll see that the cash impact of  acquisitions in the year was €72.5 million and then the settlement of a legacy – legal case in the Environmental  division was €12.3 million. Dividend paid, €16.6 million, meaning the net cash flow movement for the year was  €5.2 million. The – so the overall debt number at the end of the year €165.5 million, our net debt to EBITDA of  1.12 times.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: It has become, I'd say, a somewhat more competitive, particularly around the coal storage markets, which  traditionally for Kingspan at least has been a lower margin business. And therefore it doesn't have the same  impact on the bottom line, thus, that becomes a little tighter. But in essence, intake was positive and we will look  forward to, I would say, for sure a year of progress in North America as we look ahead into 2013.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Finally on the divisions, the Environmental division had a, I'd say, a well predicted difficult year. It's undergone  quite a lot of change in the 12 to 18 months just gone by. The business has been organized and structured very  differently to take account of the different circumstances that it faces. But in essence, what's affected the  profitability here more than anything was a single French contract which expired around last April, so April 2012.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Our position in the UK remains very strong in treatment and water, and we would expect that to as I say,  contribute going forward. The more recent products of solar thermal, has been as they show, steady progress and  they're naturally key aspects of this particular businesses as we look ahead into the future.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Moving onto slide number 24, which is headed, Insulated Panels, UK, Ireland, Western Europe. This is obviously  the single largest operational chunk that we've got. It had a slow start to the year as did most of our geographies,  which was largely weather-related, if you recall, at the time. But generally [ph] only (11:04) business picked up as  the year wore on, both in the UK and in the Benelux, which had been quite weak for a couple of years in advance  of that.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: The Energy, Kingspan Energy business, which is on slide 27; it's very early stages for us in this particular initiative  whereby we're effectively combining Insulated Panel and on-roof PV systems focusing on the UK for the  immediate term.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: There are two options in terms of how we approach this: one is via the client directly where they simply buy a  product as is the normal channel; and the secondary is whereby we effectively fund the installation, locking in the  income streams, then bundle that and exit then to financial investors. The combination of both o f these two  channels, if you like, we expect to generate revenue of about €25 million in the current year and it will be profit  generating as well, naturally, even in year one. So as I said, very early days, but an encouraging first step into this  market whereby we're effectively using the solar PV market to generate incremental Insulated Panel sales for us in  the UK market.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: Newbuild did improve particularly in the UK during the year which compensated for a year-on-year significant  reduction in refurb. You'll have heard us talk before about how strong the refurb market and, particularly, in the  UK and Ireland was over the last number of years. But certainly did weaken as, if you like, the market fe ll between  two stools of discontinuing the CERT and CESP programs and really a fairly marred introduction to the Green  Deal in the UK, which hasn't really had any impact so far, and that actually affected the business.

texts.speaker: Gene M. Murtagh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kingspan Group Plc
texts.text: And then, finally, from a divisional perspective, on slide 33, is the Environmental business which has been  undergoing significant restructuring, and the last year of restructuring as far as we can see for now. The business  did stabilize from a revenue perspectiv e, and in quarter four was down a couple of percent by comparison  obviously to minus 27 % in Q1. And so there's evident stabilization here and that's the name of the game for the  current year. So effectively, keep that top line stable and start to improve the underlying profit performance of the  business.

file: KRZ - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 4August2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Food safety, clean label, food origin; consumers are paying more attention to. They want to be able to understand  the ingredients that are on the label, and they want to know the sourcing of the ingredients.

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: A rather busy visual, but it does try to capture the amount of change that is taking place in the food and beverage  industry, ranging from demand for local authentic taste profiles; millennials driving snacking; the focus on food  safety and clean label; the unwillingness to sacrifice taste for better nutrition; and it goes on and on.

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In prior presentations, we have given case studies that we think sort of give a good example of what we do. In our  last presentation, we did a case study on beverage and how important that is to the organization and how it has  grown and where we play. Today, I would like to talk just a little bit about clean label and the customer positioning  around clean label. And whether it is around replacing, reducing, removing or complete repositioning, we've built it  on – we've organized it around those four pillars where customers are seeking to replace ingredients with clean  label. In other words, ingredients that they understand or feel comfortable with, while retaining key functionality  and taste. And that's removing artificial colors and flavors, replacing them with natural flavors or in more cases  and more and more cases, with no flavors at all and with a shorter ingredient deck.

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of reducing short ingredient decks, natural ingredients, meeting regulatory and dietary compliance. And  then removing some big no-no's like BHT, for example, which is an antioxidant, or BPA, which is used in a lot of  beverages.

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then the repositioning of food around format packaging, sous-vide, for example, I referred to earlier and  culinary processing, something that we feel is more traditional and going back to the roots of food preparation if  you will and home cooked and authentic ingredients. But all of this, while appealing, from a marketing  perspective, has to be underpinned by a high level of science and high level of regulatory rigor to make sure that  it is safe and meets all the labeling requirements.

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of how we approach it, we start from the consumer insights and the clean label evolution, and what is  happening out there in the marketplace. And then we leverage in our sensory, our functionality, food safety and  regulatory dynamics, feeding in then into the applications, the development and the innovation. And then making  sure that they meet pass consumer panels and hurdles, if you will, in relation to the marketplace, but ultimately,  delivering on consumer-preferred products aligned with clean label market opportunities. Sustain technical,  functional and regulatory solutions, I touched on that. And then, it has to be scalable and being able to address  the rollout or the demand for large organizations to be able to take to the marketplace in a controlled manner.

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Touching on our Foods business and the continued innovation for today's marketplace. It's around authenticity  and flavor, and here we see some of the examples in our meals and in our sliced meats around Fire and Smoke.  The growing demand for free from, where we've launched a line of products under the Pure brand; and snacking,  which we've mentioned particularly around kids' snacking, both Ireland, UK and more and more internationally;  and meat snacking leveraging from Fire and Smoke, carrying all the authentic and taste qualities that it delivers,  and then around convenience for people that are [ph] starved for time (40:46) in terms of being able to prepare  quickly in today's environment. So, we believe that this business is now well positioned and is obviously delivering  growth and improvement in performance.

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, our outlook for 2016. We believe the model is resilient, well placed, like I mentioned earlier, in terms of the  changing environment. The unique taste & nutrition, functional ingredients and systems capabilities is really a  strength. And there is no other like it in the marketplace globally.

texts.text: Kerryconnect, going live in LATAM in the first half of 2018 and we ramped up for that with our Kerryconnect team  well mobilized at this point in time with a view to commencing North America in 2019. file: KRZ - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 9August2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: Delighted to say that our customers continue to respond very positively to our promise of taste and nutrition  integrated solutions and this really comes to life when we talk about the clean label opportunity. And I'll get into a  little bit more detail on clean label later on in the presentation.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: We've expanded our fermentation capability in the North American market and that's to support the clean label  opportunity globally. We've also expanded our manufacturing footprint through both acquisitions and also through  the opening of a new manufacturing facility in Russia in quarter two. We also opened a new center of excellence  for ME Technology in Thailand that would support that technology for the entire Asia-Pacific region.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: From an end use market perspective, meat, beverage and snack end use markets continue to perform well. And  from a technology standpoint, our clean label technologies, our natural extracts and our TasteSense sugar- reduction technology continue to drive growth.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of categories, Richmond performed well with the successful launch of chicken sausages but the overall  meals category was negatively impacted by reduced promotional activity at retailers and the weather here in the  U.K.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: Now moving on to clean label, and I referenced earlier that clean label is an important underpin of our growth.  Consumers everywhere are paying more attention to ingredient lists and health claims. And with our for-food,  from food heritage, Kerry leads in this space. We use our 5R approach to work with customers across the globe.  With our reduce, reposition, reinvent, remove and replace approach, we work right across the clean label  spectrum. And our ability to develop integrated solutions combining both taste and nutrition means that we can  provide clean label solutions without compromising on taste.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: We've done a lot of research into clean label. Now I'd like to share with you some points from our research and  incidentally we will be releasing another white paper in this space in the coming weeks. But some points: the  clean label movement is a global movement and clean label has positive relevance globally, however, has  different manifestations depending on the sub-region or region that you might be in.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: The willingness to pay for clean label is also rising, and in addition to consumers' positive opinion of clean label,  over 70% of consumers believe that clean label helps them to live a healthier lifestyle. Globally, clean label  products represent 36% of new product launches and this is even a higher percentage, more than 50% in the  U.S. market.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: As I said earlier, it's important that we stay ahead of the trends and while meat consumption continues to grow,  there's also a growing demand for plant-based protein across multiple categories and across multiple channels.  Our research shows that there's been a 267% rise in high or added protein products in the last five years in  Europe and North America.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: 71% of consumers view protein from plants to be healthier and now we see that we're at the intersection of three  megatrends. Protein consumption is increasing, plant-based protein consumption is increasing due to trends of  veganism and vegetarianism and snackification is driving consumers to look for new protein alternatives. We  believe we're uniquely positioned to take advantage of these three trends and Kerry has been working in this  space for quite some time with our Cereshred meat alternative capability. Our ProDiem TNT functional plant  protein capability for bar applications, the Ojah investment that we made at the beginning of the year, and  ProDiem Refresh, a technology developed for beverage applications.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: And this is just one example on the right-hand side of a protein drink containing our TasteSense technology, our  ProDiem Refresh, and natural citrus flavors. And we work with a customer to deliver a protein drink that's vegan,  allergen-free, soy-free, non-GMO, clean label, dairy-free, collagen-free, gluten free, kosher and halal, and of  course it tastes fantastic, now if that's not on trend there is nobody's.

texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: Kerry Foods is about brand leadership and technologies supporting those brands and then our sustainable – of  securing sustainable growth or achieving that growth in a sustainable way. And I'll just comment on each one of  those.

texts.text: How will we achieve that growth? We will do so in a sustainable way, securing sustainable growth and embedding  sustainability into our business. texts.speaker: Stan McCarthy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: The four pillars to our sustainability program is the environment, the marketplace, the workplace and the  community. And it  will be governed under the 1 Kerry model.

texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc

file: KRZ - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 19February2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: And I'm pleased to report that 2018 was another year of consistent performance for the organization in light of  what is a rapidly changing marketplace. We continue to outperform our markets with volume growth of 3.5%,  which is well ahead of our market growth rate at 1%. We made good progress in the enhancement of our Taste &  Nutrition technology portfolio like the further development of our TasteSense innovation platform, the continued  deployment of our plant protein portfolio, and the development of [ph] clean smoke (00:01:24) technology, which  is now delivering additional functionalities of both preservation and color. I'm excited about the strategic  investments that we made throughout the year to support our medium-term strategies, the investment in our first  manufacturing facility in Russia, our footprint expansions in Indonesia, China, and Malaysia, and a major  expansion of our fermentation capacity for natural preservation and food protection technologies in Rochester,  Minnesota.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Marguerite. And moving on to future prospects, I can say at the very outset that we operate in a  phenomenal sector, so dynamic and so fast paced. And for us, the Kerry, like we've said before, everything starts  with the consumer. And one of the biggest changes we're seeing is that consumers are continuously looking for  food not just for nourishment but for how it supports their overall wellbeing. And whether that's reduction in salt  and sugar and calories, an increase in protein intake or improvements in the digestive health and all this is playing  out in front of us across channels and categories right now. We call this food for life and wellbeing and it can  mean different things depending on what life stage you're at.

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: Now moving on to the center section, let's consider how the customer landscape is being transformed as a result  of these consumer dynamics. First and foremost, with the accelerating fragmentation, we're seeing increasingly  shorter product development lifecycles as consumers continuously want to try new things. Also customers are  responding to consumer demand for great taste and nutrition, for the authentic products that combine elevated  nutrition demands with more sophisticated taste preferences. Trust is absolutely paramount. Brands must be seen  as ethical as consumer seeks socially responsible offerings that not only use clean and natural ingredients but are  also from companies that follow sustainable practices. So how's all this now reshaping the industry?

texts.speaker: Edmond Scanlon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Chief Executive Officer, Kerry Group Plc
texts.text: So, now moving on to our unique Taste & Nutrition positioning, it's clear that consumers are looking for different  combinations of taste and nutrition depending on their specific life stage and that our industry has to respond with  products that meet their elevated nutrition demands and their increasingly sophisticated taste preferences. And  elevated nutrition with no compromise on taste is exactly where we play. And our for food from food ethos with  our natural sourcing, authentic culinary processes and our innovation platforms of TasteSense, Authentic Savoury  and Simply Nature, along with our sensory and consumer insights are all integrated with our positive nutrition  approach, creating products that are backed by scientific expertise, the Kerry Health and Nutrition Institute, white  papers, our global research network and various industry webinars, all designed to guide our customers and our  industry. This taste and nutrition approach is underpinned by our 5R clean label strategy that I talked about in the  past and enabled by our Taste & Nutrition Discovery Centers. This is very exciting for us at Kerry as the  intersection of taste and nutrition is growing and continues to present us with tremendous opportunities for the  future.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: And at 1 Sherwood Street, our 144,000 square foot development behind Piccadilly Lights, we're creating an office  and retail product at one of the most iconic locations in the world. The 111,000 square feet of offices will have  large, open but flexible floor plates capable of accommodating a diversity of workplaces. Wellness is at the heart  of the design. There's a central atrium and winter garden to enhance natural light, along with private terraces and  cycling and changing facilities. We'll have a Landsec Lounge on the first floor as well as an exciting rooftop  restaurant. And of course, there'll be retail on the ground floor. All in all, 1 Sherwood Street or, perhaps, 1  Piccadilly Lights, is going to be a great new destination in the heart of the West End.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: In Southwark, we own four buildings totaling 227,000 square feet and are progressing two schemes: 105 Sumner  Street and Red Lion Court. At Sumner Street, we have a consent for 135,000 square feet in two buildings. The  rectangular geometry of the design gives us an opportunity to use a modern kit building approach, where parts  are manufactured offsite and arrive ready to be assembled, a bit like Lego. This is already done in car  manufacturing and many residential schemes, and could dramatically reduce waste, time, costs and being more  environmentally friendly.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: At Red Lion Court on the river, we finished the feasibility stage for 324,000 square foot office building, which will  deliver dynamic, connected and flexible workspaces with fantastic views and a great new public realm onto the  river. The design ethos is to create an ecosystem to support businesses from startups to global brands, and we're  now progressing with planning.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: At Portland House, we're in the feasibility stage for 530,000-square-foot office building starting in 2020. Our plans  increase the floor area whilst maintaining a similar height building. We'll be extending the public realm with a large  open space linking our whole Victoria estate. One of the complexities of this development is demolishing the  existing building at speed in this very tight site. We're working with specialist demolition contractors who have  experience with this kind of challenge.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: This new tower for the West End will require significant amount of affordable housing to comply with planning  policy. Over the summer, we obtained planning for 86 affordable units at nearby Castle Lane. We're now talking to  affordable housing providers to partner with us. So there's an exciting future ahead. But now back to the present  where we're making great progress at 21 Moorfields.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: And at Westgate, we've completed the brilliant lineup with lettings to Zara, MANGO, Urban Outfitters and  Flannels. We're constantly innovating with our customers, consumers and the environment in mind to keep our  visitors coming back.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Our portfolio wide Refill Me! campaign has made a big impact reducing the use of disposable water bottles. And  our solar panels at White Rose benefit our [ph] customer service charge (00:36:08) by producing 22% of the  center's communal energy.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: And to give you a feel for the impact we can make, if we boosted average densities at Braintree, for example, by  just £100 per square foot, our income would increase by 20% which, at constant yields, would deliver a valuation  impact of over 20%. And we're pushing ahead with those plans.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Turning to the near term, our first site is at Finchley Road. Now, you will remember that we acquired the leasehold  O2 center in 2010. We acquired the freehold two years later. The site is currently a surface car park and a home  base and comprises five of the seven acres in total. As you can see, the site has amazing transport connectivity,  and we're working up a scheme which includes over 1,000 homes and aim to submit a planning application in the  summer. The earliest start on site is February 2021.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: In Shepherd's Bush on land which includes an inefficient and underused multi-story car park, we're working on a  scheme which includes 700 homes right on the Central Line and Overground and immediately to the south of  Westfield, London. We aim to submit a planning application in the spring, again with a start on site in 2021.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: The second area is sustainability where there are two points I wish to make as they play to our strengths. First,  the unsustainable use of our planet's resources means we require better performance from buildings, from the  way we design and build them to the way we use and manage them right through the entire lifecycle.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: We are the leader in our sector in sustainability and we take great pride in being top-ranked UK-listed business by  both the Dow Jones Sustainability Index and GRESB this year with specific recognition of our science-based  approach to carbon reduction and the amazing work our teams do in the community particularly in respect of our  community employment program. This is important for shareholders as it sets us apart in the communities in  which we seek to operate.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: One, occupier requirements are constantly changing. This means winning buildings have to be able to adapt. With  offices, not only our businesses and their employees looking for great environment but they've also got to have  highly efficient and technically resilient space. In retail, consumer habits have already changed beyond what the  market originally estimated and habits will continue to change. And as Richard said last year, that will have a  profound effect on anything that's not very convenient, or dominant in its catchment or both.

texts.speaker: Martin Frederick Greenslade
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: But what I'd like to do now is take you behind the cost ratio because one thing's for sure, not all costs are the same.  So, the first component of our costs is managed operations. And what these are, are largely the costs associated  with running some of our own car parks. And the associated income for this cost is in rent. And so, if we outsource  all of our car parks, these costs would disappear, but our rental income would be lower. So, that's 1.6% of our cost  ratio, different business model, different cost ratio.

texts.speaker: Richard John Akers
texts.profession: Executive Director & MD-Retail Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: We've recognized this importance and increased our exposure to leisure properties with over £400 million in  acquisitions in the year and that's takes our leisure and hotel category to some 18% of our retail portfolio. And  clearly, the environment has also been very challenging. All of these retailers have fallen into administration but  despite that, Ashley and Dominic's teams have reduced their like-for-like voids and administrations over the year  from 5.6% to 5.2%. We're pleased with that reduction and we've given you details by sector and our letting  statistics in the appendix slide.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: I'd like to focus today on how our development program looks. But before that, can we just run through the  valuation? The portfolio excluding the development program increased in value by 0.5% in the first half in green  and 3.0% in the second half in red. That's 3.5% in total. But over the year, as you can see in the middle section, our  development program increased in value by 18.2%, which means that the combined portfolio increased in value by  5.4% over the year. You can see why the development opportunities we have within our business are important to  us.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Turning to Victoria Circle, here you can see the 5.5-acre site where demolition started in October and, as you can  see, things are moving at quite a pace. Victoria Circle forms three separate phases, Phase 1 which we have  committed to, is highlighted in red and will comprise 727,000 square feet of residential, retail and office space.  Phases 2 and 3 in blue and green can follow once we get the land back from TFL. This will be after completion of  the Victoria Line station upgrade and Crossrail 2, future-proofing which is under construction at the moment, and  we're not due to get this land back until mid-2016.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: In retail, our emphasis is on providing space for retail winners. Lester and his team completely nailed Leeds and  Glasgow. That's 900,000 square feet. And as Richard has said, we have a lot more to come, much of it supported  by pre-lettings to retail winners. We've made great strides over the last few years to position our assets for  tomorrow's customers and consumers. It's about environment, as Richard said, and connection. And we're  delivering on our plan to put more emphasis on dominant centers, convenient shopping and leisure. Tomorrow's  customers and consumers will continue to change and we will respond to what they want.

texts.text: We have two major city center schemes we're working up. Through an  earlier start on site in March next year, this would see practical completion in October 2017 .

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: In Glasgow, jointly owned with Henderson, we also have outlined planning consent of finalized tax increment  funding for the public realm and infrastructure works, and we've agreed terms with Network Rail. By virtually  doubling this – the area of this existing scheme, we would establish it as the dominant retail center in Glasgow,  the second retail location in the UK outside London.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Planning consent for the application of the solar shading solution has been received and works are now underway.  These works are being carried out externally and will not interfere with tenant fit-out or occupation. The cost has  been negotiated with the cladding contractor and, as we've previously guided, will not alter our original total  development cost for the building.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: In the West End, at Kings Gate, we've made great progress on residential sales. Completion of this schem e is now  scheduled for next May following another slight delay due to the UKPN works and the very wet weather. We're not  expecting this to impact timing any further than it already has. Next door at The Zig Zag Building, we've let the  retail space to MANGO and Ibérica, and have a healthy level of office negotiations.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Just up the road from these two is Nova. And here, you can see the full scale of a 5.5 -acre city center project  coming out of the ground. First, there is the Nova Building, which is the reside ntial element in green; then the two  office buildings shown in orange, these will sit above two new retail streets shown in blue; and below that and  going on at the same time shown in pink, you can see the London Underground site. They're working on the ne w  Victoria Line Station concourse and Crossrail 2 future-proofing. We're due to get this land back in 2016 for phases  2 and 3.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, at 20 Eastbourne Terrace, right on the entrance to the Paddington Crossrail Station, the construction  contract has now been placed with weights and completion is set for February 2016. And at phase 2 of Oriana in  Oxford Street, our JV with Frogmore, demolition is under way . We'll place the building contract very shortly,  completion now estimated for September 2016.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Let me explain why we have taken this view. The green bars on this slide, and you've seen it before, show the  historical run of development completions in Central London. The bars on the right -hand side show what is  forecast to be delivered over the next two years. Pre-lets and speculative space actually under construction are  shown in white and red, respectively. The dotted bars are proposed and deliverable, our view of what will be  bought on the stream. They include new schemes and Grade A refurbished accommodation.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Last May, we talked about increased occupier activity on the horizon. We believe there were simply not enough  new, efficient, technically-resilient space being developed. And that's why we committed last year to more  speculative schemes to be delivered into 2015 and 2016.

texts.speaker: Martin Frederick Greenslade
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Land Securities Group Plc

texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Turning to the screen itself, the plan was to create a block vacant possession date of December 2016, which we  did. If it rains, the screen can rain too. We've pre-let 50%  of the space to Coca-Cola, Samsung and Hyundai at 17% above passing rent, and have just launched the  marketing campaign for the three remaining screens.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: At 21 Moorfields, we secured consent for 522,000 square feet in two buildings. We finished demolition and  committed to build to grade. All of these is in line with the plan we've shared with you previously. This approach  means that we get the time consuming below ground works out of the way, and will have created a raft above the  new Crossrail station by June 2018. In turn, this means we can construct the new buildings in 24 months, giving  us great flexibility on strategy.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: I said I'd talk more about 1 Sherwood Street behind Piccadilly Lights. The new screen is being constructed on a  stand-alone structure, which frees up everything behind. We secured consent for 142,000 square feet, and plan to  start detailed design later this year.

texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: In Southwark, we've obtained consent for 134,000 square feet at Sumner Street and anticipate an earliest  construction start on site in October 2019. We're also well under way with a feasibility study for 360,000 square  feet at Red Lion Court directly on the Thames.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: We're all in and we'll make a start. A very good morning, everyone and welcome to our Results Presentation.  Here's our agenda and we'll crack straight into it. Before I hand over to Martin, I'd like to share our approach to  running the business on the four themes; market, customers, efficiency and sustainability.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: My final theme is the need to ensure our business is sustainable in the round. And by that, I mean Landsec being  in existence and healthy in 5, 10, 15 years and so on. So, we work on those things that ensure support from all  our stakeholders, customers, communities, employees and partners and I include shareholders, bondholders and  lending institutions in that. Rightly, we continue to be recognized for our leadership role in good corporate  governance and transparency, health safety and security, positive economic impact to the areas where we do  business, social inclusion and environmental impact.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: The scheme will increase the public realm by opening up a route from Nova through to Portland House and  Cardinal Place. We get the site back later this year and detailed design is well underway. We're working towards  start in site date in March 2019. As part of this phase, we're also looking at a later second building that sits beside  the theatre. This is likely to be a lightweight structure as it sits over the Victoria line. We're continuing to look at  uses, which will complement the wider state, but it could be residential or more flexible office-type building with  amenities to benefit our whole customer base.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: The other building at Red Lion Court is directly on the river, where we're looking at our redevelopment options,  aiming to submit a planning application by March. So in all, we have nearly 600,000 square feet on site, 800,000  square feet in design, and start on site dates from next year. We've created optionality as we can either push the  button or roll income except for Nova East which is already a cleared site. And whilst all this is going on, the team  continues to track opportunities to acquire more stock. We're already beginning to see expectations not being met  and the pool of opportunities increasing. And of course, the asset team are driving the existing portfolio hard.

texts.speaker: Scott Parsons
texts.profession: Managing Director-Retail Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Next let's take a look at our sales and footfall. The cold, The Beast from The East and Storm Emma reminded us  that the weather still has a massive impact on footfall and sales. Although the snow caused a few of our centers  to close for a few days, and certainly impacted sales and footfall, the national benchmarks don't exclude snow  days or transport closure days from their figures and neither do we. Our portfolio outperformed the footfall  benchmark by 60 basis points and the BRC Physical Store Benchmark by 170 basis points.

texts.speaker: Scott Parsons
texts.profession: Managing Director-Retail Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Athleisure and sports brands have seen good growth over the past year, and are anticipated to outperform the UK  clothing market in the year ahead. At White Rose, we've upsized JD Sports and at Bluewater we've delivered  fantastic new flagships for Snow+Rock and Runners Need.

file: LANDL - Q4 2019 Earnings Call 14May2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: And fourth, the sustainability agenda. Society is demanding. The [ph] business has (00:03:00) become a force for  good rather than just an employer. Social value, mobility, and inclusion are all hot topics. Resource scarcity and  climate change are also key issues for real estate companies. Rightly, legislation is getting tougher. Being on top  of it is hugely important. It drives commercial advantage including increasingly with customers and with getting  planning consents.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: As well as new products, we are working hard on innovative ways to reduce waste and energy whilst increasing  the efficiency of our cleaning, security, and maintenance. This is important to us and our customers. By taking this  approach, we make our space even more competitive. So, that's our office portfolio and new services.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Let me take you through it starting with 21 Moorfields. The complexity plays through our strength and we continue  to complete each stage on time or even ahead of target. And here are some of the highlights. Deutsche Bank with  the whole building giving us a 25-year lease. We finished our pilings six weeks early [indiscernible] (00:35:10) [ph]  as we started (00:35:13) 15 piles, 60 to 70 meters through Moorgate station. We started installing the frame and  we remain within our TDC of £576 million. All of this activity has now substantially de-risk the project and we're on  track to deliver DB at the end of 2021.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Moving south of the river. Changing London's style, I mean, landmark building is always something we're proud  of, but when we can invest in a number of buildings in close proximity and really breathe new life into an area,  that's when we make a real difference. We've done it in Victoria and we're going to do it in [ph] Southwark  (00:39:09), an area we know well.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Lavington Street, which we acquired in December, is well-embedded into our plans. We're in the feasibility stage  and are looking at both refurbishment and redevelopment options to deliver approximately 370,000 square feet.  We started discussions with Southwark and our proposed start on site date is July 2020. At Red Lion Court, [ph]  our scheme on the Thames (00:40:08) we're working on a building 324,000 square feet with a very large public  space, we're aiming to summit a planning application later this year.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: So, that's all development. But let me take a moment to talk about how we're continually innovating to build and  design better, faster and for less to find ways of reducing our impacts on the environment by sourcing responsibly  and maximizing our use of resources. I've talked about BIM modeling, but there is another area of innovation  gaining momentum, our case of parts approach I've talked about in November.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: To remind you, this is where our parts are designed and manufactured offsite and then put together on site using  automated assembly techniques. This has many advantages including greater efficiency better quality control,  reduced risk, reduced costs from economies of scale, and less environmental impact; all of which lead to higher  margins and improved financial performance.

texts.speaker: Colette O'Shea
texts.profession: Managing Director-London Portfolio, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: But let me sum up. Our office portfolio is full. We have new products and services, which are creating a wider  customer appeal. Our focus on innovation is leading to new ways of designing and constructing buildings better,  faster, and to less. Our ambition is to lead in sustainable development. Our development pipeline is growing and 1  million square feet will be onsite by this year. We're working on 1.4 million square feet of new homes. We're  committed to London and delivering space usable for the way people want to live, work, and play. And we're  confident about the value we can generate for shareholders.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: Internally, we've been focused on what it would take to be the successful property company of the future. This  now means delivering more than just a great building on time and to budget. It's resulted in the development of a  range of property services and modern building techniques and taking a lead in environmental and social factors.  At the same time, we've been preparing and expanding our 3.6 million-square-foot pipeline for development.

texts.speaker: Robert Montaque Noel
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Land Securities Group Plc
texts.text: We're widening our range of products and services thoughtfully ensuring that we can meet future demand in  terms of space, amenity and building performance. We're innovating to increase efficiency and reduce cost, waste  and risk. We have a deep and demonstrable skill base and great partner relationships and finally, we're the  sustainability role model in our sector.

texts.text: It is interesting that as fire and smoke are the last piece you could say in the ventilation system that consists of  more intelligent products, and therefore, it has been a long time wish for us to enter into this part of the business. texts.speaker: Jan Olof Svensson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: And as a complement to Ruskin, earlier this week, Swegon announced that they had bought yet another  acquisition in the Irish company, Safegard. [ph] We see  (08:19) that there is a possibility with these two companies to increase our presence in other geographies as well.  Safegard has an annual turnover of €8 million with a profitability above our average and will further strengthen  Swegon's position in the UK but will also be, together with Ruskin, the platform for growth on other markets  outside Great Britain.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Svensson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: Thank you. Thank you. We'll turn to the next slide and we'll go through our financial targets, and you probably  already [ph] recognize (17:26) these now. And we had a return on operating capital of 16.1%. So, at the moment, given that the business climate  is quite good, it's maybe not surprising that we are overachieving a little bit.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Svensson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: We are, of course, happy for the good business climate at the moment, but we are not really scared and see  possibilities for us especially when it comes to acquisitions even if the business climate should deteriorate slightly.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Svensson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: I still feel that the business climate is good for us in most markets where we operate. This is especially so in the  Nordics and in western Europe. However, the European construction industry is struggling a bit with lack of  capacity for installation mainly, which in our operations mostly affects Swegon. The general feeling however is  that all the markets where we are active, the business climate is good for the product portfolio that we today offer.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Svensson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: I have always been cautious to predict the near time development, but outside Europe where the business climate  is relatively good, Asia, including China and India, continues to be improved, while the U.S. is still more uncertain  to predict. Since more than 80% of our business is still in Europe, we are in good shape to meet possible market  challenges the coming year.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Svensson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: Micor is based in Laholm in Sweden, develops and manufactures circular saw blades for industrial applications.  NODA is a Swedish software company delivering system for energy optimization in district heating grids and  intelligent heat control for residential buildings. In December, we acquired the Finnish company Hakaser to  DENSIQ. Hakaser is a small company specialized in maintenance and repair of industrial valves for the Finnish  process related industries. This means that we in total added seven businesses this year or during 2017 for the  wholly-owned group. This acquisition adds 8% acquired growth on an annual basis, and in absolute terms this is  about SEK 750 million per year.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Svensson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: So I think that most of the companies or almost all of the companies in our portfolio at this time are meeting our  investment criteria in a very good way. So this position together with our financial strength gives us a lot of  opportunities. Should the business climate go down, we still see that we can continue to grow, especially outside  of Europe and where our market shares are very, very small and we see opportunities when it comes to  acquisitions if prices will come down slightly again.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: In a way it also proves that the business climate has been continuously good for us, our businesses does not yet  show signs of downturn, but many comments from around the world makes it necessary for us to be prepared for  a possible downturn in the global economy during 2019.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: The task at hand now of course is to focus on actions to remain in this position. And I would like to point out that in the wholly-owned group, this is all taken care of, and  I'm sure that is also the same in the portfolio companies.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Svensson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Investment AB Latour
texts.text: However, after Q3, I talked about the growth in North America and in Asia and was proud that we had once again  increased the figure, the figures from 9% and 7%. Our strategy is, of course, to be long-term and  active shareholder in all the companies with proprietary products and good possibilities for international growth. I  do think that we have a portfolio that to a very large degree is in line with our investment criteria.
