texts.text: This co-investment alongside partners is becoming an increasing feature. For example, we co-invested £370  million with PGGM, the Dutch pension fund, in property assets in 2014 and a further £375 million in 2015. We've  also committed to £1.5 billion to support a £15 billion UK regeneration-funding vehicle. We'll do this in  conjunction with the UK government's Regeneration Investment Organization or RIO as it's known. LGIM will act  as the investment manager for this entire vehicle.

texts.speaker: Kerrigan Procter
texts.profession: Managing Director, Legal & General Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: And now, on to individual retirement. We have a number of responses to the new environment for our customers.  Historically, people underestimate how long they will live and how much money they might need in retirement.  However, the over 60s in the UK have some £1.3 trillion worth of housing equity. We expect many will want to  access this to supplement their retirement income.

texts.speaker: Kerrigan Procter
texts.profession: Managing Director, Legal & General Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: In General Insurance; the quality story continues with good operating profit of £59 million and a combined  operating ratio of 87% despite the flooding and bad weather in Q1 causing an impact of £12 million. Significant  benefit this year has been driven by the digital and direct story with direct sales increasing by over 25% in the  year, and we remain the largest online writer of household new business, consistent with building an ever stronger  digital delivery.

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: Housing and personal finance are closely interwoven in the UK. As John mentioned, we already intermediate £40  billion of mortgages per year and have real property expertise. We've made a great start with color. So, housing  and urban regeneration is an obvious next major segment for Legal & General.

file: LGENL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 15March2016 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark J. Gregory
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Legal & General Capital delivered strong net cash, £187 million compared with £162 million in 2014. Operating  profit was up 15% at £233 million. LGC has been actively managing and diversifying its po rtfolio with a particular  focus on direct investments in housing, urban regeneration, clean energy, and alternative finance. Direct  investments in LGC now amount to £867 million, not just used in our balance sheet size and duration to capture  illiquidity premium, but also driving synergy gains across the business.

texts.speaker: Mark J. Gregory
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The General Insurance business saw operating profit reduced by £8 million in 2015 to £51 million. That includes a  £15 million impact from the UK floods in December. The combined operating ratio of LGR business in 2015 was  89% compared to 87% in the prior year.

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: LGC, led by Paul Stanworth, has four areas of focus for direct investments: urban regeneration, housing,  alternative finance, and clean energy. We are already leading the way in building an impressive real asset portfolio  for the business. These are marketplaces with a clear funding gap where supply and demand are out of balance  and where we can deploy our large long-dated balance sheet effectively offering partnering with sector specialists.

file: LGENL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 8March2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark J. Gregory
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on then to dividend, 12 months ago, we announced our new progressive dividend policy, reflecting the  group's medium-term underlying business growth. In line with our policy, the board has considered the best  trajectory of dividend growth taking into account sustainability across a wide range of scenarios and the group's  anticipated financial performance. Accordingly, the board has recommended a final dividend of £0.1035 given a  full year dividend of £0.1435, up 7% on 2015.

texts.speaker: Mark J. Gregory
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: Operating profit for our General Insurance business was £52 million, up 2%. For what is predominantly a  household book, the profit performance did benefit from relatively benign weather conditions in 2016, although we  did have to absorb the first annual Flood Re levy of £9 million, which added 3 percentage points to our combined  operating ratio of 89%. Our direct business grew by 20% and now accounts for 37% of gross premiums. And in  2017, recently signed distribution agreements are expected to increase GI gross premiums by around 10%. One  final point on GI, we expect zero profit impact from the recent Ogden rate changes.

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: Pemberton successfully raised €1.2 billion for its first fund and is targeting €3 billion by the end of 2017. In clean  energy, NTR deployed 66% of its initial €246 million fund and plans to launch second €500 million fund this year.  We've also delivered strong revenue growth from our existing businesses, including CALA, which had a record  year building nearly 1,500 homes creating revenues of £718 million. This compares to £384 million as recently as  2014.

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: CALA Homes is planning to build 5,000 homes by 2020. Our Build to Rent partnership will grow into a multi-billion  pound fund and we will bring the manufacturing and finance to the [ph] £143 billion (00:32:32) affordable housing  sector. We're already regenerating 10 cities and towns across the UK. We want to double this, building on our  very successful development model whilst we also want to create the platforms to fund parts of the UK's £40  billion clean energy market.

file: LGENL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 7March2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Stuart Jeffrey Davies
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: And finally, GI contributed £37 million, down £15 million from 2016, predominantly due to the impact of increased  costs from escape of water in line with industry experience as we reported at the half year. We're happy to say  we've not seen a repeat of this in the second half.

texts.speaker: Stuart Jeffrey Davies
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: In our Housing portfolio, we will continue the expansion of our Build-to-Sell and Build-to-Rent offerings. And we  have measured plans to develop businesses in the later living and affordable housing sector. We intend to grow  the Urban Regeneration portfolio through further investment into existing projects and the regeneration of cities  where we do not yet have a presence.

texts.speaker: Stuart Jeffrey Davies
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: In GI, gross premiums increased 13% to £369 million, whilst maintaining our pricing discipline in a competitive  market. 38% of our premium now comes from our direct channel. As flagged at half year, our operating profit was  affected predominantly by the impact of increased costs from escape of water claims in Q1. We took action to  address this and saw improved claims experience in the second half, as can be seen by the 92% combined ratio.

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: LGC has two principal goals. First, it uses our strengths including our existing businesses, network, brand and  talent to invest our shareholder capital to maximize returns. Secondly, it supports our other businesses by  creating or unlocking debt-like investments with great counter-parties for LGR, and by creating opportunities for  LGIM and its clients. Recent examples include the Urban Regeneration project in Cardiff and seeding LGIM's  Build-to-Rent fund. LGC invests in four principal areas: Urban Regeneration, Housing, SME Finance and Clean  Energy.

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: LGIM is a business we have built for the future. Once rooted in UK DB pensions, LGIM's strategy today is focused  on three things: broadening our investment capability, growing globally, and expanding our UK DC and retail  businesses to address the UK savings gap. We've expanded into the white space, huge multi-billion pound  markets such as global high yields, multi assets, real assets, factor-based investing. We have no legacy problems  on the upside. And we're taking a global lead on ESG, more of our inclusive capitalism. Sacha Sadan and his  team are leading the markets across the world.

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: Now, a few case studies for future growth. In 2017, we launched LGIM's Future World Fund to address the  demand for better risk-adjusted returns alongside greater ESG impacts. With over $6 billion in the fund to-date,  we have a $100 billion ambition. And our Build-to-Rent fund is currently a £1 billion business, seeded by LGC, but  it has also attracted investors from LGIM's global institutional clients. It is truly amazing that to-date we haven't  created an institutional asset class in Housing in the UK. We will change that.

file: LGENL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 6March2019 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: A couple of bits of housekeeping. Here are the usual forward-looking statements. Please switch off mobile  phones. And if there is a fire alarm, the home team will shepherd you downstairs.

texts.speaker: Nigel D. Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: In summary, against complex political, economic, weather, and market background we delivered in 2018 as we  have done consistently over the last 10 years.

texts.speaker: Jeff Davies
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: General Insurance was down due to the industry-wide adverse weather experience. In addition to our continuing  operations, we have  £79 million of operating profit from Mature Savings, which we sold in December 2017 and  expect to complete in 2019 following the Part VII transfer with a profit at that point above  £400 million. Our results  demonstrate the diversified business model that can deal with temporary fluctuations in specific markets while still  delivering consistent returns to our shareholders and investing for growth.

texts.speaker: Jeff Davies
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: GI operating profit was nil in 2018 as a result of adverse weather experience in line with the market, primarily  relating to the Q1 freeze and subsidence surge due to prolonged dry weather over the summer. Excluding both  these impacts, operating profit would have been  £26 million, and the combined operating ratio of 97%. Gross  premiums increased 11% to  £410 million, of which 36% now comes from our direct channel demonstrating the  returns on our investments in technology, SmartQuote and SmartClaim. Since the start of 2016, GI has  established nine distribution agreements with major UK financial institutions with three new partnerships going live  in 2018.

texts.speaker: Laura Mason
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Institutional Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: The table shows an updated list of our largest 10 direct investments. HMRC remains our top tenant in our  property-backed leases. We've increased our portfolio with them since this time last year by adding leases in  Glasgow, Sheffield, and Stratford, and more recently in Salford with deals sourced for by LGIM real assets who  work closely with HMRC to structure the leases as well as working with LGC to find a number of the sites. We  continue our investments in other sectors, focusing on secure cash flows and the opportunity to have a positive  impact on the daily lives of our customers and their environment.

texts.speaker: Laura Mason
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Institutional Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: The three areas of focus for us currently that meet those three preferences are Future Cities, Housing, and SME  Finance. I will cover each of those in turn. But, first, a few words on the overall deployment of our portfolio of  shareholder assets. Across LGC and treasury, we have assets of approximately £8.6 billion. £2.4 billion is in what  we call direct investment, £4.4 billion in cash or near cash, and £1.8 billion in traded assets, predominantly equity.

texts.speaker: Laura Mason
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Institutional Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: Just over £700 million is made up of joint ventures or minority shareholdings. This is mainly within the Future  Cities business which has evolved from our experience gained in urban regeneration and clean energy. The  majority of the £200 million increase in investment is from our 50/50 joint venture with Bruntwood in September  called Bruntwood SciTech. The final £500 million is an externally managed funds with our partners Pemberton for  SME lending, NTR for wind farms, and a range of venture capital funds. We invested further in all three areas  over 2018.

texts.speaker: Laura Mason
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Institutional Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: Future Cities is our business that helps future-proof the regional economies of cities. Legal & General bring  together long-term capital, experience of working with local partners, and a set of skills to help get things done.  These skills include developing workplaces with new ways of working in mind, modern retail experiences,  providing places to live, digital infrastructure, infrastructure to support mobility and clean energy to power the  cities. This image sets out our vision of a future city.

texts.speaker: Laura Mason
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Institutional Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: LGC is actively looking at investments in many of these areas. To help deliver this, we are forming partnerships  with universities, local governments and local businesses. I've picked out a few examples to bring this to life.  LGC's activities around Leeds include a joint venture to invest in our successful modern commercial and retail  scheme called The Springs at Leeds Thorpe Park, an innovation center with Bruntwood SciTech called Platform,  a build to rent scheme alongside clients of LGIM, our factory that makes modular houses, and solar and wind  farms with our partner NTR.

texts.speaker: Laura Mason
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Institutional Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: Around Manchester, we have a joint venture in MediaCity, a range of science and technology focused real estate  with Bruntwood SciTech, build to rent, a mixed use commercial property. We continue to make further  investments in the infrastructure to support Future Cities. Recent examples include our joint venture in a  datacenter development servicing the London to Cambridge corridor called The Kao Data Campus, clean energy  generation through onshore wind with NTR, investing more in renewable technology solutions such as more  efficient photovoltaic cells with Oxford PV and our investment last week in electric vehicle charging with Pod  Point.

texts.speaker: Laura Mason
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Institutional Retirement, Legal & General Group Plc
texts.text: What next for LGC? For Future Cities, we have more to do with many cities across the UK. We also think that the  concept has applicability in the U.S. Our focus on housing is execution and building out the three dimensions of  freedom strategy. For SME Finance, Paul Miller is developing an expanded strategy of our venture capital. We  clearly see the potential for DC pensions investment. Overall, we are confident that LGC can deliver good returns  for shareholders and help create assets for PRT and LGIM clients.

texts.text: In spite of the considerable rise in fuel prices, Lufthansa was still able to improve its key operating  result figures. texts.text: 4 profiting considerably from our fuel hedges. The intrinsic value of our core options went up  significantly, by a total of €435 million. This represents the difference between the strike price of our  options and the current oil price, or in other words, our advantage over the current market price.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome. Good afternoon to you, and good morning to the U.S. Welcome to our Q1 conference
texts.text: In a robust pricing environment, demand for Lufthansa Cargo remains very stable. In contrast to the  passenger airlines which can only adjust their fuel surcharges to the changing oil prices with a  delay, oil price fluctuations can be passed on to the customers much quicker on the logistics  business. The pronounced expansion of capacity is due to the reactivation of our laid-up MD-11  freighters, the inclusion of Austrian Airlines cargo activities and the marketing of AeroLogic freight  capacity. As you can see from our good load factors to date, though, we have been able to sell this  expanded capacity. Based on advanced booking figures which tend to come in a shorter period in  the freight business than with passengers, this situation is not expected to change significantly in  the near future.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome. Good afternoon to you, and good morning to the U.S. Welcome to our Q1 conference
texts.text: Even with all these short-term adjustments that we’ve been forced to make, we must continue to do  our homework and improve our cost base structurely. A good example is Lufthansa Passenger  Airline’s Climb 2011 initiative and the resulting unit cost reduction which we are committed to on our  short-haul routes. We saw clear improvement towards the end of 2010 as a result of the fleet  rollover, with the exception of the month of December when we had to cancel a number of flights  due to adverse weather condition. These improvements continued in the first quarter of 2011 as we  recorded clear unit cost reductions in all three months. Incidentally, this is true regardless of  whether fuel costs are included or not, and takes the additional expenses from air traffic tax into  account.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome. Good afternoon to you, and good morning to the U.S. Welcome to our Q1 conference
texts.text: In view of the current situation, I would like to take this opportunity to also talk again about our  hedging strategy. When I look at the performance of airline shares over recent weeks,  developments seem to be primarily by fluctuations in the oil price. We haven’t changed our  objective of our hedging strategy, which is to reduce the price volatility of external factors and to  give us more time to react so that events such as sudden hikes in oil prices have a delayed effect.  This gives us the lead time we need to adjust both of these structures and fuel surcharges. You  could say we synchronize cost with demand, as there’s a delay between bookings and journeys as  well.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome. Good afternoon to you, and good morning to the U.S. Welcome to our Q1 conference
texts.text: 8 This strategy has now served us well for many years, and because of the successful track record,  we will use this same strategy for emission certificates which we’ll have to acquire from 2012  onwards under the EU-wide Emission Trading Scheme. This strategy will involve calculating the  anticipated volume of certificates that we’ll need at the end of each year, and subsequently  purchasing them in advance and step by step over a longer period of time, thus smoothing out any  price fluctuations. We currently anticipate annual costs of between €150 million and €350 million  depending on the certificate price. The upper range corresponds to €35 per certificate, as this was  the highest figure we saw during the last peak prior to the financial crisis. Emission rights for 2012  are currently being traded at about the half, at about €18.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome. Good afternoon to you, and good morning to the U.S. Welcome to our Q1 conference
texts.text: A look at our current fuel hedging for this year reveals a now familiar picture. We are currently 75%  hedged for 2011, and 35% for 2012. The average hedging level over the next 24 months is 46%.  We will benefit from our hedging if the price of oil exceeds US$92. As I’ve already shown, this  allowed us to compensate for nearly half of the price increase seen in the first quarter of 2011.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome. Good afternoon to you, and good morning to the U.S. Welcome to our Q1 conference
texts.text: The enormous oil price burden and the events in Japan and North Africa have disrupted the course  of business, as the first quarter results show. However, we have secured our course and our goal  remains profitable growth. Under these circumstances, we confirm our outlook for the 2011  financial year, and continue to anticipate a year-on-year increase in revenue and operating profit.  We also remain committed to all of our other goals for the current financial year.

file: LHA - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 3May2012 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Volumes and pricing in the passenger business were both increased successfully. This growth made up for the  lower volumes and slight yield contraction in the freight business. Higher overall transport volumes in the  passenger and freight businesses lifted traffic revenue by €129 million. Pricing accounted for €101 million.  However, this price effect, of course, mainly reflects higher cost components which have to be recouped. It also  includes additional income of €193 million from fuel surcharges, for instance, which we also use since this year to  cover the extra cost for emissions trading. Finally, exchange rate movement added €55 million to traffic revenue  compared with last year.  If we come to the costs, the overview of the group's costs shows total expenses of €7.6 billion, a rise of €436  million or 6.1%. Additional fuel expenses alone accounted for 70% of this increase. They shot up by 23% or by  €304 million. Without fuel, total expenses would only have risen by 2.3% on the year. Thus, fuel costs are also the  major driver in the cost of materials and services, which rose by 9.4% to €4.2 billion. Fees and charges also  contributed, rising by 4.9% to €1.2 billion.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The new government instruments to finance the state deficits accounted for another €100 million. Air traffic taxes  cost €83 million and the cost of emissions trading in the first quarter came to €18 million. Staff costs went up by  4.9% to €1.7 billion in the first quarter. The average number of employees increased by 3.1%. Foreign exchange  movement, additional pension expenses and higher costs from the new wage agreement all added to expenses.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The individual drivers show the improved efficiency and productivity of our fleet. Although we expanded our  production in the sector – in the passenger sector, by 3.6%, fuel burn did not increase. Fewer volumes required  actually reduced expenses by €6 million or 0.5%.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The reason is that, thanks to the fleet renewal and new seating concepts, we can offer more seats per flight and  reduce the number of flights at the same time. The higher oil price led to an increase in fuel costs of €373 million.  Our hedging was able to absorb €114 million of this, so that the net price effect came to €259 million.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Of this, around 55% – and this is more than normal – was recouped by additional income from fuel surcharges of  €193 million. Finally, the euro's depreciation against the US dollar added €51 million to fuel costs compared with  last year. All in all, fuel costs increased from €1.3 billion to €1.6 billion.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The load factor increased by 1.9 percentage points. The reduced capacities combined with a higher load factor had  a positive impact on our average yield. In total, they increased by 0.9% year-on-year. And this is a very good  development as we have to take into account – a number of factors into account here.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Overall, the current demand development is robust and in line with our expectations. However, the volatile  environment and uncertainty in macroeconomics development makes the forecast very difficult. But at the same  time, we are seeing some ease on the cost side, in particular because of the fuel price development.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The oil price has fallen substantially in the past few weeks. Based on an average forward price of $100 per barrel  for the rest of the year, we anticipate fuel costs for the full year totaling €7 billion. This is approximately €200  million less than at the time of our last forecast, and it's around €400 million less than in the previous year.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: I had shown that fuel costs were even slightly up on year-on-year in the first quarter. So the fuel – sorry, the full  effect of the cost relief is therefore expected in the coming quarters. This is a positive development, of course, but  is certainly not one that we can rely on. Still in early April, we forecasted €400 million more in fuel costs based on  the currency rates back then.

file: LHA - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 6May2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-May-14.pdf
LHA - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 5May2015 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: A detailed look at the cost items shows strong deviation compared with the same quarter in the previous year. This  has been caused by three factors of influence: the much lower oil price, the weak euro; and the low interest rate.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: €209 million were saved in fuel costs compared to the previous year period. We benefited in particular from  cheaper oil and kerosene prices, although this was offset in part by a negative hedging result and the weakness of  the euro against the U.S. dollar.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: Lufthansa Cargo capacity will remain stable due to the ongoing active capacity management in the freighter fleet.  The changes in fuel price are playing essential role this year. For this reason, we have provided a more in -depth  fuel cost forecast for you as you see on this slide. We now expect fuel cost totaling to €6.2 billion for the full year,  which is still significantly below previous year, but €200 million than we expected two months ago.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: At the current forward rates, the savings are generated primarily from the lower kerosene price and are offset in  part by the strong U.S. dollar. We continue to expect a higher negative hedging result as in the previous years. As  you can see, we have increased the extent of our hedging in recent months. Our hedges now cover larger shares of  our fuel needs for the coming months and have also been concluded for longer periods than usual in the past.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: It is important to mention that our activities in hedging still fall within our tried and tested good hedging strategy  and that we hedge using options, meaning that we will continue to benefit from lower prices should oil prices fall.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: The oil price, exchange rates and the development of yields continue to be volatile will in turn gives rise to a  general uncertainty surrounding the forecast. We see the Lufthansa group, however, as steadily remaining on  course this year to reach the goals we have set ourselves.

file: LHA - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 3May2016 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board
texts.text: Capacity reductions on routes to the Middle East and Africa had a positive effect on the load factor. A pricing  pressure in this region remains high driven by the relatively large overlap of our traffic flows of those of the Gulf  carriers.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board
texts.text: Y ou know that the sustainability of unit cost reduction is particularly important to us. So in the upcoming  quarters, we want to show that we can keep this trend going.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board
texts.text: Our forecast to the full-year remains unchanged. We are still expecting adjusted EBIT to be slightly above the  previous year. The fuel cost projection is unchanged at €4.8 billion which is €1 billion less than last year. With the  exception of lower capacity growth, the forecast for the operating performance indicators is unchanged. However,  we may consider further reducing our capacity plan for the winter.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board
texts.text: For the unit cost, we expect the full year improvement to be less strong than in the first quarter due  to the positive  factors I already talked about. Nevertheless, we will reduce our ex-fuel unit cost this year.

texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: And what we can see today, it will not fully compensate for the still significant increase in fuel cost. Our guidance  remains, therefore, unchanged. We continue to expect an adjusted EBIT slightly below previous year.

texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: With this in mind, we confirm our unit revenue and margin outlook for both airline groups irrespective of the  slightly higher fuel cost outlook. texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
