file: LHA - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 28July2011 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The second quarter of the previous year was characterized by the immense impact of the airspace closure  occasioned by the ominous cloud of volcanic ashes. Based on the assumption that such an episode would not  recur, we had expected, let's say, normal second quarter in 2011. How wrong we were? The consequences of the  earthquake in Japan and the so called Arab Spring belts negatively affected business of some companies more  than others.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: 2011 also saw another volcanic eruption in Iceland, but at least Grímsvötn is easier to pronounce than its  Euro zone countries, and not least, following reports of the precarious federal budget situation in the United  States, macroeconomic expectations were adjusted downwards. In June, IATA too halved its airline industry profit  forecast for 2011 consequently from US$8.6 billion to US$4 billion as a result of overcapacity and the increase in  fuel prices.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The higher prices, which despite this growth, we were able to push through for tickets and price rates, contributed  €453 million to the increase which corresponds to 4.5%. This figure also includes proceeds from the air traffic tax  and higher fuel surcharges charged as compensation for the increase in costs.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The impact of changes in exchange rates is negligible at plus €15 million. Due to passenger numbers rising by 10%  and an increase of almost 14% in trade volumes, operating expenses also increased in the first half year by €1  billion, or 7.3%. More than half of the increase in total expenses can be attributed to the high oil price.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Adjusted for fuel costs, the increase was only 3.8%, which I think is remarkable given the growth of the company. I  will return to the fuel costs in detail shortly. They were, of course, also responsible for the increase of 14.3% in the  cost of materials and services. But the 17.8% increase in fees and charges resulting from increased traffic also  contributed to this as did the air traffic tax which has already been mentioned. In the first half of this year, we paid

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Now, let me give you a breakdown of the fuel costs. All-in-all, they increased by €598 million, or 24.6%, to just  over €3 billion. €234 million of this increase was due to higher demand, but the higher oil price had a far greater  impact which led to an increase of €957 million in expenses. The average oil price was US$117 per barrel in the  second quarter of 2011.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: In the same quarter last year, it was just $79 per barrel. This price increase would normally have caused a greater  increase in fuel costs. Thanks to our fuel hedges, we were able to generate a positive hedging result of €434  million, thereby compensating for almost half of the increase. The US dollar exchange rate eased the situation  further by another €159 million.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Another €93 million or minus €93 million came from time value changes before hedging transactions, despite the  fact that our hedges, as described earlier, are currently highly effective. Not only that our realized hedges have  substantially shortened our fuel bill. At the same time, the increased intrinsic value for our outstanding hedges  has clearly outgrown the negative time value changes in the P&L.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Finally, Germanwings has reacted to the fall in demand resulting from the increasing price of oil by sharply  reducing its capacities as from summer flight timetable. It was thereby possible to keep the load factor stable  overall in the first half year. After six months, however, an operating loss of €46 million is in the accounts, €7  million more than in the previous year.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: And at this point, I would like to address my thanks to the German government which had its share by introducing  the air traffic tax. Thus Germanwings, too, of course, has initiated steps to safeguard earnings and expects the full  year to bring the operating result higher than that of the previous year.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Here you can see the structural effect on the top right-hand corner. New aircraft models that we incorporate into  our fleet typically has larger numbers of seats than their predecessor models. This reduces not only the unit cost,  but also the environmental burden. Let us, for example, take a look at the A380. If we compare it with a Boeing  747-400, an A380 has around 50% more seats in the economy class, but only 25% more seats in first and business  class.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Let me again remind you of the drivers of our capacity growth. Firstly, there is the base effect of around 1% caused  mainly by weather-related cancellations in the winter flight plan. The aforementioned measures for increasing  productivity have an impact of 7% in the winter timetable. We had originally foreseen around 4% for pure network  expanding or genuine growth. That makes a total of 12%. As part of the review, we've now adjusted these plans to  the normalizing market growth rates and will refrain from implementing some of the planned measures in 2011.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Let's come to the fuel. We also updated our forecast for fuel costs. For the current financial year, we have 75%  hedged under Lufthansa Passenger Airlines. This figure is even at 85%. And the group as a whole, the hedging  level for 2012 is currently 50%. The so called breakeven point in the oil price, after which we benefit from our  hedging, has in the meantime increased to $94 per barrel.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We are nevertheless expecting lower costs in 2011. All in all, our forecasts for fuel costs in the current financial  year now amounts to €6.4 billion. This sum is about €100 million lower than in our last updated May. This is  caused mainly by the downward trend in the oil futures price.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: However, the slight decrease in our expected fuel price cost is not stopping us from continuing our search for new  ways of making structural improvements to our fuel efficiency. That is why we're continuing to invest in new  technologies.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: As you know, we have ordered a total of 190 aircraft for the next few years. These will be delivered gradually. We  are looking forward to the additional A380 aircraft, the B747 eight intercontinental, the A320neo and new C- Series from Bombardier, for example. This capital expenditure will ease the burden on both the environment and  our cost base because in addition to any other advantages they provide, they improve the fuel efficiency after all.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The CapEx plan, which includes these orders, now provides for capital expenditure payments totaling €2.7 billion  to €2.9 billion for the current and following years. These figures include not only large aircraft, however, but all of  the group's capital expenditure. And sometimes even the smallest things can have a large impact. Contributions of  that kind will also come from innovative projects and products such as the new lightweight container for air  freight or the Light Weight Quantum Trolley developed by LSG Sky Chefs, which is now going to be used  throughout the entire Lufthansa fleet. This product alone will make it possible to save up to 9,000 tons of  kerosene per year.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We're also participating in the Pure Sky project, which will involve us using bio fuel in regular flight operations for  and Frankfurt four times a day with an engine who is fuel has a 50% biosynthetic kerosene component. The  objectives of this trial phase are to reduce CO2 emissions, of course, and to investigate the effect of biofuels on the  maintenance and the service life of engines because in our industry too the future lies in the search for alternative  fuels and technologies.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: As we're aware of the fact that there have been some critical voices in the recent past about our long-term testing  demonstrates one point. Our biofuels are being processed sustainably. This means the used raw materials do not  compete with agricultural food production. As I conclude my presentation, though, let us remain in the near  future. The burdens I mentioned in the beginning will naturally have an impact on our full year results.  Fundamentally, however, we're also expecting the positive trends in the amount of sales to persist.

file: LHA - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 2August2012 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Traffic revenue grew by €608 million and, therefore, influenced the development of the group revenue decisively.  Of this, €252 million came from the increase in volume, while €278 million is attributable to higher ticket price  and freight rates. This item also includes the fuel surcharge and air traffic tax, which are intended to offset the  primarily generated by the business segments MRO, IT Services and Catering, also improved, increasing by 8.8%  or €216 million.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Fuel costs are part of the material expenses which rose by €726 million or 9% year-on-year. Nearly 90% of this  amount was due to fuel expenses, an issue that I will address in more detail shortly. €110 million can further be  attributed to higher fees and charges, including air traffic tax. Together, these two cost increases accounted for  €752 million and were thus stronger than the overall rise in the cost of materials. In other words, we actually  lowered the cost that we were able to influence directly in this cost line.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: As promised, we have here closer look at our fuel costs. Fuel prices were the main driver causing a cost increase of  €605 million alone. In the first half year of 2012, the average oil price was another $3 higher than in the previous  year's period at $114 a barrel. As a reverse effect, the volume, that means our fuel consumption, actually decreased  slightly due to the reduction in the number of flights. Moreover, our fuel hedging limited the fuel cost increase by  more than a quarter, thanks to positive hedging result of €154 million.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: However, the weakness of the euro against the US dollar had a very negative impact. While in the same period last  year, the euro was still worth $1.40. It was only worth $1.30 in the first half year of 2012. This sector alone caused  our fuel cost to increase by €214 million. This effect is often overlooked in public debate about fuel surcharges.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: However, other financial items amounting to minus €148 million, once again, were a heavy burden on EBIT.  These items were almost entirely lower time values of fuel options in the amount of €122 million, which has to be  recognized as cost in the income statement in accordance with IFRS standards.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: On the cost side, our fuel expense forecast had slightly decreased. We even saw a significant fall of the oil price  followed by a small rise. As a result, we reduced our forecast from 7.5% at our Q1 conference to now €7.4 million –  sorry, €7.5 million at our Q1 conference to now €7.4 million – billion, sorry. As you are aware, our forecast is  based on forward prices of oil and exchange rate for the remainder of the year. On July 20, when we did the  forecast, these were $106 for a barrel of oil and nearly $1.28 to the euro. We all know how dynamically these  parameters are currently fluctuating.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: This sub-project is also a good example of SCORE's sustainable character. This is something we have a strong  focus on, in order to find the leverage to reduce both complexity and costs, although part of this particular project  savings might only become full visible beyond the time horizon of the SCORE project – or program.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: SCORE also does examine external cost items. The group airlines, Lufthansa, SWISS and Austrian Airlines, have  launched a joint project designed to improve fuel efficiency. This is expected to boost earnings by up to €60  million in the course of the program. Besides the introduction of a uniform KPI system, best practices in fuel  reduction, which are already in place in individual companies, will be rolled out systematically throughout the  group – the airline group.

file: LHA - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 2August2013 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: So, where were the challenges in the first half-year, and where was the excitement? Certainly, strikes and weather  as well as currency and fuel price movements did challenge us. And we are glad that we concluded an important  wage deal with our ground staff and continued to make progress with SCORE.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: This good development was mainly driven by lower cost of material. In the cost of material, fuel costs fell by 2.5%.  The main driver of this development is not lower fuel prices; they are being compensated by a negative hedging  result in our case. It is the lower fuel consumption which stems from a mix of less flights and more efficient  aircraft. We produced the same capacity with 5.1% less flights.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Let me further illustrate the positive effect of the accelerating fleet rollover. Last year, we managed to reduce the  average fuel consumption by around 3% to now only 4 liters per passenger per 100 kilometers flown and we work  hard to further optimize it. The lower number of flights had a positive impact also on other cost items. Fees and  charges reduced by 0.9%.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We still forecast a fuel bill of €7 billion. That means €400 million less than in 2012. As we have had already  savings of €90 million in the first half-year, we should see roughly another €300 million to come over the course  of the third quarter and fourth quarter, mainly driven by volume and lower prices, which, however, continue to be  partly offset by negative hedging results.

file: LHA - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 31July2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We will now grow only 3% instead of 5% in the winter schedule. We will take out the equivalent of three long-haul  and five short-haul aircraft. With a new winter schedule, we currently project full-year capacity growth to be 2% to  3%. Unchanged, we target a 4% unit cost reduction versus last year, of which about two percentage points are  coming from the change in depreciation policy.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Also unchanged, we expect fuel costs to be at €6.7 billion in the full year, which means a relief of about €400  million compared to last year. Given that we had already some €250 million lower fuel cost in the first half year,  we can only expect smaller reductions in the third and fourth quarter. As this relief is mainly driven by a weak U.S.  dollar, which is at the same time a burden on revenues, we would see €150 million to €200 million of the lower  fuel costs to become a benefit on the bottom line. More than half of this we have already seen in the first half year.

file: LHA - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 30July2015 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: Fuel costs are having a positive impact at least quarter. Following the higher fuel cost forecast in the last quarter,  the oil price trend and in particular the weaker U.S. dollar has prompted us to cut the cost forecast again. We now  expect total cost for kerosene of €6 billion again in the current financial year.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: Lower fuel cost continued to be a double-edged sword, that is due to its cost in the short-term, but potentially  hindered consolidation and bring additional capacity into the market in the medium term and longer term. The  danger that long-term low fuel cost will have a negative impact on revenue in the coming quarters has increased  with a renewed drop in the oil prices. Also because of this, we now expect lower revenue per available seat- kilometers in the second half. Nevertheless, the lower fuel costs have made insignificant contributions to the  improvement in earnings in the first half year. Despite intense competition, we succeeded in keeping revenue at a  level that resulted in the solid improvement in our margin. Nevertheless, we will have to continue working on the  performance of our unit costs and unit revenues adjusted for the currency effects.

file: LHA - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 2August2016 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Fees and charges. At the moment, they are the airlines' biggest cost factor, even ahead of fuel. Fee negotiations  with Fraport are making progress. We are insisting that the charges do not go any further. This year, we are  already seeing significant reductions, among others, a German Air Traffic Control and the Zürich Airport came up  and totaled to €85 million of savings. But that alone is not enough. We continue to negotiate because we are  convinced that everyone in the value chain has to contribute to achieve the necessary efficiency gains in our  industry, not just the airlines.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: At the same time, the management of Lufthansa Technik has initiated efficiency programs to cut specific segment  rollout cost. In the years ahead, €70 million per year are to be saved in the administrative budget. Engine  maintenance, it will generate efficiency gains of 40% due to the recent agreement with our collective bargaining  partners. Overall, we expect a reduction of 700 jobs over the next few years here in Germany.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lufthansa Cargo is also obviously due to the difficult markets working hard to achieve more competitive cost  structure. Its efficiency program C40 should stepwise deliver annual savings of €80 million by 2018. And high  income for innovative products, expanding partnership and last but not least also continued, this transition should  also help us to improve earnings. And the aim here, to expand the leading position of our service companies. We  are number one globally by means of profitable growth.

file: LHA - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 2August2017 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Ex-fuel unit cost came down by 3.4% in the second quarter on the back of unit cost reductions at all three  Network Airlines and organic growth of Eurowings. The first time consolidation of Brussels Airlines and the wet- lease of Air Berlin further support this development by a mix impact of 0.8 percentage points.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: As stated before, we expect constant currency unit revenues to turn negative, and particularly due to the  uncertainty in trading in the fourth quarter and the dependency on short-term bookings. We continue to expect the  reduction of non-fuel constant currency unit cost and expect them to be slightly negative in the second half of the  year despite higher passenger volumes and therefore additional passenger-related cost. As is visible in the first  half year however, cost per passenger are coming down and profit goes up.

file: LHA - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 31July2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Integration cost at Eurowings partly masked a very solid operating performance across the business. Excluding  the one-off charges at Eurowings, Lufthansa group would have recorded profit growth, irrespective of the fuel cost  increase in the quarter. This demonstrates the progress we have made in structurally improving the group's  profitability.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: In the reporting period, it became evident that the entire European aviation ecosystem is facing a lot of  operational pressures. In the second quarter, in particular, flight cancellations and delays were caused by strikes  and the general shortage of personnel at the air traffic control operations. Infrastructure limitations at airports and  adverse weather conditions also impacted. We very much regret that this has led to inconveniences for many of  our passengers across the different group airlines.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We expect integration costs amount to another €50 million in the third quarter, but do not anticipate any further  impact thereafter. Fuel cost increased by more than €200 million in the second quarter, driven by a higher price  but also greater volumes.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: As a result, we expect the reduction of constant currency unit cost ex-fuel to reach the lower end of our additional  1 to 2 percentage target range. This means that the cost reduction would be higher in the second half year  compared to the first half year and amount to around 1% in the full-year 2018. In addition, the fuel increase will be  larger than projected at the beginning of the year. As of the end of June, we expect fuel cost in 2018 to become  approximately €850 million higher compared to the previous year.

file: LHA - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 28October2010 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Welcome to our Analyst Conference for the presentation of the results from January to September.
texts.text: You’ll probably remember, the start into the year was not the most ideal one. We had extreme  winter operation. We had a sort of self-fabricated losses of production due to strikes, and the  needless airspace lockdowns that followed the volcano eruption in Iceland led to major production  losses and resulted in immense costs for us. But all this is behind, and we have caught up again,  and the recovery of the market helped us to record a positive result in all of our business segments.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Welcome to our Analyst Conference for the presentation of the results from January to September.
texts.text: Our cost reduction and efficiency improvement program, CLIMB 2011, is on track and is making  progress in all the fields. It will achieve its goal to improve the earnings at Lufthansa Passenger  Airline by 1 billion euros by the year 2011.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Welcome to our Analyst Conference for the presentation of the results from January to September.
texts.text: The familiar close-up of fuel costs reveals that, alongside the effect of consolidation which  increased fuel expenses by almost 400 million euros, it was primarily the higher oil price and  adverse exchange rate movements that were responsible for pushing up costs, adding 652 million  euros and 153 million, respectively.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Welcome to our Analyst Conference for the presentation of the results from January to September.
texts.text: The pronounced pace of the global economic recovery from which we and, indeed, the majority of  the aviation industry are benefiting has, of course, also its downside. And so the overall recovery  has a direct effect on the market for crude oil. The price of forwards for delivery in December 2011       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Welcome to our Analyst Conference for the presentation of the results from January to September.
texts.text: For the full year 2010, we are still expecting fuel costs of 5.2 billion euros. For 2011, we anticipate  that the figure will increase to 6.0 billion, based on the current forward rates. At the same time, the  effects of prices rises are reduced by our systematic hedging policy, which we have not altered.  Our break-even price for 2010 is still 78 U.S. dollars, and for 2011 it stands at 88 U.S. dollars. Our  hedging ratio for 2011 is currently 61%.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Welcome to our Analyst Conference for the presentation of the results from January to September.
texts.text: Further progress has been made here in recent months in key areas of the initiative. We have  already implemented measures to secure savings of more than 230 million euros in the current  financial year. In administrative areas, agreements have already been signed that will deliver 70%  of the targeted reduction in staff capacity in a socially acceptable manner. The hiring freeze in this  area has also been extended.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Welcome to our Analyst Conference for the presentation of the results from January to September.
texts.text: The rollover of the short-haul fleet is progressing smoothly. So far, 44 out of 49 50-seaters have  been retired. This increases the productivity of direct traffic even further and brings the cost base in  this area closer to the standard among competitors flying with larger aircraft, without jeopardizing  the USP of the Lufthansa brand. In fact, the new aircraft do not just provide greater comfort; they  are also more fuel efficient and thus combine economic and ecological advantages.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Welcome to our Analyst Conference for the presentation of the results from January to September.
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I have now reached an important topic and the last one in my presentation,  the famous outlook. At the half-year conference, I commented with despair that we had wished for  a smoother and calmer flight over the first six months of 2010, but in fact we came up against  considerable headwinds, which by the way is good if you climb, but if we are on travel altitude,  backwinds are not too bad. Now three months later, we can justifiably say that we have made good  use of the weather conditions to gain additional altitude. If you will allow me briefly to use an  analogy from a different industry, for a change, we have been able to get the horsepower to the  ground.

file: LHA - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 27October2011 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The group results stand at €288 million, a minus of 42% – sorry, 45%. Of course, this is not the goal that we have  dreamt of and that we have set ourselves, but it is nevertheless a considerable result in comparison to our  competitors here in the European environment.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Fourth, despite all our cost saving measures, the increase in costs due to fuel prices and taxes as well as, for  example, the new cost for the EU emissions trading scheme that we will probably be facing as of 2012 and the fees  and charges of oligopolistic suppliers, they nullify our efforts time and time again and we have to solve this issue.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: First, the unilateral EU emissions trading scheme which shall be introduced as of January 1, 2012. Despite  extensive international protests, the EU unflinchingly maintains its collision course with major countries, so much  that the United States just this week passed the EU ETS Prohibition Act in the House of Representatives with an  overwhelming majority. The Act forbids US carriers to participate in EU emissions trading, and this is not the only  country.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We have put together an extensive catalog of short-term measures for this winter schedule at Lufthansa Cargo, but  all of these measures are economically and ecologically nothing short of grotesque. However, we are forced to act  in this way in order to at least maintain some of our freights turnarounds in order to help out our customers who  have relied on our Lufthansa Cargo services. With regard to the costs, we expect an additional bottom line burden  in the mixed double digit millions for Lufthansa Cargo alone.  European aviation must in part deal with the framework conditions. We may complain, we may suggest  improvements, but in the end of the day, that's where we can do our business. And it is clear that these conditions  differ entirely from those of many important competitors, for example, in the Middle East or Asia. But during the  next 10 to 20 years, it must at least be – we must be in a position to keep up with these companies. And in itself,  this is an ambitious goal, no doubt about it. We will have to be able to make enough money to connect Europe to  the rest of world safely and efficiently. We have to earn the money to modernize our fleets. No profits, no fuel  efficient, no ecologically sensitive aircraft. And beyond that, we have to offer our shareholders the dividends to  attract them to invest in our industry and a decent perspective for the future.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: However, I can be brief here and I won't indulge in such a lengthy review. And I know that you know all the  buzzwords like Arab Spring and earthquake and nuclear disaster in Japan and the discussion about a new global  financial crisis and also the already mentioned preliminary night flight ban in Frankfurt that is all more than  enough to refresh your memories.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: In line with passenger numbers and trade volumes, which each grew at 8% operating expenses, climbed by €1.8  billion or 8.4%. Once again, the oil price was the largest driver behind the increase in total expenses. Adjusted for  fuel costs, the growth was much more modest at 5.2%. I will take a look at the fuel costs in detail in just a moment.  As often, they were the prime reason behind the 12.8% rise in the cost of materials and services. However, fees  and charges were also up 15.7% in connection with higher traffic figures, which contributed to the increase as well.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: As promised, I would like to give you the usual overview of our fuel costs, which climbed by €913 million overall to  €4.8 billion. This corresponds to an increase of 23.7%. Greater fuel consumption accounted for €302 million.  However, the higher oil price, as you can see, was responsible for the major part of the additional cost,  contributing €1.5 billion to the fuel bill.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The average oil price, by the way, in the last three quarters was US$112 per barrel. This is 43.3% up on the first  nine months of last year. The price rise could have had an even greater impact on fuel costs. However, our  systematic fuel hedging generated a positive hedging result of €616 million, thereby compensating for 40% of the  price increase. And finally, the US dollar exchange rate eased the overall situation further by €312 million.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The other earnings indicators reflect the weaker operating result as well and fell further due to the impact of IAS  39 implication and valuation effects on other financial items. I've talked about these effects in the previous two  quarters. I try not to do it again, but I'm happy, of course, to answer questions here if you have any at the end. The  valuation effects that are – I still call it virtual negative impact of €116 million on the financial results almost  exclusively because of the fuel hedges, while at the same time our fuel hedging instruments alleviated fuel costs  significantly in real terms as I've just shown.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Please note that much of the remaining additional capacity arises from measures under the Climb 2011 initiatives  and brings about a sustainable improvement in our cost base and competitiveness. I'd just like to remind you of  the fleet rollover from the 50 seater to the 90 seater and the introduction of the new lightweight seats which have  increased capacity as such by almost 8% in this business segment.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Unlike the general mood and our booking indicators, the oil price has so far proven unaffected by the economic  forecast and remains high, and this is an unusual pattern too. Our fuel forecast for the full year 2011 remains  unchanged at €6.4 billion. As I've already shown, our hedging transactions give us a clear advantage over the  market price. However, this advantage is dwindling down from month-to-month as the hedges we concluded at  very favorable prices back in 2009 gradually expire and are being replaced by less favorable hedges.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Nonetheless, our hedges, of course, remain effective also for next year. And if the oil price falls over the coming  months, we would participate as well. Our hedging transactions for 2012 currently breakeven at a price of US$104  per barrel as the blue line on the left-hand side of the chart shows. As of today, we have 63% of our fuel  requirements for next year.

texts.speaker: Stephan Gemkow
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: There are simply too many factors involved with booking factors being extremely volatile and trends changing  literally from week-to-week. It's also uncertain to what extent the oil price will adjust to the macroenvironment.

file: LHA - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 31October2012 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: SWISS remains our high achiever even if the framework conditions have deteriorated with a strong Swiss franc  and high oil price having negative effect.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The topic of fuel efficiency. Seeing us create new structures that will help us to implement not only airline specific  measures, but also cross-airline cost-saving measures more quickly.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: At the initial conclusion of SCORE, we can say that we will achieve our SCORE target for 2012 and much more  shall be significantly exceeding the planned contribution of €280 million. However, what we will not yet be  achieving this year is an improvement in earnings, this simply being eaten up by the obstacles that we face. Above  all, the high kerosene prices for which we have had to plan additional costs of approximately €1.1 billion for 2012.  Therefore we plan additional measures at the airlines as well as in the other areas of the group.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The increase of €972 million in fuel costs that I mentioned was driven solely by a higher price and ForEx effect.  The average market price for Brent in U.S. dollars was only slightly higher than the same period last year.  However, this price was further driven up by €455 million due to the euro's weakness against the U.S. dollar.  Furthermore, in 2011, we had benefited stronger from our fuel hedges. As we continue to apply our rolling hedge  system, this means that its effect diminished over time, if oil prices remain on a high level.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: In the first nine months of 2012, our hedges only shortened fuel cost by €145 million. This is only a quarter of the  hedging result we recorded a year ago. If you look at it for a second time, you will notice that this number is  exactly the same as the figure I gave you for the first half-year. Unfortunately, this is not a bug, the number is  correct, and it means that in the third quarter we did not save money at all with our hedges.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: On the other hand, it needs to be mentioned that our capacity management had a positive impact. By flying larger  aircraft, we were able to cut the numbers of flights, while the number of available seats even went up slightly. This,  combined with phased-in of more modern aircraft, reduced kerosene consumption and saved €49 million in fuel  costs.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: There is, unfortunately, also no relief inside for our number one cost driver, fuel. Fuel remains volatile on a high  level. The way the market is behaving, anything is possible of course. But at the moment, we cannot assume that  prices will fall in near future. Our projected fuel cost has fluctuated over recent months between €7.4 billion and  €7.6 billion. Currently, that is for mid-October, they stand at €7.4 billion for the full year.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: However, this still represents additional expenses of €1.1 billion compared with last year. We have to make up for  this fuel budget which has been rising for years with other operational cost savings. I explained earlier that this  cannot be achieved solely by means of hedging and fuel surcharges.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: I can only say again, anyone who wants to survive in this face of high, volatile fuel prices and perform well, has no  alternative but to adapt their structures to these new cost levels. Then the fluctuations in kerosene prices will still  give a headache, but they won't break one's neck. That's another reason why we need SCORE.

file: LHA - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 31October2013 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Looking a little bit further ahead, we do not expect that this process of change is ending in 2015 with the  completion of our SCORE Program. SCORE represents only the first milestone in the management of the  continuous changing within our company. And as long as the environment and the markets we are operating in  are dynamically changing, this will also be reflected in internal changes for the Lufthansa Group in order to stay  the market leader here in Europe and keep this leadership position.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The second major workflow is a comprehensive package of measures to improve the profitability of our long-haul  flights by a sustainable 10% reduction in unit cost. Shorter round times, additional fuel efficiency measures, the  introduction of a premium economy class or two-class flights on certain routes are only some of the initiatives,  which all together, are contributing to this 10% reduction.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: So Lufthansa will continue to do our share to improve results and reach our targets, but let me use this  opportunity today to say quite clearly that we also expect here in the new German government coalition that is  being formed, that we have to improve also, that they have to work on the legal framework, which is quite  burdening here in the German environment and that there is need for action.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Our success, at the same time, in this environment depends also substantially on constant investment and here  too, we have delivered. The modernization of our fleet is continuing. And as you know, we have communicated our  just placed orders for 59 new long-haul aircraft, with a total list price of €14 billion to be delivered between 2016  and 2025. So this is a mid to long-term perspective of fuel efficient and less environmentally burdening fleet and  providing us with a substantial reduction in unit cost in the production.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: This good development was reached through cost control. We managed to reduce non-fuel cost in absolute terms  and the unit cost in the passenger business. A decrease in a non-fuel unit cost of 1.2% is quite remarkable for an  airline which is not growing in terms of capacity.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: In Q3, non-fuel costs increased slightly by 0.4% and staff costs increased by 4.6%. Both figures are normalized for  one-off items again. As always, a detailed overview of translating the profit from operating activities into the  operating profit can be found in the Annex. In there, you'll find, for example, book gains or losses that are not  included in the operating result.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: While the revenue side remained disappointing, I'm happy to report to you that our unit cost position improved  again. In the first nine months, the non-fuel cost reduced by 1.2%. And in the third quarter, we even managed to  reduce the non-fuel cost by 2.6%. This is the desired outcome from our measures.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: On the fuel side, we currently see a little relief. For the full year 2013, the fuel cost forecast now stands at €7.1  billion as I indicated last week during our call already, which is less than the €7.2 billion, we had expected a  couple of weeks ago. This means €300 million lower fuel cost in 2013 versus 2012. Given that, we had €161  million lower costs in the first nine months, we should now be seeing more than €100 million benefit in the fourth  quarter.

file: LHA - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 30October2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: At the same time, however, we unfortunately have to reduce our expectations for 2015. The economic outlook for  next year has changed from where we were earlier this year, and so have the growth forecast for our core markets.  As you know, the air industry is strongly dependent on economic developments. This means we need to be more  careful with regard to passenger and freight volumes. As a reaction to this, we have adjusted our capacity plans of  the next year to only 3% growth now.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: This also applies to retirement and transitional benefits. All of our employees, with the exception of the German  main line pilots have made contribution to Lufthansa's success in the future. Our detailed offer to redesign the  transitional benefits includes a comprehensive retention of the current status and privileges and a gradual  transition to sustainable model for all current pilots. Even after this change, the transitional benefits would still be  among the best in our industry.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: The detailed cost figures for the third-quarter show a development which is in line with the year-to-date numbers.  In contrast to the first half year, we have almost no fuel cost benefit in the third quarter. Fuel costs were only  down by €9 million. Nevertheless, we have strongly improved our fuel efficiency.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: Year-to-date, we increased our total transported tonne-kilometers by 3% while the fuel volumes consumed  increased by only 1%. Our specific fuel consumption improved by 1.6%, which is equivalent to around about €100  million on a full-year basis.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: Our fuel forecast remains unchanged, despite the strong movement in the oil price and the euro-U.S. dollar rate in  the past weeks. The sensitivity analysis, however, shows that the upside potential from falling oil prices is small  for this year. Even more important than the current swing is, however, the fact that we continue to reduce our fuel  consumption constantly as I explained earlier.

file: LHA - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 29October2015 410 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our balance sheet also looks more stable in comparison to the previous year. It is one of the reasons why our  investment-grade rating was once again confirmed this year. Essentially, four factors have contributed to the good  results. First of all, the low oil price. However, as you can see, it was by far not the only reason why our results  improved. Secondly, and maybe most important for our strategy, our premium products, the investments are  paying off.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: We are aware, however, that the interest rate and, therefore, this item of our balance sheet, continues to be  volatile. The need to make adjustments to the Lufthansa Group pension system has, therefore, not changed. A  look at the income statement shows the extraordinary high reduction in fuel cost of €377 million in the third  quarter. This is a bigger saving than in the entire preceding six months together and results from the particularly  strong decrease in the oil price compared with the same period last year.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: Due to the drop in oil prices in recent months, we expect an even greater reduction in fuel costs. Our forecast for  cost of €6 billion at the half-year point is now at €5.7 billion. On a full-year basis, this represents a decrease of  over €1 billion compared with last year. We expect the further cost reduction of slightly more than €300 million in  the fourth quarter, based on the assumptions outlined. As a result of our proven option-based fuel hedging  strategy, we benefit from falling oil prices sooner than our competitors. But we will also see significant relief in  this cost item next year, which is now 73% hedged.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And now, coming to the end, coming to the third action area: continuously improving efficiency. SCORE has now  crossed the finish line and we will proceed as a continuous efficiency improvement program as one of our seven  areas of action. Our tried and tested pipeline of earnings-increasing measures will also be well filled in the future.  We have already defined measures that are intended to generate cost savings of about €1 billion for 2016. The  improvement of our efficiency has become an ongoing task, which is just what we have strived for.

file: LHA - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 2November2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Nevertheless, the decline in fuel prices, which is about half of the number I just showed you, and the particular  geopolitical situation had a highly adverse impact. In a more stable environment and with slightly higher oil prices,  we are expecting the decrease of unit revenues to slow significantly as we go into the next year.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The third criterion is that the transition must open up new or attractive markets. The Belgium market is one of the  biggest catchment areas in Europe with significantly above average purchasing power.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: You may remember that we were the only major European airline to deliver on its original full year forecast last  year when most other European airlines were falling short of theirs. At that time, this had been mainly a result of  our successful active steering and our ability to redirect traffic flows with our dense network in an environment  burdened by terrorists and new political uncertainty.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: At the same time, constant currency non-fuel unit cost were down 9.9%. All these resulted in a slight margin  increase to 17.6% in the quarter. Lufthansa Cargo has seen the continuation recovery of demand across all  regions and a consistent implementation of the C40 cost-saving program.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: This goal has already moved further along. We now have been taking on a shaping role in the rapidly advancing  consolidation in Europe. And we are able to invest again in profitable growth in many parts of our company. The  basis for the sustainability of our business is and remains to consistently reduce our costs. Reducing complexity,  leveraging efficiencies, and continuously lowering unit costs are essential to continued successful development.

file: LHA - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 30October2018 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: All of you are very well familiar with the airline business. You all know how important it is to be the market leader  at this or that location. And we will be seeing and feeling all the benefit that this status brings in Eurowings as  well. In developing Eurowings, we also have shown that the Lufthansa Group can drive Europe's industry  consolidation. That trend is sure to continue. It may be at a slower pace and less visibly than with the media  mergers we have seen in the U.S. But we also have just six European airlines go into insolvency in the last three  months alone. The rising oil prices are likely to accelerate this development. Only airlines with a strong market  position and a sound customer base can survive higher oil prices for an extended length of time.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: So, for 2019 and the years beyond, the Lufthansa Group will be doing everything in its power to reflect these  higher oil prices even better in the prices of our tickets. If oil is costing over $80 a barrel, flying cannot and flying  will not remain as cheap as it can be at a barrel price of just $30. As Europe's leading aviation group, we are  confident for the future despite these oil prices. With an adjusted EBIT of €2.4 billion, we have achieved not just a  very solid nine months result, we have also further added to our financial strength. For 2018, as a whole, we still  expect to report an adjusted EBIT result that is slightly below last year's record levels. In other words, we are  confident that we can largely offset the higher cost of more than €1 billion that will occur this year through higher  fuel prices and the repercussions of our operational instabilities.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together

texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: We have of course also saved and are continuing to review, and where necessary, correct our  processes and our cost base, despite, or maybe rather especially in order to secure the financing of  our considerable investments throughout the next years. texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, now let’s turn to our outlook for 2011. Lufthansa is a driving force of innovation in our  industry and a company focused on long-term success and profitable growth.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: Europe is therefore in danger of losing its role as one of the logistics centers of the world. Detours would have to be flown on many routes,  resulting in significantly longer flight times and up to 40% more emissions, for example, on the  routes from Europe to Asia.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: The German air traffic tax, which was, unfortunately, introduced in January only in Germany, not  EU-wide, is another uncertain factor whose true implications we are currently not yet able to  assess. How this tax will affect the booking figures on the entire year remains to be seen. However,  it is a fact that it will hit our customers where it hurts. And it will also hit us, because we are unable  pass the whole amount of this tax on to our customers, given the current very severe competitive  situation in Europe. So Lufthansa must bear a significant portion of it in our company’s result.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: A further aspect is the fact that the tax affects European airlines will be much more serious in the  future than the effect on non-European airlines. texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: Another point of criticism is the speed how the Single European Sky, the largest environmental  project in the EU, is moving forward. texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together

texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: And according to the latest forecasts, airfreight will also increase by 6.4% per year until 2014 and  we, of course, also want to benefit from this development. texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: The structural improvements mentioned earlier and our continued cost management can be seen  by looking at the different expense items. All cost items went up significantly less than revenue in  2010. Total expenses climbed by 16.7% to €28.9 billion, or by 8.3% after adjusting for consolidation  effects. For this increase, the higher oil price is largely responsible. If we adjust expenses for fuel  costs too, they were just 4.6% higher in 2010 than in the previous year. The cost of materials and  services rose by 21% to €15.4 billion. And as fuel costs account for a large proportion of this item, I  will go into more detail later, as you know.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: Now we come to the detailed breakdown of fuel costs. They went up by a total of €1.5 billion to €5.2  billion. The additional capacity only accounted for €68 million of that. And I think this is remarkable,  because it really reflects the use of the larger, more fuel efficient aircraft, creating more capacity,  but at the same time not creating more fuel burn, which, of course, is twice important, because of  the fuel cost and the emission certificates we need in the future.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: The main factor driving the cost up was the oil price, which rose by 27.8%, setting the Group back  €795 million. Thanks to our well-known systematic hedging, we were nevertheless able to mitigate  this rise slightly by €21 million. The stronger U.S. dollar increased our purchasing costs further by  €261 million. However, I should say that in 2010, we also realized approximately €65 million income  from U.S. dollar hedges that can be clearly and directly attributed to the fuel exposure. So in total,  our hedges basically had a value of between €80 million and €90 million. Last but not least, the  expansion of the Group accounted for a further €410 million.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: One of the main drivers is cost reduction in the loss-making decentral traffic. By exchanging smaller  aircraft for larger, more fuel-efficient models we were able to increase the average body size in  decentral traffic from 76 to 91 seats, which has already reduced unit costs significantly. The new  so-called Europe cabin will bring further improvements here.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: I should also mention that, of course, bmi is in a very difficult environment currently, as you – at  least those of you who come from the U.K. know. The U.K. market was the only market last year  which has seen a reduction in the number of passengers. Only in the U.K. was this the case. And a  number of governmental cost cutting is underway and the environment is really difficult.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: And those of you who follow bmi more closely also know that their main – one of their main traffic  areas is into the Arabic countries and North African countries, which, of course, are currently also  no easy territories to serve. But as I said, we are very satisfied with the progress of the [ph] First Air  but we, of course, have to recognize, the environment is very different than what it has been a year  ago.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: At our last conference in October 2010, the pace of the global economic recovery had already  contributed to a notable price increase of oil and kerosene. However, the first few months of 2011  have seen escalating unrest in Libya, which alongside Nigeria, has the largest oil reserves in Africa.  And this caused oil prices to reach their highest level for more than two and a half years.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: On the basis of current futures prices, we are anticipating fuel expenses now of €6.8 billion for  2011. And compared with fuel expenses of €5.2 billion for 2010, this represents a rise of another  30.8% or €1.6 billion. Lufthansa Passenger Airlines, the other companies in the Airline Group and  Lufthansa Cargo, have responded to these developments with adjustments to their fuel surcharges  and will continue to monitor oil price movements closely. And you should not be surprised to see  fuel surcharge increases.

texts.speaker: Frank Hülsmann, Head-Investor Relations
texts.profession: This is the first conference for our new CEO, Christoph Franz, who will present the results together
texts.text: But we still have to go a long way until the end of the year. And as with every long-haul flight,  there’s always the risk in business that some turbulence may occur. Therefore, severe weather  conditions cannot be ruled out, particularly in the form of future further oil price hikes, intensive  competition and also, upcoming collective bargaining, although we are little bit more relaxed in that  regard as than we have been some months ago. To the extent to which the air traffic tax will lead to  a downturn in demand is also still difficult to predict.
