texts.text: As I already mentioned and also Christoph mentioned it, our operating result was nevertheless down by around  €300 million compared with the previous year. One of the main headwinds was the €1.1 billion rise in fuel costs.  This clearly illustrates how important this program has already become to the Lufthansa Group. Christoph will  therefore provide you with a more detailed inside into SCORE's successes in 2012, and the measures currently  underway.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: With regard to operating costs, we have seen an encouraging development. They went up by 4.3% last year, it  doesn't sound encouraging, I agree. The main driver behind this increase was fuel costs, which added cost of €1.1  billion year-on-year. Excluding fuel, operating costs would have risen by 0.8% only, far less than the revenue  growth. And we have reached this good performance despite higher fees and charges.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: On the one hand, we have managed capacity intelligently. On the other hand, we achieved many cost savings  through the SCORE program. Taking a closer look at the individual drivers, we can see that the rise in fuel costs  was due in particular to the higher of the price, to the higher oil price with an impact of €876 million, and  currency effects with an impact of €519 million. These almost eat up the positive effect of the exchange rates on  revenue. By the way, in total, exchange rates had a negative impact of €109 million on the operating result 2012.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: As I said, the fuel price development will have a significant impact on our results. We expect our largest external  cost item to remain on a high level. However, as of today, we can expect a slight relief. Projected fuel costs have  fallen compared with our last forecast. We currently expect costs to amount to €7.2 billion in the full year. We  have now had 75% of our fuel costs, which gives us some reliability in the planning. However, further fluctuation  may well result from the changes of the U.S. dollar versus the euro.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Looking at the sensitivities provided here, you can see that, thanks to our proven hedging model, we would benefit  to a much greater extent from the possible fall in oil prices than a further rise would negatively impact us.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: To put it in a nutshell, we are convinced that this program will strengthen us for the future. It is not meant to be  designed as a counter reaction only to an economic downturn or short-term increase in fuel prices, but it is  designed to increase the level of profitability for the next years, and thus guarantee the long-term success of the  Lufthansa Group.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The key success factor of SCORE, as you can see from these examples, is the interplay between these lighthouse  projects, I – to give you some idea of them right now, and the many, many smaller scale measures and  improvements. Each of our individual companies has its own lighthouse project and if you put them together, the  top 20 of them throughout the group is accounts for a sustainable improvement in earnings of about €1 billion.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We, as Lufthansa, selectively promote and shape this process of change that the European airline industries  currently undergoing. However, we will only be able to do so if the corresponding earning power is existing, which  is the only thing that will allow us to invest into our business segments, to invest into our products and to invest  into existing and future partnerships. And believe me, the investments are necessary. We need in this market and  given our history legacy and brand perception high product and quality standards, and this is something which we  will have to keep and improve in the future. Only they can lead to a sustainable increase in the company's value,  an expansion of the market leadership held by our airlines and service companies, and improvement in customer  satisfaction and profitability, both in an economic and an ecologic perspective. And it is precisely this strategy that  can – that is reflected in our fleet policy. The continuous modernization of our fleet is progressing further.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: According to the proposal, SWISS will receive six Boeing 777-300ER for its long-haul fleet, allowing a further  growth in their hub in Zurich. Lufthansa Passenger Airlines will receive two additional Airbus A380 and 30 Airbus  of the A320 family with the current engine option. And in addition, the Executive Board also granted permission –  the Executive Board was granted permission to conclude the ongoing negotiations for the purchase of further 70  A320/321 aircraft of new engine option. These aircraft will cover the future replacement and growth requirements  of the Lufthansa Group airlines. And, obviously, it will allow us to offer not only state-of-the-art products on part  of these aircrafts, but they are particularly environmentally friendly and significantly quiet, quieter than the  existing generation.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Capacity growth that we have planned until 2025 is designed to cover approximately half of the expected market

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the environment for air transport remains changing. We know that the global economy is  not booming. Oil prices will, most likely, remain high, and the crisis in Europe has not yet been overcome. And as  usual that is a difficult point of departure to issue a forecast, particularly if it's that early in the year.

file: LHA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 13March2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The operating expenses excluding fuel costs and one-off items went down by 0.7% and we spent 4.5% less on fuel  compared to last year. 1.5% of this was due to lower fuel consumption. The remaining 3% resulted from the U.S.  dollar which weakened versus the euro compared to last year. The tailwind from lower fuel cost accelerated in the  fourth quarter, leaving us with 9.5% lower fuel cost for the quarter versus last year.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The decrease of fuel consumption is an important confirmation of our strategy. We produced the same capacity  with fewer flights, by using aircraft with a higher seat capacity. This also helped us to keep fees and charges  slightly below last year's level, despite the increasing passenger numbers. In total, the cost of materials and  services declined 2.4% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We now anticipate they will remain slightly below last year. So profitability will go up nevertheless because non - fuel costs per available seat-kilometers will reduce by 4% and thus, the spread between the revenues per available  seat-kilometers and the cost per available seat-kilometers improved.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We guided for only 2% non-fuel cost reduction at the beginning of the year. Economically, the situation has not  changed. The 4% simply includes the €340 million benefit from the depreciation policy. So, the ch ange is a pure  accounting issue.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: All together, the optimization of the relationship between unit revenue and unit cost will help us to drive our  business further. We have seen how successfully this has worked in the past two years. And it is fair to say  however, that while we are confident on the development on non-fuel cost per available seat-kilometers, the real  challenge for the year will be the market development in general and pricing development in particular.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: What will help through the year is the development of our fuel costs. We expect a fuel bill of only €6.8 billion in  2014, though. We have to keep in mind though that the tailwinds will be coming mainly from a weaker U.S. dollar,  and will therefore remain very volatile.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The U.S. dollar advantage in the fuel price will be – at the same time, depress our revenues at a similar level. Our  estimate is based on a euro-U.S. dollar rate of $1.37 and the Brent oil price of $109. Based on these assumptions,  we derived a €250 million lower fuel bill for the year. The current hedging level for 2014 sits at 7 7 %. Our hedge is  breakeven at a spot oil price of $110 per barrel. Any update will have to be observed cautiously of course, as  changes in the U.S. dollar will affect revenues almost as much as the fuel bill.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Looking at a clean basis, we expect €380 million of one-off costs. Excluding those, we expect an operating result of  some €1.7 billion to €1.9 billion. In order to compare these numbers to our actual result in 2013, let me remind  you that you have to take into account the positive impact of €340 million from the new depreciation policy.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: If we look at last year's cost inflation figures, which amounted to about 1.8%, this does not necessarily subside. Of  course, we are currently witnessing lower fuel prices that may compensate some of the cost inflation. However, we  should prepare ourselves for additional headwinds, and as we will be looking for ways to further grow and fill our  pipeline.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We will have a hard time finding such a comprehensive approach and such a consistent product at any of ou r  competitors. Our success heavily depends on our investments in the fleet, as well as in products on board and on  the ground. During the past year alone, we have placed an order of 167  new airplanes with a list price of €23  billion. This is the largest order in the history of our company. Overall, we have an order book adding up to €32  billion list price for new and modern aircraft to be delivered between 2014 and 2025. So this is framing the fleet  development for the next decade. For us, this is by the way the most effective environmental protection program  in terms of noise and in terms of fuel efficiency.

texts.speaker: Christoph Franz
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Last but not the least, noise and fuel emission are being constantly reduced across our entire fleet. And in 2013  was the first year when the average consumption of the Lufthansa Group Airline fleet was lower than 4 liters per  100 passenger kilometers, a new load ever.

file: LHA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 12March2015 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: The local GAAP result 2014 was burdened by the sale of the IT infrastructure of Lufthansa Systems and by  contingent losses from fuel hedging activities, following the drop in the oil price at the end of the year. And in the  local GAAP, other than in IFRS accounting, the change in our pension liabilities is reflected directly in our  earnings. The corresponding seven-year average interest rate which is calculated by the German Bundesbank fell  during the period under review from 4.89% to 4.54%. It will further decrease this year as a result of the current  interest rate situation and the respective formula. Accordingly, it will negatively impact our local GAAP result  again this year.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: Notwithstanding the strong tailwind from lower depreciation and lower oil price, the Passenger Airline Group was  therefore only able to increase its operating result by a total of €40 million. This is not enough. We need to make  faster progress here in improving our cost structures, as Carsten mentioned already, and structurally increase our  margins. Otherwise, we have to consider whether our existing business can be operated in the same order of  magnitude in this area.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: So what are our assumptions for the current financial year? We will reduce our number of flights while capacity  will grow by around 3% at the same time because of bigger aircraft. We expect our yields to fall significantly,  excluding foreign currency impacts. Increasing competitive pressure is the major factor here. I remind on easyJet  and Ryanair's plans for expansion in Germany and the unbound growth of state-owned Gulf airlines. We also  expect our competitors to cut their prices as a result of the lower oil price which will put pressure on our prices,  too.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: An exciting and heavily discussed topic this year is our fuel cost development. Compared with our last forecast  based on December figures, we can today see a slightly smaller reduction of only €800 million compared to the  previous year. The main difference from our previous forecast is the further rise in the value of the U.S. dollar. The  oil price on the basis of the forward rate of the 28th of February 2015 is, with $66 per barrel, still slightly below  the forward rate of our last forecast.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: As a reaction to this special situation, we have further increased our hedging levels which are now at 78% for the  remainder of 2015 and at 50% for 2016. So if the price of oil is volatile, we are better hedged against this. We also  take to mind the time horizon of our hedging policy with regard to an extension.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: We expect Lufthansa Cargo to record a slight increase in its adjusted EBIT. However, presumably, its revenue in  2015 will be down on the previous year due to the dynamics of its business and lower fuel surcharges.

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Aviation Services Officer
texts.text: Uncertainty factors mainly include the oil price and changes in the jet fuel price, which is the difference between  the oil and the kerosene price; the euro exchange rate, especially against the U.S. dollar and the Swiss francs; the  actual development of the yield at the Passenger Airline Group; and finally, the further development of union  negotiations at Lufthansa Passenger Airline.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In recent years, we have already achieved a lot that we can now build on. Since 2012, we have put more than  6,000 efficiency measures into effect as part of the SCORE program. All in all, these activities have delivered a  gross earnings improvement of €2.5 billion. By the end of this year, it will be €3.5 billion with the huge effort of all  employees which we are quite proud of.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The third-party business and that accounts for the lion's share of revenue at Lufthansa Technik, we set ourselves a  goal to achieve profitable growth of more than 10% per annum. In regional terms, we primarily want to gain  market share in Asia and America, truly invest in America by expanding existing partnerships and winning new  customers. We will be successful in this because we will continue to invest in innovative solutions, be it in  aerodynamics, which means reducing fuel consumption or in digitalizing our services and manuals.

file: LHA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 17March2016 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Simone Menne
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board
texts.text: Let me now come to the forecast for the entire Group for this year. We expect adjusted EBIT to be slightly higher  than last year. This is based on forecast fuel expenses of €4.8 billion. Since our last announcement in January, the  fuel cost forecast has been reduced by €100 million. But if the oil price has increased again significantly over the  past weeks, we are somewhat reluctant to give a more aggressive guidance at this time of the year. It is quite early.  As we need to specify our original statement, however, we leave it with slightly above previous year.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Simone. Allow me to pick up where you left off with sustainability. Sustainability is the focus of  everything we do at Lufthansa. However, the environment in which we operate has become significantly more  volatile and the challenges, obviously, are becoming even greater.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lufthansa Cargo is working intensively on its program to ensure sustainable increase of profitability. Moreover,  Lufthansa Cargo has extended its portfolio to cover the private customer segments and will be taking over the air  freight activities of the Eurowings Group.

file: LHA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 16March2017 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The fuel benefit came in at €899 million in 2016. This is lower than the €950 million expected at this time of our  Q3 results, mainly due to higher oil prices in the fourth quarter. This has resulted in an adjusted EBIT of €1.75  billion for the group. This matches our guidance of an adjusted EBIT on previous year's level, excluding the strike  cost of €100 million in the fourth quarter of 2016.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: The Network Airlines were the major driver of this good development. They successfully reduced their absolute  cost [ph] beyond (11:19) fuel cost savings. Cumulatively, they were able to offset the sharp decline in unit  revenues and increase their result.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Next to good cost control, the driver of this performance was the optimization of the route portfolio by cutting the  least performing routes. If we want to grow again, we must continue our efforts to achieve structural sustainable  cost reduction.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: We do, however, intend to further lower our cost to at least mainly offset the negative effects of rising fuel prices  in following years. We also aim to further strengthen our financial profile through good results, through cautious  investment and through further cost reduction. Our prime focus this year will be on integrating our Air Berlin wet  leases and Brussels Airlines into Eurowings. Eurowings is and remains our biggest strategic project, and it's also  important in terms of potential further consolidation scenario.

file: LHA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 15March2018 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: For 2018, we are currently expecting an adjusted EBIT slightly below last year. While we feel confident to offset a  significant part of the expected fuel cost increase of €700 million, it would be imprudent at this stage to assume  we would be able to fully recover this.

file: LHA - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 14March2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: And I think, it's fair to say today that our results also last year have lived up to this expectation. As one of the few  companies in our industry, we achieved the financial targets we had set ourselves at the beginning of the year.  The group's operating profit amounted to €2.8 billion, which is the second best result in our history. While sales  reached a new record high, we were further able to reduce cost. The modernization of our fleet continued with the  reception of 46 new aircraft, not only upgrading the customer proposition, but also improving our environmental  footprint.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Fuel cost came in as expected at the time of our last reporting at the end of October. In the full year of 2018, fuel  cost increased by 16% or €855 million and amounted to almost €6.1 billion, €261 million of the increase were due  to the capacity expansion. Without hedging, cost would have increased by nearly €700 million more.

texts.speaker: Ulrik Svensson
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Taking it altogether, ex-fuel unit cost reductions will be key when it comes to mitigating higher fuel cost in 2019  and achieving a group adjusted EBIT margin of 6.5% to 8%.

texts.speaker: Carsten Spohr
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Deutsche Lufthansa AG
texts.text: Besides the improvements of the customer experience onboard, the roll-over will drive significant cost and carbon  emissions reductions. Obviously the new models will consume around 25% less fuel compared to the aircraft they  are replacing.

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: As you know, we've had a sluggish consumption environment and unfavorable weather conditions in this first  half. Plus retail sales in Klépierre shopping malls uphold to be resilient. Retail sales were flat on a current  portfolio basis and down only 1% on a like-for-like basis. The leading teams of Klépierre has continued to  strengthen the partnerships with the must-have international retailers such as H&M, Inditex. And we have also  supported strongly international expansions of some champions on the rise like Primark, Calzedonia Zodio,  Hema, Kiko and we have also examples now of upscale retailers willing to join our shopping malls, I'm talking  about brands like American Vintage and Emporio Armani, Bose, Zadig & Voltaire to say a few. We have hosted a  highly visible marketing events in our malls through some of our partnerships, one notably with Coca-Cola,  another with Disney for example. In total, we have signed more than 1,000 new leases during this first half of the  year. We've had significant reversion in key markets, especially in France, where we have achieved more than 17%  reversion. At the same time at 11.8%, we believe the occupancy cost ratio of Klépierre is still very, very sustainable.

file: LI - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 21July2014 1215 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board and Chief Executive Officer, Klépierre SA
texts.text: We are also very actively working on our project in Oslo, Økern, waiting for new steps in autho rization this year  from the city of Oslo. I cannot comment too much on the unoccupied pipelines, but I can tell you that we have –  we may have new opportunities on this side as we discuss with the potential landowners with new projects always  in our targeted regions.

file: LI - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 1215 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-15.pdf
LI - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 27July2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: In France, I will not elaborate too much on why it has been so difficult for our retailers. It's a combination of  different factors. It's the terrorist attacks having quite an impact on the footfall and sales. The weather conditions  that has been, I would say, quite surprising for our retailers. When you talk to them, they are a little bit [ph] close  (6:21) between winter and summer. And they have difficult time to sell their merchandising.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Denmark is posting 5.3% like-for-like NRI increase. Sweden is doing 4.8%. The main driver is the good assets like  Field's and Emporia that have seen significant improvements in occupancy and a significant also improvement  into the NRI to GRI ratio and more [ph] sales base (13:24) rent.

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board
texts.text: So, a few words on development. As you know Klépierre strongly believes that the best opportunities to allocate  capital those days is to invest money into a secured, well-managed, well-monitored pipeline of new extensions,  and in some occasions, some greenfield development.

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board
texts.text: And as you can see the Phase 2 is this orange part which is currently under leasing. And, of course, as you can  see now, it's becoming real. And, as you can see, this is the crossroad of the corridor, the [ph] south (48:35)  corridor and the Style room very clearly.

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board
texts.text: As you can see, the green part will be built as an additional connection from the center to the metro. It's an  additional 13,000 square meter that we will build there. No doubt that there will be strong appetite from retailers  from this very exceptional pass from the metro to the one of the most popular shopping centers in France.

file: LI - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 26July2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Michel Gault
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Member-Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: Scandinavia was flat, minus 0.3%, with Sweden doing pretty well, plus 1.7%, and Norway down minus 1.4%. This  was partly due to cold and rainy weather condition in Q2 in Norway.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: As you have doubtless heard, we have hired a new Chief Development Officer and his mission is very clear and  lies in one motto, one mall, one project. And this is – and our strategy is still very clear. We aim at upscaling our  shopping centers. We continue to improve and optimize our risk/reward profile favoring extension to greenfield  and accelerate the retail transformation in our malls. So the next steps for 2018 will be the opening of the  extension – of the greenfield project in Prado, in Marseille. In designing this project and in leasing it, we were  driven by the two convictions and the overall ambition that I referred to earlier in my presentation.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: We will also develop our food destination with more than 10 restaurants, including Factory & Co, Les Petits  Producteurs, Wagamama, and Big Fernand. And this Prado project is currently 78% pre-let and the yield on cost  is 6.5%. And as you can see some pictures, the canopy will be just astonishing and it's completed today. And  Prado will be unique, as you can see on the picture, and unique as we design it and we think the architecture will  play a great role in the success of this shopping mall.

file: LI - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 26July2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: Prado in Marseille is our newest family member. We opened it in March. It was an immediate success and has  been unwavering since then. The foothold is increasing as are opening flagship store few months ago, and the  roof top terrace is truly unique and entirely dedicated to a sophisticated dining offering. Prado is a fantastic venue,  as some of you have visited, leading edge in terms of architecture and environmental performance. It, I think,  exemplifies Klépierre's style and know-hows.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: To conclude on the highlights of the first half, let me comment on the retailer sales in our malls all over Europe.  They increased by 1.4% in the first half, outperforming national indexes by 100 basis points. The overall  performance was driven by Iberia which is still buoyant and Germany as well as Central Europe and Turkey.  Scandinavia is lagging a little bit behind because of Denmark, and Italy was negative because it suffered probably  for the – most important bad weather condition in Europe and which has a significant impact on the fashion  segment and also macroeconomic situation affected by political uncertainty.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: So thank you very much for – this is [ph] Jean-Marc Jestin (24:21). On the development, we will just remind you  that we have given – our development pipeline is about €2.9 billion. As you know, it's also very focused on  extension as we seen a [indiscernible] (24:36) from the retailers to go for large greenfield project. And we have –  and we also consider that this is a better risk/reward strategy for our shareholders to focus on extension.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: So, as Laurent indicated, we have – in the Klépierre, there's been a lot of transformation. We have good assets,  liquidity assets. We have sold – we have done massive disposals. So probably to access the main element that's  justified the quality of the performance to date. But on top of that, we have started at t he end 2012 to implement  some operational initiatives. You all know them, it's the [ph] ClubStore (12:11), we include here the performance  of the customers [indiscernible] (12:15) with a very customer-centric approach. We have also the older marketing  initiative at Klépierre that has been reinitiated. I'm not going to go too much into the details, but we have now  shopping centers being more attractive for our customers and we have one initiative which is called ClubStore  which has – no, sorry – Good Choices, which is to reduce the cost of operation and also to improve the social  environment and a sustainable environment. We believe that these initiatives have also enabled us to both target  operating performances.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: France, even though Klépierre malls outperformed the national index by 200 basis point, France has been marked  by a quite sluggish macro-environment and as you all know by a quite significant negative impact of the terrorist  attacks in November and slightly in December.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: In Denmark, sales are up by 3.7%, which is also very good. Norway economy, as you all know, it's suffering a little  bit from the decrease of the oil price, and this mitigates a little bit the sole performance of the two neighboring  countries.

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board
texts.text: Third, we strongly believe, of course, that the environment in retail is more and more competitive, and we believe  that consumers will go to [ph] our centers (52:21) or just stop at [indiscernible] (52:23) transportation, if and only  if the retail – the real estate is properly managed and properly secured and refurbished when it's due for that. So I  would say, the three pillars of Klépierre when it comes to managing the properties will still be the ClubStore, Let's  Play marketing and Digital initiatives and Good Choices.

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board
texts.text: We also have – we've a clear guidance at Klépierre to improve the sustainable aspect of all our properties.  Klépierre has some clear objectives in that with a clear objective of [ph] 50% (57 :23) decrease in gas emission  between 2013 and 2020. So we have already achieved a reduction by 13% in two years, so that's a very strong  achievement. There is also a very commitment at Klépierre to improve the accessibility  for non-car users to our  centers, and we have seen in two years, an increase of 4% of the percentage of people coming to our centers by  public transportation.

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board
texts.text: Klépierre is clearly one of the top [ph] ranked (58:05) company in all the sustainable economy. As you can see, we  are still in best-in-class, when it comes to the different ratings. This is not – all the initiative we take are not only  to get those rankings, it's more for efficiency that we do that. But it's a fact that Klépierre continues to have a very  strong reputation in the industry and we'll continue to do so.

texts.speaker: Laurent Morel
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board
texts.text: Another example of the pipeline, which is now one of the few greenfield projects that we have is in Oslo City,  another city that goes highly regulated and that we know well, we happen to know quite well. So, we have there the  only chance in the market in Oslo to build fully modern large shopping center. It's a 55,000 square meter scheme.  Again, extremely connected to transportation systems, so we are continuing to work with the municipalities and  with different authorities there to make it happen. Again, we have done the a very [indiscernible] (01:08:27)  regulation to build such an asset in Oslo and we hope we can launch it very soon.

file: LI - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 7February2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: We also favor extensions and brownfield projects because greenfield projects often yield less. We make targeted  acquisitions, and we have a pretty strong track record in that area. And Jean-Michel will showcase Plenilunio later  in the presentation. And lastly, we have made opportunistic disposals, and the bulk of our transformation has  been done with more than €5 billion of disposals over the last five years. I'm not saying we could not further  improve our portfolio marginally, but I believe we can create great value with this portfolio.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: Italy is plus 0.9%, reflects an unfavorable base effect for shopping centers in and around Milan, which had  significantly benefited from World's Fair in the second half of 2015. France recorded positive sales growth of 0.2%  despite the climate created by the terrorist attacks, a mute performance for fashion, and an unfavorable base  effect. Indeed, sales grew by 2.1% in 2015. Nevertheless, both of our Italian and French malls outperformed  market by 130 and 150 basis points respectively.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: This higher reversion was achieved across virtually all countries in our portfolio. France was at a solid 10.9%  despite a mute economic climate. Italy stood at 16.7%, many thanks to rightsizing and new concepts coming to  our market-leading malls.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: As you know, we have been making also good choices for the environment and set ambitious objectives to meet  our targets by 2020. We are ahead of schedule. We have notably reduced our electricity consumption by 17% in  three years and aim to achieve a 25% decrease by 2020. We have reduced carbon emission by 14% in three  years and aim for 30% reduction by 2020.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: In terms of waste efficiency, we have recorded 75% of our waste with a target of 90% in 2020. And the share of  our portfolio which is certified stands today at 65%, in line with our objective of 90% in 2020.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: These solid results have led to several awards which highlight again Klépierre's undisputed leadership in  sustainable development. We are the industry leader for RobecoSAM and number two worldwide in the listed  retail sector for GRESB. We also joined the Carbon Disclosure Project A list.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: Thank you very much, Jean-Michel. Let me walk through our development pipeline quickly. Our development  pipeline is €3.3 billion worth of development. And as you know, it's 75% focused on extension projects because  we believe we can easily create additional value with our existing portfolio. 25% is of the committed and controlled  pipeline consists of greenfield like Prado. Most of you know the three projects we are going to open soon. Let me  update you quickly on the three of them.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: Prado, as you see, this is a greenfield project that we are going to open in February 2018. So, this is on time, on  schedule. And as we speak, we are already 60% pre-let or in advance negotiation. The rest of the pipeline is well- known for you. We have four of them that we want to highlight quickly. We have the Gran Reno extension. This  will make Gran Reno a regional shopping center. This is a dynamic shopping center in Bologna and we expect to  increase the size up to 55,000 square meters, and the opening is scheduled for 2020.

file: LI - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 8February2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: The first one is Retail First. It's all about improving the tenant mix and making it more modern and rightsizing the  anchors. The second one is let's play. Let's play, it's all about marketing, animation, innovation, digital. Clubstore  is how we are investing in our properties to make them more appealable for the customers, so it's all about  customer experience, sense of hospitality, and sense of design. And last but not least, which is part of our daily  operations, is the good choices, our CSR approach, and I will unveil today the new objective we have regarding  CSR.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: And we have worked out with a panel of independent stakeholders including retailers and different parties, and we  have come to a new strategy which is demanding, and what we want it to be is something which is fully integrated  in our operations because we think this is not only to be green. This is meant to create value for our stakeholders  and including our shareholders.

file: LI - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 7February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: And this is probably why our energy and the quality of our team makes that our KPIs are still very good. So if we  look at the EPRA Vacancy Rate it's still at 3.2%, so no big chance in that number. The occupancy cost ratio of our  clients stay at a very low level compared to some of our peers, so 12.3% so still [indiscernible] (00:06:25) situation  for us looking forward. And the bad debt it's [ph] how much we (00:06:33) collect, so you can see that this is still  below 2%. So, very solid KPIs for the portfolio.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Jestin
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, Klépierre SA
texts.text: We will do that in Campania. We'll do that in Le Gru. We already bought space back from the hypermarket. And  Rives d'Arcins, this is an additional anchoring with a Decathlon and with a big Zara store. So, step by step we  continue improving our properties.
