texts.speaker: Nils Fredrik Knagenhielm-Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, President & Director, Lifco AB
texts.text: Systems Solutions, we have a good improvement. Last quarter was especially good and half of the profit increase  comes from project sales. We have three companies, pure project sales companies. There's two in the Forest  division, that's Hekotek and Hydal and then Eldan in Environmental. Forest can go up and down a little bit from  year-to-year. In the Environmental, there's also structural change in the market.

texts.speaker: Nils Fredrik Knagenhielm-Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, President & Director, Lifco AB
texts.text: So, what's happened is that a lot of scrap – and Eldan is producing equipment to take care of scrap; copper, tires  and things like that. A lot of these scrap was, during the last 10 years, shipped to China and China took care of it.  But now, China has blocked the import of scrap because of environmental reasons. So, there is a structural  change. And basically, the scrapyards in Western Europe and in the States they have to take care of scraps now  locally. So, they have to build, to purchase equipment for taking care of the scrap. On a yearly basis, these three  businesses, they account for 25% of the profit increases approximately.

texts.speaker: Nils Fredrik Knagenhielm-Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, President & Director, Lifco AB
texts.text: The second acquisition is Indexator and they are making rotators primarily for forest machinery, it's about 85%.  And they have a high – very high market share there for rotators, it's about 90%, and the uniqueness with their  product is that the lifetime of their rotators is much longer than the rotators of their competitors. That's why they're  having such a high market share. And we're very happy with that acquisition as well. You can say it's a  complement to our – the company we acquired a couple of years ago called Hultdins. So between the forest  machine and the equipment of Hultdins, you have these rotators. That's what's everything I have to say. So I will  leave you to ask some question. Thank you.

file: LIGHT - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 21April2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Business group LED and Home achieved double-digit growth driving LED-based sales growth around 19%, and  these businesses are now representing 61% of total sales for Philips Lighting in Q1. Operating profitability  continues its gradual improvement trajectory with an adjusted EBITA margin in Q1 of 8.4%, an improvement of  130 basis points versus the same period last year.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: I propose that we move to the next slide and talk about our LED business group. So, in Q1, we still comparable to  sales growth of 16.7%, volumes were effectively higher due to the continued price erosion and mix impact, but all  regions contributed to the growth, although we noticed, once again, the countries with low LED penetration rates  showed high growth.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: And finally, as you can see, we continue to implement our cost reduction actions and we achieved €7 million of  savings on indirect cost compared to last year. We see further cost reduction opportunities that should result in  savings in selling expenses, IT, and other internal overhead like finance, HR and real estate, and we are working  on those opportunities.

file: LIGHT - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 26April2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-18.pdf
LIGHT - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 26April2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: On the next slide, slide 7, you can see some of the business highlights for this quarter for LED, so let me zoom on  the launch of TrueForce Urban in Europe, which is a lamp that we use to replace conventional high-intensity  discharge lamp. They not only create a pleasant and safe atmosphere in outdoor environments with LED retrofits,  but they're also easy to install, create 80% energy savings with a payback period of less than two years.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Another innovation that I would like to highlight for this quarter is the launch of the world's smartest outdoor LED  driver, which enables connect-ready and connected outdoor lighting. So, the driver has a low inrush current due  to IntelliStart, a driver integrated feature which is enabling a maximum number of light poles on a single circuit  breaker. This driver also features integrated energy metering with an accuracy of 1%. In addition, it allows high  surge up to 10 kilovolts specifically designed for tough environmental conditions.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: There are a couple of business highlights that I would like to bring to your attention on slide 9. Let's start with  Prime Delica, so we enabled that customer to grow healthier and safer crops for 7-Eleven customers in Japan.  Through research, we helped Prime Delica to develop an optimal light recipe to increase vitamin levels and the  nutritional value of lettuce. This ensures the vertical farm facility in Japan a year-round supply of high-quality  lettuce, spinach and coriander while reducing up to 90% on water consumption. Increased automation also  resulted in reducing time from seeding to harvesting from 70 days to 39 days.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: A second innovation that I would like to highlight is that we let our customers experience light before they buy it  with our virtual reality app. So, customers can now step into a virtual world to visualize how lighting can transform  their fashion store. Very accurate 3D rendering enable retailers to immerse themselves in a virtual fashion store  and see first-hand how lighting can make shop windows more dynamic to attract shoppers' attention and grow  footfall in the store. It enables retailers to sample different lighting design and find the right lighting for their store.

file: LIGHT - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 22July2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Éric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: The three other businesses, LED, Professional and Home, strategically have to grow and they're growing. And  they also have to improve on their profitability. And you see that in Q2, this is also what is happening with an  improvement of 550 basis points for LED, 110 basis points (sic) [100 basis points] (03:49) for Professional, and  850 basis points for Home.

texts.speaker: Éric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Now let me run you through more details about each of the businesses. So, we've said it's, 17% decline for the  conventional Lamps business. This is pretty much in line with our expectation and directly due to the transition  from conventional lighting to LED lighting.

texts.speaker: Éric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Just to mention a very interesting offer that we have been launching on the market in Q2. So, it is called CorePro  LED PLC. But it really means that this is the first ever LED replacement for compact fluorescent lamps in the  Professional market. And the good thing is that it's just – we just can click the LED lamps in lieu of the compact  fluorescent lamps. We don't need to change the balance and we gained 60% in energy efficiency. We believe that  there are around 150 million of these lamps in Europe ready to be converted.

file: LIGHT - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 21July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Let me now quickly walk you through our business groups starting on slide 6 with Lamps. Comparable sales  declined by 18.2% due to the ongoing transition to LED lighting. We estimate that the conventional lighting market  continue to decline faster in a range between 23% to 24%, which results in market share gains. Despite the high  decline in top line, Lamps was able to sustain a high level of profitability once again at 20.7%. This clearly reflects  the success of our last man standing strategy.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: In the second quarter, comparable sales increased by 20.9%, driven by significant volume growth, which was  partly offset by lower selling prices and stronger growth in affordable products. All regions contributed to the  growth, although we noted that countries with low LED penetration rates showed higher growth. The adjusted  EBITA margin improved by 220 basis points to 10.6% in Q2 driven by operational leverage and procurement  savings, offsetting price reductions and mix impact.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Let's now look at slide 11, where we provide a snapshot of our LED-based sales which grew by 17% to €2.1  billion in the first half of 2017. In the left chart, you can see that our LED-based sales grew with CAGR of 28%  since 2013, and now represents 62% of total sales in H1 2017.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: In the chart on the right, we see that 40% of our LED-based sales comes from business group LED, while 48%  comes from Professional, and 12% from Home. In each business group, we saw double-digit comparable sales  growth in LED-based sales in the first half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: We continued in parallel to implement all the cost reduction initiatives that we have launched and we have  achieved a €9 million savings on indirect cost. This reduction is after the additional investment that we have made  to support our growth, in particular, in Home Systems.

file: LIGHT - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 27July2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: On the next slide, slide 8, you can see some of the business highlights for this quarter for LED. So, let me zoom in  on the launch of these Philips MyCare LED bulbs in Asia. So, part of the design of these bulbs are inspired by  sunflowers. The bulbs use our patented interlaced optics technology that reduces glare by 35%. It results in  uniform light that is more comfortable on the eye. Furthermore, we launched a new innovative product in India,  which is, as you can see, the funny T-Bulb. Indian consumers indicated that they prefer a linear form factor  because of a better light spread and the decorative look, which is perceived to be more premium.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Now, let's move to slide 10, and there are couple of business highlights that we would like to bring to your  attention for the Professional business. For example, this quarter, we won the next phase of the world's largest  horticulture LED lighting project at Agro-Inwest in Russia. So, Agro-Inwest is doubling the size of its greenhouse  to the equivalent of 100 soccer pitches. The quick pay-up of the first phase that we started to install last year,  together with a clearly visible improvement in the crop yields of this tomato grower, resulted in the expansion of  their investment in Philips GreenPower LED toplighting and interlighting.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Also for Home, we had a couple of business highlight that we would like to share with you on the following slide,  which is slide 12. On that, I would like to call out is what – is that we strengthen the position of Philips Hue as the  world-leading system for the home by launching the Hue outdoor range in the U.S. and Europe, extending Hue  features and functionality to any outside area. All the products are designed for outdoor use and easy to install  through the plug and play system. The products include both Hugh white and Hugh white and color ambience  ranges. The products have a color temperature range of 2,200 Kelvin to 6,500 Kelvin and feature, as usual, the  famous 16 million colors.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Thank you, Stéphane. Before I move to the outlook, let me briefly zoom in on the performance for H1 as we  normally do. So, on slide 21, we provide a snapshot of our LED-based sales, which grew by 5.3% to €2.1 billion in  the first half of this year. So, in the left chart, you can see that our LED-based sales grew at a CAGR of 24% since  2013. As a result, nearly 70% of our total sales is now LED-based compared to 26% back in 2013. In the pie  chart, it is also interesting to see that Professional represents half of total LED-based sales and is growing by  10%.

file: LIGHT - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 19October2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Thank you, Robin. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I propose that we go straight to  slide 4. So, in line with our objectives, we achieved a positive comparable sales growth in the quarter.  Comparable sales increased by 1.3%. For the first time in our transformation, the growth of LED and connected  lighting systems and services more than offset the decline of our conventional businesses. Total LED-based sales  increased by 22%, and now represent 68% of total sales compared to 56% in the same period last year.

file: LIGHT - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 26October2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Sustainability is core to everything we do, and we are therefore pleased with our recent achievements, and  recognition we've received on this front. We have achieved carbon neutrality for our business in the United States  and Canada. We have been an industry leader in the Dow Jones Sustainability Index for the second year in a  row, and Sustainalytics moved us up to the industry leader position in a group of 43 electrical equipment  companies.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Let me now provide you with a bit more detail for each of our four business groups, and let's start on slide 6 with  Lamps. Our comparable sales declined by 11%, which is better than the previous quarters driven by higher sales  ahead of the halogen bulb ban in Europe that came into effect on the 1st of September. A solid performance in  consumer lamps such as CFLi and HID outdoor, and certain specialty lighting categories such as digital  protection.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Let's now move to LED on slide 7. Comparables has declined by 1.9%. The comparable sales trend in LED  electronics continued to improve while the CSG of LED lamps reflects a high – relatively high base of comparison  and a soft level of activity with retailers in Europe, and also in the U.S. Also, LED lamps faced an ongoing shift to  private label, most notably in North America and a more challenging environment in China.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: On the next slide, slide 8, you can see some of the business highlights of this quarter for LED. Let me zoom in on  the launch of our Interact Ready Master Connect LEDtube. So, its networking technology enables wireless  integration with a variety of control devices such as sensors and switches through dimming, occupancy sensing  and daylight harvesting. These tubes deliver 50% more energy saving, thanks to the Master Connect technology.  This also works seamlessly with Interact Pro, our intuitive dashboard and app which brings additional benefits to  our customers through connected lighting.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: In the third quarter, we also launched an innovative controller for outdoor luminaires, service controller that you  see on the slide, adds connectivity and sensing to outdoor luminaires and allows customers to remotely install a  very accurate on and off switching and dimming scheme that can then be easily controlled with the use of a  smartphone. The settings can be saved in a profile that can then be applied to all the nearby luminaires to quickly  and easily create a virtual group with the exact same behavior.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: There are a couple of business highlights that we would like to bring to your attention on the next slide, slide 10.  For example this quarter we launched Interact Hospitality which enables hotel guests to personalize lighting,  control the temperature, and make room service requests at the touch of a button.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: The smart system also lets hotel staff know if a room is occupied and had them to respond quicker to guests'  requests, providing useful information to improve the guest experience, optimize operations and save energy. The  first commercial implementation of this smart system takes place at the Swissotel in Stamford in Singapore which  has more than 1,200 rooms.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Another highlight this quarter is that Navigant ranked us as the world leader in smart street lighting and Navigant  estimates the global market for smart street lighting to be well $837 million into 2018. They expect that annual  smart street lighting revenue will grow to nearly $8.3 billion globally by 2027, presenting CAGR of almost 30%.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: For example, we introduced Philips Hue Play, which is a compact highly versatile bar that you can position in a  variety of ways to create a truly immersive lighting experience. It provides an indirect light effect, and can sit  horizontally or vertically next to your TV, or be mounted behind as a backlight.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Furthermore, we have introduced new luminaires for dining such as the Philips Hue white and color ambience,  Ensis and Flourish. Our Philips Hue outdoor light strips are the latest addition to the newly launched Philips Hue  outdoor range. This is what I wanted to cover regarding the business and operational performance.

file: LIGHT - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 23January2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Jan-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: So our priority to optimize cash from conventional products to fund growth were supported by an improvement of  our free cash flow as a percentage of sales for Lamps by 12% in the year. Our LED share increased from 43% of  total sales in 2015 to 55% of total sales in 2016, underlining our priority to innovate in LED products commercially  and technologically to outgrow the market. Our priority is to lead the shift to Systems and to capture adjacent  value from new Services business models were both supported by a strong increase in sales of 51% in our  Professional, Systems & Services business and by a fast growth in the Home Systems sales. The growth rate  increased by 40%, very specifically, for our Home Systems business.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Let's move now to the next slide where basically we are showing our total LED sales, and we're showing that they  grew from €2.2 billion in 2013 to close to €4 billion, €3.9 billion, in 2016.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: In the left chart, you can see that our total LED sales growth with a CAGR of 28% and now 55% of sales is  coming from LED for the full year in 2016. The chart on the right, we show that 39% of our total LED sales come  from our business group LED, 49% from Professional, and 12% from Home. In each business group, also double- digit comparable sales growth in LED in 2016.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Let us then have a look at the full year performance by business groups in more detail, and I will immediately start  with Lamps on slide 18, for the full year. So the full year we saw a decline of 15.8% in comparable sales due to  the transition from conventional to LED lighting. The adjusted EBITA margins has seen improvement of 400 basis  points, mainly driven by lower than anticipated sales decline and an efficient manufacturing footprint  rationalization and productivity procurement savings.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Now, let me move to the LED business on the next slide. Comparable sales had increased by 16.1% due to  robust volume growth with procurement savings enabling continued price reduction. The comparable sales trend  in the Americas started softening in the second quarter. Some countries in Europe showed slower sales growt h  due to high LED penetration rate. While the rest of the world continued to deliver robust growth.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: We continued our strict focus on innovation in LED. In 2016, we introduced mainly innovative products,  SceneSwitch, which is a new LED bulb brand with multiple light setting. Other examples can be The Dubai Lamp  that we've commented quite extensively today, but also we introduced the Philips GreenPower LED flowering  lamp, which is the next-generation energy-efficient LED lamps for horticulture. And last but not least, we also  develop a high lumen LED alternative for popular high wattage CFLi bulbs, these LED retrofit bulbs which put out  up to 3,000 lumen and fit existing fixture and luminaires are available, not only in Asia but also in Latin America.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: To give you some examples of innovative projects that have been working – that we've been working on in 2016,  let me talk to you about the following. We have installed nearly 90,000 connected street lights in Jakarta by using  our Philips CityTouch street light system. We also implemented Philips Power-over-Ethernet technology for  connected sustainable lighting which made the skyscraper Torre Europa the smartest office building in Madrid.  We also adopted connected lighting in the stadium of VfL Wolfsburg in Germany which is the first German football  club to use our connected LED lighting.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Let's look now at the next slide which is about sustainability. It's a very important subject for us and we wanted to  communicate to you how we've performed in 2016 when it comes to the six targets that we had in our  sustainability program.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: First, sustainability revenue, 78% of our revenues was sustainable in 2016, which is an improvement of 6%  compared to last year and close to our 2020 targets of 80%. The sale of 2 billion LED lamps, so we sold to-date  628 million LED lamps in 2016, which is an improvement of 44% compared to last year. We target to be carbon  neutral by 2020 which further reduced our CO2 emissions by 39% in 2016. 100% of our sites should be zero  waste to landfill by 2020. So, this is basically a new KPI that we are introducing, this is why we have no base of  comparison. But in 2016, 26% of our sites had zero waste to landfill. So, we are progressing according to the  target.

file: LIGHT - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 2February2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: So on page 6, you can see an overview of the financial performance for the company and also by business group.  You can see, our comparable sales increased by 3% and that's been driven by the growth of LED and connected  lighting Systems & Services which is in line with our strategic priorities.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: The overall LED-based comparable sales grew by 19%, and they now represent 68% of our total sales which is  €4.5 billion. The adjusted EBITA margin improved overall for the company by 120 basis point to 10.9% in the  fourth quarter. And connected lighting Systems & Services substantially contributed to this performance.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Let me now talk to you about our cost reduction actions on slide 13; you can show the year-on-year evolution of  our adjusted indirect cost base, which was 29.1% of our sales in the fourth quarter. This is a 160-basis-point  reduction compared to the fourth quarter of 2016. As we talked to you, on a regular basis, we continue to  implement all the cost reduction initiatives that we have launched and that has allowed us to achieve €20 million  savings in indirect cost. Of course, that amount is after the incremental investment that we are making to support  our growth in particular in Home Systems.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: On the next page, you can see a bit more details about those cost reduction initiatives. As we've talked to you  many times, the benchmark suggests that the indirect cost in the industry should range in the range of 25% to  29% of sales and this is the goal that we have. For that, as you know, we are implementing and managing a lot of  cost reduction initiatives and at the same time making sure we can continue to invest. And you can see on the  right-hand side, a number of those initiatives that relate to the process optimization, footprint reduction both in  terms of industrial, but also in terms of real estate, simplification of our organizational structure, simplification of  the product portfolio, continuing to optimize outsourcing strategy.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: There are many initiatives happening across the company, and this is what is driving the cost reduction that you  saw in 2017. And there is more to come in 2018. Overall, we expect that the benefits of these initiatives will be  even more visible in the second part of the 2018 and in 2019.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Let me now walk you through our strategic priorities and proof points in 2017 on our next slide. Our priority to  optimize cash from conventional products to fund growth was supported by an increase of our free cash flow as a  percentage of sales of lamps of 400 basis points. Our LED lighting share increased from 55% of total sales in  2016 to 65% in 2017. This clearly underlines our priority to innovate in LED products commercially and  technologically to outgrow the market.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Let's now take a closer look at our achievement in sustainability on the next slide. So you may remember that we  have fixed targets in sustainability. So let's review them briefly. Sustainable revenues. 77% of our revenue was  sustainable in 2017, which is a reduction of 0.6% due to a stricter 2017 definition heading to our 2020 target of  80%. We sold 1.2 billion LED lamps cumulative from 2015, which is an improvement of 53% compared to last  year, in line with our objective to deliver more than 2 billion LED lamps by 2020.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: We also target to be carbon-neutral by 2020. We reduced our CO2 emissions by 20% in 2017. 100% of our sites  should be zero waste to landfill by 2020. In 2017, we reduced our waste to landfill by 26%. So we want to assure  a safe and healthy workplace for our employees. This is extremely important for us. Our total [indiscernible]  (00:25:17) cases declined by 18% in 2017.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Philips Lighting NV
texts.text: Finally, we have achieved also a sustainable supply chain as 95% of our [ph] real (00:25:32) suppliers have been  audited already achieving our 2020 target.

file: LIGHT - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 1February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: I propose that we go straight to slide 4. So, first, I am pleased with the solid progress we've made on the transition  from conventional to LED and connected lighting systems and services. In 2018, our LED-based sales grew by  2.5% on a comparable basis to 71% of sales. And our installed-base of connected light points increased from 30  million at the end of 2017 to 44 million at the end of 2018.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: As you know, sustainability is going to be my next point and is at the center of what we do and we are very  pleased with the progress we've made towards achieving on our sustainability targets for 2020. For example, we  target to be carbon-neutral in 2020. We reduced our CO2 emissions by 43% in 2018 and we are now carbon- neutral in line of our markets.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Let me now go to slide number 5. It is a very important slide for us. So, today, Signify is the leader in LED lighting  and in connected lighting systems and services. We have been building this new worldwide leader focusing on  growing profit engines, in line with our strategy to move to LED and connectivity, developing new growth platforms  and creating new systems and services business models.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Turning to next page, slide 9, you can see here some of the business highlight of this quarter for LED. Let me  highlight one of them on the glass filament decorative range expansion on the left-hand side of the slide. This is  our new range of decorative LED glass filament bulbs. They capitalize on the trend for vintage-style bulbs, which  we see everywhere, and they come in very classic shapes and they command premium, which, of course, is great  for our pricing and profitability. They use the latest LED technology and they are around 80% more energy- efficient than a conventional light bulb and they last 10 times longer.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Turning here to the business highlights for our Professional activity on slide 11. For example, this quarter, we  completed our largest ever connected architectural lighting project. This is a massive project for the Shanghai  municipality, which involved dynamically lighting the [ph] city (00:11:15) iconic waterfronts with 3 bridges and over  40 buildings in the financial and tourist districts.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: We installed more than 50,000 connected light points along a 1.2-kilometer stretch of the waterfront in Shanghai.  This new lighting is expected to save the city between 50% to 70% of its annual lighting cost when compared to  the previous area that was lit by conventional lighting.

texts.speaker: Stéphane Rougeot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Our Interact Landmark software is being used to control and manage the light on the building rooftops and also on  the three bridges. The scale and the sophistication of this project illustrates our leadership as we are able to  unlock the potential of connected lighting to transform cities and help them also be more energy efficient.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Let me tell you more about our new and promising growth platforms on the next slide. So we are investing heavily  in the fast-growing areas of horticulture, solar and LiFi as these areas all contribute significantly to a more energy- efficient usage of electricity and, hence, strongly support our company's contribution to realizing a more  sustainable world.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: We also see – I also see great opportunities in solar. Let's have clear in our mind that there are still more than 1  billion people who do not have access to the electricity grid. Solar-powered lighting provides this access,  showcasing the vast potential of this market. Solar is a safe and sustainable alternative to currently used fuel- based resources, both in the professional and in the consumer markets. The market for solar lighting is expected  to grow by 20% per year until 2024. In 2018, we sold more than 300,000 solar lights, which approximately 55,000  are related to road lighting.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: Let's now take – sorry. Let's now take a closer look at our achievements in our six sustainability targets on the  next slide. First, on sustainable revenues, 79% of our revenues were sustainable into 2018, nearing our 2020  target of 80%. On a cumulative basis, we sold 1.7 billion LED lamps since 2016. We are the only lighting  company in the world that has achieved that level of performance. So, as far as we're concerned, we have now  achieved 87% of our commitments and are just ahead of track to deliver more than 2 billion LED lamps by 2020.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: We also target to be carbon neutral in 2020, and we reduced our CO2 emissions by 43% in 2018, and we are  now carbon neutral in nine markets. 100% of our sites should be zero waste to landfill by 2020. In 2018, we  reduced our waste to landfill by 30%.

texts.speaker: Eric Rondolat
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Management, Signify NV
texts.text: We considered various small to medium-sized acquisition opportunities that resulted in the acquisition of the  Chinese urban lighting company, LiteMagic, in 2018 which enables us better capitalize on the large and fast  growing urban lighting markets in China. In 2017, we acquired some small companies, of which Stack Lighting  and PointGrab are two examples.

file: LISN - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 22July2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Dieter R. Weisskopf
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: The big question in the next 12 months remains the development of the cocoa market. The market experts expect  for the harvest season 2015, 2016, that's the current one, cocoa deficits being higher than 200,000 tons, some go  up to 300,000 tons even, what would bring the stock-to-use ratio at the end of the period to low 36%. Reasons for  the low harvest outlook is the climate where the El Niño effect led to less rainfall in West Africa in the last winter  and spring. But the markets already look into the next crop season where fundamentals so far look good. That is  as well the reason that you could see in the future's prices over the last 10 days some liquidation of long positions  that led to lower market quotations. The future outlook nevertheless depends on the positioning of speculative  market participants, holding still a future long position reflecting 25% of the total world harvest. One reason as  well, we have to look at one factor, you have to look at for the next 2017 business year is to further develop [ph]  enough (16:15) cocoa butter.

texts.speaker: Dieter R. Weisskopf
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Again, the bad weather, low rain led to a bad [ph] mid (16:23) crop in West Africa, and that means now that some  of those factories [ph] or region (16:31) factories have to close down, and that led mainly to a steep increase in  cocoa butter. So, if you would like to watch a little bit material prices in 2017, then have a good look at the butter  as we view of course as well. We assume that we will – after year-end, we will see some lower prices again.

texts.speaker: Dieter R. Weisskopf
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: And that leads me now to the last chart, and that is the outlook for environment and 2016. Full year, so, you see it  in front of us – of you. So, we have Europe/North America, we see economies basically stable, very low growth  rates, but at least for the time being, rather firm. Let's hope that we survive as well the Brexit impact, and that it  has not a big impact mainly on Europe.

file: LISN - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 25July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-17.pdf
LISN - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 24July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Hug
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Chocoladefabriken Lindt & Sprüngli AG
texts.text: Now, moving from revenue to the different cost elements, starting with material costs, this is adjusted by the  change in inventory. It came down to 33.5% which is 30 basis points lower than in the previous year and 140  basis points below 2016. The main reason for the decline are benefits from decreases in the cocoa bean prices,  partially offset by the high cocoa butter prices and packaging material costs.

texts.speaker: Martin Hug
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Chocoladefabriken Lindt & Sprüngli AG
texts.text: So for those of you who are interested in more details on cocoa bean and cocoa butter, we have prepared a  chart. And we can see cocoa bean prices in London are currently trading between £1,700 and £1,800 per ton.  And cocoa butter ratio has more or less stabilized at very high levels of 2.90. This compares when you go back  one year in July 2017. We can see that one year ago cocoa butter is at 2.60 and cocoa bean prices were about  £1,500 per ton. So, we have definitely seen a clear increase here in recent – in the last 12 months.

texts.speaker: Martin Hug
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Chocoladefabriken Lindt & Sprüngli AG
texts.text: So going to operating expenses, a big part here is marketing and this goes slightly up and there are two main  drivers of it. On the one hand, we have seen again efficiencies, reducing costs, on the other hand, increased  marketing investments. As previously announced, our goal is to invest additional funds in brand building activities  such as advertising. The lower cocoa bean prices coupled with a slightly positive price mix impact have allowed  us to do that.

texts.text: We've made a good start to all of these and we'll obviously update you on progress through the year. In terms of  the numbers, we've also made a good start. texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, LondonMetric Property Plc
texts.text: So, low energy investing has become increasingly popular with corporate pension funds, local authorities,  dedicated income funds, and overseas buyers, all competing for the opportunities. In contrast, large multi-let  operational assets are falling out of favor, and buyers are certainly in short supply. For example, UK retail funds  are sitting on the sidelines and many U.S. private equity purchases are no longer in the market having seemingly  attractive high-yielding acquisitions made two years ago or so, failing to achieve hurdle rates due to diminishing  income and negative yield shift.

texts.speaker: Andrew Jones
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, LondonMetric Property Plc
texts.text: As I said in my statement this morning, consumer shopping patterns continue to change. Technology is disrupting  traditional retailing and as I think I said in my quote that the tectonic plates are indeed shifting. As a result,  retailers, a lot of retailers are having to shrink to grow. They're having to right-size their store portfolios. Less  shops, bigger floor plates.

file: LMPL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 30May2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Francis McGann
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, LondonMetric Property Plc
texts.text: But projecting forward, the full rental effect of our pipeline of developments including Bedford, Weymouth, and  Derby will increase our net rental income by a further £7.6 million, taking the contracted rent roll to £98.3 million.  And then utilizing our remaining fire power, we see the annual rent roll increasing up to and past £100 million.

texts.speaker: Andrew Marc Jones
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, LondonMetric Property Plc
texts.text: And finally, liquidity, we think is polarizing. There is strong demand for low energy assets, particularly smaller lot  sizes and what we call nonoperational. It's the four checks a year sort of asset, which is why you've seen such  strong performances from our convenience and our [ph] low (00:33:35) income portfolios. In other parts of the  market, liquidity is scarce or nonexistent for large, more operational assets and we think that that will begin to play  itself into valuations over the next 6 to 12 months. In fact, we're probably surprised it hasn't already be more  visible in some valuations already.

texts.speaker: Vincent Pilette
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Accounting Officer
texts.text: Going into fiscal year 2016, [ph] this (12:42) currency headwinds of historic magnitude will significantly impact  our gross margin. We have deployed pricing increases across most of our products in key impacted markets. We  have developed new cost reduction initiative specifically related to the decline in oil price and the dollar  appreciation. It will take time to see the impact of those actions but we are confidently maintaining our long-term  gross margin target of around 35%.

texts.speaker: Vincent Pilette
texts.profession: Chief Financial & Accounting Officer
texts.text: Moving forward, we have slightly adjusted our inventory strategy. We ended Q4 with higher inventory balance  compared to the prior year. A portion of this increase was related to the West Coast port strike in the United  States, but much of it was driven by our strategic actions. With sales in our mobile speaker category and video  collaboration category doubling for the second year in a row, we chose to invest in more inventory for those  categories in support of our strong sales momentum. Additionally, as one example of our cost reduction  initiatives, we have implemented a strategy to reduce air freight expenses by building products early enough to  allow for shipment via sea.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Stefan Borgas, Chief Executive Officer, and Chief Operating Officer of Life Science Ingredients  Thank you, Dino. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Start from our site in Visp in Switzerland,  clear skies, sharp view into the mountains, and very clear image also a little bit further out, but  gusty winds and clouds coming in fast and going fast, all of this quite symbolic to the business  environment in which we are at the moment.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our cost savings project was scheduled to end at the end of March of 2011. This is done. I think we  could put the tick mark behind this. All measures have been delivered and we are now adapted on  the cost side.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The raw material prices that we challenged mainly oil and Palmkernel Oil are being passed on. This  works quite well in our Microbial Control business where we are catching up nicely. This works  quite well also in a lot of the high performance materials businesses. We have some issues with  Niacin as I have already mentioned and we have some issues with some of the chemical  commodities in Europe. This is not unexpected but this is the focus of the theme at the moment.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: UN sanctions against Libya are a headwind for us from two perspectives.  You might ask what does  Libya have to do with Lonza.  Well, of course, it impacts the oil price, but more specifically, the  Libyan sovereign wealth fund has a big refinery group in Europe called Tamoil, and Tamoil has a  refinery very close to our site in Visp and they deliver by pipeline their raw materials for our cracker  or a big portion of the raw materials.  This refinery shutdown due to the U.S. sanctions at the  moment and this gives us the challenge with supply.  This at the moment has a single – low single- digit million impact on raw material purchases because we got to go to alternative sources which  are a little bit more expensive.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Life Science Ingredients, the raw materials are the second big concern. Also here structurally this is  not a dramatic problem for us, but this is a time-limited freeze.  Every price round takes three to  four months to push through.  This doesn’t go any faster because the whole supply chain of course  commits to a certain raw material cost and that’s the time it takes to push through the supply chain.

texts.speaker: Toralf Haag
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: In water treatment, the early autumn patterns for recreational water indicate sales to be on target in North  America and in EU which is fairly important. texts.speaker: Operator

texts.speaker: Stefan Borgas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Before I go into the presentation, usually I start with an atmospheric comment and if I look out at Basel's weather  today, we've had dark clouds this morning, super sunshine in the middle of the morning and now we have big  clouds everywhere. This changed as fast as the currencies do. So in both we should refrain – in both we should  refrain from making forecasts because they will most likely be wrong.  So before I go into the presentation and lead you through most of the charts that we put out on the website this  morning, let me make a couple of introductory remarks from which I think are the highlights of the messages of  today.

texts.speaker: Stefan Borgas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Also the raw material effect that you see in the second column is one that step-by-step now will get lower in effect  because prices are catching up. That is under the assumption we have no oil price hike. We were [ph] rather lucky  (14:18) this morning. I just read a report now that oil price again went over $100 this morning in oil trading. So  we don't know how things go, but that's, of course, always a variable.

texts.speaker: Stefan Borgas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: We've also had a quite a bad semester for snail – for our snail product, Metaldehyde because of this fantastic  spring that we have had in Europe that – it was just simply too dry for snails. And the U.S. we have had the exact  opposite. We've had floods everywhere, so it was too wet for snails or for agriculture to put – to do anything. So  that was a weak weather, most of this came together. This is now starting to change in the second half, because  weather is much more friendly to snails.  And in the performance business, the high performance materials business going very well, the commodity  margins, of course, are most under pressure from the raw materials effect. And the ag business was very, very  weak in the first half because of order placements and plant and therefore plant utilization. This has already  turned as of June and we are looking at quite a strong ag business for the next 12 to 15 months.

texts.speaker: Stefan Borgas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: And on the Chemical side, the pipeline also made pretty good progress. And the one area I'm the most pleased  about here are the Peptides. Half of this increase of the early stage pipeline is Peptides. And that is so important  because once you have Peptides in your facilities, they hardly ever go anywhere else because of the very complex  regulatory environment here, so very encouraging.

texts.speaker: Stefan Borgas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: So cutting people doesn't help, because it will reduce output. So we need to increase output with the same number  of people, it's totally different program, and the cost reduction that we had two years ago.

texts.speaker: Stefan Borgas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: We will then add to this the next step in the value chain, biogenerics, you know all about it. Microbial Control, one  of the driver for Arch was – for the Arch acquisition is this move forward towards the consumer but more than  one-third of their business is forward integrated, so that will help us, also as a translation to for example, our  nutrition business.

texts.speaker: Stefan Borgas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Just a couple of example of moving down the value chain, I talked about Microbial Control already. Their water  business for example is very nicely forward integrated into their personal water area pools mostly, where they sell  directly to retailers. So we gained this whole competence how to deal with the retail chain. But also on the  industrial water side, they sell directly to waste water treatment plants, community plants, cooling water  application, people where Lonza is two steps away, so also here we will learn a lot and that's by the way a very  attractive growth area.

texts.speaker: Stefan Borgas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: On the wood side as well they sell directly to those people who produce the wood that is then put into use in  different applications. So quite a good step towards this strategy. Biosimilars no need to talk about this too much  in this topic because you know very much about it but here of course we sell at the end directly to patients through  our partner.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Hygiene is on the agenda. People living more closer together, if there is a pandemia from our recent history, last  five years, the pandemias has spread quite fast all over the world especially in congested areas. Water is going to  be a big, big topic. It goes together with the megacities. If you're in Asia, in some mass megacities, there is no  portable water available or almost no portable water available, not easy to get there.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Last but not least, water. Water business today, we are more in a traditional water treatment, which is more of a –  I think, the spa pool business, mainly in United States and in South America. But the company has started – or  even in Arch times has started to also move into the segments of portable water, other water treatment  applications. The know-how is there. Now, the transformation is to go into more growing segments of that market.  So, from my perspective – my conclusion is, we are well-positioned to harness megatrends. The consequence is we  need to grow into these markets more stronger than ever before. What is, I would say, the link between the  different market segments we want to go to, and the link is the great technologies of the company.

texts.speaker: Toralf Haag
texts.profession: CFO & Member-Management Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: We are also looking at development of new products here, and one example is the new business in oil and gas, I'll  touch on later. And the integration, finally, is on track delivering the synergies we have targeted.  If we look at the different businesses within Microbial Control, we first have the Water Treatment, which went  very well in the first half. And within the Water business, recreational water, where we supply products for pool  treatment and other recreational applications, was ahead of target, and industrial water was on budget.

texts.speaker: Toralf Haag
texts.profession: CFO & Member-Management Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: One product innovation that you see here, where we have strong demand right now, is for shale oil and gas  extractions, where water is needed to do this. We have applications and products and actives who clean the water  after these extractions. So this is a growing business field, one example where we have innovative products in this  market.

texts.speaker: Toralf Haag
texts.profession: CFO & Member-Management Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: The other two businesses, Wood Treatment and Material Protection, were basically on target in the first half of  2012.

texts.speaker: Toralf Haag
texts.profession: CFO & Member-Management Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: And like we said, we are investing in new technology, mostly in our pesticide in the area of conjugates highly  active ingredients, but also cytotoxic products. So this is all on-track, and we're continuing with the build out of  these technologies.

texts.speaker: Toralf Haag
texts.profession: CFO & Member-Management Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Also in this business, we are continuing to invest mainly in our Slough facility, where we have the small-scale  fermenters for the Biological Manufacturing.

texts.speaker: Toralf Haag
texts.profession: CFO & Member-Management Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Our intention is to produce, of course, again, free cash flow in the second half. Right now, as we see it, we target to  be slightly below CHF2.4 billion of net debt at the end of 2012. With these numbers, we have some headroom with  our financial covenants. And as said before, we don't need any equity measures in order to get our refinancing  done, which we target for the second half of the year. We have various finance instruments in place. We will now  wait for the market reaction to the results, and then decide on the refinancing instruments in the second half. The  second tranche will expire in the spring of 2013, but we intend to refinance it earlier in the second half of 2012 in  order to make also use of the low interest rate level that we still have in the environment.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: An early decision, as one of the first implemented elements of our manufacturing footprint review, we have  successfully completed and closed our Swords site in Ireland and transferred the activities to Rochester, New York  and Suzhou in China. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Now in slide 13, I briefly go through some details in the segment. As I mentioned earlier, Specialty Ingredients  delivered good performance with substantially increased profitability. All  the segment had a high asset utilization in most technologies and this is also very good to see.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Personal Care turned into a solid performance and the Hygiene & Preservation business experienced a robust  demand around the world and saw the first benefits of introduction of new, innovative products against norovirus  and hospital-acquired infections and diseases. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: The manufacturing footprint program has been initiated and first site activities started. The portfolio review is  well under way with the Wood Treatment carveout project now initiated.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member - Executive Committee

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member - Executive Committee
texts.text: You'll see in slide 12 that Industrial Solutions and the Wood Protection, two business units within Lonza that  participate in similar industries, means protecting surfaces, both made satisfactory progress in the first half of  2015.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member - Executive Committee
texts.text: The sales performance in Industrial Solutions, however, was influenced by the lower prices in crude-oil-based  basic intermediates. On the positive side here, we could avoid any effect on margins. The Wood Protection  business saw a rebound of construction activities in U.S. in Q2 compared to Q1, when I think the weather in North  America was quite cold and the business was a little bit behind. The rollout of new innovative products such as  metal-free wood protection has been initiated and is proceeding as planned.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member - Executive Committee
texts.text: On slide 13, as I mentioned earlier in Water Treatment, we can report a better H1 performance than prior years  but we are not yet at the level of the record years. Steps to increase the internal share of the Industrial business are  continuing.

file: LONN - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 25July2018 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: As you'll see on the next slide, our new reporting structure for Specialty Ingredients consists of two divisions:  Consumer Health and Consumer & Resources Protection, as well as the business unit Water Care. Here, we are  disclosing sales, CORE EBITDA, and CORE EBITDA margins as KPIs.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Let's look first at the Water Care numbers and put them into perspective. We had a weak first four months due to  the weather, but we are encouraged by the performance in May and June and by the positive outlook. More about  Water Care later.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Moving to slide 17 Consumer & Resources Protection; this is an important pillar for Specialty Ingredients, but it's a  kind of a hybrid division as it includes specialty and high-margin businesses, as well as the more mature basic  chemical part of the portfolio. Last year, 2017, some of our basic products were at a cyclical high. But this year,  the downward cycle for some high-volume basic products and the raw material price increases on top have had  an impact on this division, although the delayed construction season in North America due to the weather was  reflected in the results of the wood business, for instance.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: On slide 18, the Water Care story is one of acceleration. Even worse than usual weather delayed the start of the  pool season in key markets such as North America. But, as I mentioned before, May and June were much  improved, and the momentum continues to build going forward. We are boosted by sales initiative and expected  new business, and so we've got a strongly positive outlook for the second half onward.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: The ongoing business model redesign has resulted in restructuring costs that are reflected in these numbers. In  addition, we have made significant investment in commercial excellence programs and in innovative offerings that  are beginning to bear fruit like new digital concepts in residential water. We expect this turnaround in the Water  Care business to continue. Water Care will continue to focus on further growing the business and developing new  technologies, while we are now in the process of considering all strategic options for the future. Just a side  remark: as we are on the process, I will also later in the Q&A provide much more information about it.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: The key targets of our Mid-Term Guidance 2022 are covered in the graphic on slide 21. As Rodolfo explained  earlier, we have adopted a stringent definition of the ROIC: its net operating profit after taxes divided by year-to- date average invested capital. Our CORE RONOA is now complemented by ROIC. And today, we are setting an  attractive double-digit ROIC target by 2022.

I think you  will agree the 9% sales and 12% CORE EBITDA organic growth figures underscore our ability to deliver on our  strategy.

texts.speaker: Rodolfo Savitzky
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: We had an excellent CORE EBITDA margin of 27.3%. So again, we delivered on our commitment to achieve 100  basis points margin improvement on a reported basis. We achieved this margin improvement for Lonza both with  and without Water Care. Of course, the Water Care divestment is margin accretive by 180 basis points. CORE  RONOA is up 31%, and is another proof of Lonza's positive returns on its organic investments. ROIC remained at  8% as a result of a more normalized tax rate in 2018.

texts.speaker: Rodolfo Savitzky
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: On slide 10, you see more numbers for Lonza including discontinued operations as the Water Care divestiture will  only close in Q1 of this year. So we have continued to make further progress on deleveraging and are on a clear  path to achieve a net debt to CORE EBITDA level below 2 by the end of 2019, a return to the levels of 2015. The  proceeds of the Water Care divestment will be used partly for that deleveraging as well as investing in growth.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Moving now to Specialty Ingredients on slide 16. Again, I don't need to dive into these numbers, but I do want to  point out that Consumer Health and Material Protection were top performers in that Specialty Ingredients portfolio.

texts.speaker: Richard Ridinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: The first bullet point on slide 20 is a reminder of the decision announced in the 1st of November 2018 to divest the  Water Care business to Platinum Equity. That strategic move allows us to focus even more on the Healthcare  Continuum. Water Care continued to make operational improvements to further grow the business and developed  further new technologies throughout 2018 based on headwinds, however, like late seasonal start in North  America and Europe and higher transportation cost.

texts.speaker: Marc Funk
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer-Pharma & Biotech and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Now, let's begin by looking our mid-term guidance on slide 22. I remind you that after completing the divestment  of Water Care, we will provide an adjusted midterm guidance to account for the Water Care disposal. Our goal  was and is to reinvest part of the proceeds of the Water Care disposal into the Healthcare Continuum. We  expected higher return to deliver more shareholder value.

texts.speaker: Marc Funk
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer-Pharma & Biotech and Member of the Executive Committee, Lonza Group AG
texts.text: Until closing of the transaction and the subsequent adjustment, we'll simply confirm the midterm guidance  including the Water Care business unit. Sales of CHF 7.5 billion, CORE EBITDA margin 30%, CORE RONOA of  35%, double-digit ROIC. We can also confirm the growth trajectory by business that we have outlined at our  September Capital Market Day.

texts.text: Coming now to the promising opportunities in our trade, I’ll start with energy efficiency on page 15  to 18. You can take a quick look on page 16 and 17 to some  of our solutions, with which we can save from 10% to more than 50% of the energy bill and which –  this is the key to success – are easy to install and easy to operate, with for instance the use of our  Eco-Etiquette or eco-tag, which for each product gives you the saving in euros and in carbon       corrected transcript

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 3 emission and the timeframe for your return on investment. Simple, pragmatic and quite appreciated  by our clients.

texts.profession: Operator

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: Third, we are launching today our fourth CSR roadmap 2019-2021, which is built around three focal areas;  business ecosystem, people, and the environment with ambitious targets contributing to the UN's Sustainable  Development Goals.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: I would like now to move to a third part on page 19, dedicated to our CSR initiatives. Indeed, the group has  launched today its four CSR roadmap, which covers three years from 2019 to 2021. It is built around three focal  areas, business ecosystem, people and the environment. These areas are broken down into 10 key challenges  that contribute to the UN Sustainable Development Goals and it has been defined through a materiality survey  that involved more than 3,600 group stakeholders.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: Within the frame of this roadmap, Legrand has also set itself ambitious targets for 2030 aimed at deriving 80% of  group sales from sustainable products, increasing the number of women in management, and achieve gender- balanced workforce, and reducing its carbon footprint through a 30% decrease in CO2 emissions directly linked to  our operations. Full package of information on this CSR roadmap is available on the legrand.com website.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good. Good morning to each and every one of you in the room, as well as through the conference
texts.text: Talking of sustainable, sustainability, one word. We don’t have this morning the time to go through  all the details of this slide, but of course we will be happy to elaborate on this later if you wish. The  important takeaway from this slide is to say that sustainability at Legrand is really part of our  business model, either through business opportunities, and we’ll come to that in a minute when we  talk about energy efficiency, electrical vehicles, et cetera, or because it helps us to enhance our  global performance by saving energy, water or other materials.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good. Good morning to each and every one of you in the room, as well as through the conference
texts.text: Energy performance, everybody is talking of energy efficiency. Wire mesh, which is a very clever  way to channel cables and data through very demanding types of infrastructure such as data  centers, the food industry, the automotive industry, et cetera, and residential systems which used to  be called the Domotics or smart home in the past.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good. Good morning to each and every one of you in the room, as well as through the conference
texts.text: Maybe you’re focused with a few slides on energy efficiency because everybody is claiming to be a  prominent actor in energy efficiency. We are convinced that energy efficiency is at the heart of the  Legrand specific expertise, which is the electrical and digital infrastructure of buildings. Why so?  Because buildings account for 40% of the energy consumption and 90% of buildings, when we talk  of buildings, these are small to medium-sized buildings, less than 2,000 square meters, for instance  in France. And this is where Legrand, has a solid franchise, owning the relationship with the  distributor and the electricians.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good. Good morning to each and every one of you in the room, as well as through the conference
texts.text: 9 As far as energy efficiency is concerned. Legrand has already a very dense offer, lighting  management, energy consumption, distribution panel, airtight, electrical infrastructure, temperature  management, shutter control, you see on this slide, and this is for residential. And for commercial,  the same applies with all what you’ve seen before, plus measurement devices and compensation of  reactive energy which is more specific of larger of – I mean, commercial office typically.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good. Good morning to each and every one of you in the room, as well as through the conference
texts.text: And the specificity is still talking of this energy efficiency topic, the specificity of our approach in this  topic is to work in partnership, unlike many of our competitors in partnership with all the players that  you see on the slide because we believe that energy efficiency will work only if it is played as a  team, and Legrand talks daily to all the players in this industry being obviously distributors and  contractors, which are the key decision makers in the business, but also all the other players being  design institute, architects, investors, et cetera, all the specifiers of the activity.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good. Good morning to each and every one of you in the room, as well as through the conference
texts.text: One word – I mean, one slide on each of those three topics as far as electrical vehicle are  concerned. And you’re looking here at the French case study, but obviously this is not the French  situation. This is throughout the world. So what we are estimating and this is shared with many  other players in this environment is that there will be by 2020, which is just nine years from today  but not so far away, 4 billion private charging stations which is typically the work of our trade  channel to be installed by the electricians, to be distributed by distributors and to be supplied by  players like Legrand, four million private charging stations to be installed in order to cope with the  ambition, which I believe will effectively occur of two million electric vehicles by 2020. And these are  interesting opportunities given the size it may represent, because obviously you may multiply this  by so many countries where this will happen, Italy, Spain, Portugal, well Legrand at leadership  position being the specialist of this electrical infrastructure of the building.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good. Good morning to each and every one of you in the room, as well as through the conference
texts.text: The second topic that everybody talks about is smart grid. Here, something has to be clear in  everybody’s mind. Utilities, I mean suppliers of energy will not be able to develop smart grid if they  do it on their own. They will need the active cooperation of all the players up to the end-user, who  will obviously not accept to be dependent on the supplier for a smart grid efficient and intelligent  network. And we’re convinced that the communication that is needed between the supplier of  energy and the end-user, we don’t need a significant fundamental upgrade of the electrical and  digital, because if we say smart grid, it means intelligent, connection of infrastructure of the  building.

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Legrand Holding SA
texts.text: And lastly, for a very small amount today but potentially much more significant tomorrow and the day after  tomorrow, is investment in future markets including, as we state here, assisted living, charging station for  electrical vehicle and smart grid.

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Legrand Holding SA

But we invest in those activities in order to create optimal future  significant flows of activities, namely those long-term drivers can be assisted living, electrical-vehicle for charging  station that's smart grid.
