texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Antoine. So, before moving to the dividend which is a natural consequence of this financial  performance. A couple of slides on the non-financial performance which means the CSR performance on page 16.  As a reminder, we launched our CSR roadmap back in 2014. This is an ambitious five-year roadmap. And  interestingly, it's a roadmap which involves all managers. When I mean all managers, for instance, all and every  country managers as now part of its remuneration in relation to CSR criteria.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, where do we stand? That's on page 17. Two – couple of comments. And of course, we will be happy to detail  further if you have any question. First is this year saw achievement, is ahead of the development plan. Compared  to our 2015 objective, we are at 120%. So, this is good news. And the second comment is that some of the  initiatives that we have made in 2015, I believe, are really innovative. Among them, the certification ISO 50001  which, I believe is a great achievement.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, this is it for the financial performance. And now moving to maybe the second part of this publication which is I  believe an important message relating to new technologies. So, I'm on page 23. I'm sure that you are familiar with  this slide that we have been using for some time. Well, the key message is we have two long-term growth drivers  for Legrand's activities. On the left-hand side is social megatrends: energy saving, security, communication, et  cetera; and on the right-hand side, technological megatrends which are listed there.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On page 31, for the interest of time, I will not comment. This page is just to illustrate the variety of products that  the teams are working on. Some of them being already sold, some of them being planned to be marketed during  this year, 2016. And on page 32, here, again, for the interest of time, I will not go through the four example that we  have on page 32, 33, 34 and 35. So, let's maybe just take one minute for this example on page 32, which is the  lighting – digital lighting management.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, what is it about? We're talking about social media trend, which is energy efficiency. We're talking about  technological breakthrough, which is to turn traditional lighting control into digital management system capable  of monitoring from a distance, all lighting loads plus sockets which is another application from a s ingle system.  So, it's about flexibility. It's about the productivity. It's also about compliance with energy codes more and more.  And clearly, as Antoine referred to when talking of the U.S. organic growth in 2015, this is a good example of one  of these growth driver for Legrand. And these digital lighting management is potentially for all commercial  buildings.

file: LR - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 9February2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: And you also remember that this new organization is reporting to a single management, helping or facilitating the  implementation of transversal initiative. I'm thinking, of course, of a productivity programs such as the Legrand  Way, but also visions for the future of what we're referring a minute earlier to Industry 4.0, and also cross- functional initiatives like [indiscernible] (08:53) with energy efficiency program and Eliot. And this is actually a  good transition, if you to move to page 11 and to make an update on Eliot.

texts.speaker: Gilles Schnepp
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: It's also value for the contractor because it provides for retrofit, very easy way to do it. It's using the existing  cabling, no box. And the configuration, the commissioning, takes only a few seconds. And it's upgradable,  scalable, very easy-to-install. And for partners, that's interesting. And this was a point since the discussion that we  had with home builders. For them, it's a way to be more productive because it's part of the infrastructure, the  same infrastructure for all the building. With equivalent [ph] backburner (17:37) allowing them to either provide  service, energy efficiency and also to allow service providers to access whether tenants are in the building. And  we have also developed with La Poste the partnership on those products. So, this is it for the first growth engine.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & EVP, Legrand SA
texts.text: On the left-hand side column, you can see that it is made of three components; two financial KPIs that you well  know, organic growth and adjusted operating margin before acquisitions; and one non-financial criteria, which is  the achievement rate of our CSR roadmap. As far as the CSR achievement in concerned, as you may know, we  have annual milestone within our CSR roadmap and the aim is to reach 100% of the annual milestone every year.  The second column of the table recalls the objectives that we announced in February 2016. The third one relates  to the target we updated in November 2016, in particular, slightly upward as far as profitability is concerned. And  finally, the fourth column is our 2016 achievements.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & EVP, Legrand SA
texts.text: As far as the adjusted operating margin before acquisitions is concerned, I remind you that we slightly raised the  high end of the target to 19.6% in November 2016. And you can see on the slide that we slightly exceeded this  raised target with 2016 achievement of 19.7%. And finally, we are ahead of schedule for our 2014-2018 CSR  roadmap; thanks to 122% achievement rate in 2016. We believe that [indiscernible] (23:52) good showings  demonstrate once again Legrand's capacity to create value for all of its stakeholders.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & EVP, Legrand SA
texts.text: In Italy, 2016 organic sales growth was plus 3.4%. This solid performance was, in particular, driven by two factors;  first, the success of the launch of our Class 300X door entry system which I remind you is connected, and as such  is part of the Eliot program. And second, one-off projects in energy distribution in H1 2016 alone. Excluding these  two one-offs, organic growth in sales in Italy would have come to around plus 2% in line with the estimated market  trend.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & EVP, Legrand SA
texts.text: Moving now to the non-financial performance on pages 35 and on page 36. On page 35, first, about our 2014- 2018 CSR roadmap. It is built on four focus points covering users, society, employees and environment. And two  comments; first, this roadmap is widely shared internally and there is a strong commitment from manager to  deliver on it; and second comment, this roadmap is also evaluated externally by auditors and agencies.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & EVP, Legrand SA
texts.text: And to finish on page 36, now about the 2016 CSR achievement. First, Legrand is ahead of its roadmap with an  achievement rate of 122% in 2016. Second, the four focus points are all above 100%. And third, you will be  finding on the slide some of the 2016 detailed CSR achievements, [ph] among which (36:44) Legrand joining the  Science Based Targets Program, a program encouraging companies to act against global warming.

file: LR - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 8February2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Legrand SA
texts.text: Then on page 16, now rapidly to tell you that I will cover the financial performance and the CSR performance, and  then hand over to Benoît for the value-creation demonstration and dividend proposal.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Legrand SA
texts.text: That's all for the financial performance. A word on CSR performance before handing over to Benoît. On page 29,  you may have in mind that our roadmap, starting in 2014 and will end in 2018, with four focus points and 21  priorities. On page 30, we show that the CSR roadmap achievement rate in 2017 is 122%, and the key message  here is that the five-year CSR roadmap is almost achieved in year four.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Legrand SA
texts.text: Then moving to page 31, to give you a bit of detail by focus point. The first is the user – the four focus points are  user, society, employees, and environment, and the first one is user. We show that, thanks to innovative  partnership, we are able to offer – or to accelerate our referring in sustainable solutions in energy efficiency  solution and also well-being solutions.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Legrand SA
texts.text: Moving to society focus point, we mention our initiative with Electricians without Borders, but also the role of the  Legrand Foundation and taking the example of the Electricians without Borders, the idea is to promote access to  electricity for all.

texts.speaker: Antoine Burel
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Legrand SA
texts.text: On page 32, a word about employees, saying that Legrand has launched Serenity On, a program aiming at  bringing to all Legrand employees a minimum healthcare by 2021. And we also mention here our attachment with  full respect for human rights and diversity. And finally, as far as environment is concerned, also interesting to  mention that by reducing its ecological footprint, in particular by reducing its CO2 emission, Legrand is also  actively taking care about environment.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: So, on page 34, all targets, as already said by both Gilles and Antoine, are met. Organic growth, the upper end of  the guidance was plus 3%, we delivered plus 3.1%. On adjusted operating margin before acquisition, upper end  of the guidance 20.1%, we delivered 20.1%. And as Antoine just said, on the CSR roadmap, we have an  achievement rate of 122%, so we are almost – we delivered almost a result of the roadmap one year in advance.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: So, new products also include, on page 42, the Eliot products. I know that you're already familiar with some of  those products, for example, the Classe 300 door entry system. We have a number of further initiatives in  temperature control, in door bell, in EV charging. And the last product we'll be launching is Céliane with Netatmo,  a range of connected user interface that we launched in France a couple of weeks ago, and that we will also roll  out in a number of countries in the months to come.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: And the two next slides provide examples of what those partnership can bring. The first one, page 45, with  Céliane with Netatmo, which is already installed in number of buildings. And the next one with two different – in  two different verticals, in the hotels with Samsung and Marriott, in the car with Renault. The last one is interesting  one, because it show that the ecosystems are moving a bit. Typically, it is now important not only to connect  within the home, but also outside of the home. And, for example, this partnership aims at allowing the end user to  do from his car screen whatever he can do from his door entry system or phone, for example, welcoming visitors,  lighting the various rooms, raising the temperature, and so on and so forth.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: On page 51, this acquisition ticks all criteria for Legrand, interesting deal, attractive field of activity, leading market  position, high value, of course, attached to the product, customer loyalty, innovation-driven business, and an  active CSR policy. So it was, as already said, very interesting transaction for Legrand.

file: LR - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 14February2019 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: Let me now conclude the review of our 2018 performance with the CSR achievements on page 15 and 16. Here  also Legrand performance was good with an achievement rate for 2014-2018 CSR roadmap of 122%,  demonstrating the group's commitment to creating sustainable value while taking all stakeholders into  consideration.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: Two examples of important initiative that we launched in 2018 as far as CSR is concerned. First, we have  adopted a target, validated by Science Based Targets, that calls for 30% reduction in greenhouse gas emission  by 2030. Second, we have released our first Human Rights Charter on the occasion of the 70th anniversary of UN  Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: Additionally, the group has retained a target for adjusted operating margin before acquisitions, at 2018 scope of  consolidation, of between 19.9% and 20.7% sales in 2019. Please note that this range embeds an estimated  favorable impact of around plus 0.1 point linked to the implementation of the IFRS 16 standard. Legrand will also  pursue its acquisition strategy and its CSR approach by launching a new roadmap for 2019-2021.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: Well, page 45 just an iteration of a number of Industry 4.0 initiatives.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: And the fifth and last initiative relates to CSR. And we are launching our first CSR roadmap as shown on page 47  of the deck, which is a 2019-2021 roadmap and you see how CSR is rooted in Legrand organization and we  started as early as 2004 our CSR strategy.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: You have on page 48 main focus point of our CSR roadmap, it's around business ecosystem, so improvement of  the value chain, and it's about people, human rights diversity, involvement communities and so but environment  with decrease in carbon footprint, circular economy and the inclusion of CSR priority in our industrial processes.  Those are for 2019-2021 CSR roadmap.

texts.speaker: Benoît Coquart
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Legrand SA
texts.text: And on page 49 we have also added longer term 2030 objectives in line with United Nations' Development Goals  which are very important for Legrand, which we are pushing hard. So number one, we want 80% of our revenue  which is sustainable by design or by usage. Number two, in terms of diversity we are aiming to have a parity in  the workforce and to have at least one-third of our key positions being held by women. And number three, in  terms of CO2 emissions we intend to reduce by 30% emissions for scope 1 and scope 2.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The other point, which from my perspective is more important, is to highlight the operational  decisions that were taken in course of the very first quarter that will ensure that the transformation  that has started in 2005, that this transformation migrating Lanxess to a more profitable and  stronger – structurally stronger company will continue in the years to come. Because all these  investments – if I relate to the butyl investments, the PBR capacities, the high rubber ends, basic  chemicals, all the water purification investments that have been communicated – they will come on  stream in the years 2011, ‘12 and ‘13 and will of course nicely further transform the company in the  future. As far as financials are concerned, 233 million EBITDA and net income of 104, I think also  close up the first quarter with a good financial start.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So if you move on page number 12, we give more color to the underlying products that we are  selling here and, especially here the sophisticated engineering plastics, which are sold in a variety  of end-applications. What we would like to stress here are the innovations that with which we enter  into new models, into new cars that are basically not only the high-premium cars in Germany, but  also the more volume-oriented producers. We basically see that the entire car industry is moving  towards lighter ingredients, lighter products, lighter possibilities to reduce the weight of the car; and  we see that we have here end-applications with which we differentiate ourselves substantially and  thus leading to reduced weights and also further functionalities that steel or aluminum was not able  to offer before.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And as far as iron exchange resins is concerned, the project that’s should be completed in course  of this year in India is fully on-track. So our resin sites will most likely be already going into the       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The second point I would like to make is we do have a flexible cost structure in place. We  established that in 2009. And we have a plan in place that gives us support also for the years 2010  and ‘11, and from that standpoint I think we are now in a very nice situation to manage in whatever  macroeconomic environment we are in. We have underline very good trends. I’m alluding to the  mobility trends; I’m alluding to the high-performance tires trends that will need high-performance  rubber; I allude to the urbanization that we benefit from, especially in the performance chemicals  cans; and also the water purification; and of course the trend towards the lighter vehicles. And in all  of these areas I think we have business units that will benefit through this.

texts.text: Thank you, Oliver. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. We published Q1 figures today. They are disappointing.  They are as guided before. So all those plants on temporary base don't  want maintenance. And in these areas where we can reduce availability, we can reduce maintenance CapEx.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Düttmann
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Supervisory Board, LANXESS AG
texts.text: With that, I would like to go immediately to the Performance Polymers segment. In that segment, we have seen a  drastic decline on sales by 18.5%. Butadiene prices, raw material prices were substantially higher than the first quarter  last year.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Düttmann
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Supervisory Board, LANXESS AG
texts.text: On performance chemicals, we have a mixed picture. Stable all in all are – the prices are all in all stable. texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s move on to chart number 18, and two points that I would like to stress as far as this chart is  concerned. We had in Q4 2008 beneficial windfall profits because in Q4 2008 benzene and toluene  collapsed on the raw material price sides while we stuck to our product prices at that point in time.  So we had round about high – round about high single-digit million windfall profit, which of course  diluted the base somewhat. But point two, clearly as I stated in November, already we saw  weakness in the agro market and this turned out to be true. In November, we already gave color  through the first half of 2010 where we – our view is that the agro supply chain will still be loaded,  and therefore we would see here from the agro industry weakness, but don’t get me wrong.

file: LXS - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 17March2011 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As you know, we focus on hi-tech, on premium products and it is fair to say premium and  technology really sells. And in particular in the emerging countries because it has the similar  challenges we have, they need to do, they’re desperate to go for hi-tech, for energy efficiency, for  resources efficiency, they want to build their infrastructure, their countries and they are desperate to  go for latest technology. And here we come we have a lot to offer, that’s the reason why over the  years we focused in a big portfolio realignment on the four big mega trends, really being driven by  the growth and population. So this is mobility urbanization, agriculture and water. We have been  discussing this since sometime, we definitely need a greener mobility, we definitely need to go for       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 energy efficiency and resource efficiency in terms of the growing urbanization and in particular in  light of the tragic and devastating situation in Japan. We need to reevaluate, we need to rethink  about energy consumption of planet Earth and this is exactly why we are very well positioned. We,  over the last years, we have improved our own energy consumption our own profile, but well  beyond on that, we have developed, we have invented products which allow consumers to reduce  their energy footprint dramatically.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have developed products for a greener mobility, a mobility which will use by far less fuel and  energy in the years to come. And talking about green mobility, as you know we have a strong  position, a strong technology position in the world on green tires, which have the potential to save  up to 30% of fuels and we have another strong position in high-tech plastics which allow to make  cars much lighter than in the past and this will have a significant impact on the fuel consumption.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And both product – set of products are important to a greener mobility, doesn’t matter if it’s  conventional car or if it’s an – if it’s for the electro mobility, mobility itself needs a better energy  efficiency and here we are, we have a lot to offer.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Also R&D expansion is on the rise plus 15%, €116 million in 2010, which is still fairly low, but this  highlights our focus and discipline and our R&D strategy. We also increased our share in Gevo.  Gevo is an U.S. based startup company having invented a process, a fermentation process to  produce bio-based butanol which we then take to dehydrogenate and then to inject it in our existing  butyl facilities. And this will allow us to develop a second leg in terms of the raw material supply for  this high tech synthetic rubber. We’re working hard on the process for the dehydrogenation and we  are making good progress on that. And our target is to have a significant amount of butyl produced  in the middle of this century on the basis of this bio-based fuel. Particularly in light of the recent  developments in the world this will become more and more important to have an alternative source.  These are the fuel-based petrochemicals. The fermentation process and our dehydrogenation  process is a very smart process and I’m very pleased to say this is a process which is based on a  C4 molecule, so it’s not a fermentation process producing bio-ethanol, which is for, let me say,  burning.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: No, this process is designed to produce a C4 molecule, which is not for burning but for making very  valuable products out of it, what we do. So it is not to – it is a real raw material based on a  fermentation process and then on a very short sequence then we produce bio-base, we are going  to produce bio-based butyl. And we already have done this in recent weeks and months in a lab -on  a lab scale and we are working, as I said hard, to have decent facilities at hand in the very near  future.

We'd be going back there with a new rig and then there was one dry well.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then, we took the Tyra South East on stream late Q1 in Denmark. So, that's also positive. On the Culzean – on  the Chissonga, there's no news. Also on the back of the drop in the oil price, we're retendering this project. We're  looking at technical changes and so on. And I don't expect any news on this project to come out this year.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, that's the situation in Maersk Oil. A good first quarter but helped by the change in tax rate in the UK. We are  adjusting our forecast for the year, slightly upwards as a consequence of slightly higher oil prices. So, of course, if  the oil price is above $60, that should be a basis for a profit for the full year.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: APM Terminals results is decreasing compared to last year, as I alluded to before. And that is due to lower  earnings in the oil-exposed economies. We're still delivering good returns. We're still confident that we will return  to growth in profit. But for this year, we do forecast the pressure in these oil-related economies to continue. And,  therefore, we're taking down our guidance for that business.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, the business is performing well in the first quarter. And we also still expect an improved result compared to  last year for the full year. Then there's some details on the deliveries. And we've taken delivery of one ultra  deepwater drillship, which is going on a 3.5 year contract in Ghana with Eni. And we've also taken delivery of a  ultra-harsh environment jack-up, which is going on a long-term contract with Statoil in Norway. So, that looks  good and solid.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil, expect small positive underlying result for 2015, as a consequence of cost savings a nd, of course,  estimating a low oil price around $55 to $60 per barrel. The entitlement production is now expected to be above  $265,000 and the exploration expenses still expected to be around $700 million.

file: MAERSK.B - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 4May2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, if we go straight to the forward-looking statements on page two, and then while you read that, I'll just give a  little bit of flavor to the accounts as we see them. I mean, we appreciate, of course, that the markets are in a very  bad situation. We've gone through Q1 where oil prices – I can't say that they bottomed out, but at least they were  lower than even today, down around $30 a barrel during most of the quarter. So, that was tough. And the shipping  rates were record low in Q1. They, by the way, are still very low. So, we've gone through a difficult quarter from a  market perspective. Nevertheless, we improved the results versus Q4 last year, coming out with a small profit, and  we are pleased with that.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Most of our businesses are still making money, the two that are not is Maersk Supply Service due to the very poor  ordering situation in the sector. And Maersk Oil due to the very low oil prices, but I'll come back to that later.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Oil going down from $200 million to a slightly negative result, actually, better than we expected for Maersk Oil.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: APM Terminals down, and I'll come back to that, of course, but background is deterioration – continued  deterioration in the oil exporting markets. Most of them have no money for imports. So, you see massive trade  impacts in those countries.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, a good result on the cost level and, of course, bunkers have had an impact. So if you look at, if you compare the  total reduction of $389 per FFE, the bunker impact of that is almost half. So, that's the way it works. It goes in the  right direction and we'll, of course, continue to work on reducing the cost.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Moving over to Maersk Oil, we're actually quite satisfied with the development in Maersk Oil. We have beaten our  expectations on cost reductions and production. And that means that our breakeven cost has moved down from  the $45 to $55 we said at the beginning of the year, down to $40 to $45. So that's a clear improvement, and of  course, we don't give sort of a specific guidance for the annual result. But it means that given that oil prices are  where we are today, we're quite optimistic that we'll get a result around zero. So, that's improvement compared to  last year.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Not much more to say here. We had a dispute settlement. That means that the operating cash flow turned negative  in the quarter. And we've also had some discussions in the press on the future of production in Tyra West and  Tyra East. And the background for that is that the platforms are sinking. We've been taking gas out of the ground  for so many years that there is a space to fill. So, that means the platforms have been sinking.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The 2C reserves have declined compared to last year, the contingent resources as they're called and the  background for that is partly that we've taken some reserves from there, resources and develop them into reserves  at Culzean and Johan Sverdrup, but also because the lower oil price means that some of our oil resources are no  longer feasible, and therefore they have been excluded.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Going then to page 13, an overview of the total consolidated income statement. On the revenue side, a decrease  from $10.5 billion down to $8.5 billion, $2 billion down, and that is really driven by Maersk Line and Maersk Oil;  $1.3 billion from Maersk Line due to the 26% decrease in rates but, of course, an increase of 7% in volume adjusts  that number and Maersk Oil approximately $400 million, which is done by a change of oil prices of $20 a barrel,  but compensated by 15% in increased entitlement production. So, that is really the two main drivers that goes  through the changes from the first quarter of 2015 throughout the numbers.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For Maersk Oil, following the cost reductions, we now expect a breakeven result to be reached with an oil price in  the range of $40 to $45 per barrel. We previously had an estimate of $45 to $55, but as you can see that is taken  down due to the significant effects of the cost elements.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The entitlement production we have an increasing expectation up to – we now expect between 320,000 barrels  and 330,000 barrels a day. For exploration cost, we have adjusted that expectation to be below last year.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For APM Terminals, we have also changed our guiding and we now expect the underlying result to be below 2015  due to the reduced demand expectations in oil-producing emerging economies, as Nils mentioned.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And as always, I'll guide you to the sensitivity. There is considerable uncertainty, and market uncertainty adds on  to that. But I will guide you to the slight changes in the sensitivity guidance for oil price due to the fact that the low  oil price and the tax effects of the different countries have an effect. It is not symmetric at these levels of oil price.  So that is slight change to the previous sensitivity guidance.

file: MAERSK.B - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 11May2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: And then, the third highlight of the quarter, I would say, is Maersk Oil's performance, strong financial results, very  much, of course, driven by higher oil price, but certainly also driven by good performance on costs.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: In terms of lowlights, I have to say, of course, that we cannot be satisfied with the overall level of profitability for  the group. We cannot – and first of all, secondly, Maersk Line remained in the red. We're reporting an $80 million  loss, underlying loss, despite higher freight rates and it's been driven by a much higher fuel bill than we had last  year.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Thank you very much, Jakob, and we will turn to the Energy division and start on page 14 with Maersk Oil. And as  Søren already mentioned, Maersk Oil came out of the first quarter with a very strong financial performance and an  underlying profit of $292 million. This was positively affected by a one-off tax income of $42 million, but also, as  you can see on the slide, helped tremendously by continuous focus on cost and efficiencies.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: When you look at our entitlement production, it declined 21%. This was mainly caused by the large decline in  Qatar, which again is caused by the higher oil price and lower operating cost giving us this entitlement  production's – this entitlement [indiscernible] (16:19) cost recovery. However, we also saw decline in the UK when  we compared to the first quarter last year. This decline already materialized in the third quarter 2016. And during  the last quarters, we have stabilized this production through interventions and we are now at a stable level at the  current production levels. We have also seen other good developments in the UK.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Turning to page 15, showing our reserves and resources for the year-end 2016. They come out as expected with  a 1P proven reserves of 339 million barrels of oil equivalent and with a 1P Reserve Replacement Ratio of 40%.  There are no write downs in relations to the Qatar exit here in 2017 and our 2P reserves of 555 million barrels of  oil equivalent, [ph] those (17:18) also not include the second phase of Johan Sverdrup and all the Tyra rebuild as  these two projects have not yet been sanctioned, but the reserve development is in line with expectations.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Moving fast to page 17, starting on the left-hand side with Maersk Supply Service. Maersk Supply Service is still  heavily affected by the oil supply in the industry and they, therefore, also saw a steep decline in both revenue and  bottom line. There's a continuous strategic focus in Maersk Supply Service in launching integrated customer  solutions. As an example of this, in January, we signed a long-term partnership agreement with Oceaneering  International, and the integrated solutions are gaining quite a bit of customer interest.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: That was a fast review of the four energy companies. And I'll hand the word back to Jakob.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer and Chief Financial, Strategy & Transformation Officer-Transport & Logistics, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Then, we have a couple of pages just basically for your information. Page 20 showing the consolidated financial  information and page 21 showing how we are now and in the future will show you the segmented results, so that  we really focus on looking at the Transport & Logistics in total and the energy in total. There is no kind of group  anymore. Things are splitted out. Obviously, the majority of the overhead costs are located into Transport &  Logistics. We have not yet, but that they will come, allocated all overhead costs into the individual businesses in  Transport & Logistics.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Thank you. And I just want to end quickly by saying that or repeating that we're clear that – we're confident that  the container market is improving. Prices are up. Demand is up. We are making progress on our strategic  priorities when it comes to revenue growth, consolidation, synergies in Transport & Logistics, and digital. And we  are also confident about the cost performance in Maersk Oil leading that company to be profitable at today's oil  price.

file: MAERSK.B - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 17May2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Moving on the results. If we start with the positive story, then it's about growth; it's about the fact that we are  replacing the revenue that is leaving the group along with the energy companies and we are not becoming a  smaller company as a result of this transformation. Revenue is up 30% driven by the acquisition of Hamburg Süd  but also driven by organic growth across the business including in the Non-Ocean segments.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Moving on to Energy – the Energy separation, as I said, we reported a very strong profit of $3 billion. That  includes an accounting gain of $2.6 billion related to the sale of Maersk Oil, which we closed in March. We now  own 97.5 million shares, almost 4% of Total S.A. and those shares have a value of more than $6 billion right now.  They have, of course, benefited significantly from the increase in the oil price in recent months.

texts.speaker: Vincent Clerc
texts.profession: Chief Commercial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: This difference was – temporarily disappeared in 2016 and 2017 as demand was impacted in some of the  emerging markets by the lower oil price and cascading of tonnage. And we are basically seeing right now a  gradual recovery in the North-South where rates are regressing back to where they were before the price war. So,  that's a positive development for this part of the business.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, A.P. Møller - Mærsk A/S, Chief Operating Officer, Chairman, Maersk Container Industry & Board Member of Hamburg Süd
texts.text: We have put a number of plans in place right now, ranging from the entire part of the cost toolbox. Let me explain  a few. We will implement a number of capacity reductions over the next two quarters, capacity reductions in  trades that are not yielding the desired results. We will optimize the landscape of feedering. That means we will  reduce the number of feeders that we have out there and generally channel more volume to direct ports. We will  push harder on fuel efficiency over the coming quarters as we have now fully integrated the Hamburg Süd fleet  since two weeks. We'll do a number of things in procurement, a number of things on improving our MT cost base,  and a number of things on improving utilization where it makes sense.

file: MAERSK.B - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 18August2010 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: But the other businesses are also performing well. We have a profit growth in APM Terminals as  well. This is mainly due to sale of the shares in the Yantian Terminal in China, which was booked in  the second quarter this year. We have also growth in the profits in the oil gas – oil and gas  business; I’ll come back to that, but of course mainly driven by increased prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have some – of course the driver of this is the container business, also the oil business. But it is  also very important, as I said in the opening, to note that we have worked very, very intensively with  our cost and competitiveness situation over the last couple of years. And without being very  detailed and very well documented on it, if we have not improved our cost position in the container  business, it is very likely that we would still be talking about a result very close to zero in the first       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So we turn the page and go to slide four and straight into the business unit that has given the main  changes in the first half, the segment result improved from a loss of US$995 million to a profit of 1.2  billion, a very significant improvement. And looking – if comparing to 2009, the rates are up 31%  and volumes are up 11%. So, all the bases are working in our favor. Bunker prices are up 69%  compared to the first half last year, but we managed to cut – continue our trend of reducing bunker  consumption. So we cut our consumption with 6% and the outcome is a very, very positive EBIT pr.  FFE 64. It is absolutely in the high-end of what we have ever delivered, and they compare of  course to, well, you can say an extremely unusual situation in 2009. So it’s almost irrelevant, but  obviously a negative figure.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: But in order to put the things in perspective, we’ve put in two – or we’ve put in comparison to 2008  in the two graphs you see below. And if you check the graph to the left, you will see that the  development in rates, which – here the growth rate, so it’s including bunker adjustment factor, in  order not to have two very technical separations. But you will see that actually – the rates in the first  half of 2010 were actually below the rates in 2008. So even if we see a tremendous increase  compared to the 2009 figures, we’re still not back to the 2008 levels. If we adjust for increasing  bunker prices – or decreasing bunker prices compared to 2008, it gets a little bit closer but here you  can say, at this point in time, we’re probably cleaned for bunker price differences at the 2008 level,  but the first half is still below. So it’s not that the rates are moving through absolutely unusual  territory. It just increases to against a very weak 2009 that are unusual. So 2009 was the exception,  it is the message I’m trying to bring out.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: There is of course some uncertainty about the U.S. Gulf of Mexico and the general drilling situation  following the Macondo BP accident. So far we are not seeing any effects of it, but of course if the  drilling moratorium is extended or is going on for a long time or activity is reduced, that would mean  that some of the rigs could be move to other areas and there could be pressure on rigs. So far it’s  more of a theoretical consideration, but we think it’s worth just keeping an eye on that. We have  good contract coverage both in our drilling but also in our supply vessel area. But here the spot  markets are affected by quite a lot of supply, new vessels coming.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We’ve taken some impairment losses on LNG ships and FPSOs, in total of US$155 million, when  that actually doesn’t really change the total picture in comparison to last year because last year we  had a very significant write-down in the tanker business. So in the total, that’s not a big change  compared to last year. And we also completed, as I said before, the sale of Norfolkline, and we are  now owning 31% of DFDS and that will in the future be accounted for as an associated company.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So going through slide seven, the oil and gas activities, of course the result is very positive. We  warned already at the end of last year that we would have lower production this year than in 2009  and that has also come true, but of course the pricing has gone up. We are now having oil prices  about 50% higher than in the first half of 2009. We have a positive impact of lower exploration cost.  They’re down 41% compared to last year, and this is mainly due – affected mainly due to reversal  of provisions and special circumstances in the drilling. We’re actually having the same drilling  program as normal, and therefore we also know for a fact that in the second half our drilling  expenses or exploration expenses will go up, which is why we say that we will have a significant  lower result in the second half than in the first half, also because we are closing a couple of fields  down for the period for maintenance.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: You can see the share of production down in the bottom. Decline – significant decline in Qatar  that’s because of the profit sharing model we have with Qatar Petroleum. We’ve I think tried to give  as much transparency into this previously as well. Denmark oil, still a decline in production but  actually this year we see quite a bit of – quite a good sales of gas from Denmark, which is  compensating the decline in the oil. The U.K. is up so far this first half year, which is partly because  we had closedowns in the first half last year. So the oil business is doing quite well. We have six –  had six exploration and appraisal wells during the first half and we will have slightly more activity in  the second half of the year. The acquisitions we mentioned a couple of times, so there is nothing  new here, but we are still looking to invest in the oil sector as we’ve previously stated.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Trond Ø Westlie, Group Chief Financial Officer  Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. As Nils said, we’re very satisfied with the results for this first  half. As you can see on slide number nine, the – our revenue in the first half year is 20 – a bit more  higher than US$27 billion, 20% over last year; and an EBITDA of 7.8 billion. That is as much as  84% over last year’s numbers. Depreciation, amortization is very much based to the same  impairment level and slightly up from last year due to the fact that we have a higher asset base in  our balance sheet. Sales gains in the first half is 551, very much influenced by the 430 million gain  on the Yantian transaction and some other minor transactions in other segments. That leaves us  the earnings before interest and tax of $5,438 million, which is a very much more – or basically  220% more than last year, and as we can see very much driven by the return to profit in the  container business. Financial items, on the same level as last year, 623, and taxes increases from  1.6 in 2009 to 2.3 billion as a result of oil – and – the improved oil result, as a result of the oil prices  coming up. That leaves us a profit and loss for the period of $2,523 million.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Going then to slide number 11, expectations for 2010; for the second half the group container  shipping and related activities are expected to post a positive net – a positive result at the level that  we see in the first half of 2010. We must say though that it is with significant uncertainty for  especially the fourth quarter this year. On the oil and gas side, we expect that the second half is  expected to be somewhat below of the first half year, primarily due to planned maintenance in  Denmark and Great Britain but also as a result of exploration being much higher than the first half.  That leaves us – the overall expectation for the A.P. Møller-Maersk Group are that the result for  2010 will exceed $4 billion. That expectations are based on the retention of the present level of  freight rates, oil prices and US dollar exchange rate and are excluding the expected gain from the  sale of Dansk Supermarked of approximately $700 million. And as I said, the outlook for 2010 is  subject to considerable uncertainty, not least due to the development of the global economy, which  is then driving of course the uncertainty of the fourth quarter, as I mentioned.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We also believe that the focus we have laid out for – in the area of investments – is the right one.  We of course make sure that we keep capacities in place to grow the markets in – basically in all  our business units, but we will continue to focus on expanding our activities in oil and gas and the       corrected transcript

file: MAERSK.B - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 14August2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: But we'll go into more details now and the group financial highlights on page four, if you can go there. The profit  of the group in Q2 was US$965 million, compared to a result of US$1.6 billion last year. The difference here is that  we had extraordinary income from the sale of Netto UK and that makes up for the difference. Otherwise, the result  development is flat, which we consider pretty good, given the fact that we have declining oil production and we are  in a turnaround phase within Maersk Line.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Line's profit was US$227 million against a small loss last year. Maersk Oil's profit was US$468 million  against a profit of almost US$700 million last year. We'll come back to that, of course, in a minute. But this is the  expected decline in oil production that takes its toll on the results and it's totally as expected.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Drilling had a stable result and major rig contracts were signed, which we take as a good sign of customer  interest in our business and the new very modern rigs we've ordered. And then, we continued our reduction  efforts on our FPSO and LNG businesses. So we had – we completed the sale of Peregrino in July. So this doesn't  impact the second quarter figures. But we have now successfully divested the Australian FPSO at the end of last  year, LNG vessels this year, and Maersk Peregrino, the second large FPSO, also this year. So we are progressing on  our strategy.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We also have seen a unit cost decline of 1% when we exclude the effects of the bunker price increases. This is also  to be regarded as a first step. We'll have to work much more on reducing both overhead and operational cost over  the coming quarters, but it is pointing in the right direction. And then, as I mentioned before, the restructuring of

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We continue, both we and we've noticed similar moves with competitors to reduce capacity somewhat through  slow-streaming, vessel-sharing agreements and other measures, and this is less costly. It's saving fuel and it is less  costly than being off-vessel, so it's probably a good model.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Nothing much to add. You've seen that the biggest drop is coming out of Qatar with 28% to 114,000 barrels a day.  And this drop will continue so that we, for the rest of the year, expect around 100,000 barrels of oil equivalents  per day from Qatar.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And if you go to Maersk Drilling, I think maybe I should add here that the guidance for the year is about just  265,000 barrels of oil today so it is slightly below what we have produced in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going to – if we take Maersk Tankers, we continue in the market having the situation of persistent oversupply.  The order book is shrinking, but we see lots of oversupply in particular in the VLC area, but also in product  tankers. The only segments here where capacity is more or less in line with demand is the gas area that delivers  acceptable returns at the moment.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil expects a result for 2012 at the same level as the result for 2011, including the impact of the settlement  of the tax dispute in Algeria. The expected result is based on share of production of 265,000 barrels of oil  equivalents per day during 2012 and the average oil price of $108 per barrel for the remainder of the year.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Exploration costs are expected to be above $1 billion. APM Terminals, expect a result of 2012 above the results for  2011 and above market growth in volumes, supported by portfolio expansion.

file: MAERSK.B - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 16August2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The oil production is bottoming out. And we are seeing and expect to meet our full-year guidance by delivering  increased production in the second half, so we're pleased with that.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil's production was bottoming out in the second quarter, just as predicted. But we're seeing increase in  figures now as Gryphon and El Merk ramps up. And as predicted, we will see increasing production in the second  half, setting off, you can say, a gradual growth towards the 400,000 barrels of oil per day in 2020. I'm not  promising a smooth ride. There'll be ups and downs, but we continue to regard this as our target.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Line continued to reduce its unit costs further, and they are really getting very competitive. The main  drivers of the reduced costs, I'll come to that – back to that in detail, have been reduced, bunker consumption  achieved through improved utilization and network efficiencies.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil had some wins in the second quarter. Gryphon, the FPSO in UK, started its produ ction or restarted its  production. We've got El Merk onstream finally. It had been hit by delays in its ramp -up, but it's now ramping up  towards full production that we expect to be achieved somewhere around the end of the year. We've been working  on the Chissonga field development plan for quite some time. We're getting very close to being able to submit it to  the Angolan authorities. One of the things that we have to clarify before we submit it is what we believe around the  Cubal well, which we drilled in an area that is immediate adjacent to Chissonga and which shows hydrocarbons.  And if our test shows that this is as promising as we hoped, then this will be an addition to the field, and we just  need to finalize and understand fully what the impact of that is on the production opportunity. And then we had  this small new field, Balloch, into production in the second quarter, and that is at full production for 1,000 barrels  a day, so some early wins there.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil was, quite as predicted, down. I'll go into the details later on. But the main driver of this was actually  the high level of exploration costs and then the falling oil production and lower oil prices.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going to slide six, we start diving into the details of the business units and starting, as usual, with Maersk Line.  And significant progress, there's a drop in revenue which has been – which is due to lower rates. The lower rates  have been more than compensated by the cost reduction, but I think it just underlines that the environment and  the industrial situation remains quite challenging, so the improvements are actually due to improvements that we  have made in the business.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And if I go to the highlights, I would say the unit cost decrease is probably the most important thing to notice here.  It's a $394 unit cost reduction per FFE compared to Q2 2012. And the decrease is mainly driven by bunker cost,  31% down to – compared to Q2 last year. 18% of that is lower consumption driven by a more efficient network, but  I'll come back to that in more details in a minute. And 15% is lower bunker price. So, actually, the improvements  due to network efficiencies, et cetera, is more than the bunker price reduction.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Deepening or going a little bit deeper into the details of the Maersk Line cost reductions because they are very,  very significant, and the total cost reduction is $900 million, $897 million to be exact, of which $310 million was  due to lower bunker consumption. This is network efficiency and slow steaming, and there's a bullet on that just  below. And the lower bunker price gave us a saving of $263 million which, of course, has been more or less equally  shared across the industry. So, other liner companies will report similar savings, well, at least in line with their  total volume.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: So, just in the next bullet, we just try to outline the main impact of – main reason or large reason, at least,  explanation for why we reduced bunker efficiency. We've taken out two strings from Asia to Europe, and we've  used the surplus vessels to introduce in the remaining strings, reducing ave rage speed in the service and  dramatically cutting the cost of operations.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: So, that's sort of to give a little bit more light, shed a little more light on the cost reductions that we, of course, will  continue to work on but they really have been very impactful in the first half.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil is, of course, a little bit more of a mixed bag this quarter. We did bottom out in – production-wise, in  the quarter. And we had a decline in production by 21% due to maturing fields in Denmark and the UK. But also,  and more important than that, was actually the reduced Danish ownership from 39% to 31.2%, which has been  related to the entry of North Sea Fund into the DUC ownership structure.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And then we had an unplanned closedown of Tyra West, which has an impact of around 3,000 barrels of oil per  day in the quarter. So, we bottomed out a little bit lower than we had expected. The result may come out below  what external – some external people expected, which we fully acknowledge. Part of that is, of course, the lower oil  price, and it is, of course, also the volume. But it is – but then we have had a very high level of exploration cost  which, of course, is impossible to predict from the outside.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We have had a successful appraisal well on Johan Sverdrup, which further lifted our expectations to the field. And  then we've had three wells discovering hydrocarbons but, however, not assessed to be commercial at this point. Of  course, we continue to look into it and see what we can learn but nothing positive to report at this point in t ime.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Cubal in Angola discovered hydrocarbons, and we're evaluating that as we speak, and hopefully, this will add to  the quality of the Chissonga development that we are planning to give you more information on during the second  half.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going on to the consolidated financial information, our focus on the first column on second quarter 2013, we're  showing a revenue of $14.163 billion. It's a decline of $1.201 billion from last year. The drivers of that decline is  Maersk Line with $670 million and Oil of $665 million. And on the counter side, the business units that pic ks up  is Dansk Supermarked with $130 million and Drilling with about $100 million. So, Line, as Nils mentioned, is  really the top line, basically, the rate decrease. And the Oil, as Nils mentioned, was the entitlement production and  the oil price going down.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And in addition to the safe operations which are always top of our minds, in particular, in the oil and oil-related  businesses, the most important target for Maersk Oil is to get some good hits in the exploration work, of course,  but also making sure that we deliver progress on the key projects, Chissonga, Johan Sverdrup, that are key to  bringing up our production to 400,000 barrels in 2020.

file: MAERSK.B - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 19August2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: If you have uploaded (sic) [downloaded] the presentation, the first thing you will see on the front page will be a  drilling rig. It is our new – one of our new jack-ups. It's a very large harsh environment rig that will go on contract  or starting working here in August and each one of the five big – six big drilling rigs that we will take delivery of  this year. And, hopefully, everything will work well. We're quite convinced about that.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And if we then go to page two, it's the usual sort of responsibility limitation on our forward -looking statements, if  any. That, of course, we are living in an uncertain world and we have still uncertainty on oil prices, on s hipping  rates and so on to take into accounts. And we just ask you to bear that in mind.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And then we have taken a fresh look on our oil business. We have impaired our investment in Brazil, written it  down with US$1.7 billion to US$600 million. Have in mind though, and we'll come back to tha t later, but we still  have two interesting projects there. And we are convinced that they will materialize into business.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil has had good progress on key projects. We still expect to have both Jack and Golden Eagle starting  production towards the end of the year or around the end of the year. So that's on plan. And also the other large  projects are progressing both in Norway, Johan Sverdrup; Culzean in the UK; and Chissonga in Angola. So we  seem to be on a good track. And we also reiterate our expectation to reach 240,000 barrels of oil p roduction this  year on a daily basis. So that should be good.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The reported result is, of course, impacted by the gain from sale of Dansk Supermarked and negatively impacted  by the impairment of Brazilian oil assets. So if we take the profits, excluding one-offs, then it's up 34% to US$1.3  billion, which we consider good progress. And that takes our progress in the first half up to 42%. The main driver  has been, of course, Maersk Line, but both Maersk Oil and APM Terminals contribute very positively to the  continued progress.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And we have seen some cost increasing. The main increases come from terminals but also the intermodal inland  has been picking up somewhat on the back of, probably, more economic activity in some of the markets where we  operate. And we continue our effort to reduce bunker costs. And this time, actually, the drop in price has been less  important. It is the bunker consumption which has been reduced significantly with 7.2%. So, this is very good.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going to page eight, the highlights on Maersk Oil result, a loss of $1.4 billion reported but actually when you  reduce or clearly when you reduce the – or take out the Brazil impairment, a result increase in underlying profit  from – to $431 million from $140 million. Also better oil price actually than we had expected, increase in  production and then lower exploration cost. We talked about this before but recent years exploration results have  led us to reevaluating the exploration cost. It's still work in progress but we will be more critical on this when we  go forward.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The revenue base is just short of $12 billion, slightly up from last year. We see that the revenue increase is coming  specifically in Maersk Line and Maersk Oil. Maersk Oil as a result of higher entitlement production, as well as the  higher oil prices driving that.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: EBITDA of $3.1 billion or sort of which is also – just flows through as a result of the cost efficiency both when it  comes to lower exploration cost in oil as well as the efficiency in Maersk Line. Even though nominal cost goes up,  we see that the revenue increase is higher.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: This is based on average oil price of $108 per barrel. And we have upped that from $104. And we still expect an  entitlement production to be above 240,000. Exploration costs are expected to be below $1 billion for the year.  For Terminals, we now expect underlying results above 2013.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: For the outlook of 2013 (sic) [2014], there are considerable uncertainty, not least due to the development of glo bal  economy, the container rates and the oil price. And we have set out the bigger sensitivities as we see it for 2014 in  the oil price, bunker price, container rates and the freight volume as such at the bottom on the right side.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil will continue to deliver progress on key projects. And then, we hope by the end of the year to be able to  report first oil from Golden Eagle and Jack and actually have no reasons to believe that that should not be the  case. They're both progressing well. APM Terminals is, at the moment, very close to opening the Maas vlakte II  project. And that's, of course, important that we get a good start there. But apart from that, we'll continue to  optimize the portfolio, as we just said, with Virginia, which will be closed within the coming days.

file: MAERSK.B - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 13August2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: While you look at the forward-looking statement on page 2, I will just give you just a few highlights and the first  one is that in a quarter which has been strongly impacted by low oil prices and also pressure on rates, in  particular, from Asia to Europe. We're pleased to present the result of $ 1.1 billion. It's in line with last year when  you correct for the fact that we basically handed out our Danske Bank shareholders to the shareholders during the  second quarter. So, we regard this as satisfactory. And on the back of this good performance, we  also maintain our  guidance for the year of $4 billion.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: There are some changes in the strategic update or strategic situation of the company, following the turbulence and  you can say now three quarters with low oil prices. We have changed the outlook and expectations for Maersk Oil,  Maersk Drilling, and the oil service businesses in general, by the way, as well as for APM Terminals, that have a  number of terminals that are affected by the economy in the oil-producing market. So, we're stepping down from  targets for these, let me say, numeric concrete targets for these businesses. And we will replace that kind of  communication with more flexible plans, adapting it to the volatile environment we're facing here. We're  maintaining the overall targets for the group, so the 10% ROIC, we're maintaining the expectation o f a strong  balance sheet growing dividends and all these things remain the same. But in order to ensure that we can also  deliver that, we will have to be more flexible in these oil-related businesses, making sure we get the maximum out  of the situation going forward.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And I suggest we go to slide 4, which is on the individual business units. I've stated some of the points already  here, but very briefly, Maersk Line, delivering more than 10% return in a quarter where rates are actually on –  basically on 2009 level when you correct for the oil price, and I think that is very, very satisfactory and it shows  the steadiness and the resilience of this business that it's been true every year and solid turnaround. We were very  pleased with that.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil, we still have our ambition to reduce OpEx by 20% towards the end of 2016, with good progress on  maturation of key projects. And we have in line with what we've said previously, decided to reduce our exploration  cost at least gradually and instead being more open to M&A activity, and I'm talking fields here, mainly in two  substitute reserves that we produce.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: APM Terminals, no real change in the underlying strategy. We are impacted in APM Terminals, and I'll come back  to that of course, by the oil-dependent markets, and also Maersk – or APM Terminals is quite exposed to changes  in the Asia-Europe trade in terms of volume.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk Drilling, doing well. We've now introduced seven of the eight new fleets or new rigs in our fleet, and that  has led to a nice increase in earnings as they were under contract and we've decommissioned one rig and drew oil  in the process of it. And also here, cost reductions are on the agenda and are giving effect already now.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Going to page five, we're talking about the financial highlights. Those figures are – they are not that different from  first quarter. But comparing the absolute figures to the same quarter last year, we have a profit year of $1.1 billion  under total stated profit compared to $2.3 billion last year. The $2.3 billion last year were affected by the wri te- down in Brazil of our oil assets, as well as a gain from Dansk Supermarked. So, it's not really comparable. What is  comparable is the underlying profit which was $1.2 billion last year and $1.1 billion this year. Correcting for  Danske Bank, it is more or less exactly in line with last year in spite of the increasing competition in line of  business as well as the pressure on the oil prices.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: This is you can say not what we want to see. We want to see real underlying cost reductions. And we still are  ambitious to achieve that, but we have slightly or our capacity was in the second quarter slightly larger. And we  need it and that of course costs money. The bunker efficiency is essentially was the same as it was in Q2 last year  and again a little less volume, a little lower capacity utilization combined with hopefully better underlying  performance here.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil results, I think they're also pretty good. We had an underlying profit decrease by 31% and this is of  course only driven by the lower oil price. We have an increase in production of 30%, helped by you can say the  distribution formula in Qatar but also by very strong performance in production across the markets, in particular  UK did very, very well in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We are still targeting cost reductions. I said before, 20% by the end of 2016 but the ambition for this year is to get  to a 10% reduction in operating cost and I'm confident that we will get there.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And Culzean, we have had project approval and sanction and agreement from the partners, and while we expect  sanction in the second half of this year and ready to invest, and we think this will also be a goo d project. APM  Terminals being under pressure from the reasons I mentioned before, but still managed to deliver a ROIC above  10%, actually almost 11% in a situation where volumes are under pressure from the oil-dependent markets, as well  as the decline in the Asia to Europe business.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Going then to page 15 on the consolidated numbers, the revenue is down 12% or $1.4 b illion, down to $10.5  billion. All of our business unit except Maersk Drilling is coming down this quarter. And the drivers – the main  drivers of this is, of course, oil price and container rigs. And those are basically making up for almost a total of the  $1.4 billion.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So that leaves us an EBIT number of $1.539 billion. And as I said, it's really the impairment, the oil price that  drives most of the change on the EBIT number. Financial cost comes down approximately $100 million. Most of  the effect in the finance cost is the positive effect of Danske Bank this year as a result of selling the shares to our  shareholders.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On Maersk Oil, we now expect the positive underlying results for 2015 significantly below – at an oil price below  last year, sorry, at the price range of $55 to $60 per barrel. Just taking into consideration that our average oil price  first half were $58. The entitlement production, we do expect now to be around 285,000 barrels a day for the year.  And we expect the exploration expenses to be at the same level we previously have stated at approximately $700  million.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Having said all this, I do think that when we look at the turbulence in the oil price, as well as the container rates  right now, I would advise you to look at the sensitivity in the schedule because we do see uncertainty going  forward on both the oil price development, as well as the pressure on the container rates has shown itself during  the second quarter. And there is, of course, concerns related to that for the remainder of the year.

file: MAERSK.B - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 12August2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
