texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer of Maersk Line
texts.text: In terms of strategy update for the group, overall we see the group performing well relative to the industries that  we're in. Pretty much all of our businesses are top quartile, and in some cases, they are leading the industry in  terms of profitability in 2015. And we achieved this strong position through operational performance, through  utilization, focused efforts on cutting costs, and in production efficiency in the oil business.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer of Maersk Line
texts.text: Bunker cost, of course, is a big part of it. We also saw a significant decline in bunker prices year-on-year, 42%,  and of course, that helped a lot, but we continued also our journey in terms of improving our bunker efficiency,  which came down another 3% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Søren, and a very good morning from me as well. Ladies and gentlemen, so continue on slide eight in  Maersk Oil, and the Maersk Oil delivered a profit of $130 million for the quarter. And we see that the Brent oil  average for the quarter is 46%, down 26% from last year. And you can see that the revenue decline is only 19%  from last year. So, it's compensated by the entitlement production specifically in Qatar.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Very good development during the quarter on costs coming down from last year of – operating costs coming  down from $632 million down to $475 million, that's a decline of 25%. And that is also the reason why we actually  increased our target for cost reduction up to between 25% to 30% for the year and it's really a good traction on  the efficiency in Maersk Oil on the efficiency side.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The invested capital is $4.3 billion and the return on invested capital is 12.1%, which we're very satisfied with as  such given the oil price. The Qatar, Al Shaheen, just to give you the effects, the, sort of, the short-term effects, we  see no reason for impairments because it's all under consideration in the contract and there is no effect as to the  loss of the contract or basically not having a renewed contract from mid-2017. We do not see any effects on  reserves and resources as such.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: When it comes to Terminals, we now expect an underlying result significantly below 2015. We see a continuous  pressure on the oil-related countries, and also some challenges relative to the market development of pricing. And  as a result of that, we have reduced the expectations on Terminals.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On Shipping Services, we reiterate the expectation of the underlying results significantly below 2015. And as  always, the sensitivity guidance is of importance, specifically when you see how the oil price, as well as the freight  rates is going to affect our numbers going forward. So, you need to consider that.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer of Maersk Line
texts.text: There are a few highlights of the result though. And the one that I would like to point to is the fact that Maersk Oil  makes $130 million in the second quarter at 12% return. It means that we have been able to adjust cost in Maersk  Oil to be profitable at the current oil prices. I think that's a great achievement, and also relative to the oil industry,  a quite competitive result.

file: MAERSK.B - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 16August2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: We believe that what we see now is probably the strongest fundamentals for container shipping that we have had  for quite a while and, certainly, since 2010 in the financial crisis. The global economy is doing well. Global GDP is  edging up towards 3% driven by the big oil economies in Europe and U.S., as well as China. And we also see that  contraction have stopped in some of the significant economies that are depending on raw materials and oil prices  such as Russia and Brazil. Those economies are no longer contracting, and we are starting to see some growth.  Adding to that rising corporate profitability across the world means a good investment climate.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: On the energy side, we have again, I think, a solid result from Maersk Oil that continues to improve earnings and  we are able to deliver a breakeven of our price. We have had to take a significant impairment in our tanker  business, and our Vice CEO, Claus Hemmingsen will talk more about that in the Energy section.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer and Chief Financial, Strategy & Transformation Officer-Transport & Logistics, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Moving on to page 10. I think it's important to remind ourselves that while we are going through massive changes  in A.P. Moller – Maersk, looking at structural solutions and Energy, recovering in Transport & Logistics, and  integrating our Transport & Logistics business, we keep on protecting our balance sheets, and we are committed  to remain investment grade.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: So, now, let me take the opportunity to hand over to Claus Hemmingsen, our Vice CEO, who will talk about the  Energy division.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: If we turn to the numbers page, you can see or I can inform you that the operating expenses kept on being  reduced by 3%. This is excluding exploration costs and excluding the costs for purchasing of oil and gas for  resale. I can also highlight here that exploration expenses, as you can see in the numbers, were kept low as we  have also advised they would be and the exploration cost in the quarter was all related to Kenya.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: So, all in all, Maersk Oil, they continue to expect at the end of 2017 and beyond to operate at an OPEC  breakeven oil price of $40 to $45. One highlight from July is that we, as you all know, exited Qatar on the 13th  July, as planned, it's after the quarter. But it's worthwhile mentioning that everything went according to plan.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: On the entitlement productions on the next page, we saw a decrease in the entitlement production by 14% from  second quarter last year. It is all as expected. The main decrease came from Qatar, which was a result of the  combination of oil price and cost recovery. But as you see from the chart, whereas we saw the expected decline  in the UK from second quarter last year mainly from Balloch and Janice field, then we also saw stabilizing  production on the first quarter this year which is why we have included the first quarter columns. Actually, all the  rest of the fields is stabilizing or slightly increasing production. That also means that as you will see later that we  maintain our guidance for the second half 2017 production to still be within the 150,000 to 160,000 barrels range,  excluding Qatar.

file: MAERSK.B - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 17August2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: We grew our business in Ocean – or in total business by 24% during the quarter over last year, very much of  course driven by the acquisition of Hamburg Süd, but also growth across all of the businesses that we are in. We  are pleased about in particular the growth we had in our non-Ocean business, where our Terminal & Towage  business and our Logistics & Services business is starting to show good growth momentum. Our earnings – our  EBITDA was negatively impacted significantly by the increase in oil price, which on a like-for-like basis added  $260 million to our cost during the quarter due to a 28% increase in fuel prices.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Right now, it's difficult for us to predict the timing around Maersk Supply Service, but I have to also underline this  is the smallest company in our oil and energy related portfolio and whether or not we are able to separate out  Maersk Supply in the near-term will not really truly impact our strategic agility and balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: During July, we decided to sell a part of the shares that we own in Total. When we signed the deal with Total, the  shares were valued at $4.950 billion. We have seen a very impressive development in the share price as the oil  prices improved, and we have decided now to sell about $1.2 billion worth of shares, so that we retain a holding in  Total with a current value of around $5 billion. And the proceeds, of course, will be used to strengthen our  financial flexibility.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: We would have liked to see a lot more of the growth in turnover actually also hit the bottom line. We're not seeing  that, and we explain that basically by the increase in the oil price during the last year, which are going to cost us  in this – cost us in the second quarter around $260 million on a like-for-like basis and for the year probably  somewhere north of $1 billion of extra fuel costs that we have to absorb this year.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, Chairman Maersk Container Industry, Board Member of Hamburg Süd Advisory Board, A.P. Møller-
texts.text: Mærsk A/S  Thank you, Søren, and good day, everybody. Diving in specifically on Ocean, we grew our revenue both including  and excluding the contribution of Hamburg Süd. Obviously, as we have also reported, we have a significant  impact by the higher oil price, also more than offsetting the increase in freight rates. But we did also manage to  grow other revenues, especially so-called demurrage and detention, which is storage fees, and also income from  slot sales, mainly the agreement with HMM.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, Chairman Maersk Container Industry, Board Member of Hamburg Süd Advisory Board, A.P. Møller-
texts.text: The capacity curtailments that we have done and the general efficiency improvements that we have done has  helped us deliver an improved efficiency. It's true that bunker price and bunker cost increased mainly due to the  price, but we have now this quarter again dropped back down well below the 900 kilos per FFE mark. And now,  we're also giving a new disclosure on efficiency, which is so-called grams fuel per total TEU deployed times  nautical miles, which is a measure that gives a little bit better indication and insight into the real efficiency of  running the fleet, whereas the other one poses efficiency and utilization asset intensity. We'll be disclosing this  also in the quarters to come.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer, Energy Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: As Søren said, we are still working on finding structural solution from Maersk Supply Service, but the market  remains challenging. On the positive side, the strategy to diversify its business into new markets has progressed,  amongst others, with the announcement of the partnership with Vestas aiming at lowering the logistics and  installation cost within sustainable wind turbine solutions.

file: MAERSK.B - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 9November2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Partner & Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: If you move to slide number six, we have the oil and gas activities. Here we have a 14% lower production share.  And this is a natural decline, plus, of course, the shut down at Gryphon, and then we had one and a half month  closedown at Dumbarton for maintenance purposes, which impacted us negatively. On top of that, the high oil  prices will, due to the nature of the contract in Qatar, also mean that our share would go down for that reason  alone. Of course, the businesses – or the business benefited from a 48% higher oil price and, with $113 per barrel,  this was – remained in very healthy levels, in spite of the much talked about economic slowdown around the  world.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Partner & Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Drilling continues to do well now in the third quarter, a profit of $138 million. And that means that we  continue heading for a very good result on a yearly basis. Maersk FPSO and LNG is also up, driven by good  performance of the Peregrino unit and we expect this development to continue. Of course, when LNG is sold, we  will not have a positive impact from this business, that at the moment is sailing at very good rates.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going then to the outlook for 2011 on page 13, we now expect the profit for 2011 to be in the range of $3.1 billion  to $3.5 billion including divestment gains. In the container activities, we now expect a negative result for the full- year as a consequence of lower rates on especially the Asia-Europe trade. The oil and gas activities expect a profit  well as other businesses is expected to be above the 2010 level excluding divestment gains. For retail, the result  excluding divestment gains is now expected to be below 2010.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Cash flow from operating activities is expected to develop in line with the results, while cash flow used for capital  expenditure is expected to be significantly higher than in 2010. And as previously, the outlook for 2011 is subject  to uncertainty, specifically on the development of the global economy, oil price and global trade condition.

file: MAERSK.B - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 9November2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We keep focus on expanding our activities in the Terminals business, as well. We have, during the quarter, signed  an agreement to take over coal controlling shareholding in Global Ports in Russia, the largest port operator – or  terminal operator in that market. In addition to that, we are on a – in growth load in Latin America. We took over  the operations of Callao, Lima in Peru last year, expanding and modernizing that facility. And we expect to grow  into operation in centers in the early part of 2013. So very good progress here as well.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And in terms of the oil, we realized that the production figure is slightly less than we had – we believed and or  expected. The main reason for that is actually that we are delayed in the start-up of the crude on Gryphon, the  FPSO in the UK that arrived late to station and came into bad weather and then we had some issues. We're getting  right contractors at the right time. So we're struggling a little bit with that, and we hope the start-up would be  efficient when it come on-stream, probably early next year.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We have announced a dry rate increase on November 1. This is part of our efforts to support the ongoing rate  stability. And in order to prepare for the future, we've also announced significant rate increases in the reefer area  from January 1, which we expect to be giving positive results. And they are reflecting the fact that the reefer  business, that everybody thinks should be very profitable and it is, of course, very capital intensive and also quite  costly to handle energy consumption-wise and so on, and this has not been reflected in rates. And so we just need  to raise them, and what we're seeing at the moment in the market is that our competition sees the same need, to  get this business back on track.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We are seeing a step-down in the contribution in Denmark or the volumes that we are getting in from Denmark.  This is partly because of decline in the production. But the main effect here is actually that we have the Danish  North Sea Fund in to take 20% ownership. It doesn't reflect the profitability, but it does reflect the amounts of oil  that come to our – into our hands.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Exploration costs were slightly lower than we had expected. It's not a conscious decision from our side, but the rig  market is very tight. And that means that a number of wells, both our owned/operated but also our partners'  operated wells are being delayed. So there's a savings so to speak, but in reality a delay here and – but we're still  very active in the drilling area.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: If we then just compare some of the clean numbers out there, the profit for the period is $933 million. If we take  the clean number effect of this quarter, the number is $979 million. The earnings per share in US dollars is $197  million and the earnings per share for the third quarter in Danish kroners is DKK1,178.  Just to spend just a slight more time on this slide here, on the nine-month of 2012 numbers. So far this year, we're  delivering profit for the period of $3.073 billion. That, of course, includes some of the one-off effects, specifically  the Algerian tax case. But if you take the one-off effects out of that number, the clean number of the first nine  months is $1.929 billion. The cash flow for the first nine months is $5.6 billion and the CapEx net of sales  proceeds is then $3.6 billion, so a good cash flow.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil is expecting a result of 2012 above the result for 2011, and that is including the impact of the  settlement from the Algerian tax dispute, and that was an income of $900 million. The expected result is based on  the share of production of 258,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, that is down from previously 265,000 barrels  of oil equivalent per day, and we're basing that on an average oil price of $110 a barrel for the remainder of the  year. The exploration costs, we are also taking down from around $1 billion to now around $900 million due to  some postponements that is postponed into 2013.

file: MAERSK.B - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 13November2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: But going to page 3, the profit in the quarter was good. We reached a ROIC after $1.2 billion result, a ROIC of  9.5%. And that takes us through the first nine-month result of almost $3 billion and a ROIC of 8.3%, so rather  positive. As we alluded to at the Capital Markets Day, Maersk line is continuing its effort to reduce costs. And we  did actually continue showing good results in this area. I'll come back to it later but lower fuel prices helped but it  continues to be lower fuel consumption that actually carries the main – or takes the main honor of that or  whatever reported.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We ordered an additional large jack-up for the Norwegian sector backed by a long-term contract by BP. So we now  have eight rigs under construction. So we continue our effort to invest and build Maersk Drilling. And that means  that both APM Terminals and Maersk Drilling are on track to achieve their $1 billion NOPAT targets in 2018 and  2016, respectively.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Bunker cost is a big driver. It's down 17% and it's more or less 50 -50 between the lower consumption and lower  bunker price. But also, network efficiency and utilization has been improved, reflecting a little bit what we've said  from the beginning that the new vessels we'll take in will be compensated by taking out other capacity. So we keep  a very well-utilized network.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Nice free cash flow for Maersk Line, in spite of the investments, of $7 7 0 million. This is in line with our strategy  and we say we should grow with own cash flow. We have nothing new to report on the P3 lines. Of course, we read  the press and follow the debate there. We continue to be of the opinion that this does not affect the markets in any  negative way as it's a capacity-sharing agreement, which allows us to reduce cost and give our customers a better  network as well as reducing the global CO2 footprint. So, we think this is a real win-win situation for us and the  shipping markets.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The total costs were reduced by $237  million, of which was caused by lower bunker, lower bunker cost, $ 116  million lower bunker consumption and $154 million the lower bunker price which of course benefits the whole  industry.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And the bunker consumption reduction comes from increased efficiency but it also comes from us closing a couple  of services down and becoming more effective there, upgrading the size of vessels that we operate on the  remaining routes. And we saw an increase in terminal expenses by 6% but that is lower than the volume increase  also that was very satisfactory.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: In terms of longer-term development, we finally, as I said before, handling the plans for Chissonga. They have  been agreed with Sonangol and now in the Ministry of Energy , and we hope this will be resolved quickly so we can  get into the ordering phase.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The Cubal successful discovery well in Angola and new successful appraisal well at Johan Sverdrup. We drilled  Itaipu and other appraisal well also finding oil, which is been accessed at the moment. And then we had three  other wells in Brazil, Kurdistan and Norway, which did not encounter commercial hydrocarbons.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: That's a little bit untypical there because from the bottom, the Maersk Oil is still very low but that is because we  are only entering now on the phase where we'll have larger capital investments and also because we do expense  our exploration costs as a general rule.

file: MAERSK.B - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 11November2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If we start on page two, there isn't much left of the year. So, o f course, the uncertainties slowly going down, but  still I would like you – to remind you that what we say about the future is based on our expectations and, of  course, these things will – may change as we've just experienced in the last quarter with the drop in the oil price.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But if you take this figure and you take into account that we have had some currency effects to exclude th e  financial cost, then the underlying effects on the five – or the underlying profit on the five businesses actually  improved approximately 10% on average, which is – which was driven by general progress. You can see that in the  bottom part of the graph, with progress everywhere – or not everywhere, but in the three largest business units,  and the planned decline in mass drilling, and basically a stable situation in APM Shipping Services. The main  driver of the progress was Maersk Line, up by $120 million c ompared to last year, but also, I would like to  underline that Maersk Oil, in spite of the oil price drop, managed to improve its result on the back of a 4%  increase in production and savings on the exploration cost.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And the most important part here is the terminal business or the terminal rates that have gone up, not rates but  general cost have grown up in line with volume. Also, Inland Services have increased, which is quite natural, with  increased volumes. Vessel costs have increased, but actually less than you wo uld expect given the increased  volumes. And then we have had a reduction in bunker consumption. And here, we don't actually have yet any  effect of bunker price of any significance. It's a 0.8% decrease in the bunker price. The main part of the saving  comes from reduced bunker consumption per FFE.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, more of the same and I'm sure it doesn't give you a lot of surprises. But I would like to point out that actually  the average bunker consumption per FFE has been reduced, again, with 6% compared to last year, which is quite  an achievement in our opinion.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Going to Maersk Oil, I've said most of it already under the opening, but a very nice increase in profit by 18% to  $222 million. But 4% higher production and lower exploration cost as the main reasons for that.  The average oil  price declined in the quarter, but on an annual level, it still remains more or less in line, if I'm not mistaken, with  the last year.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The reduction of the exploration cost is – amounted to $46 million. This is partly by – or it is by design. We  continue to evaluate our exploration efforts very carefully. But it is also reflecting, of course, a concern that with  the present oil prices and present prices of oil assets, that a high level of exploration as we have had in Maersk Oil  in the past years may not be the best way to build our reserve base. We've had a number of exploration wells  throughout the – through the quarter. Three of them have been without commercial discoveries in Kurdistan, in  Denmark and in the UK.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We had a well, Marconi, drilled in second quarter and also the Buckskin 3 appraisal well has been finalized. And  they both have positive oil indications and we are evaluating the commerciality. And on the good side, also,  Golden Eagle produced its first oil in October which was ahead of plan, which I believe in this industry is not  something you see every day.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil still expects an underlying result in line with 2013 of $1 billion. If we then include the impairments of  $1.7 billion in Brazil that we did in second quarter, we expect the full-year loss to remain around a loss of $700  million. That is based on an average oil price for the year of $102 per barrel. On the entitlement production, we  still expect the entitlement production to be above 240,000 barrels a day.

file: MAERSK.B - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 6November2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, I'll just repeat a little bit what I said on October 23 when we had the downgrade of results. We expect an  underlying result for 2015 of approximately $3.4 billion based on an underlying result in Maersk Line of around  $1.6 billion. And that is a result that we're not 100% happy with, but it comes after a third quarter where we've  seen oil prices being down 50% and freight rates down 20% compared to the same period last year. And that, of  course, put our business under quite a bit of pressure.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So that's what I wanted to open with, and I suggest we go into page 3, as you may have read page 2. That, of  course, all what we say, even now, is subject to uncertainty. We're giving you sensitivities but the market now is, at  the moment, is very, very volatile, even the oil price is volatile, and it's very hard for us to give you the exact  number what we predict, of course.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil also specified its action to meet the 20% reduction target we had at the end of 2016. And it was, again,  mainly clarification but also, you can say, publishing the plans for the still-to-be-done restructuring, and means  reducing the number of employees by 1,250 in 2015. And then the plans for meeting the 20% cost reduction  objective by the end of 2016.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: APM Terminals had already launched its Adapt to Market. It's the second time in a few years that we do that, and  they've taken out quite a bit of cost during the year. Unfortunately, [audio gap] (7:30-7:33) APM Terminals, I'll  come back to that, but we are quite exposed to oil exporting markets and therefore, also, quite exposed to some  negative developments in general markets.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Financial highlights are, of course, and should be, in line with what we said two weeks ago. We're delivering a  headline profit of $778 million and an underlying profit of $662 million, both approximately 50% of what it was  last year. And I can say with some confidence that this is really only due to the lower oil price and freight rates.  We've taken a lot of initiatives to deliver as much as we can. A ROIC of 7.6%; given the circumstances, probably  not a bad figure.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then what we didn't give you last – or two weeks ago were the underlying profit by activity. But you'll see that  there's a major decline, and that is the impact in the quarter of Maersk Line and Maersk Oil. Maersk Line for the  reasons that I said before, and Maersk Oil exclusively because of the oil price. We're having very good production  figures, and everything actually runs very well in Maersk Oil.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We said at the beginning of the year that we had a breakeven in the oil business between $55 and $60. And now  we are at an average price of $50, making us more profit. The main change in that is cost reductions plus reduced  exploration cost and increased oil production. So there, we have, I mean, improved our competitive position there  as well.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk APM Terminals a little bit down due to the exposure to the oil exporting markets. Maersk Drilling up due  to its good contract coverage. And APM Shipping Services, in line with last year, which is basically high, and I'll  come back to that in a minute, but basically improved result in Maersk Tankers and deteriorating results in  Supply Service, Damco and Svitzer dropped, but I'll give you the figures on that in a minute.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's go to page 5. Here you have the details of Maersk Line results. And, I mean, basically the headline figures are  down and the 19% decrease in rates means [audio gap] (11:01-11:05) close to $1.2 billion in reduced turnover, so  that's the explanation for the drop in turnover. And, of course, that drop in turnover is not, we're not able to  compensate fully. Oil price is helping us somewhat on the bunker price with, if I'm not mistaken, $222 per FFE  but essentially, of course, brought us down to the bottom line.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So in, if you then expect or take that out, then, of course, we did have a reduction in cost also from other factors,  but that is mainly driven by currency and other things. So, if we exclude that bunker price and FX then we actually  had an increase in the unit cost due to lower fleet utilization. And you can see that in the bunker, that you can  basically that the bunker consumption effectiveness is increasing ,or is decreasing. So we use now 2.8% more  bunker per [audio gap] (13:48-13:51) fee, which is, of course, negative but driven by the lower fleet utilization.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil results on page 7. Basically, simple figures. An 86% decrease in underlying profit. I have given you a  background for that. It's, of course, the low oil price. But entitlement production was up by 26%. Basically, of  course, helped by Qatar, where we have an automatic mechanism, but we also had good production performance  across the board, and some new fields giving us production, in particular, in the UK. So, operationally, actually, it  was a good quarter.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We've cut back on exploration cost, a drop by 61%. This is, of course, in the quarter. But also on our yearly  expectation, we will now come out with lower exploration cost than we had expected at the beginning of the year.  And we're expecting a decision on the exploration license or what will happen with the field development of Itaipu  and Wahoo by the end of 2015, we're not operators and of course, involved in the process. But needless to say,  with the pressure in oil prices, it's not easy to develop these fields.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Revenue improvement and cost savings gave us approximately $50 million. But, of course, it underlines the  pressure we are under given that we still have it in spite of that, have a decline in the results due to the mix and the  pressure in the oil dependent markets.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: When the rig contracts run out and they will, then of course we're faced with the same market as our competitors.  And we'll have to work very hard to sustain profitability in this sector unless the oil markets improve.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil, we continue to expect results significantly below 2014, but we have lowered our expectation for the oil  price for the remainder of the year. On the entitlement production, it's now [audio gap] (28:18) we expect around  295,000 barrels a day, and we have reduced our expectation of expenditure on exploration cost to be around $500  million for 2015.

file: MAERSK.B - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 2November2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: For the third quarter of 2016, the group delivered a profit of $438 million. It was down 44% from $778 million last  year, pretty much driven by lower container freight rates. We delivered a return on the invested capital of just  under 5%. We see this as not a very satisfactory result given that our target is to deliver a double-digit return on  invested capital. But we also note that this result, a 5% return, is delivered at a time with an oil price less than $50  and all-time low freight rates.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Delivering an underlying profit of $146 million at an average oil price of Brent of $46. That shows that we basically  are working on our cost program and are efficient on that. And that is also why we say that we see now that we  have a breakeven level below the $40 a barrel.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Producing or having entitlement production of 295,000 barrels a day. And you can see the allocation of those  295,000 if you go to the bottom of the page and look at the different countries. Be aware, though, that at least in  the North Sea, it's the third quarter, and as a result of that, there are some maintenance project that has been  going on during the quarter that affects the production levels. All in all, very good progress on the OpEx  efficiencies and a reduction of 21% compared to last year. And our ambition has – we raised our ambition of the  cost reduction to be between 25% and 30% by the end of 2016 when we compare the baseline to 2014.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Looking at the projects, Johan Sverdrup, Statoil have announced a new breakeven level of $25 a barrel in phase  1 in the project, which we, of course, are very satisfied with and are giving our contribution where we can. In  Culzean, the rig Highlander is in place and have spotted and basically have started drilling. So, good progress in  Culzean. And we also see a smaller project called Flyndre being on track and seeing first oil in the beginning of  2017.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: In addition to that, we have decided to exit Buckskin in the Gulf of Mexico, and we're also continuing on our  predevelopment in Kenya. So, overall, very good progress. We are also continuing on our efforts to address the  business and the organization both through the low oil price environment and, of course, the exit of Qatar that's  coming out in the midst of 2017. But third quarter with a return of 13.5% is a good quarter for Maersk Oil.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Having said that, for the oil-related or dominated countries we're in, we're seeing a bit of a mixed picture. Nigeria  showing small positive improvements, Russia saw some stabilization, while Angola continues to be severely  impacted by the lower oil price. All in all, focusing on cost efficiency around the world in the different terminals and  having been the efficiency of that as a result, we've been approximately reducing the staff with about 1,000 by the  end of Q3.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Going then to the consolidated aggregated numbers are delivering revenue of $9.2 billion, decline of 9.2% last  year. But the major driver on that is the rates in Maersk Line. The second biggest is the oil price, but as a result of  oil price not having come down that much. From the third quarter 2015, it really is the Maersk Line driver.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: So, overall, I must categorize this as – even though we don't like the returns of 5%, considering the oil price,  considering the challenging oil service market and the loss of Maersk Line this quarter, I must say that I have to  define 4.9% return as a very acceptable number.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil still expect a positive underlying result. Breakeven is – we have now changed to below $40 a barrel  from previously $40 to $45. And we still expect our entitlement production between 320,000 to 330,000 barrels a  day.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: For Shipping Services, we reiterate the expectation of an underlying result significantly below 2015 basically as a  result of low rates in supply and weaker rates in Maersk Tanker. As always, there are a few factors that  dominates the sensitivity in these guidelines and that is, of course, the container freight rate and the oil price. So, I  urge you to look at the sensitivities for the rest of 2016 on the bottom right.

file: MAERSK.B - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 7November2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Maersk Line Ltd.
texts.text: In addition to the comments on capacity, let me also say that the development on our fuel efficiency developed  adversely, again, mainly attributable to the fact that we have sold slots to HMM and Hamburg Süd, where we  account for the kilos but we don't account for the FFEs. But, of course, we get a slot charter income.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer and Chief Financial, Strategy & Transformation Officer-Transport & Logistics, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Let me stop here and hand over to Claus for the Energy businesses.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Supply Service has divested 12 vessels now over the past year for recycling, and they have started to  take delivery of new buildings, which increases the standards and capabilities of the anchor handling and subsea  construction fleet in Maersk Supply Service. Maersk Supply Service has successfully added contracts and  revenue actually in third quarter, thereby increasing the backlog, albeit still at relatively low rates.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: In terms of discontinued operations, as already mentioned, we have previously stated that we aim to have  structured solutions in place for all oil and oil-related businesses within 2018. As we believe, we will be able to  determine a viable solution for Maersk Drilling within the timeframe, we decided to reclassify Maersk Drilling as a  discontinued operation. And in this connection, we took an impairment of the assets of $1.75 billion.

file: MAERSK.B - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 14November2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: As you can see, we only invested – had CapEx of $400 million during the quarter and that's the journey that  brings down the committed CapEx that is playing out. You see a reduction in guidance for CapEx. And we now  only have $1.1 billion of committed CapEx for the two next year, 2019 and 2020. We have added $80 million of  CapEx because of scrubbers, so that is a relatively non-event in this respect.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer & Member - Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: On fuel cost, we are very pleased with the progression, not on price, but on efficiency where we managed to  reduce it also in the coming quarter. We're satisfied with that performance and it's an important metric for us as  we also look into a 2019 and 2020 with an average the fuel price will increase.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer & Member - Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: If we look at capacity, then one of the points that we mentioned continuously that we would work on was to  optimize the network and do something about capacity. We have now fully integrated Hamburg Süd's fleets into  the Ocean network. We have fully integrated the equipment fleet, and in this quarter managed to reduce our  deployed capacity by 2.7%.

texts.speaker: Vincent Clerc
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Member - Executive Board & Chief Commercial Officer, Maersk Line, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: However, the bunker cost, if we look at it year-on-year, we're 47% higher than they were in the Q3 of 2017. That  represents $127 per FFE. And if we look at it year-on-year, we've been managed to increase our freight rate by  $100 per FFE. So good progress, but we are not yet fully compensated for the increase that we have had in fuel  cost, and that remains a key focus area going forward.

texts.speaker: Vincent Clerc
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Member - Executive Board & Chief Commercial Officer, Maersk Line, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: This is a segment as I mentioned is of high strategic importance to us and where we are also reorganizing right  now to accelerate the growth. But we see also that margins as a result of the efforts that we have put in place are  improving. They are partially offset by higher IT spend as we get a larger pipeline online as part of our growth or  the growth that we would see materialize in the coming quarter for start-up supply chain management contract,  but also as I mentioned a lot of the revenue growth on in-land is due to fuel prices which we have actually passed  onto our customers but which is not generating improvement in the average margin.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 4March2010 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 position. We did continue during the year, in spite of the difficult economic environment, we did  continue during the year to put emphasis on reducing emissions, first and foremost through more  effective use of energy, and of course this is for us mainly bunker oil.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The average bunker price was down and that, of course, helped a little bit, but you can say in terms  of competitiveness, what is most important for us was that the bunker consumption was down by  12%. We saved in the Container business, excluding bunker prices, around USD1.6 billion, which  needless to say is a significant amount.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: What happened was that slow steaming, which was introduced widely last year, took out some  capacity, approximately 5%. This is not something we expect to return to the market because the  container lines are still very – or loss-making, most of them. And the rates we’re seeing now can  not really sustain an increased cost level and slow steaming actually saves significant amounts of  bunker oil. So we don’t expect that to change in the near future.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 3 On top of that we had laid up, as an industry, approximately 12% of the fleet, so you can say that  takes out approximately 17% of the capacity we saw at the beginning of the year. So an increase in  the oil capacity during the year, but probably less than we had expected when we went into it.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Of course the oil industry as such, we still see good oil prices, reasonable oil prices, but for the  tanker industry this has limited effect because good oil prices are maintained because of good  discipline within OPEC, and that means restrictions on output. The tanker markets will, for sure,  improve somewhat when the good oil prices are maintained because of demand. And we hope this  will happen in the future.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And with that going – being said, I think we can go through the next slide, which is the Oil and Gas  Activities. And here we did see, as I said at the beginning, significant reduction in revenue and also  a significant reduction in the segment result, even if we still stayed comfortably profitable within this  business. And the only – or the only reason for the decline in result and turnover was really the oil  price because we did produce slightly more in terms of oil, exactly one million barrels more than we  did the year before. So it was really exclusively an oil price issue for the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And even if we got less than we had hoped for and bid for in the Gulf of Mexico, we did get one  share of an oil field, the oil field Jack, out of the portfolio of fields that we bid for out of the Devon  portfolio. So things are – a number of things are going on in the Oil and Gas Activities and we will  for the year keep high exploration activity in Maersk Oil and Gas.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Trond Ø. Westlie, Group Chief Financial Officer  Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I’ll now take you through the consolidated financial  information and some outlook at the end before handing over to Nils again. As we can see on Slide  #12, we ended up with a revenue of USD48.5 billion for 2009. The decline is driven by, as Nils has  repeatedly stated, the freight rates in Container business and volumes, the lower tank rates, as well  as the oil price driving the revenue.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Financial items at short of 1 billion, an improvement of almost 0.5 billion, due to not having write- down of market values of investments, and also currency losses that was in 2008. So ended up at  profit before tax on 2.9. Tax is high due to the hydrocarbon taxes from 3.8, leaving us at the loss for  the year of just above USD1 billion.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Tanker markets have benefited from the cold winter and declining oil stocks in early 2010.  However, rates remain unsatisfactory and the additional new tonnage combined with weak demand  for crude oil and refined products is expected to cause challenging markets conditions in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In spite of the rising oil prices and a positive outlook for the oil industry, Offshore markets are  expected to be negatively affected by excess capacity putting pressure on rates in 2010. Relatively  good contract coverage ensures fairly high employment for Maersk Drilling, Maersk FPSOs and  Maersk Supply Service also in 2010. However, several rates and ships are not under contract at  the beginning of 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For the Oil and Gas segment, activities are expected to maintain a high activity level with increased  investments in the exploration in 2010. The Group’s entitlement of production for the next 4  quarters is expected to be lower than in 2009, but on average slightly above the entitlement of  production in the fourth quarter 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have to emphasize, though, that the outlook for 2010 is subject to considerable uncertainty, not  least due to developments in the global economy. But specific uncertainties relate to the container  freight rates, transported volumes, the U.S. dollar exchange rate and the oil prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We had a loss and which was caused by low rates in the Container business and the Tanker  business. And needless to say we had falling oil prices, but that was not really the issue. The issue  was very low rates in the Container and Tanker business. But we still managed to generate 4.7  billion in operating cash flow due to our ability to cut USD2 billion in cost. And we do feel that this  resulted in an acceptable loss of USD1 billion.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We will focus on also on investments in the Oil and Gas Activities, as we’ve said before, and  continue to be interested in investing more money into APM Terminals. That, for 2009, really  proved that it was a solid business. In addition to that, we will look out for distressed assets. We are  not in the market really for acquisitions. At least that’s not high on our wish list, but in the case that  distressed ships or rigs or other single assets come on the market, we’ll be interested in looking at  that.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 23February2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So if we go to Page 3 or Slide #3. We present in the chart here a net result of U.S. $5 billion, which  gives us a return on invested capital of 12.2% which is above our ROIC. As I just alluded to before,  the improved profits compared to 2009 are obviously a result of better volumes, and in particular,  better rates and better oil prices, but also because we have managed to make our business much  more competitive across the group.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We’re taking some steps to expand the oil portfolio during the year. We ended the year investing in  three licenses in Brazil, and we see that as a big job also going forward to build a very strong oil  business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: But starting with the container activities on Slide #4, an improvement of U.S. $4.7 billion coming  through improving competitiveness first and foremost. Unit cost reduced compared to 2009 with  4%, excluding bunker cost, and a bunker consumption that is reduced with 10% per FFE  transported through slow steaming, a lot of better operational measures such as how we balance  the ship, how we load them, how we maneuver in relation to wind and waves and so on, so really  good work throughout the organization.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And when we mention that specific class that’s because that’s what our competitors gets delivered  this year and the coming years. And we will have a 50% lower CO2 emission per TEU than the  average of the current fleet trading Asia, Europe. So major step forward both of course in  competitiveness, but also in CO2 emissions, which irrespective of what global legislative system  there will be regarding fuel consumption and CO2 emissions, should place us very well for the  future.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: If we take the next slide, oil and gas activities. Really, the increase is coming because of an  increase of 29% in the average price of oil. We had, as we predicted, a share production that went  down with 12% due to falling share per our production sharing agreement with Qatar, and partly  compensated with increased production in the U.K.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: If we go to Slide #7 drilling a little bit deeper into the oil and gas activities, talking about the future.  We have concrete plans for, that means approved and running investment projects, for two new  areas. One is in the new area El Merk in Algeria where we expect first oil or actually first gas in  2012, and the U.S. Gulf of Mexico at the Jack field where we expect first oil in 2014.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Then we’re doing work on a number of other finds, which is Culzean, the gas find in the U.K.;  Cawdor/Flyndre in the U.K.; the Buckskin find where we are 20% shareowner with Chevron as  operator; and Norway, two finds; and in Brazil, the Carambola find, where we are operating and  which we just released information earlier this year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The LNG business also took impairments. So when you take the FPSO and LNG together and  exclude the impairments, actually there’s a slight positive result, but clearly nothing we can be  satisfied with at all.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And you can see that that is, of course, contributing to the elements of competitiveness, as Nils  mentioned, but also the oil price, leading us at an EBIT in fourth quarter of $2.2 billion. That is after  an impairment in the fourth quarter of $332 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Going then to the full year numbers of 2010, we have a revenue of $56 billion, an increase of $7.5  billion from 2009, and you also see that the EBITDA ends up at $15.9 billion. That is an increase of  $6.7 billion, so we have an increase in the revenue of $7.5 billion, and an increase in the EBITDA of  $6.7 billion. The major increase to the EBITDA is, of course, the revenue growth and the margin  improvement in Maersk Line. It is the oil price, but it is of course, also the cost savings and the  effectiveness coming in to the results.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Going then to Slide number 13, you see the development in net interest bearing debt, starting the  year, of $18.1 billion and making $15 billion, almost $16 billion in EBITDA. That, of course, have to  be taken into account of the taxes paid of $4.6 billion. Of the $4.6 billion, oil and gas tax is  $4.10650 billion. That it is very sort of dependent on, of course, the oil price and the development.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Maersk Oil expects a higher level of exploration activities than in 2010. The group’s share of the oil  and gas production is expected to decline to around 125 million barrels. Maersk Oil results for 2011  is expected to be lower than in 2010, based on an average oil priced around $90 a barrel.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Then we’re looking at a transformation of Maersk Oil. You have seen that we have invested, as  we’ve said we would, in getting more oil reserves and resources into the company. But on top of  that it’s, of course, very important that we also make sure that the company is top notch in all  operational aspects relevant to us. That means operation of mature fields and chalk and the areas  where we are already today leaders, and placing ourselves to become even stronger in the future.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 27February2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Line has broadened its service palette as well as regained market share. The Daily Maersk is delivering  Maersk Drilling have delivered high uptime and also committed for new long-term growth. And we have signed to  sell the Maersk LNG and the quoting is scheduled for this week. So all in all, we have delivered on – progress on  our strategy and making an acceptable result for 2011, considering that the shipping market is difficult.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going then to the next page, page six, on Maersk Line; as mentioned, Maersk Line is having its long-term strategy  on reliability, ease of doing business, environmental impact and competitiveness. We're still focusing on that even  though we are making changes to our pricing strategy as well as taking out capacity in the market. The CMA  agreement that was announced last week is going to effectively reduce our capacity on Asia-Europe. We're going to  maintain our deployed tonnage but the average speed reduces, as well as we're doing some extra port calls.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going to page seven on Maersk Oil; production declined, as anticipated, during the year with 12% year-over-year  due to Qatar and production – lower production in Denmark. The U.K. went down as a result of the collision  incident that happened in February. And all of this is slightly offset with the increase of production coming out our  acquisition in Brazil on the SK Energy, and that is the Polvo Field. The revenue is higher, going up with $1.4  billion from 2010 for the full year due to higher oil price. We have increased the exploration activity and here we  see effects of that. We have – Chissonga was declared commercial. We are doing – working on the development  Avaldsnes, part of the Johan Sverdrup field in the Norwegian sector. We have development plans approved on the  Golden Eagle and we have hydrocarbon finds that are encouraging. So all in all, there has been good development  in our prospect portfolio as well as good progress in all the new development projects. And as a result of having  the arbitration with the – our Algerian arbitration, that is also – have a possibility of coming up in the near future.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going to the outlook for the core growth business unit, Maersk Oil expects a result significantly below the result  for 2011 based on expected 20% decline in the share of oil and gas production to a level of around 265,000 barrels  oil equivalents per day at an average price of $105. The production decline is predominantly caused by share of  production in Qatar and the natural maturation of the North Sea fields. The transfer of 20% ownership of DUC to  the Danish North Sea Fund by mid-2012 will reduce the group's production share in Denmark, but will have no  impact on the net earnings. Exploration costs are expected to be above $1 billion.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Drilling has almost full contract coverage at attractive rates in 2012 and expects the result in line with  2011. Maersk Supply Service expects the result at the same level as in 2011, with one-third of the available vessel  2011, excluding divestments in gains and impairments. And of course, the rest of this is substantial. It is very  much dependent on price expectations in the container market as well as the world oil price, which are the big  drivers, as well as currency effects on this. You have some sensitivity effects on the right side on page 15.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Overall, we would say that the 2012 will be a challenging year on different circumstances. For the Shipping side,  we are in the supply-demand challenge as well as – even though we are taking actions it is uncertain weather that  supply – that those effects will be sufficient to actually create that balance. On the oil and gas side, we're in the  midst of the declining production towards 2014 where it changes. But we're also in the midst of high investment  phase in both prospects and development plan. We are en route towards our 400,000 barrels per day, but we will  have challenging years when it comes to P&L effects, as we are seeing for 2012.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 22February2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We continued our efforts to build the four core businesses, with above trend investment in exploration in the oil  business. We continued progress in the APM Terminals, the results on the back of the last year's investment in  growth market, and we continue, also, going into 2013, or investment in our growth sectors, infrastructure and  growth markets as well as Oil Services and Oil Exploration in order to get progress on our strategy plan.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: We continue to work on the mile – on the Maersk Oil development, it is our objective to get to 400,000 barrels of  where we will invest $1.5 billion in the Al Shaheen field in Qatar. And APM terminals continued its recent years of  successes, expanding both margins and the portfolio, making this another good year for APM terminals.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And we did see progress in particular in the four main businesses, that all reported improved profits with the  exception of Maersk Drilling, where we had some prolonged yard stays. We have to remember that we are  changing mass drilling from being a low water or not deep water jackup operator into an operator in ultra-deep  waters.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The share production declined 23% year-on-year and, more or less, the same in Q4 – on Q4. This is mainly driven  by less share of production in Qatar and the transfer of 20% ownership share in the Danish North Sea to the  Danish North Sea foundation. There was also a bit of natural production decline in Denmark, but the main effect  came from the ownership transfer. That has no impact on the bottom line by, the way.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And the oil price was stable, slightly better than what we expected at the beginning of the year, $112 per barrel as  an average. And we did bring up the exploration cost with 10% and we expect to keep this level more or less going  into 2013, as we continue our efforts to build towards the 400,000 barrels of oil production per day in 2020.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: This is unfortunate, but on the other hand, we are, as I said before, moving Maersk Drilling from being a shallow  water jackup rig operator to becoming a leader in quality in the deepwater segments as well. And of course, we  would need to make sure that every step on the way is taken with absolute care to safety and, also, reliable  operations for our customers once we go on contract.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going then to the full-year numbers of 2012. We have a revenue of $59.036 billion. That is $1.2 billion down from  2011. The development of that revenue comes from growth in Maersk Line, Damco and also in APMT, and a  negative decline as a result of the declining oil production from Maersk Oil.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The earnings before interest, tax and depreciation is then $12.581 billion, down $2 billion or $2.1 billion from last  year, basically driven by the same effects, the growth in the earnings – or the results of Maersk Line and the  decline in the oil production that is coming into the EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil expects its share of production to be in the range of 240,000 to 250,000 barrels of oil equivalence per  day, lower in the first half than the second half in 2013 at an average oil price of $105 per barrel. The lower  production share is predominantly caused by a natural decline and reduced ownership share in Denmark. And it's  counted by the start-up in El Merk in Algeria and the Gryphon field in UK, on the North Sea UK sector.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Exploration costs are expected to be above $1 billion. APM Terminals expect a result above 2012 and to grow  ahead of the market, supported by the volumes from new terminals whilst improving productivity in existing  facilities.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: And we will continue our strategy of investing those money primarily in what we see as growth areas. And that is,  for us, the infrastructure investments in developing markets. It is the oil services, in particular, offshore.  Deepwater will take up quite a bit of investments. And then, the oil business itself, in order to prepare for the, you  can say, significantly expanded production that we expect in 2020.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 27February2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Maersk Oil is down by – from $1.4 billion to $1 billion on the back of reduced oil production. The positive element  in this business is, of course, that we managed to stabilize the production in Q3 and we actually came out of Q4  with an upward trend, so that the starting position for 2014 is around 240,000 to 250,000 barrels of oil per day.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The cost base reduction is the main driver or the – is a driver of the improved results. Rates have dropped by 7 %,  but the hard work on the cost reductions, some benefit from bunker price improvements, but mainly bunker  savings and other cost savings is what makes this result.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going a little bit more into details on Maersk Line's cost reductions on page five, you'll see coming back to the  network optimization and utilization. We have reduced our weekly carrying capacity significant compared to  2008. And on bullet – on the bullet points below, in bullet one, you'll see a number of examples of this. I won't go  into details, but this is all known stuff. But it's just all to summarize what has been going on.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: The cost improvement of $1.9 billion is mainly driven by bunker savings, $1.4 billion, of which half is price and  half is consumption reductions. And then, we've taken – and you'll see that to the left, we've taken $400 million  out of inland transportation cost. And of course, if you say bunker prices and reduced inland transportation cost  will, of course, be part of the reason why the rates have declined during the year, in all fairness. And then a small  increase in terminal expenses by 2%. But that still means that the unit cost for terminal expenses is going down  because it's a little less than the increase in volumes.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: But as you also have registered during 2014, we are continuing that effort with the contracts and the sale on the –  contracts on VLCCs as well as the Dansk Supermarked. In addition to that, we also see that the reallocation or the  refocusing of our invested capital towards the oil terminal and drilling is continuing.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Even though oil has not progressed that much in 2013, we see that both drilling and terminals have grown. And as  you have heard Nils saying, of the six rigs being delivered in 2014, we also see that drilling is going to increase  slightly more in 2014.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Not going to mention too much on the full year results, $47 million – $47,400 million in revenue, $2 billion down  from last year mostly driven by Maersk Line and Maersk Oil; Oil as a result of oil price as well as entitlement  production; Maersk Line as a result of rates going down more than the volumes coming up.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group CFO & Member-Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Going to Maersk Oil, we expect a result below 2013 based on an oil price of $104. We also expect the entitlement  production to be above 240,000 barrels of oil equivalents per day. The seasonality in the pr oduction will be there.  We see that the planned shutdowns will result in a lower production in second and third quarter as a result of  being the maintenance periods where we are producing.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: Of course, we also hope and strive to see first oil from the Golden Eagle UK and Jack in the U.S. by the end of  2014. These will not have a significant impact. So our forecast for at least 240,000 barrels of oil per day do not  depend on when these fields come into production. There's no significant production effective included in 2014.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Partner, A.P. Møller-Maersk A/S
texts.text: APM Terminals, we are putting into operation the most modern container terminal in the world in Maasvlakte in  Holland, in Rotterdam. And then we have the efficiency improvements, but we also of course have a lot of other  big projects running.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 25February2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The underlying result of the company with $4.5 billion is also very good. It's in line with our expectations and  represents an improvement of 33% compared to last year. We continued our efforts to focus the conglomerate on  shipping and oil-related activities with the sale of Danske Bank and handing back the income from the sale or total  sale prices dividend to the shareholders. So we believe we meet a wish from the shareholders, from minority  shareholders to get a more focused business, and we think we deliver that.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also want to signal here that we are, of course, taking action on the cost side of the – as a consequence of the  drop in the oil price. So we're running cost programs and CapEx reductions and also exploration cost reductions  in the oil and oil-related businesses. But we are on a way forward in the oil business. We just approved the build- out plan for the Johan Sverdrup signed in Norway, committing $1.8 billion. And we are also expecting to commit  to the buildup of the Culzean gas field in the UK North Sea during the first part of this year. So we are – even if the  oil price gives us, of course, challenges in those industries, we are still on the way for ward.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk Drilling impairment in EDC our oldest rig-up in the fleet in total is a little more than $70 million. And this  is basically reflecting the fact that what we believe that older rigs are losing value now where we expect a low  activity level in the oil industry in general. Fortunately, overall, Maersk Drilling has a very modern fleet, but these  are some of the oldest assets that we've decided to impair.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Underlying profit by activity in the fourth quarter, Maersk Line up very, very strongly and helped by good growth,  but first and foremost, a decline in cost helped to a large extent, I'll come back to that in a minute, by a decline in  the bunker price. Maersk Oil, down $150 million and this is in spite of higher pr oduction, exclusively an effect of  the oil price.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil's result, underlying good, of course, not so good in the fourth quarter with a decrease by 50% to $150  million. But this is caused by the lower oil price, which, of course, we have limited impact on. It was partly offset  by more production and also a decline in exploration cost and we also started reducing cost already in the fourth  quarter last year. And we'll continue on that trend.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We had an impairment charge related to the UK, I explained that before, $188 million, and this is producing  fields. So this is basically just reflecting the immediate lowering of the oil price. Production increase in the fourth  quarter to 275,000 barrels per day. This was expected, but, of course, was stronger than expected even because of  the lower oil price which does impact our take in Qatar.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We had less exploration costs, that's a good news. The bad news is that we also did not find any oil in the last  quarter. But we had good progress on the Culzean and Johan Sverdrup project. As I said before, we have  commissioned one and we expect to commission the second in the first half of this year.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
