texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The Chissonga project is still challenged by the low oil price and we're still considering how this can be done.  We're still working on it. But with the present oil prices, it is very challenged. We'll keep you updated, but we don't  have any news on this, and we also don't have any urgency to get to a decision here as we have the other two  projects where breakeven cost are clearly below the present oil prices. Golden Eagle and Jack came on stream as  planned in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then on page 10, just a few statements on what we're trying to do to mitigate, and that is in Maersk Oil to  mitigate the impact of the lower oil price. And we do expect to reduce the OpEx cost in Maersk Oil by double-digit  percentage. We expect, by 2016, to reach 20% reduction in this area. We're also  looking at the production  portfolio. And of course, we're also negotiating terms both on ongoing OpEx, but also, of course, under the CapEx  terms of CapEx cost and so on. So we get the best possible deals and the most possible reduction of cash flow out  as a result of the drop in the oil price.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Coming to Maersk Oil, we expect a significantly lower underlying results for 2015 than for 2014, as a breakeven is  reached with an oil price in the range $55 to $60. We expect an entitlement production to be around 265,000  barrels a day and exploration expenses are expected to be around $700 million.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: APM Shipping Services, we expect the underlying results to be above 2014. And the usual sensitivity guidance, we  have given you some of our major sensitivities below on this guidance line. I'm not going to say too much about it,  but just referring to that, we had the average oil price in 2014 was $99, and we have said that plus -minus US$10 a  barrel for Maersk Oil isolated, will be effect of $0.25 billion. So that will really guide you relative to the  understanding of Maersk Oil results.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 10February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: First of all, of course we realized that by taking an impairment of $2.6 billion on the oil assets, we make the result  for the fourth quarter look very complicated and very negative. But the fact is that we've decided, based on the  lower price we saw in January combined with cautious expectations for the future, to take a relativ ely firm view on  the value of our assets and we've written down the $2.6 billion, which is basically it's the deepwater offshore finds  that we have where there's some preproduction investments that have been activated as well as acquisition costs  and those we're writing down to zero.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On top of that, we've also looked at our producing assets, those who are near the end of life and made a cautious  estimate to the oil price during the remaining part of their life and that have led us to the conclusion that th ey may  be overvalued in our books and then we've written them down as well. So, it's quite significant write -down, but it  leaves us with a very reasonable carrying value, we believe, of the oil business.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On top of that, and that I think is the other negative you see in the accounts that we also for the fourth quarter  come out at the lower end of our expectations, and we will show you on page four why that is, but the background  for that is simply that the oil price and the freight rates deteriorated much faster than we expected and to lower  levels. So, we were negatively surprised by that, and it left us then with a profit of $3.1 billion.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Underlying profit by activity is just below, and you'll see that the main culprit is Maersk Line, a deterioration from  $2.2 billion to $1.3 billion, $900 million. We'll come back to that later. But actually I believe that the result given  the circumstances is quite strong on the back of a good first half. Maersk Oil also deteriorated in result with $600  million exclusively based on the oil price, and I'll also come back to that. They also delivered good operational  performance.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, let's go one step deeper and just – and this – the page four really explains basically everything this company  has gone through last year. And if I start with the obvious, that both – or the container freight rate and the oil  prices are at a very, very low level, both at historic lows actually. And the reason why we missed the fourth quarter  forecast – or were too optimistic is also – should be also clear from this graph. If you look at the container rates,  and this is the Shanghai – the China Containerised Freight Index, you look at the Q4 development, it's down from  an average freight rate of $850 at the beginning and down to a level of around $700 at the end. And $150 p er  container means quite a lot to our business. Y ou can multiply it by 2 million containers. So, that is broadly  explaining the shortfall in our result.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We were not helped by the situation in the oil business either. The oil price deteriorated from a leve l of $50 at the  beginning of the quarter, down to a level slightly above $30 at the end of the quarter. And of course, these things  we did not foresee, but they did come very rapidly and with much bigger movements than anybody I think could  expect. So, we're taking strong words in our mouth for talking about the group highlights, we call it the perfect  storm for the group. But I think on the back of these graphs here, I think you'll understand why.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, if we then go to the quarter figures, the quarter result is down from a profit last year of $189 million, down to a  loss of $2.5 billion. The underlying situation is – and that's, of course, due to the write-down orf impairment in  the oil business. The underlying figure is slightly better, but still, of course, not satisfactory. We went down from a  profit of $1 billion to $900 million last year and the only effects are freight rates and oil prices. If we look at cash  flow, it did a little bit better but still, a significant decline from $844 million to $500 million in the quarter. So a  very, very tough market situation.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, if we look at what the key variable for us is our EBIT margin compared to our competitors, and it did stay  above 5% during the year. It narrowed somewhat towards the end of the year, we believe, on the back of lower oil  prices, thereby lower bunker prices. And, of course, an important part of our increased competitiveness have been  our more economic use of fuel, which comes on the back of our CO2 emission reduction p rogram. So, that  advantage is higher when the oil price is high. So, we are losing a bit on that.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Maersk Oil on page nine, impairments, of course, completely impacts the result of the year, as they did, by the  way, also last year. But the underlying result is, actually, not too bad if you take the year. It's actually quite good.  And also, in the quarter, I think it's a respectable loss of $21 million, given the low oil price, I think, that is a  respectable figure.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We had the impairment – just commenting on, and here's a little bit more description. Operationally, we  continued the good trend during the year. We had our entitlement production increasing 21% to 333,000 barrels  of oil equivalent per day. It's mainly coming from increased production in the UK, where among others, Golden  Eagle delivers good results. And then the price-driven effect in Qatar, where we get a higher share of entitlement –  or higher entitlement share.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also managed to implement the planned operational cost reduction program and this is nothing to do with  exploration, but we had a reduction of 12% in our OpEx cost for 2015. And we had planned also to continue that  reduction in 2016 so that we deliver the 20% we promised at the beginning of 2015. In addition to the  OpEx  program, we also reduced the exploration cost by 67% in Q4, and 45% during the year and of course, a very  relevant way of lowering our breakeven cost.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: CapEx also went down, but that doesn't mean that we're less enthusiastic about the two big fields that we are  developing, Johan Sverdrup and Culzean. They will both come into activity, hopefully, in 2019, and hopefully, in a  more benign oil price environment.

texts.speaker: Nils Smedegaard Andersen
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We did one small acquisition during the year. We bought half of Africa Oil's assets in Kenya and Ethiopia and paid  an upfront price of $365 million for it. We bought reserves found and also a quite promising exploration program.  So we're excited about that, and of course, this is also something that will give us oil in the future, in the 2020s,  where we hope that the oil price will have improved compared to where it is today.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Going then to page 15. Just to highlight summary of the consolidated financial information. Q4 first, delivering  $9.1 billion, down $2.6 billion from last year. The big contributor in that reduction is the rates of Maersk Line, and  Maersk Line totally driving $1.7 billion of that reduction and Maersk Oil when it comes to the oil price of totally  accounted by the entitlement production, basically reducing more than $500 million.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: If we then look at the full year numbers, much, much more to say of the FX, but we're leaving the year with $40  billion in revenue, a decline of 7 .3% from last year, driven by a reduction from Maersk Line of 3.6% and Maersk  Oil of 3.1% that drives that development. So it basically is the rate and the oil price that is driving the changes in  the results.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For Maersk Oil, we expect a negative underlying result. As a guidance, we say that breakeven is reached with an oil  price in the range of $45 to $55 per barrel. And Maersk Oil entitlement production is expected to be around  315,000 barrels per day. Exploration costs are expected to be around – to be in line with 2015.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For APM Shipping Services, we expect the underlying result to be significantly below 2015, predominantly due to  lower rates in Maersk Supply Service. And as always, the volatility and uncertainty of our expectations, it's not  least due to the development in the global economy, the c ontainer freight rates and the oil price.

texts.speaker: Trond Ødegård Westlie
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Having said that, I would guide you to the sensitivities for 2016, but also maybe give you a special attention to the  oil price effect for underlying profit as it has increased due to the low oil prices and the tax effects coming out of  that. So as a result of that, $10 a barrel will have a negative or positive effect of approximately $315 million. Other  than that, the other sensitivities are in line with the guidance that we have given previously.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 8February2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: For the Energy division, we are continuously working on finding sustainable structural solutions. As earlier stated,  we will not give any progress update on the roadmap for finding structural solutions as we will return with news  once and when we have identified actual solutions for each of the four businesses.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: I will now give the word to Jakob Stausholm. He will walk you through the Transport & Logistics numbers, and  then after, Claus Hemmingsen will walk you through the Energy numbers, and then, I'll be back with some closing  comments.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer and Chief Financial, Strategy & Transformation Officer-Transport & Logistics, Maersk Line A/S
texts.text: And with those words, I'll hand over to Claus to take you through the Energy numbers.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Thank you very much, Jakob, and I will comment briefly on the business units in the Energy division, and we are  on page 12. So starting off with the underlying profit, you will see here that the underlying profit in Maersk Oil and  Maersk Drilling improved in 2016 to $497 million and $743 million respectively; while we saw, at the same time,  Maersk Supply Service reporting an underlying loss; and also profit in Maersk Tankers deteriorating due to very  weak markets.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: I will take you through the development in each of the business units in the Energy division in more detail in the  following slides. But before doing so, let me also just highlight what has already been mentioned that we have  taken the consequence of a significant oversupply, long-term reduced demand expectations for both Maersk  Drilling and Maersk Supply Service and therefore, recognized in quarter four here an impairment of a total of $2.6  billion pre-tax, $1.5 billion in Maersk Drilling and $1.1 billion in Maersk Supply Service. That is the effect of the  markets and the effect of the situation we see coming out of 2016.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: As a final comment before going into the business units, I'll just also reiterate what Søren already mentioned that  we do not today give an update on the progress, but we do continue to work on the objective of the Energy  division to identify individual structural solutions to separate out each of the four energy businesses from A.P.  Møller-Mærsk A/S and come with those solutions before the end of 2018 and that can include mergers, joint  ventures, listings of the businesses either individually or combined.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Turning to page 13 and having a look at Maersk Oil. Then Maersk Oil continued the positive earnings  development in quarter four, with an underlying profit of $250 million due to a higher oil price that reached $49 per  barrel in quarter four and further initiatives to reduce costs and also reduction of abandonment provisions of a  total of $93 million.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: So that concludes a fast and brief review of the four business units in the Energy division, and I will hand back the  word to Jakob to go through some of the financial slides.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: And as far as the Energy business is concerned, the main work, of course, will be around finding the sustainable  structural solutions to each of the businesses.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: On the Energy side, obviously, we are facing very, very tough situations in oil services, and we're going to have to  deal with it as best as we can, but we are quite happy with the fact that our oil company is profitable, quite a lot  actually, and has a breakeven operating margin now below $40, which is also, given today's oil price, a pretty  good place to be.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 9February2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Good morning, everybody, and welcome to A.P. Moller – Maersk Result Announcement for 2017. My name is  Søren Skou, I'm the CEO. I'm joined here today, by Claus Hemmingsen, our Vice CEO and Head of our Energy  Division; Jakob Stausholm, our CFO; Vincent Clerc, our Chief Commercial Officer; and Søren Toft, our Chief  Operating Officer.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: We have now reclassified both Maersk Drilling and Maersk Supply Service as businesses held-for-sale, and we  are working hard to find solutions for how to separate Maersk Drilling and Maersk Supply during 2018. We expect  to close the Maersk Oil transaction, as previously announced, this quarter, and as far as our Hamburg Süd  transaction, you all know, it closed on December 1, and we are on track with the integration.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Maersk Line Ltd.
texts.text: Our fuel efficiency, I know we reported, as Vincent Clerc said, on a kilo per FFE including a capacity deployed for  third parties. If we deduct that from the numbers, actually, our fuel efficiency in quarter four was lower than the  corresponding quarter four in 2016, slightly below the 900 kilo per FFE level, so we take some comfort in that too.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer and Chief Financial, Strategy & Transformation Officer-Transport & Logistics, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: But let me now hand over to Claus for the energy businesses.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Thank you, Jakob, and let me make a few comments on the energy businesses. Undoubtedly, the markets on  Maersk Drilling and Maersk Supply Service have been tough also in 2017. However, we did see the oil price  improving throughout the year, and we did see our oil company customers making profits. So, we also saw an  increase in tender activity during the year, which continued into the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Claus V. Hemmingsen
texts.profession: Group Vice Chief Executive Officer and Chief Executive Officer-Energy, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Let me just add one comment on Maersk Oil. Søren already mentioned it that we expect the transaction to close  in the first quarter, but I just want to remind you that we are still exposed to the oil business, and you will probably  have taken note of the Total shares having increased in value, so that we're, at this stage, $450 million ahead of  the of the value when we signed the deal.

file: MAERSK.B - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 21February2019 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: We have also, during 2018 successfully integrated our big acquisition from late 2017, Hamburg Süd and delivered  synergies from that transaction better than planned. We have following our digitization journey to the point that in  Ocean, the customers transaction with us are now largely digitized, more than around 90% of oil prices are now  issued via our website.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Now moving on to the Energy separation, last year we also made significant progress there. As you all know, we  separated out Maersk Oil in a transaction with Total in March of 2018. And we have been selling shares in Total in  the last year and this year and we currently hold around 28 million shares with a value of $1.6 billion in Total.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: We are still looking for solutions for Mærsk Supply Service. We remain challenged by the market conditions, but  we are sure that at some point we will find solution. With the transaction of Maersk Drilling, we will have done all- in energy transactions for more than $12 billion to separate out these businesses and have cash flow close to $9  billion from that.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Now, moving on to Transport & Logistics, we have 2018 result which can be characterized by the following. It was  a year where we delivered very strong growth. We added $8 billion to the top line, of course, very much driven by  the acquisition of Hamburg Süd. But we also delivered a good organic growth. It means that, now, since 2016  where we started on this journey, we have added about $12 billion of turnover. And with $39 billion of turnover in  2018, we now have a higher turnover than we had in 2016, where we included also the oil and energy-related  businesses.

texts.speaker: Søren Skou
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chief Executive Officer-Transport & Logistics Division, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: And as a result of that, on top of that, we have quite some uncertainty as to what happens with the fuel prices  there. They have gone up quite a lot in the last months or so. And then finally, we will be as an industry  implementing IMO 2020 towards the end of the year which will all things equal also mean a significant increase in  fuel prices.

texts.speaker: Carolina Dybeck-Happe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: Despite postponing $100 million of CapEx from 2018 to 2019, we have lowered our expectations for gross CapEx  for 2019 to around $2.2 billion from previously $2 billion to $2.5 billion range. The lower CapEx is due to our focus  on CapEx discipline. And I would like to repeat that we will not be ordering any new large vessels until at earliest  2020 and no new greenfield projects in the Terminal business in the foreseeable future.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer & Member - Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: On fuel costs, we continued the progress that we have showed the last several quarters, where of course the cost  increased due to the price year-on-year, but our efficiency improved nearly 10%, also due to initiatives from the  Hamburg Süd acquisition and the network synergies.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer & Member - Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: For 2019, on a like-for-like basis, capacity will be flat compared to the second half of 2018. When we then include  impact from already announced slow steaming initiatives and the effect of the temporary scrubber installation we'll  see – we expect capacity will slightly increase year-on-year to the tune of 1% to 2%. But remember the scrubber  effect is a temporary thing and obviously capacities of the slow-steaming [indiscernible] (00:23:34) that are  helping both the product that we offer to our customers as well as the cost position that we have.

texts.speaker: Søren Toft
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer & Member - Executive Board, A.P. Møller-Mærsk A/S
texts.text: If I then continue with the Manufacturing segment, then the brief story here is that MCI's revenue decreased  quarter four over quarter four 2017 from $247 million to $215 million, mainly because of lower dry volumes and  significant price pressure on dry business. And we have as a consequence of that, as you know, decided to close  the dry factory and focus MCI for the future strategically fully on the reefer business and coal chain services.

file: MAP - Investor Day 25March2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Fernando Mata Verdejo
texts.profession: Director & Group Chief Finance Officer, Mapfre SA
texts.text: First of all, my apologies for visitors. Madrid is the one of the greenest city in Europe. This is very good for the  planet, and no complaints. But for people like me who are suffering from allergies,

texts.speaker: José Luis Jiménez
texts.profession: Chief Investment Officer, Mapfre SA
texts.text: Last but not least, we will have to show you the environmental, social and governance analysis of our portfolio.  On left hand side, we have classified all the securities we hold in our European and U.S. and Brazilian portfolio,  we are talking around 90% of the total, and most of these securities has been analyzed. Some of them has been  excluded and here I'm talking about sovereigns and municipals, but it will be included soon as soon as we finalize  our own methodology on these type of issues.

texts.speaker: José Luis Jiménez
texts.profession: Chief Investment Officer, Mapfre SA
texts.text: And the rest has then been analyzed, which represent around 12% of our assets under management. For those  securities, where we have [indiscernible] (01:05:00) ECG footprint, the vast majority, I'm talking about 90%, are  with the highest scorings or on the first quartile or second quartile, something that we are really proud of. For  those securities in the fourth quartile, less than 1.5 of our total assets under management, we have set a watching  list that require a deeper analysis of these issues and a periodic review in our risk committees. The ECG profile of  our portfolio is an area of continuous improvement and we are actively involved in different working groups on the  subject.

texts.text: This reduction is stemming from the absence of extraordinary weather-related claims in the U.S.A. along with  improvements in technical management, especially in Iberia. And the cost containment measures taken in Brazil  and Iberia that have also contributed to these positive developments. Net financial income has remained flat  considering the strong effect of currency movements, the underlying result has actually been quite resilient given  the low interest rate environment.

file: MAP - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 26October2017 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Fernando Mata Verdejo
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Mapfre SA
texts.text: Now, I will hand the floor over to Eduardo, MAPFRE RE's CEO, who will talk to you about cat loss and  protections.

texts.speaker: Eduardo Pérez de Lema Holweg
texts.profession: CEO & Management Committee Chairman-MAPFRE RE and Executive Committee Member, Mapfre SA
texts.text: Thank you, Fernando, and good afternoon to everyone. I would like to start on page 8, where you can see the  break-down of the impact of recent events, which were exceptional in MAPFRE's results. These events, as I said,  were exceptional at both in size and in frequency, with three massive hurricanes making landfall and two  earthquakes happening in Mexico, all within a short period of time. Additionally, the season so far suffered three  major hurricanes that didn't make landfall, making it one of the most active on record.

texts.speaker: Eduardo Pérez de Lema Holweg
texts.profession: CEO & Management Committee Chairman-MAPFRE RE and Executive Committee Member, Mapfre SA
texts.text: Hurricane Harvey hit the Southern U.S. and mainly affected MAPFRE GLOBAL RISKS. Irma hit the [ph] Virgin  U.S. Island (09:47) and Florida, and Maria especially hit Puerto Rico, impacting the retail business as well as  large corporate clients. The Mexican earthquake also mainly affected MAPFRE GLOBAL RISKS. All of these  events had an impact on MAPFRE RE as well. However, the strict underwriting policy in the affected regions and  our business mix made the impact moderate.

texts.speaker: Eduardo Pérez de Lema Holweg
texts.profession: CEO & Management Committee Chairman-MAPFRE RE and Executive Committee Member, Mapfre SA
texts.text: It's also important to highlight that these catastrophes are earnings events for MAPFRE, not a capital event. Net  losses only represent 2% of the eligible own funds. Finally, the Coastal El Niño affecting Peru during the first  quarter has had a positive loss development during the year, as we no longer consider this an exceptional loss  event. Also, at MAPFRE RE, the large loss burden, both cat and man-made, has been extremely low during the  first half-year of 2017, so that the impact of the recent events could be absorbed within the large loss budget of  the year.

texts.speaker: Eduardo Pérez de Lema Holweg
texts.profession: CEO & Management Committee Chairman-MAPFRE RE and Executive Committee Member, Mapfre SA
texts.text: The aggregation of the retentions of the different companies, for example, in Puerto Rico, Dominican Republic  Global Risks and MAPFRE RE for Hurricane Maria adds up to what we call MAPFRE Group retention. The  retention is the one that is subsequently protected by our group protections. Our global catastrophe protection  program is designed on what we call [ph] several covers (13:32) defined on a territorial specific basis. The first  one that we call [ph] NARC (13:38) covers essentially the territories that could be affected by large wind events in  the Atlantic.

texts.speaker: Eduardo Pérez de Lema Holweg
texts.profession: CEO & Management Committee Chairman-MAPFRE RE and Executive Committee Member, Mapfre SA
texts.text: The second one that we call [ph] MERC (13:45) is designed to cover risks in other territories not covered by [ph]  NARC (13:48) and where the main peril is earthquake, but it also covers for other perils. The third one, smaller in  size and with a reduced retention cover, is what we call smaller territories and those where MAPFRE GLOBAL  RISKS has exposures, but we don't have a MAPFRE company. On top of these covers, we buy a so-called  umbrella layer that works if any of the previous covers is exhausted in a given event and designed to work only for  extremely large events.

texts.speaker: Fernando Mata Verdejo
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Mapfre SA
texts.text: Global Risks has suffered a large impact from the catastrophes, €33 million, and there were also several large  non-cat losses during the year. You already – you know well, because we already mentioned during the previous  result presentation.

texts.text: In North America, Puerto Rico has had a solid recovery after 2017 net cat events, and as mentioned, the  Northeast USA was affected by winter storms during the first quarter of the year, and the non-Northeast combined  ratio is improving, but it is still too high and is being carefully monitored. We expect 2019 to be a turning point for  both USA and Brazil operations.

texts.speaker: Fernando Mata Verdejo
texts.profession: Director & Chief Financial Officer, Mapfre SA
texts.text: Please turn to slide 9. Here, I would like to talk about extraordinary impacts that affected results. Weather-related  and NatCat claims are down over a €150 million year-on-year. Hurricanes and earthquakes affected Direct  Insurance, MAPFRE RE and GLOBAL RISKS in 2017, as you know. This year there had been severe winter  storms in the U.S. during the first quarter with an €11.5 million net loss for MAPFRE USA and €7.6 million for  MAPFRE RE due to the quota share reinsurance agreement.

file: MBG - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 27April2010 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On April 7 Daimler and Renault-Nissan announced a strategic cooperation, which focuses on  concretely defined projects in the area of small cars and engines. The partners have signed a  general framework agreement on long-term strategic cooperation. This involves the following  projects: First, we will develop a common architecture for our smart and the Renault Twingo. As  part of this project, we will launch a new smart 4-seater. Another aspect is that an electric drive  version of all smart models will be supplied right from beginning.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 And second, we will expand our engine portfolio by jointly developing new small 3 and 4 cylinder  engines. Third, Nissan and its premium brand, Infiniti, will procure larger gasoline and diesel  engines from Mercedes-Benz. And fourth, we will extend our range of vans by using a common  architecture for city vans and we will also share powertrain components for mid-sized vans.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The new generation R-Class had its all over premiere at the 2010 New York International Auto  Show. The original SUV Tourer has been extensively updated including a completely redesigned  front end. Our latest research vehicle, the F 800 Style presented in Geneva impressively  demonstrates Mercedes-Benz’ ability to harmonize automobile fascination, with the continually  increasing demands of environmental compatibility, and unparalleled safety features.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Overall demand in the regions outside Japan was 18% higher than in Q1 2009. Revenue of Daimler  Trucks of €4.9 billion was close to the level of the prior year period. Further signs of recovery are  apparent from the development of incoming orders, especially the Trucks Europe/Latin America  and the Trucks Asia units achieved more orders than in the previous quarters. As expected,  incoming orders in the NAFTA region decreased in Q1, due to some pull forward effects in the prior  quarters, before the introduction of the EPA ‘010 emission regulations.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 4 As a significant product enhancement Daimler Trucks is extending its product range and will  gradually introduce EEV versions in certain output classes of the Actros, Axor and Atego up to July  2010. EEV means Enhanced Environmentally Friendly Vehicle, and is a classification used for  engines, which comply with an even more stringent exhaust emission standard than Euro 5. The  EEV standard reduces particulate emissions by roughly one-third compared to the already stringent  Euro 5 limits.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Also as part of our Shaping Future Transportation initiative, 10 Fuso Canter Eco Hybrids are  undergoing a 3 year fleet trial in London. Depending on its particular application, The Canter Eco  Hybrid uses around 10 to 15% less fuel than the conventional light duty truck, with correspondingly  lower CO2 emissions. Last week, Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation unveiled the new  generation of the Fuso Super Great. The fuel-efficient and environmentally-friendly truck complies  with the JP09, which is currently the world’s most stringent emissions standard. Fuso’s flagship  truck features a new 6R10 diesel engine with BlueTec technology from Daimler Truck’s new engine  generation for use in commercial vehicles worldwide.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: A prototype of the Mercedes-Benz Vito with battery electric drive recently undertook and passed a  series of the harshest winter tests near the Polar Circle. The test van encountered no problems with  even in extreme cold, snow and ice with regard to the safety systems, drive, suspension, or all of  the other components of a Mercedes-Benz van.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Electric Vito is the first vehicle in its class worldwide that is delivered from the factory with an  electric drive system as standard equipment. Equipped with a lithium ion battery, the range of the  Vito averaged 130 km but can be considerably higher given an appropriate driving style. There is  no loss in terms of payload or load volume compared to a conventional powered Vito. In the middle  of the year up to 50 Vito E-Cell vans are participating in a test project in the Stuttgart area. The  project is supported by public funds and intended to promote the development of urban  infrastructure and electric mobility of public transport.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Last month Eagle Bus handed over 2 Mercedes-Benz Citaro G BlueTec Hybrid buses to the  Hamburg Municipal Transport Company. The Citaro BlueTec Hybrid is the only hybrid bus in  existence today that can travel for certain distances solely on electric power without using its diesel  engine. Following the comprehensive facelift for the new Setra TopClass 400 in Europe, the Setra  brand presented the revised U.S. version, the Setra TopClass S 417 in Las Vegas.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Daimler Buses North America delivered the last batch of buses to New York City Transit from an  order of total of 1350 Orion Diesel-Electric Hybrid Transit buses. Daimler Buses is the world’s  largest manufacturer of Diesel-Electric Hybrid buses with over 3000 units either in service or on  order.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: What does it mean for our earnings? We expect the Daimler Group to post EBIT from its ongoing  business of more than €4 billion in 2010. The key factors of this result are the further recovery of  markets, the improvement of the economic climate, and the market success of our products.
